DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Praise Bush Troop Proposal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs after 8th graf pvs, bgng, `House Democratic,' with comments from Dole, Gray, Moynihan and Gingrich.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush won Democratic praise Wednesday night for his plan to cut U.S. and Soviet forces in Central Europe, while Senate GOP leader Bob Dole said the proposal would put the United States ``on the offensive'' at the bargaining table. Rep. Les Aspin, the Democratic chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said ``the president should be congratulated'' for the plan, outlined in a State of the Union address. ``Trying to negotiate lower limits on forces deployed in Europe is clearly a good idea,'' said the Wisconsin Democrat. Said Dole: ``The ball is now in (Soviet leader Mikhail) Gorbachev's court.'' At the same time they were hailing his troop cut proposal, Democrats made plain their intention to battle with Bush over other issues in the current election-year session of Congress. In a nationally televised speech that served as the formal Democratic response, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said his party would work with the president ``wherever and whenever we can. On some issues, we will have difference because we care deeply about certain principles,'' he said. He scoffed at Bush's call for a ``meager'' 2 percent rise in education spending, and said Democrats would battle the administration this year on legislation dealing with capital gains taxes, child care and clean air. As for abortion, he said, ``We will continue to defend a woman's right to choose, for we are convinced that politicians cannot and should not attempt to make the choice.'' House Democratic Leader Richard Gephardt of Missouri faulted Bush for not being ``more specific about how he intends to strengthen our economy and lift the economic fortunes of people who work for a living.'' Republicans applauded Bush's statement that the ``last thing we need to do is mess around with Social Security,'' with GOP House Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia saying the president's position ``is going to be clearly the only acceptable political position _ saying that nothing affecting benefits can be considered.'' Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., in an attempt to block the government from using surplus Social Security taxes, has proposed rolling back a tax increase that took effect Jan. 1 and to reduce another increase scheduled for next year. Following the speech, Moynihan said despite Bush's promise not to fool with Social Security, ``They're messing around (with Social Security) where they're using the trust fund as general revenue.'' Overall, Dole called Bush's speech ``an optimistic `can do' State of the Union, which advances a hope agenda, one in sharp contrast with the Democrat's nope agenda.'' But House Democratic Whip William Gray, D-Pa., said Bush's speech ``ought to be introduced to his budget. There's a disconnect.'' But domestic issues aside, lawmakers on both sides of the aisle chorused their praise of Bush's proposal to reduce troops in the so-called ``Central Front'' in Europe to 195,000 for each superpower. Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, said Bush ``skillfully seized the element of surprise and thereby seized the opportunity to put the United States back into the forefront of negotiations to reduce conventional forces.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said the reduction plan ``makes the arms control proposal that we have on the table much more relevant to the changing circumstances in Europe and also much more in keeping with some of our fiscal pressures.'' Earlier in the day, Foley told reporters he ``would welcome a suggestion that we could make further troop cuts in Europe.'' ``I don't think the United States should totally withdraw from Western Europe, but very substantial reductions are not only possible, but I think inevitable,'' he said. Bush's proposal is a response to the tumultuous changes in Eastern Europe, where the push for democracy has led to the downfall of hardline Communist regimes. One longtime advocate of reduced U.S. troops in Europe, Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., said she was ``delighted'' with the plan. ``There's hope,'' Schroeder said. ``Just when you thought you had a Cold War budget _ boom,'' said Schroeder, a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee. Aspin coupled his praise with a caution: ``We should be careful in this whole process not to give the Soviet Union a reason to keep more troops in Eastern Europe than it would without an agreement. For both sides it should be a ceiling, not a floor.'' Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., said Bush ``is rushing to catch the reality of Eastern Europe.'' Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, said the United States was ``falling behind the curve of popular will'' on the issue of troop reductions. Rep. Dave McCurdy, D-Okla., a member of the House Armed Services Committee and the Democratic Caucus' point-man on defense, questioned the absence of a military strategy from the administration. ``It was unwise to build up on military strength in the 1980's without a national strategy. But it is even more dangerous to build down without one,'' McCurdy said. Dole defended the president as a middle-of-the-road president. ``Ultra liberals and ultra conservatives may not like tonight's speech, which tells me George Bush is right in step with the American people,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Socialists Threaten Governing Party's Dominance in Japan
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: A blizzard is blowing and dawn is an hour away, but Socialist candidate Nobutaka Tsutsui is shivering at a factory gate, trying to entice votes away from the conservatives who have governed Japan for 35 years. Wrapped in a wool coat and fortified by hand-warmers in his pockets, he zeroes in on the unpopular sales tax that the Liberal Democratic government introduced last year _ called a consumption tax in Japan. ``Good morning. My name is Nobutaka Tsutsui,'' the smiling, 45-year-old candidate for Parliament tells workers as they arrive or leave during a shift-change at an electronics factory. ``Let's join our forces to scrap the disgusting consumption tax, and end the LDP's tyranny.'' No fancy speech about socialism, and he gets encouraging responses even in this traditionally conservative, rice-growing constituency in northern Japan's snow country. ``Good luck,'' says a young woman in a factory uniform. ``I will vote for you to get rid of the consumption tax, and so will many of my friends.'' The Socialists are counting on millions of like-minded people to knock the Liberal Democrats into the minority when ballots are counted from the Feb. 18 election, which is expected to set the tone for Japanese politics in the 1990s. The conservative party appears to be facing the greatest threat ever to its dominance. Socialist candidates like Tsutsui, a populist lawyer who wears trendy clothes and moves around the snow-bound district in a four-wheel-drive Mitsubishi, are expected to grab many normally conservative votes. The Liberal Democratic Party now holds 295 of the 512 seats in the lower house of Parliament. Polls indicate it could lose its majority in the chamber, which elects the prime minister. The Socialists are the largest opposition group, and have a chance to increase their seats from 85 now to more than 140 under the leadership of popular chairwoman Takako Doi. If that happens and the parties, with their deep ideological divides, try to form a coalition government, Japan could be headed for a period of political uncertainty. Tsutsui fell 7,000 votes short of a seat in the last election in 1986, but he is regarded as front-runner among a half-dozen candidates vying for the two seats in the constituency. ``I am aware I have some advantages this time,'' he said as he plowed through the snow in a jeep. ``But my weakness is that I still lack prominence compared with the Liberal Democrat incumbents.'' If Tsutsui wins, one of the two Liberal Democrat incumbents will be out. Four-term legislator Katsuhiko Shirakawa, 44, is trying hard to win that other seat. ``This is nothing but a fight for political survival for me,'' Shirakawa said as he was driven from one campaign stop to the next. He told about 25 factory managers who gathered at a supporter's house in rural Takada, ``I can protect the interests of people in the Jyoetsu district and make the area thrive.'' ``New train lines and new highways are going to be built in the next four to six years as a result of my efforts,'' said Shirakawa, fixing his gaze on each person in the audience in turn. ``We can expect a huge amount of public works, followed by hundreds of thousands of tourists and new business opportunities.'' Pork barrel politics is the origin of much of the Liberal Democrats' success over past decades as they spread public works around Japan, enabling them to campaign on a record of bringing local prosperity while building Japan. Shirakawa is appealing to company executives, small-business owners and farmers, trying to persuade them that he can help the local economy grow. He says he has no way of stopping those who dislike the sales tax from voting Socialist, so he tries to ``strengthen my grip on the conservative votes and try not to let them go to the Socialist or the other conservative party candidate.'' The tax, which imposes a 3 percent levy on all goods and services, has become the focal point of the campaign. Polls indicate more than a third of voters pegged the tax as the No. 1 issue. Less than 10 percent thought the big issue was socialism vs. conservatism _ the Liberal Democrats' campaign theme. Hurt by sex and bribery scandals and the sales tax, the Liberal Democrats lost their majority in the upper house in July elections, and two prime ministers from the party had to resign last year in an extraordinary show of political disarray. Opposition parties are united in their calls to scrap the tax entirely. The Liberal Democrats insist it is essential to support the budget in the 21st century, though they promise to review and improve the tax. ``I just hope that too many voters ... won't turn to the Socialists only because of the tax issue, disregarding other important national and international issues,'' Shirakawa told about 50 female workers at a backer's semiconductor factory who had gathered during a lunch break. At about the same time, Tsutsui was kneeling on a reed-mat floor with about 25 people in the home of a supporter, telling them ``Japan needs a new type of leadership that is fitting for a new era, but the LDP is suffering from metal fatigue and it must be replaced. ``And the very first thing we should do is to scrap the consumption tax, which we all hate. The tax has a symbolic significance of what a long one-party dominance will cause.''

DOC.HEAD: Gen. Sam Phillips, Who Headed NASA's Apollo-Lunar Program, Dies at 68
DOC.TEXT: Air Force Gen. Samuel Phillips, who headed NASA's Apollo program when the United States put the first man on the moon, died Wednesday of heart failure. He was 68. Phillips, who retired as a four-star Air Force general in 1975, headed the Apollo Lunar Landing Program of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration from 1964 to 1969. He returned to NASA in 1986 to conduct a management review and recommend changes in the wake of the Challenger disaster. Phillips' long and distinguished Air Force career included tours as director of the Minuteman Intercontinental Ballistic Missile Program from 1959-1963, vice commander of the Ballistic Systems Division at Norton Air Force Base (San Bernardino) from 1963-1964, and commander of Air Force Systems Command at Andrews AFB (Maryland) from 1973 to 1975. After retiring from the Air Force, Phillips joined TRW in El Segundo as general manager of its Energy Systems Management Division. In 1984, he became vice president of TRW's Defense Systems Group. He retired from TRW in 1986, but continued to serve in an advisory capacity. Phillips is survived by his wife, Betty Anne, and three daughters, Dana McMenamin of Sacramento, Janie Phillips of El Segundo and Kathleen Esposito of Redondo Beach.

DOC.HEAD: Julia Stuart, Ex-League of Women Voters President, Dead at 79
DOC.TEXT: Julia Davis Stuart, a former president of the League of Women Voters of the United States, has died at her home. She was 79. Mrs. Stuart, who died Saturday, was national president from 1964 to 1968. She was the first Westerner to hold that office. During her tenure as national president, Mrs. Stuart was noted for extensive work in conservation of water resources. In 1969, she was honored on the 50th anniversary of the league by President Richard Nixon at a White House ceremony. Mrs. Stuart also served on President Lyndon Johnson's 19-member Commission of Law Enforcement and Administration of Justice and on the National Citizens Commission on International Cooperation. Mrs. Stuart was born in Missouri and graduated from the University of Missouri. She and her husband, Robert J. Stuart, came to Bellingham from Oklahoma in 1951 and moved to Spokane five years later. Mrs. Stuart joined the League of Women Voters in Spokane and was president of that chapter from 1951 to 1953. She later served four years as Washington state president. In 1960, she was elected to the national board and two years later became national second vice president. She was twice elected president of the League of Women Voters of the United States. She is survived by her husband, Robert J., a son, two daughters and three grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher, Writer Charged With Criminal Libel
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper publisher and writer have been charged with criminal libel for failing to publish the full name of a policeman criticized in an article. The misdemeanor charges, stemming from a rarely used provision of Florida law, were filed Monday against former Polk County sheriff-turned-newspaper publisher Dan Daniels, and former Eagle Lake City Commission candidate Dave Whitacre. Polk State Attorney Jerry Hill said the two failed to publish the full name of Eagle Lake police officer Roy T. Harper in an article in The Eagle, which is published in this central Florida community. The newspaper accused the officer of ``lies, threats and theft.'' Harper said he found a Florida law makes it a first-degree misdemeanor for a writer or publisher to make accusations of immoral conduct against a person unless the article contains ``in full the true name of the person intended to be charged with the commission of such acts of immorality.'' The article in a January issue of The Eagle referred to Harper only as ``Roy.'' Whitacre, the author of the article, said he didn't use Harper's full name ``because I didn't want to humiliate his family.'' Daniels' number is unlisted, and there was no answer Tuesday afternoon at the newspaper office.

DOC.HEAD: Students at Private University Decry `Druggie' Image
DOC.TEXT: When Heather Harlan transferred to Wesleyan University last year, she had an image of a school with rigorous academic standards and a long tradition of liberalism. Now, Harlan and other students find themselves defending the private university against a new ``druggie'' label they say has been unfairly pinned on the central Connecticut school. ``The whole thing has been blown out of proportion,'' said Harlan, who transferred from New York University. ``I've seen people use drugs, but I'd say the overwhelming majority of students don't use drugs.'' Wesleyan's image problem stemmed from an incident last October when only one student was arrested among an estimated 400 attending an annual campus marijuana-smoking party known as the ``Smoke Out.'' Some students estimated 100 students smoked marijuana at the party. A storm of publicity followed the Oct. 27 party, most of it focusing on assertions by several students that Wesleyan administrators were willing to look the other way when it came to drug use and did little to stop the party. ``They didn't really do anything to stop it. They brought in a few cops instead of a whole army,'' said sophomore Marc Flacks. Wesleyan spokesman Bobby Wayne Clark defended the single arrest made during the party, saying by the time police arrived, most of the students who were smoking pot had stashed it. But three months later, the 3,400-student university is still reeling from the unwanted attention. And although administrators insist they are not soft on drugs, the hullabaloo has prompted them to review the school's drug policy. Dean Edgar Beckham said administrators are considering strengthening the wording of their policy to get out a tougher message about the school's attitude toward drugs. Wesleyan's current policy is to work with Middletown police to make drug arrests on campus, including tipping them off when they know a big party is scheduled where drugs are likely to be used, Beckham said. The university's code of conduct defines the sale of any illegal drug as a ``serious breach.'' Possession of cocaine and heroin also has that classification, but the code does not specifically mention marijuana or LSD. Students who break the university's rules are subject to penalties ranging from a warning letter to expulsion. Beckham said the school is considering either deleting any mention to specific drugs so as not to give the impression some drugs are condoned, or adding marijuana and LSD to the list of drugs considered serious breaches. But many students and administrators said they were tired of defending a policy they say does not need defending. ``When we're encouraging police to come on campus and make arrests whenever possible, then I would say that's a harsh policy, not a lenient policy,'' said Beckham. With an annual tuition approaching $15,000 and a competitive admissions policy, students say Wesleyan is not a school where people go to party. ``We're being called a druggie school, but I don't think that's accurate, compared to other institutions,'' said senior Eric Ford. But there are students who think administrators should put more teeth into enforcement. A good place to start, they said, would be to crack down on large campus parties, like the ``Smoke Out'' and ``Uncle Duke Day,'' an event that is usually held the following day. ``Uncle Duke Day,'' named after the self-indulgent drug-abusing character in the ``Doonesbury'' comic strip, is openly advertised on campus, and students know the day's activities will include drug use. ``If you're going to do any type of drug enforcement at all, why don't you start with the obvious _ Uncle Duke Day,'' said junior Elan Grossman. But administrators said policing every party would be impossible. ``There are institutions that have codes that sound tough, but aren't,'' said Clark. ``Wesleyan has a code that puts the burden of responsibility on students, and we believe that works.''

DOC.HEAD: Poe First Edition Sold at Auction
DOC.TEXT: One of 12 known first editions of Edgar Allan Poe's first published book sold at auction for $165,000, Sotheby's said. The book, ``Tamerlane and Other Poems,'' went to a private American collector, said Laura Stewart, a spokeswoman for the auction house. The copy sold was one of two in private hands; the other sold at Sotheby's last year for $198,000, Stewart said. Also Tuesday, a four-page autographed letter by Herman Melville to Nathaniel Hawthorne's wife was bought for $132,000 by Profiles in History, a Beverly Hills, Calif., dealer in books and manuscripts, she said. In the Jan. 8, 1852, letter to Sophia Peabody Hawthorne, who had complimented Melville on ``Moby Dick,'' the author denied that the book contained any symbolism. Tuesday's sale of American literature and children's books from the library of H. Bradley Martin totaled $2.6 million, Stewart said. Sale of the collection was to continue today with Americana, including George Washington's copy of ``The Federalist Papers.''

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department Allows Limited Restart of Oak Ridge Reactor
DOC.TEXT: The most powerful nuclear research reactor of its kind has resumed limited operation at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory after being shut down for more than three years by safety concerns. The High Flux Isotope Reactor was restarted Monday, Department of Energy spokesman Steve Wyatt said. He said the reactor, which has a maximum power of 85 megawatts, will operate at no more than 11 megawatts for the next few weeks as part of a training and testing exercise for operators. A schedule for resuming full power will depend on the outcome of the tests. The reactor is used to produce and study heavy man-made elements. It also supplies special isotopes for medical and industrial use and is used in irradiation testing for fusion and fission reactor development.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Passes Bill Including China Trade Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is expected to sign legislation that provides for trade sanctions against China, but allows the president to suspend them if he finds it is in the national interest. The Senate voted 98-0 late Tuesday for the measure, which was passed by the House in November before Congress' two-month holiday break. Prompted by Beijing's crackdown last June on pro-democracy demonstrators, the sanctions are part of a $9.7 billion measure authorizing activities of the State Department for the 1990 and 1991 fiscal years. The legislation would suspend: _Financial underwriting through the Overseas Private Investment Corporation for U.S. companies doing business in China; _Aid under the Trade and Development Program; _Issuing licenses for controlled munitions or crime control and detection equipment; _Export of U.S.-built satellites, certain bilateral nuclear cooperation and liberalization of multilateral export controls. Most of the sanctions reflect actions Bush himself had already taken in the wake of the bloody suppression of pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing on June 4, and their place in the bill is regarded as mostly symbolic. The administration already has begun to lift some of those sanctions, including the one barring export of satellites, citing improved conditions in China. The bill approved Tuesday would permit Bush to terminate any of the sanctions if significant political reform occurs in China or if Bush finds waiver of the sanctions is ``in the national interest'' of the United States. There was almost no debate on the bill, in contrast to the showdown last week over whether to uphold Bush's veto of a measure that would have protected Chinese students in the United States from deportation. The Senate narrowly upheld the veto after the White House waged an all-out campaign to pressure Republican senators to back the president. An administration official described the fight as ``not a battle over how to handle China, but a battle over who should be handling China.'' Democrats used the occasion to again accuse Bush of too-cozy relations with a regime that has done little to adhere to U.S. human rights standards. The largest amounts in the bill _ $3.3 billion this year and $3.7 billion next year _ are for the State Department, primarily for salaries and the expenses of running embassies and consulates around the world. Also included are about $2 billion over two years for the U.S. Information Agency and $600 million for the Board for International Broadcasting, which runs Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty. Not voting were Sens. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, and Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Accuser Testifies Before Grand Jury
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors appear to be building a drug case against Mayor Marion Barry by securing the cooperation of a man who law enforcement sources say accused the mayor of drug use. James McWilliams, a District of Columbia employee, pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor drug charge Tuesday and then immediately began testifying before a grand jury investigating Barry's ties to convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis. ``This is another significant step in this investigation,'' U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens said. ``The mayor's arrest was a significant step, and this ... was a significant step too.'' In another development, a source familiar with the case said several members of the mayor's city security detail are expected to testify before the grand jury in the near future. The guards _ who are assigned to the mayor on a round-the-clock basis _ are expected to be asked whether they ever witnessed the mayor using drugs or helped get drugs for him, said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. At a news conference, Stephens refused to say whether he intends for the bodyguards to testify before the panel, but said prosecutors ``will want to cover any witness that might be able to provide information regarding this case.'' Barry, who was arrested Jan. 18 on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge, has denied under oath using drugs with Lewis at a downtown Washington hotel more than a year earlier, in December 1988. The charge against McWilliams stemmed from allegations of visits to Lewis' hotel room, some of which prosecutors say coincided with Barry's visits. Meanwhile, Washington's WRC-TV, quoting unnamed sources, said Barry could be indicted within two weeks by the grand jury, which has been looking into allegations of perjury and cocaine possession. McWilliams, a city motor vehicles department employee and a longtime Lewis associate, declined to comment either before or after his grand jury testimony. He pleaded guilty to a charge of aiding and abetting drug possession, which carries a maximum penalty of one year in prison and a $100,000 fine. According to a source familiar with the case, McWilliams has told authorities he was present once when the mayor and Lewis disappeared into the bathroom of the hotel room for a short time. McWilliams told prosecutors he smelled crack cocaine and then saw the mayor emerge from the bathroom under the influence of the drug, the source said. The Washington Post, in today's editions, quoted Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard W. Roberts as saying that during the hotel episode, McWilliams loaned money to Lewis for Lewis to purchase drugs and later lent his car to Lewis so that Lewis could go purchase additional drugs. McWilliams, 57, was called before the grand jury investigating the case last January but refused to testify. Carole Bland Jackson, a former business partner of the woman who was in a hotel room when Barry was arrested this month in an FBI sting, also said in weekend interviews that she was present when Barry used cocaine at a 1986 party. The mayor is in Florida at a private facility being treated for what aides say is primarily an alcohol abuse problem. Lewis pleaded guilty to cocaine conspiracy charges last November in Washington and was convicted on cocaine distribution charges in the Virgin Islands last spring. Lewis, who is cooperating with prosecutors, testified under oath during his plea bargaining session in November that he supplied Barry with crack cocaine. In meetings with prosecutors in the past week, McWilliams also said the mayor called him after Barry's ties to Lewis became public and told him he trusted him to keep quiet about what he had seen in the hotel room, two law enforcement sources said. Barry has said he only called McWilliams to urge him to cooperate with authorities investigating the case.

DOC.HEAD: New Institute Devoted to AIDS Research
DOC.TEXT: An institute devoted solely to AIDS research will open this year in Manhattan, launched with $11.4 million in foundation and city funds, and is expected to grow into one of the world's largest AIDS laboratories. Dr. David Ho, 37, an AIDS researcher and member of the AIDS Advisory Committee of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, will be director of the new Aaron Diamond AIDS Research Center. The center will concentrate on creating an AIDS vaccine and preventing the damage AIDS causes to people already infected, officials said. ``When a cure for AIDS is found, it will be in a place such as this,'' Mayor David N. Dinkins said at a news conference. The sponsors said the center would rank in size with such leading AIDS programs as the Pasteur Institute and the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., in about two years. The center, started with $3 million from the Diamond Foundation and $3.4 million in city construction and renovation funds, is expected to open in about six months and will be housed, rent-free, in the city's Department of Health Laboratories building. The Diamond Foundation also has promised $1 million a year toward the center's operating budget for the first five years. Its immediate goal is to attract about 50 topnotch scientists _ many of whom already have federal research grants _ and gather them under one roof for collaboration, said Ho, who was lured from the University of California at Los Angeles. Ho predicted it will take several years for researchers at the center or elsewhere to develop a successful AIDS vaccine, and several more years to put it into widespread use. The Diamond Foundation was established by the late real estate developer Aaron Diamond, who died in 1984. It finances medical research, minority education, arts and human rights programs.

DOC.HEAD: Southern Capital Overwhelmed By Hunger, Terror
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of starving people are being held captive in the besieged southern capital of Juba, where rebels and army forces are at a standoff in some of the civil war's fiercest fighting, relief workers say. The relief workers, who were evacuated from the city this week, said Tuesday that government soldiers have prevented residents from leaving so many people are digging trenches to shelter themselves from rocket attacks by rebels ringing the city. ``Juba has become a death trap,'' said Irishman Daniel Eiffe. ``People live in terror from the shelling. This is a whole new dimension.'' Eiffe, of the Agency for Cooperation and Research in Development, a London-based relief group, flew to Khartoum on Monday with three other Westerners as part of a U.N. airlift. Fourteen other Westerners flew to Nairobi, Kenya, and they too spoke of terror and starvation. An Italian doctor said he saw security forces beat back two groups of people attempting to leave, mainly women and children. Civilians fleeing the fighting in the countryside have swollen Juba's population to nearly 300,000 and food is running out. Another doctor who fled to Nairobi said people fear riots over the meager stocks that remain. The angst is exacerbated by the uncertainty of what will come if rebels of the Sudan People's Liberation Army end their long siege of the city with a military advance. The rebels end broadcasts on their clandestine radio station with the ominous sign-off: ``Black people be ready.'' John Garang, a renegade army colonel, began the bush insurgency in Africa's largest country in 1983. The rebels are fighting the Moslem-dominated government in Khartoum for increased economic and political autonomy for the predominantly Christian and animist southern half of Sudan. Hundreds of thousands have died in the civil war, most of them victims of a famine caused by farmers being driven from their fields to seek refuge in government-controlled places like Juba, 750 miles south of the capital. The rebel push around Juba is their fiercest offensive in nearly seven years. They have captured 11 communities south and west of the city, virtually ending access to it by road. The army has 9,000 to 10,000 troops and several thousand armed civilians and militia in Juba, which sits on the west bank of the White Nile and is the largest town in southern Sudan. About 5,000 rebels are thought to surround the city; and military sources in Khartoum said the insurgents lack the firepower or manpower to take Juba. The rebels have shelled the city twice, on Jan. 21 and last Friday. Eiffe said at least 23 civilians were killed in the attacks. On Monday, rebel radio said the shelling would resume and advised residents to leave. Eiffe said the city was paralyzed. He said businesses and schools were closed and food distribution so limited that rations were half of what is considered minimal daily fare under international standards. More than half of Juba's residents are displaced people who live in crude camps. The government banned relief flights to the south on Nov. 3 because of intensified fighting and Juba's only source of food has been daily Sudan Airways flights chartered by the Lutheran World Federation in Nairobi. The flights bring in 50 to 60 tons of food a day but the city needs 150 tons a day to adequately feed people, relief workers say. ``The Sudan airways pilots are very brave,'' Eiffe said. ``They fly in despite attacks on them.'' ``Thousands of people gather around the Sudan Airways office in Juba trying to get tickets out,'' he said. ``They fly out around 80 to 100 Sudanese daily.'' Eiffe said Juba residents fearing new shelling had been crowding into his office begging for shovels and picks to dig bunkers in which to hide. Others fled to the deep banks of the Nile for protection. Some of the Western evacuees blamed both the army and the rebels for Juba's desperation. All spoke on condition they not be identified by name or organization. They said the rebels shelled Juba indiscriminately with rockets that make terrifying noises when they explode and burst into hundreds of pieces of maiming shrapnel. The army in turn has planted land mines as part of a security cordon around the city. The evacuees said the troops also refuse to let residents leave, apparently hoping their presence will keep the rebels from trying to invade. One evacuee said many Juba residents sympathize with the rebel cause, but nobody can understand their purpose in shelling the city. He said residents listen to government and rebel propaganda and feel trapped in the middle. ``A few weeks ago, food was the major concern,'' Eiffe said. ``Now that's changed, and it's terror from shelling.''

DOC.HEAD: Parrot Costume Returned After Reward Offered.
DOC.TEXT: After flying the coop unexpectedly, the Pirate Parrot has come home to roost. The furry green costume, worn by the Pittsburgh Pirates' mascot, was taken to a radio station that had offered a $200 reward for its safe return. Two unidentified men dropped off the costume at WBZZ-FM Tuesday evening, about 24 hours after police say it was stolen. The Pirates said the costume is worth $8,000. The costume was taken Monday night by someone who broke into the parked car of Mike Recktenwald, 26, of Brentwood, one of two people who play the role of the mascot. ``I couldn't believe it,'' Recktenwald said. ``The costume was brand new. I only had it a week.''

DOC.HEAD: `Coupon' Connie Found Guilty in Conspiracy, Fraud Trial
DOC.TEXT: Despite her federal fraud conviction, ``Coupon Connie'' says her coupon-clipping was just the zealous performance of a housewife's duty. But she'll never clip again. ``You should never use coupons,'' Connie Santos Arvidson said Tuesday after being convicted in a $2 million counterfeit coupon scheme. ``I won't ever again.'' The Boca Raton, Fla., woman could be ordered imprisoned 15 years when she is sentenced March 23 for mail fraud and conspiracy. She insisted during her three-week U.S. District Court trial that she didn't know the manufacturers' coupons she began buying and trading through a magazine advertisement were counterfeit. Co-defendant David Rees of Center Point was convicted of conspiracy, and printer James Floyd Richards of San Antonio was cleared of three counts. The defendants were accused of counterfeiting more than 600,000 copies of coupons issued by 47 companies, including Procter & Gamble, Nabisco Brands Inc. and Campbell Soup Co. Mrs. Arvidson, who has also been called the ``Dumpster Lady'' because she rooted through garbage bins looking for coupons, used some to buy products and then sold them at flea markets, said prosecutor Steve Sucsy. Her main income came through selling the coupons for more than she paid for them, he said. ``Basically, it's just a story of greed,'' Sucsy said in closing arguments. ``Her statement to the effect she was only doing what any number of innocent housewives were doing was not so.'' Prosecutors said Mrs. Arvidson purchased bogus coupons from San Antonio counterfeiter David Rackmill. Rackmill pleaded guilty to mail fraud and conspiracy and acted as an informant, as did six others indicted in the case. Mrs. Arvidson, 34, testified that she earned about $30,000 in 1988 in rebates, price breaks and free products from manufacturers and used the proceeds to buy furniture, toys, to make a down payment on a BMW and pay for cosmetic surgery for herself. The counterfeit ring was indicted in August after a four-month investigation by the U.S. Postal Service.

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan's Good News May be Bad News for Interest Rates
DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan's good news message _ a lower risk of recession coupled with stable inflation _ is being interpreted by financial markets as bad news for interest rates. Greenspan, in testimony Tuesday to the congressional Joint Economic Committee, said the risk of a recession in the next six months to a year is lower now than it was last spring. Inflation, while still unacceptably high at 4.5 percent, is stable, he said. His seemingly mild comments unsettled stock and bond markets, where traders interpreted them as a sign the central bank will not lower interest rates anytime soon. A volatile New York Stock Exchange session ended with the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials down 10.14 points. ``What he's really saying is ... if you want to get inflation down it may be you have to live with crummy economic growth, not for a few quarters, but for a few years,'' said economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch. That's a blow to President Bush's prospects of trimming the federal budget deficit. Bush's budget released this week relies on relatively strong growth to boost government revenue and lower interest rates to hold down the cost of carrying the national debt. Earlier this month, Bush pressed the Fed to lower interest rates. The Fed last eased just before Christmas when it nudged a key bank lending rate down by a quarter of a percentage point. It was the latest step in an effort begun in June to stimulate the economy with lower interest rates. Before that, the central bank emphasized fighting inflation over battling a recession and pushed rates up. Now, signaling an apparent return to a tougher anti-inflation stance, Greenspan said ``4.5 percent (inflation) is unacceptable ... because it is very difficult in that type of environment to prevent it from accelerating.'' ``Inflation at this stage represents the greatest threat of recession that we have because it will bring with it the types of imbalances which hold us back,'' he said. Despite some caveats, analysts said Greenspan was clearly more optimistic about growth than he was last July, when he told Congress Fed policy had shifted toward avoiding ``an unnecessary and destructive recession.'' ``There was a greater stress on inflation and less worry about the possibility of recession than we've heard from the Fed in the recent past,'' said economist David Wyss of DRI@McGraw Hill Inc., a Lexington, Mass., forecasting firm. ``I don't think it means they're going to tighten, but it does mean they're not going to loosen right now,'' he said. On other matters, Greenspan said: _``It's difficult to say'' if an increase in inflation expectations in the United States was causing Japanese investors to shy away from purchasing Treasury securities sold to finance the national debt. ``There is probably some element of shift'' because interest rates in Japan have risen sharply compared with U.S. rates, he said. _The administration's economic forecast of 2.4 percent growth this year and 3.2 percent growth in 1991 ``are not by any means unreasonable.'' Private economists have accused the administration of issuing a rosy forecast to make it easier, on paper, to trim the budget deficit. Greenspan cautioned, however, that the administration's economic forecast was conditioned on Congress passing the president's budget proposal ``in total.'' _Comments by White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater that ``lower rates are justified'' were ``inappropriate.'' Such statements from the administration are better made in private, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Conservation Group Hails Impact of Law Aimed at Soil Erosion
DOC.TEXT: Despite a few complaints about federal enforcement, a private conservation group says historic provisions in 1985 farm law will help farmers move rapidly toward eliminating severe soil erosion on much of the nation's cropland by the mid-1990s. A study of more than 1,000 farms in selected areas across the nation showed the conservation provisions of the 1985 Food Security Act have been a main force in prodding farmers into protecting soil and water resources. The report, released in Washington Tuesday by the Soil and Water Conservation Society of Ankeny, Iowa, focused on the law's provisions governing the use of fragile, highly erodible land, and wetland areas. Specific deadlines were set for farmers to comply with Agriculture Department regulations for conservation planning and project completion. The law also established a 10-year Conservation Reserve Program with a goal of removing 40 million to 45 million acres of highly erodible cropland from production by the end of this year. About 34 million acres have been signed. Under the program, farmers must plant the idled land in protective grass or trees. In return, they get federal cost-sharing payments to establish the soil cover, plus annual rental payments for 10 years. Those average about $50 per acre annually. ``For the first time in history, receipt of most federal farm program benefits _ commodity price supports, agricultural credit and crop insurance _ became legally contingent on the application of appropriate land stewardship practices by agricultural producers,'' the report said. The law's four conservation parts outlined the Conservation Reserve Program, or CRP, and so-called sodbuster, swampbuster and compliance provisions that the report said have been generally well accepted by farmers. ``We may well accomplish a greater measure of erosion control on the nation's cropland in the next five years than we have accomplished in the preceding 50,'' said project director Max Schnepf. ``But this report makes it clear that a great deal remains to be done by farmers and by the federal government if we are to realize the full potential of the 1985 farm bill's conservation provisions,'' he said. Schnepf said the project began in mid-1988 and the report is the first of several planned for a three-year evaluation. Norman A. Berg, a member of the society's steering committee and former head of the Soil Conservation Service in USDA, said the farm law for the first time linked farm policies and program benefits to sound conservation practices. ``The law provided leverage we did not have before to curb erosion and protect wetlands,'' Berg said. Society officials said the study, which had financial support from the Joyce Foundation of Chicago, was ``by no means a statistically valid survey'' of all U.S. land. However, the project did entail a close look at conservation work in 22 representative counties. The report said: _CRP field checks show soil erosion will be reduced 91 percent on land enrolled in the program, although the total tonnage of soil saved may be lower than the USDA has reported. _Sodbuster and swampbuster provisions, with the potential loss of federal benefits, appear ``to be discouraging farmers from improperly cultivating fragile land and converting wetlands to crop production.'' However, there have been violations, and ``USDA officials are not adequately monitoring or enforcing the policies in some areas.'' _Conservation compliance, which requires farmers to adopt and carry out conservation plans, will result in significant reductions in erosion if the plans are implemented. But final implementation ``will be difficult for a significant number'' of farmers unless they adopt additional, low-cost erosion-control practices.

An Agriculture Department survey shows wind damage to land in the Great Plains is down sharply from a year ago's near-record losses that resulted from the 1988 drought. Wilson Scaling, chief of the department's Soil Conservation Service, said Tuesday 1.74 million acres were reported damaged in November and December, down almost 20 percent from 2.16 million acres damaged in the same two months of 1988. Even so, the damage in November and December was nearly 60 percent above the 20-year average for those months. Lingering drought and limited snow cover were the major reasons for the damage, he said. ``We've had several years of drought with resulting lack of (crop) residue and poor vegetative cover,'' Scaling added. Texas, with 576,000 acres reported damaged, accounted for about one-third of the total. North Dakota, was close behind with a state record of almost 553,000 acres damaged by wind. November and December are the first two months of an annual seven-month season when winds are highest and the soils are driest in the Great Plains. Surveys were made in 541 counties of the 10-state region. In 1988-89, 14.3 million acres were damaged by wind in the Great Plains, the most since the agency began keeping records. In 1954-55, damage was reported at nearly 16 million acres. According to the survey, the state-by-state breakdown comparing damaged acres in November and December with the damage during the same two months a year earlier, included: _Colorado, 65,041 acres damaged this season and 28,795 in 1988-89. _Kansas, 105,770 and 135,550. _Montana, 214,465 and 510,875. _Nebraska, 30,575 and 54,405. _New Mexico, 28,650 and 51,100. _North Dakota, 552,952 and 188,200. _Oklahoma, 57,540 and 68,480. _South Dakota, 54,680 and 112,250. _Texas, 576,320 and 664,128. _Wyoming, 54,595 and 346,754.

The quality of last year's wheat crop was down slightly from the 1988 harvest, according to an Agriculture Department report. Of the 13,363 samples checked by the department's Federal Grain Inspection Service, 56 percent were graded No. 1, compared with 64 percent in 1988, the agency said Tuesday. Ratings by grade are based on a number of factors, including test weight per bushel, damaged kernels, foreign material, and shrunken and broken kernels.

DOC.HEAD: GAO: 14 Government Programs Ripe for Major Losses, Abuse
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen government programs, including Medicare and the new agency handling the savings and loan bailout, are high risks for fraud and abuse, a congressional report says in warning of possible ``major losses'' of taxpayers' money. The General Accounting Office said Tuesday that many of the problems have persisted for years because there is no way to force government agencies to correct them. GAO provided the list to two congressional committees, saying it decided to identify the government agencies and programs most at risk following disclosures last year of widespread management problems at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The chairmen of the panels promised hearings to review the problems. ``I have been concerned about the possibility of other HUD-type problems for some time and, unfortunately, I am convinced that they do indeed exist,'' Comptroller General Charles A. Bowsher said in a letter accompanying the list. Bowsher warned that unless reforms are implemented, ``major losses of federal funds and collateral fraud and abuse incidents will continue.'' GAO's list included: _The Resolution Trust Corp., the agency set up by S&L bailout legislation to handle the sale of assets of failed thrifts, worth an estimated $200 billion to $300 billion. ``A sale of this magnitude is unprecedented in history,'' Bowsher said. ``The desire and potential to acquire these assets at bargain-basement prices will make this area highly susceptible to fraud, waste and abuse.'' _Management of seized and forfeited assets stemming from drug and other investigations. The GAO said the two agencies that handle these properties, the Customs Service and Marshal's Service, have ``significant internal control weaknesses'' that invite abuse. _Medicare. GAO said this multibillion-dollar program is riddled with waste, saying $527 million in inappropriate payments in 1985 alone ``illustrate the magnitude of potential savings.'' _Defense Department inventory management and purchases of major new systems. GAO said at least $30 billion of the $100 billion in DOD inventory was not needed and the opportunity for fraud was plentiful as the department handles more than $900 billion in planned purchases. ``Following established management controls to deliver capable and supportable weapons to the user when and where needed, and at a reasonable cost, has been the exception rather than the rule,'' GAO said. Among the other areas GAO said it singled out for special attention were the IRS' failure to collect more than $60 billion it is owed; the management of loan and grant programs for students, farmers and mass transit; the reliance of the Energy Department, the Environmental Protection Agency and NASA on private contractors; the State Department's overseas construction program and government oversight of the $2 trillion private pension system. The committee chairmen, Rep. John Conyers of the House Government Operations and Sen. John Glenn of the Senate Government Affairs, said they hoped the Bush administration would cooperate in determining ways to correct the problems. ``We simply can't afford to sit around and wring our hands over this situation while more taxpayers' money is wasted or put at risk,'' Glenn, D-Ohio, said in a statement. ``The real question now is: What is being done to fix these problems?'' Conyers, D-Mich., laid the blame for government-wide management problems on Reagan administration deregulation policies. ``Ten years ago we were told by the incoming Reagan administration that the answer to so many of our problems was `less government,''' Conyers said. ``Today we see that the chickens have come home to roost and the legacy of the Reagan administration's `get the government off our backs' mentality is mismanagement, taxpayer rip-offs and outright fraud.''

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,188.95, down 26.72 points, or 0.07 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Base Closure Panel Not Ruled Out
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, accused of putting ``a political gun to the head'' of Congress with a base closing list, says he's open to the idea of a blue-ribbon panel studying the controversial issue. But Cheney, in an interview Tuesday with wire service reporters, rejected charges from House Armed Services Committee Chairman Les Aspin that the list was partisan and would be used to influence lawmakers' votes on legislation. ``The idea that somehow I tried to put a gun to the head of Congress is not a valid one,'' Cheney said, arguing it is Congress' job to make the tough choice between their districts' desires and cutting defense spending. ``It seems to me eminently reasonable, that if you are going to shrink the size of the force, have fewer tanks and fewer ships, you need fewer bases to support them,'' the secretary said. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said there was ``potential'' in Cheney's list of more than 72 domestic facilities and 14 overseas installations that could be closed or scaled back. But he objected to the way the administration wants Congress to deal with the list and introduced legislation that would create a bipartisan commission to make new recommendations. ``This is merely a list of candidates for closure,'' Aspin told reporters at a news conference. ``The upshot is that the list can be changed. Bases can be deleted or perhaps added. That creates hostages for the administration. Vote against a veto override, your base is safe. Vote to override, your base is threatened. ``The process is dead,'' Aspin said of Cheney's approach. Cheney, queried about Aspin's proposed commission, said, ``I wouldn't rule it out completely,'' but insisted that his approach wasn't dead either. ``Obviously, Congress is going to take a look at it. I'm perfectly happy to talk to Les Aspin or anybody else,'' Cheney said. Aspin's suggested panel _ similar to a commission created by Congress in 1988 _ would produce an all-or-nothing list of closings for approval or rejection by the defense secretary and Congress. The recommendations of the 1988 panel to close 86 bases were adopted by Congress last year. Cheney, in presenting his $292.1 billion military spending plan for fiscal 1991, proposed on Monday a list of bases for closing or realignment that would be considered by lawmakers on an individual basis. ``This puts a political gun to the head of a member with a base in his or her district,'' Aspin said. The lawmaker contended the process ``opens an enormous bargaining bazaar'' and creates ``a lot of bargaining chips for the administration'' when time comes to influence votes. Aspin charged that of the 32 bases he'd looked at, 22 were in Democratic districts, making the list clearly partisan. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a senior member of the House Armed Services Committee, said Cheney has produced ``an unbalanced, partisan hit list'' that is unacceptable. However, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., declined to accuse the Bush administration of playing politics, saying with a grin, ``I've heard some Republicans are very angry'' with the selections. Cheney argued there may be more bases targeted in Democratic districts because there are more Democrats in Congress and because a large number of military installations are in Democratic-controlled states. ``California gets about a third of the defense budget. ... Texas has a large number of bases. It's really not political,'' he said. ``That's a petty kind of game that I don't think serves anybody's interest. I didn't sign on as secretary of defense to get Democrats. If I'd wanted to do that I'd have stayed in the House,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Helms Wants More Answers on U.N. Anti-Torture Convention
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Jesse Helms says he is going to work to slow down Senate ratification of a United Nations convention banning torture because he wants the Bush administration to provide more information about it. ``There are scores of questions we need to analyze,'' said the North Carolina senator, the ranking Republican on the Foreign Relations Committee. ``This is such a complicated subject I hope we don't just move it along.'' Helms also said he was upset that only four senators _ himself, committee chairman Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., Larry Pressler, R-S.D., and Frank Murkowski, R-Alaska, showed up for a hearing on the subject Tuesday. Officials of the Bush administration joined human rights activists in telling the panel they want the Senate to vote by a two-thirds majority to ratify the convention. ``Early ratification of the convention by the United States will clearly affirm our known abhorrence and condemnation or torture,'' Abraham Sofaer, the State Department's legal adviser said. The administration has said there is an ``urgent need'' for Senate approval of the measure to send a signal to other countries around the world that torture will not be tolerated. Sofaer said the convention will have little effect on the United States where laws are clear, but it will give the administration a voice in working against torture. Nevertheless, the administration wants to attach a few reservations to the documents to ensure no conflict on technicalities of U.S. law. Generally, the convention requires parties to prevent torture within their territories, to make all acts of torture a political offense and to bring those accused of torture to justice. Human rights activists are enthusiastic about the measure. ``Appropriate ratification ... will contribute significantly to the enforcement of the international prohibition against torture in practice,'' said Winston P. Nagan, chairman of Amnesty International. Among the groups supporting the convention are the U.S. Catholic Conference, B'nai B'rith International and the American Bar Association. Although ``nobody favors torture,'' Helms said he was disturbed that countries such as Afghanistan, Bulgaria, China and the Soviet Union which Helms says have promoted serious human rights violations have also ratified the convention. He asked if parties to the convention had condemned China for the massacre of students last summer in Beijing. ``I guess running over people with tanks is not torture,'' Helms said. Fifty-five nations have ratified the convention, including Libya, a nation the United States has accused of promoting terrorism. Twenty-two nations have signed the treaty, indicating they intend to ratify it. The torture convention came into force on June 26, 1987. Under the convention, a committee of 10 experts was established with power to investigate allegations of torture and receive reports.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Officials Say Situation ``Unsettled'' in the Philippines
DOC.TEXT: American officials and lawmakers just back from the Philippines are offering a mixed assessment of President Corazon Aquino's chances for political survival after the aborted coup last December. ``The political situation remains unsettled and ... many wonder whether the government can recover from the blow sufficiently to restore popular confidence and make lasting strides toward stability,'' said Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Carl W. Ford. ``We are hopeful that the near loss of hard-won democracy will energize the Philippine public and private sectors to work even more closely and effectively,'' he told the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific on Tuesday. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State David Lambertson said he came back from Manila ``impressed again with the determination and resilience of the government and its people.'' But ``the danger of another coup attempt exists,'' he said. He said Aquino must regain confidence by eradicating corruption and improving inefficient government services to avert another coup attempt. ``Corruption remains a real problem in the Philippines and its corrosive effects hamper government operations,'' he said. ``President Aquino is fully aware of the problem and has made efforts to deal with it'' both by example and by exhorting her people. A member of the subcommittee, Rep. Jim Leach, R-Iowa, said Congress would be unwilling to pay the price demanded by the Philippines for extending the rights to the Clark air force and Subic Bay naval bases once the leases expire next year. Leach, and the officials, suggested a growing wave of Filipino nationalism, coupled with a decline of the Soviet military threat and the tight U.S. budget raises doubts about the survival of the bases. ``The bases are very important, but it's conceivable there are alternatives,'' Leach said. ``There are alternatives,'' Ford responded. ``But they are much more expensive.'' Ford said the United States believes it can overcome the surge of new nationalism in the Philippines and reach a new base agreement. Lambertson said negotiations would begin within several months, initially between U.S. Ambassador Nicholas Platt and Filipino Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus. A special negotiator will be appointed for more detailed work later, he said. The administration witnesses also said the Aquino government is becoming the third large recipient of U.S. foreign aid in the world _ after Israel and Egypt. For the fiscal year which began Oct. 1, the administration asked Congress for $658.6 million for the Philippines. The request includes $200 million for the multi-year, international aid program. The United States has pledged $1 billion for the plan over the lifetime of the plan, for which Japan is the largest contributor. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State David Lambertson warned U.S. law would require a cessation of U.S. aid if Aquino were overthrown. The ``greatest immediate threat to the government's survival'' is a faction within the military which was responsible for the December coup attempt, Lambertson said.

DOC.HEAD: Former Defense Secretary Calls for U.S. Troop Cuts
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration should re-evaluate its military strategy and reduce U.S. forces in Europe by almost 200,000 in light of the push for freedom in the Eastern bloc, says a former defense secretary. James R. Schlesinger, a past hardliner against cuts in NATO forces, told the Senate Armed Services Committee failure to respond to the changes with troop cuts ``would ultimately be self-defeating.'' ``We should plan now radically to scale back our forces in Europe. The time for that planning is now. Implementation may extend over months or years, as circumstances warrant. But the reduction should not be precluded by the ongoing negotiations in Vienna,'' Schlesinger told the panel. Under questioning from the committee, Schlesinger said the United States should keep between 75,000 to 100,000 troops in Europe, down from the current American level of about 305,000. Last May, prior to the full-fledged drive toward democracy in many of the Warsaw Pact nations, President Bush proposed a ceiling of 275,000 on U.S. and Soviet ground and air force personnel, which would require a reduction of about 30,000 U.S. troops and about 325,000 Soviet troops. But Schlesinger said if the United States sticks to its current position on reductions in negotiations in Vienna, it may fall into the trap of ``legitimatizing the long-term presence of Soviet forces in Eastern Europe'' which might otherwise be withdrawn. ``It would be far worse, if the nations of Eastern Europe were to hold the United States or NATO responsible for the continued presence in their countries of Soviet forces,'' Schlesinger added. The Senate Armed Services Committee is holding a series of hearings on now the United States should respond to the lessening Soviet threat and its effects on the military budget. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the panel, agreed with much of what Schlesinger said in his testimony. ``The question of when we make these changes is an important one but it seems to me that you make a case of great persuasion that planning for these changes need to start now,'' Nunn said. ``And if we do not start the planning now ... then we're not going to make rationale decisions on today's budget.'' Nunn said he had spoken to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and stressed it will be important that Cheney spell out his vision for defense over the next five years. ``Where is this budget leading us?'' said Nunn. ``I hope we're not going to simply have a fiscal approach here. It's got to be a reassessment of the threat and reassessment of America's response to it.''

DOC.HEAD: USAir Workers Reject Representation By Teamsters
DOC.TEXT: Some 1,800 USAir workers who have been represented by the Teamsters are no longer members of the union after a vote by other workers for the airline. The Teamsters lost an organizing drive to represent 8,000 employees who load the airplanes for USAir, company and AFL-CIO representatives said Tuesday. The election was an all-or-nothing event for the Teamsters, who already represented USAir workers in Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, Buffalo and Boston. The union's defeat means those workers no longer are members. It was the Teamsters' third election at USAir since 1981 and the largest representation election in the private sector in four years. The union won the first two contests at USAir. Rex Hardesty, a spokesman for the AFL-CIO, said the two weeks between the call for the election and the mailing of the ballots did not give the Teamsters adequate time to campaign. ``I have every indication from the Teamsters that they will be back and that they felt they were hurt in this campaign by the fast election and all the insecurity felt these days in the transportation industry,'' Hardesty said. ``There's fear and concern among all workers and it makes them less willing to organize.'' David Shipley, spokesman for the Arlington, Va.,-based USAir, said the Teamsters needed 4,002 votes to win the election, but only slightly more than half that voted for the union. He said he did not have precise figures. ``We felt that this particular group did not need representation by the Teamsters. Obviously, the employees agreed with us,'' Shipley said. Shipley said the ballots were mailed Dec. 15 to employees nationwide who work in 180 airports. Fleet service workers handle baggage, cargo and load food onto airplanes. The ballots were counted on Tuesday. A call to the home of a Teamsters spokesman was unanswered. The Teamsters represented cargo workers at USAir before its 1989 merger with Piedmont airlines, whose employees were not members of the union. On Dec. 1 the National Mediation Board ordered the election to determine whether workers at USAir and former Piedmont employees would be represented by the Teamsters. Three other unions representing pilots, flight attendants and mechanics at USAir gained the right to represent the Piedmont workers without elections.

DOC.HEAD: DOT Proposes New School Bus Safety Rules
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Transportation is seeking to require new school buses to display a regulation stop sign every time the bus door opens to permit children to enter or depart. The department's National Highway Traffic Safety Administration also proposes to improve cross-view mirrors on school buses to provide drivers better visibility in front and along the sides of the vehicle. Both proposals are subject to regulatory action. Jerry Ralph Curry, the agency's administrator, said Tuesday that 35 to 40 school children are killed each year in accidents related to school buses. Curry said stop signals and improved mirrors could help prevent many of those accidents when coupled with increased training for drivers of the buses. More than 30 states now require a stop signal attached to school bus doors. The safety administration's proposal would standardize the equipment and apply in all states. It would consist of a stop-signal arm which would swing out from the left side of the bus to display the standard red-and-white stop sign.
DOC.HEAD: Commerce Orders New Weather Radars
DOC.TEXT: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher has ordered full production of 165 new Doppler weather radars. The $359 million project will cover the next six years, with the first of the new units scheduled for installation in the fall near Oklahoma City, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said Tuesday. Known as NEXRAD, for Next Generation Weather Radar, the new system is expected to improve weather forecasts and provide earlier warnings of severe storms, including tornados. Pre-production versions of the radar have been under test for several months. Doppler radar assists meteorologists by showing the direction of wind and rain movement on radar screens. Traditional radars can detect the presence of storms, but cannot determine wind movements.
DOC.HEAD: Justice Won't Bar Broadcast of Secretly-Taped TV Program
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court Justice Antoni Scalia has refused to bar the television program ``Inside Edition'' from broadcasting scenes filmed with a hidden camera inside a New York City doctor's office. He rejected without comment Tuesday an emergency request in which Dr. Stuart M. Berger's lawyers sought to block the broadcast. An ``Inside Edition'' spokeswoman said the program plans to include the scenes in a segment about Berger. A federal judge in Detroit ordered the program to keep the secretly recorded scenes off the air, but a federal appeals court panel overturned the judge's order as an unconstitutional ``prior restraint'' of free speech. Berger, author of several widely sold diet books, is under investigation by the New York State Department of Health's Office of Professional Medical Conduct for alleged unethical and fraudulent conduct. In its own investigation of Berger, the television program sent one of its producers to the doctor's office as a patient. Producer Amy Wasserstrom said in an affidavit she surreptitiously videotaped two visits she made to the office. Ms. Wasserstrom said Berger diagnosed her as suffering from an allergy to yeast and from chronic fatigue but another doctor told her she had no such ailments. Berger's lawyers said airing the office scenes will do irreparable harm to his reputation ``and the sanctity of his office.''

DOC.HEAD: Jetliner Crash Aftermath: Helping the Helpers
DOC.TEXT: At fire houses, police stations, schools and hospitals, Long Island residents still reeling from the Avianca jetliner crash that killed 73 people and injured 86 are beginning to help the helpers. Even as the dead are buried, the injured treated and the survivors consoled, some mental health and social workers are turning their attention to the people who rushed to the crash scene Thursday night and found a nightmare of death, injury and mutilation. In most cases, experts say, they need nothing more and nothing less than talk. ``After the crash, there's an emotional aftershock,'' said Joan Imhof, director of the Nassau County Office of Volunteer Services. ``You need to talk about the experience, what you remember, how you felt about it, any symptoms you might be experiencing. ``You have to come to grips with the fact that you and your body have suffered a traumatic experience.'' The clinical term is post-traumatic stress disorder; symptoms can include fatigue, nausea, muscle tremors, appetite loss, appetite gain, poor concentration, flashbacks, anxiety and depression. Ms. Imhof lives near the crash site at Cove Neck on the northern shore of Long Island, and worked there throughout the night. As rescue workers carried children away from the wreckage, ``we felt awful that we couldn't find their parents and reunite them then,'' she recalled. ``But there were so many serious injuries, we just had to ship them out'' to hospitals. Asked about efforts to comfort the rescuers, she spoke about her own memories of the night in great detail. Asked if she, too, needed to talk about her experiences in order to deal with them, she replied, ``You got it.'' The Boeing 707 en route from Colombia ran out of fuel and crashed on a wooded hillside Thursday night 15 miles northeast of its destination, Kennedy International Airport. Helpers at the crash site were not the only ones in need. Spanish-speaking staffers at the state's Pilgrim Psychiatric Center in Brentwood worked for days with crash survivors and the families of passengers at several hospitals. ``Emotionally, I'm still in shock,'' said Sonia Palacio-Grottola, a social worker. ``It really hasn't sunk in yet. We're still emotionally charged, and we need to have some peer counseling to come down from this ordeal.'' In addition to ``debriefing'' sessions offered by fire, police and rescue departments for their own workers, several hospitals and agencies are reaching out to the public. North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, for example, is offering free group or individual counseling. Dr. Victor Fornaci, a staff psychiatrist, said it was too early to say how many people would need help because it can take weeks or months for symptoms to develop. In addition, the county Mental Health Department offered counseling for area residents at Oyster Bay High School; at local schools, teachers and students were discussing the crash; and the American Red Cross planned to set up counseling sessions for rescue workers later this week. ``When we're finished, we'll do some counseling. But there are still dozens of family members that need our help,'' said Peter von Berg of the Red Cross. ``Right now we're still on adrenaline.'' ``We need to get our feelings out,'' he said. ``I went home Sunday night and cried for an hour.'' For some, the reality of Thursday night already had sunk in. ``We keep reliving what we did and saw,'' Oyster Bay Fire Chief Tom Reardon said after a Sunday church service that focused on the crash. ``What I saw that night was carnage. And we just tried to do the best we could to help those people. Now we're trying to get everything back to normal.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientists ``Delighted'' with Condition of Rescured Satellite
DOC.TEXT: Scientists say they are ``delighted'' with the condition of a rescued science satellite because the wear and tear it received during six years in space was just what they wanted. ``That's why we sent it up there, to find out what happens to materials after a long time in the space environment,'' William H. Kinard, project chief, said Tuesday after getting his first look at the satellite since its return. Wearing contamination-proof clothing and standing on an observation platform several feet away, Kinard and other scientists watched as the shuttle Columbia's 60-foot-long cargo bay doors swung open to reveal the 11-ton satellite known as the Long Duration Exposure Facility. Columbia's astronauts retrieved the laboratory 200 miles in space on Jan. 12, snaring it just weeks before it probably would have been dragged by gravity to a fiery death in the atmosphere. The satellite eventually will be moved to a nearby sterilized building for close examination. At the Johnson Space Center in Houston, the commander of the shuttle mission said the damage to the experiments aboard the laboratory will provide clues to what materials best withstand the harsh environment of space. ``I think it does certainly bring home the point that we have to take a good look at anything we do over a long duration in space,'' Commander Dan Brandenstein told reporters Tuesday. Kinard said the laboratory appeared to have suffered a little more wear and tear than the pictures taken by the astronauts in space indicated. ``It looked a little more weathered than we concluded earlier,'' he said. ``There are lots of small micrometeoroid craters and there are some other places where there are reactions that may have been started my micrometeoroids.'' He said there was some discoloration and that foil covering some experiments had been torn. ``We're delighted with the condition,'' Kinard said. There are 57 experiments attached to the satellite's exterior, and scientists and engineers are eager to see how the various materials in them fared during their long exposure to atomic oxygen, radiation, micrometeoroids and other phenomena in space. The results will help in designing future long-duration spacecraft, including the Freedom manned space station to be assembled in orbit starting in 1995. Four teams will study the recovered laboratory here for about three weeks, photographing it and jotting down their observations. The teams are composed of specialists in space debris, materials, spacecraft systems and radiation. Starting in mid-February, the experiments will be covered with protective aluminum and removed one-by-one from the satellite's racks. They then will be delivered to scientists throughout the nation and Western Europe for detailed study. The satellite carries 21 materials, coating and thermal systems experiments, five power and propulsion experiments, 17 science experiments and 14 optics and electronic experiments. They represent more than 200 investigators, 33 private companies, 21 universities, seven National Aeronautics and Space Administration centers and eight foreign countries. Also aboard are 12.5 million tomato seeds. A few will be planted in research labs, but most will be sent to schools where students from fifth grade through university level will plant, water and nurture the seeds for research into such things as germination rates, chromosome and genetics studies and full tomato growth. Kinard said the seeds will be among the first experiments removed, so that the students have time to work with them before the school year ends.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Reagan to Turn Over Diary Entries to Poindexter
DOC.TEXT: Diary entries by former President Reagan contain ``information of significance'' for John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial, a federal judge says in ordering the excerpts turned over to the defense. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene on Tuesday ordered the former president to provide diary excerpts from more than 29 different dates by next Monday, but said he will conduct a lengthy review process if Reagan invokes executive privilege. Such a step could delay the scheduled Feb. 20 start of the trial, which already has been moved back a month due partly to Poindexter's efforts to subpoena documents and testimony from Reagan. Reagan, in Las Vegas for a speech Tuesday night, told reporters he would not comment on the judge's order. Greene has not decided whether to approve a request by Poindexter, the former national security adviser, to subpoena Reagan as a witness. The former president is resisting such a subpoena. Poindexter is charged with conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements in connection with aide Oliver North's assistance to the Contras and a November 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. If Reagan invokes executive privilege, Greene said he would ``revisit the issue'' of whether the diaries are material to Poindexter's defense. Greene noted a similar procedure was followed during the Watergate scandal, when the special prosecutor sought access to White House tapes in the case against several of President Nixon's aides. Greene then would provide the former president and the Justice Department with a secret document Poindexter submitted to the court outlining why he needs the diaries. After court filings by all sides, the court will ``make a final decision with respect to enforcement of the subpoena'' for the diaries, Greene said. Greene said the ``vast majority'' of more than 100 diary entries turned over to the court for review last week ``contain no information that is material'' to the Poindexter case, but entries covering more than 29 dates in 1985 and 1986 ``do contain information of significance.'' Reagan was ordered to give Poindexter a diary entry relating to a ``successful'' trip Poindexter took in December 1985 to Central America. ``The entry includes a somewhat ambiguous comment arguably indicating that the former president knew'' of Poindexter's ``activities on behalf of the Contras,'' Greene said. The judge said Poindexter is entitled to diary entries in which Reagan describes an effort to persuade the government of Honduras to release a seized arms shipment that had been destined for the Contras. Greene also said Poindexter must receive diary entries focusing on U.S. military-type assistance to an unidentified Central American country that may have been used in support of the Contras. The entries ``may show what types of aid President Reagan thought could legally be provided for the military or paramilitary operations of the Contras,'' Greene said. Poindexter also is entitled to Reagan's diary entries concerning meetings with Poindexter and others in December 1985 ``to discuss the sales of arms to Iran,'' Green said, adding that one entry ``addresses briefly the issue of the proceeds from these sales.'' Greene said none of the diary entries shed ``any light on the question of what President Reagan may have known about the diversion'' of proceeds to the Contras from the administration's secret sale of arms to Iran.
