Reagan has denied knowing about the diversion and Poindexter testified before Congress that he didn't tell the president. Poindexter contends Reagan knew of and approved activities undertaken in the Iran and Contra initiatives and that therefore Poindexter had no reason to conceal these activities from Congress, as charged in the indictment.

DOC.HEAD: US Sanctions On Libya Complicate War on African Pest
DOC.TEXT: The Bush adminstration's refusal to deal with Libya is complicating an international campaign to rid Africa of a deadly pest that threatens livestock, wildlife and even humans. The parasitic screw-worm fly is proving to be a ``political insect,'' said a source at the U.N. Food and Agriculture Organization. ``The United States has the expertise and Libya has the pest.'' So far, Washington has agreed to allow critically needed U.S. technology to be used in Libya to combat the insect. But U.S. sanctions against Libya mean the technology can't be quickly authorized, and crucial months have passed. Also, the United States has refused a request by the U.N. organization to allow Americans with vitally needed experience go to Libya to help eradicate the insect. ``We would have been able to have the (full-scale eradication) campaign under way if it weren't for the obstacles'' from the U.S. side, said the FAO source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The screw-worm fly lodges in wounds or tick bites and can kill its hosts, including humans, by eating away at tissues. In addition to livestock, wildlife such as zebras and antelopes as well as some endangered species are threatened. A small but undetermined number of people in Libya have been infested with the parasite. Time is crucial to containing the fly, which, until its appearance in Libya, had not been seen outside the Western Hemisphere. Earlier this month, President Bush renewed sanctions against Libya. The ban on U.S. travel to Libya and economic dealings dates back to the administration of Ronald Reagan, who accused Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi of sponsoring international terrorism. A U.S. official who declined to be identified said the United States agreed to help with the screw-worm fly after ``we received assurances no resources would be given directly to the government'' of Gadhafi. The United States is cooperating because the insect's threat goes beyond Libya. Experts say the infestation could suddenly spread to Libya's neighbors, especially Tunisia and Egypt, then move down the Nile River Valley into Central Africa. Southern Europe also is considered vulnerable. If the pest moves beyond Libya, said U.N. official Bjorn Sigurbjornsson, ``We may not be able to eradicate the fly from Africa at all.'' The U.S. technology consists of a special way of irradiating flies to make them sterile. Under the strategy, tens of millions of flies would be sterilized at a specially outfitted U.S.-Mexican laboratory in Mexico and released in Libya. Matings would eventually cause the insect to die out. The United States became the unquestioned expert on screw-worm flies after years of devastating infestation in the U.S. Southwest. In 1982, the insect was declared wiped out in the United States. Thanks mainly to two relatively cold winters, the warmth-loving fly has been contained to a swath across northern Libya, east and west of Tripoli, said Edgar Yates, a technical expert at the International Fund for Agricultural Development, another Rome-based international agency. Yates said the screw-worm fly probably came to Libya through an infected animal from Latin America, where the pest is still a problem. FAO's request to the United States was made last May, about a year after the fly was confirmed in Libya, the FAO source said. In January, U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Clayton Yeutter asked the Senate to amend a treaty, which the United States signed with Mexico, that currently allows the sterilization flies to be dispersed only in the Americas. Approval is expected in March, said Paula Henstridge of the deparment's legislative department. The earliest the flies could be released would be early autumn, Yates said. So far, the United States has been unbending on letting American technicians go to Libya. ``As far as we're concerned, the Mexican expertise is sufficient,'' said Elizabeth Bonkowsky of the U.S. State Department. Sigurbjornsson disagrees, saying U.S. technicians will be essential when the full-scale fly release, scheduled to last up to two years, is under way. The U.S. government has cooperated in other ways. Larval samples have been analyzed in a North Dakota facility, and Ms. Bonkowsky said a Libyan was granted a visa to work with U.S. experts there. There are also problems between the FAO and the United States. The United States has refused to pay its full assessment, which accounts for one-quarter of the agency's budget. The dispute goes back to 1985, when Reagan accused the organization of being biased against the United States and of inefficient administration.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: The first U.S. band to march in the Soviet Union's annual May Day parade promises to march through Red Square to the stirring strains of ``God Bless America.'' Dorothy Hill, who has headed the Waltham American Legion band for more than 40 years, said Monday it took her three years to win permission for the band's participation in the Red Square festivities. A Soviet immigrant in Brookline eased the way for the Massacusetts marchers. Rudolph Peselman, who works as an international trader, helped arrange the nine-day trip for 150 people, including Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn and more than 70 band members. Hill said she hoped the April 28-May 6 trip will promote world peace. ``I'm a veteran of World War II. I've seen three wars. I don't want to see any more,'' she said. ``I know I'm going to be playing `God Bless America' going through Red Square.''

City officials are hoping that a good tree trimming will do what inflatable snakes, poison corn, Christmas lights and a sticky limb coating couldn't _ keep pesky birds out of the pear trees. Stillwater's concern about the trees runs deep. City Manager Carl Weinaug said the community has spent thousands of dollars during the past four years to make the birds feel unwelcome. The city commission approved the pruning in hopes of reducing the roosts and rousting the flocks of grackles, English sparrows and other birds that seek refuge in the 47 pear trees. Winfrey Houston of a downtown merchants group proposed the trees be trimmed significantly to make them unattractive to the pear pests. Although the trees may be unattractive to people for a short time, he said that was a better alternative than to get rid of the trees. The trees' height will be slashed nearly in half, to about 12 feet. The board also voted to place netting on some of the trees and to test dwarf pear trees.

Some restaurants in northwest Montana no longer automatically plop a slice of tomato onto their burgers. The reason? The tomatoes cost more than the hamburger. Tim Dutter, manager of the Kalispell Dairy Queen, says he now pays $1.49 a pound for hamburger and $2 a pound for tomatoes. Dairy Queen has not changed its policy on tomatoes, however, because customers have routinely paid a nickel extra for a slice of tomato. ``We don't raise the price of the hamburger to cover the cost of the tomato,'' he explained. Just the same, Dutter said, ``we're taking somewhat of a loss'' on tomatoes at the moment. At Wendy's in Kalispell, tomatoes have become ``a request item only,'' according to assistant manager Virginia Neuhausen. With large tomatoes costing 62 cents apiece _ compared with 10 or 11 cents normally _ nobody gets one without asking. The policy has prompted no complaints, Neuhausen said. The price rise was triggered by an unusual freeze in the South earlier this winter, according to Ron Vivit, produce manager at Rosauer's supermarket in Kalispell. In area food stores, tomatoes are selling at $2.39-$2.59 a pound _ but they're not selling quickly.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Oldest Known Flight Attendant Retires at 70
DOC.TEXT: A woman believed to be the nation's oldest flight attendant has retired at age 70 after logging nearly 4{ years in the air during a career that began in 1948. ``I had to have a goal for something and I figured it might as well be old,'' Connie Walker said Tuesday after she stepped off a Northwest Airlines flight from Seoul. With a sparkle in her eye that might have been a tear, she said her feelings were torn. ``The body is ready to quit and the heart wants to keep going,'' she said. Walker, her union and company representatives said that as far as they were aware, she was the nation's oldest flight attendant. About three dozen friends and co-workers greeted Walker at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport with flowers, balloons, hugs and a chorus of ``For she's a good lady.'' Among the well-wishers was Denise Flanagan, who Walker helped deliver on a flight to Anchorage 36 years ago. Northwest flew Flanagan from her home in Ludlow, Mass., and her mother, Lorraine Magenau, from Akron, Ohio, to help Walker celebrate her retirement. They have remained in touch and Walker, who never married, calls Flanagan her daughter. ``We're unofficial family _ love, not blood,'' Flanagan said. Magenau said it may have been anxiety that brought on the labor during the flight. When Walker came to help, Magenau remembers her saying, ``I don't know anything about babies, but I'll do what I can.'' Walker started at age 28 in 1948, flying between Portland, Ore., and Billings, Mont. She has spent nearly 4{ years of her life in the air, and her mileage is the equivalent of about 700 trips around the Earth, the airline estimated. Walker said her next trip will be a vacation cruise ``so I don't have to go in and out of an airport and stand in line.'' She plans a flight to Norway in December, but said sitting down will be a new experience. ``Like an old warhorse you want to get up and help,'' she said. Cindy Yeast, of the Association of Flight Attendants in Washington, D.C., said it is common for attendants to work into their 60s, but 70 is the oldest she has heard of. Bill Rainey, with Teamsters Local 2707, which represents 6,500 flight attendants, said he knows of none older. Northwest has no age limit for flight attendants, said spokeswoman Karen Jollie. Walker never showed her age, her co-workers said. ``She's an amazing gal,'' said Bob Ryan, who was first officer on her last flight. ``It's hard to believe that at 70 she has the spark and drive she has. It's really great.''

DOC.HEAD: Subway Hires Workers to Push More Commuters into Jammed Cars
DOC.TEXT: Commuters in Seoul were shoved into jammed subway cars for the first time today by pushers hired by subway authorities to prevent rush-hour delays. The new workers, dubbed ``pushmen,'' helped commuters at some busy subway stations push their way into already crowded cars. Subway officials said 132 students were deployed at 20 crowded stations to quicken the operation of subway trains, which had been delayed at some stations by commuters clustered around doors, struggling to get inside. One pusher, Cho Un-sang, identified himself as a college student and said he was asked to work for three hours in the morning for $2 an hour. About 3 million riders a day use the four subway lines in Seoul, a city of 10 million people, with about 1 million traveling during the morning rush hour.

DOC.HEAD: IBM, Motorola Announce Nationwide Radio-Based Computer Network
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `But IBM ...' to CLARIFY by DELETING reference to cellular phone waves; Longer version moved on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: Portable computer owners will be able to tap into central computers from almost anywhere, without using telephone lines, through a nationwide radio network being developed by IBM and Motorola Inc. ``We're giving the mobile worker access to data he's never had before,'' said Jack Blumenstein, an International Business Machine Corp. executive who was named president of the joint venture, called Ardis. Motorola had offered a similar service to clients in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles and had designed a nationwide in-house system for IBM service technicians. The companies said Tuesday they decided to combine the networks to get a payback from hundreds of millions of invested dollars. For Motorola, it provides a national radio network to market to new clients. Ardis officials said Sears, Roebuck and Co. and New York Life Insurance Co. are among major companies testing the system. Potential users include field service personnel such as equipment maintenance technicians, real estate brokers, package-delivery workers, police officers and insurance agents. By using a hand-held terminal hooked to the radio network, a mobile home appliance repairman could be told by his headquarters what service calls to make, and in turn could check on the availability of parts from his company's warehouse. The service, which will be available in April, would appear to be in competition with cellular telephones. By using cellular phones and a modem, a portable computer can be hooked up to a mainframe computer. But IBM and Motorola say their system is more useful because it is on line all the time _ there's no need to dial up a computer. In addition, they say, it provides the ability to store and recall messages that are sent to the terminal when the user is not monitoring it. Cellular phones have difficulty penetrating buildings made of certain materials, but the computer system would have no such problems, the companies said. IBM and Motorola would not disclose the amount they are investing in the 50-50 partnership, based in the Chicago suburb of Lincolnshire, Ill. Exact pricing of the service has not been set, but it is expected to cost about $100 to $150 a month per terminal.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors Claim First Successful Fetal Heart Surgery
DOC.TEXT: Doctors at a London hospital say they have carried out what they believe is the first successful fetal heart surgery. Dr. Lindsey Allan of the fetal cardiology unit at Guy's Hospital said Tuesday that doctors had corrected a heart valve defect in an unborn boy using a balloon catheter. ``As far as I know this is the first successful operation of its kind,'' she said. Two operations were carried out on the fetus during the mother's pregnancy in December, one at 31 weeks and the second at 33 weeks, she said. She did not say why there had been a delay in disclosing the details. Allan said the baby was born prematurely on Jan. 4 _ one week after the second operation _ and underwent surgery for the third time a few hours after birth. ``The child is still quite seriously ill, but we have given him a chance he would not otherwise have had,'' Allan said. She said the parents, who do not want to be identified, live outside London. Most fetuses with the rare defect, called critical aortic stenosis, die in the womb, and few who are born survive for more than 24 hours, she said. The defect blocks the aortic valve, making it unable to pump blood at the right pressure, leading to heart failure. The operations involved inserting a catheter down a hollow needle directly into the chest wall and heart of the fetus. Once in place, the balloon was dilated to open the heart valve, the doctors said. A catheter is a slender flexible tube inserted into a body passage, vessel or cavity. Its normal uses include passing fluids and making examinations. Allan said the team that pioneered the technique included herself; Michael Tynan, professor of pediatric cardiology; and Darryl Maxwell, director of the hospital's fetal medicine unit. She said there were always ethical obstacles to this type of operation. ``I am not sure that we should be meddling sometimes. There is always discussion as to whether it is a reasonable request to make of the mother. On the other hand, one knows that the alternative is almost universally fatal,'' she said. In the operation, a hollow needle measuring 0.04 of an inch in diameter and about 10 inches long was inserted through the mother's abdomen and uterine wall directly into the chest and heart of the fetus. Using a high resolution ultrasonic scanner, Maxwell guided the needle into the heart through the left ventricle. The catheter was then passed down the needle. Attached to it was the deflated balloon and a piece of platinum wire. The pumping action of the heart took the wire and the balloon directly across the aortic valve. The balloon was then inflated by pumping saline solution down the tube. When inflated, the balloon tore and split the valve to improve the blood flow. The Dec. 18 attempt failed because of difficulty in positioning the device across the aortic valve. The balloon burst when inflated and snapped off the catheter while being removed. The remains of the Dec. 18 balloon are still in the baby's heart, Maxwell said. He said an operation to remove it was too risky. ``Leaving it there does not seem to have caused any problems,'' he said. The Dec. 28 operation went more smoothly because less fluid was pumped into the balloon. Maxwell said the needle was in the heart for about 30 minutes during the two-hour procedure. The mother, who also has two daughters, was awake during the operations, the doctors said. Only local anaesthetic was administered to her abdominal wall to ensure the fetus was awake and in the right position. The mother was allowed to go home after the Dec. 28 operation, and a week later she went into premature labor. Her son was born six weeks early by normal delivery and within hours was taken to Guy's, where the third operation was performed to make sure the valve had been properly opened. Guy's Hospital is part of Britain's state-run National Health Service.

DOC.HEAD: Mothers Convicted of Forcing Children to Have Sex
DOC.TEXT: Two women were convicted of forcing each other's children, ages 11 and 9, to have sex under the threat of beatings while the women watched. The Circuit Court jury found Carolyn Wilson and Annette Sanford guilty of two counts each of first-degree criminal sexual conduct on Tuesday. The women could face life imprisonment when they are sentenced in March. Wilson, 42, and Sanford, 34, will face additional charges in the spring from an episode in which they allegedly lined up their six children and allowed men to choose among them for sex. The two women's families lived together between 1984-88. Wilson's son, now 13, and Sanford's daughter, now 11, testified that Wilson ordered them to have sexual intercourse in May 1988. Authorities say some of the children had told of being raped and molested over a two- to three-year period by men visiting the women. The women denied the charges. The children were placed in foster care homes in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: State Asked to Probe McMartin Trial Verdict; Activists Want New Trial
DOC.TEXT: County supervisors voted to ask the state Attorney General's office to review the McMartin preschool molestation trial as prosecutors considered refiling charges against Raymond Buckey. Buckey, 31, and his 63-year-old mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, were acquitted Jan. 18 of 52 child molestation counts at the now-defunct McMartin Pre-School in suburban Manhattan Beach. A mistrial was declared on 13 other counts against Buckey when jurors could not reach a verdict. Prosecutors were expected to announce today whether they would refile those charges. Parents of children involved in the nation's longest and costliest criminal proceeding cheered a vote Tuesday by Los Angeles County supervisors to ask the state Attorney General's office to review the 6-year-old case. State officials were asked to review trial transcripts and comments some jurors reportedly made afterward that they felt molestations might have occurred but that the prosecution failed to prove its case against the defendants. The county's call for a state investigation would be dropped if the charges were refiled, said Supervisor Michael Antonovich, author of the motion. At a news conference Tuesday, victims' rights activists called for a new trial. ``Child sexual abuse is no longer taboo in this country, but an epidemic. And it's an epidemic we do have a cure for,'' said Lynne Lamb Bryant of the group Victims of Incest Can Emerge Survivors in Action. Doreen Kinney of Families of Crimes of Silence said her group had received 6,000 letters demanding that Buckey be retried. ``We believe those people ... are trying to tell us that no one has a right to hurt the children,'' she said. Douglas Wolf of the Adam Walsh Child Resource Center said his group supports a bill that will be introduced in the Legislature that would lift the statute of limitations on prosecuting child molesters. He declined to discuss the bill in detail or name its sponsors, however.

DOC.HEAD: Former Guam Governor Commits Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to delete `public'; SUBS final two grafs to CORRECT Blaz' first name to Ben and spelling of Madeleine
DOC.TEXT: Ricardo ``Ricky'' Bordallo, former governor of Guam, died Wednesday of self-inflicted gunshot wounds while draped in a Guam national flag and chained to a statue in a busy intersection. Bordallo, pronounced dead at Naval Hospital 4:28 p.m., was to have boarded a plane Wednesday night for Los Angeles. He was to report to the federal correctional facility in Boron, Calif., on Friday, where he was to begin serving a four-year prison term on witness tampering and obstruction charges. Bordallo died of massive brain damage, said a hospital spokesman. Doctors had worked furiously to save his life, but emergency surgery failed. Bordallo, 63, shot himself with a .38-caliber pistol after chaining himself to a statue of Chief Quipuha at one of the capital city's busiest intersections, said police Lt. Phil Dennis. He had unveiled four placards, one of which said, ``I regret that I have only one life to give to my island,'' said Dennis. Also recovered at the scene were a blood-stained flag and a padlock and chain. Bordallo had served a governor of the U.S. territory from 1976-80, and was re-elected again in 1984. ``It's a very sad day for me personally ... he was a close personal friend during the early part of our lives,'' said Ben Blaz, Guam Republican congressional delegate, reached at his Washington, D.C., office. ``I didn't think this would happen. Ricky Bordallo always seemed to bounce back from his many adversities.'' His wife, territorial senator Madeleine Bordallo, was said to have been with her husband when he took his life.

DOC.HEAD: China Reportedly Giving More Jail Visits To Protesters
DOC.TEXT: Chinese authorities have recently allowed a large number of imprisoned pro-democracy activists to receive visits from their relatives, a pro-Beijing newspaper reported today. Wang Dan, the movement's top student leader, and Liu Xiaobo, a teacher and one of the last hunger strikers, were among those visited, according to the Chinese-language Wen Wei Po. The paper quoted unidentified sources as saying both Wang and Liu were in relatively good health and spirits. Liu has been incarcerated since June. On June 4, Liu and three other hunger strikers led several thousand students from Tiananmen Square after soldiers killed hundreds, perhaps thousands, of pro-democracy protesters in other parts of Beijing. Wang, a history student at Beijing University, went into hiding after the protests but was arrested, apparently during the summer, when a reporter from Taiwan unwittingly led police to him. The paper said the visits, which began shortly before Saturday, the Chinese new year, were the most allowed since the June 4 crackdown on the pro-democracy movement. The pro-Communist paper said the decision to allow the visits was made in tandem with the ending of martial law in Beijing. It said both moves indicate that China's political situation is ``daily becoming more stable.'' China said recently it had freed 573 people arrested for taking part in the crushed pro-democracy movement. But thousands more reportedly remain jailed in Beijing alone. The article did not say how many of these people were granted the right to see their family, saying only that people identified as ``intellectuals and academics'' were allowed visits.

DOC.HEAD: Defense: Bankers Didn't Know They Were Handling Drug Profits
DOC.TEXT: A banker charged with hiding illegal drug profits in a $32 million money-laundering case says he was tricked by federal agents and now faces guilt by association to his former customer _ Manuel Noriega. Amjad Awan, who once claimed to control Noriega's secret accounts, is charged along with four other officers of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International and a Colombian with laundering cash they knew to be drug proceeds. In opening arguments Tuesday, prosecutors wove an account of how undercover agents infiltrated a Colombian drug lord's operation, picked up cocaine profits from U.S. middlemen and went to the bankers to help hide the source of the cash. ``It's easy after the fact to look back and second-guess,'' countered Awan's attorney, John P. Hume. ``But it's standard practice: Bankers never ask where the money comes from. It embarrasses customers and drives people away.'' Hume said Robert Musella, who was actually a Customs agent posing as a high-stakes launderer, never had a deal with the bankers to launder drug cash. ``He never said he was engaged in criminal conduct. He never gave Awan an opportunity to get in or to get out,'' Hume said. Although Awan testified before a U.S. Senate panel in 1988 that he once handled $23 million in Noriega's accounts, the defense attorney also warned the government to keep the deposed Panamanian leader out of the case. ``This is guilt by association. By focusing in on Panama and General Noriega, they're causing you not to focus in on the problems of the transactions,'' Hume told jurors. The other defendants are Colombian Rudolf Armbrect of Medellin; Syed Aftab Hussain, who was operations officer of the Luxembourg-based bank in Panama; Akbar A. Bilgrami of Miami, a director of the Latin American Division; Sibte Hassan, who was an officer with the Paris branch; and Ian Howard, French country manager based in Paris. They are accused of conspiracy to traffic in drugs, conspiracy to launder drug profits and money laundering. Prosecutors said the bankers proposed a scheme in which millions in drug profits were converted into certificates of deposit at the bank's Panama City branch, and then used as collateral for loans that gave drug barons a source of cash. Undercover agents recorded 148 meetings and more than 2,000 telephone calls that prosecutors said will show the defendants were aware they were handling drug money. ``It was a policy of the bank to take in as many deposits as you can as fast as you can and don't be too careful about where it comes from,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Rubenstein said. ``My clients are the biggest drug dealers in Colombia,'' the prosecutor quoted the undercover agent as telling Awan. ``It's not any business of mine who the customers are,'' Awan replied, according to Rubinstein. Rubenstein said the bankers were motivated by ambition. ``Their career goals,'' he said, ``were more important than the laws of any country.'' Before the start of jury selection two weeks ago, two divisions of the Luxembourg bank, one of the world's largest private financial institutions, pleaded guilty to money-laundering charges. As part of a plea bargain, the bank agreed to forfeit a record $14 million in assets frozen earlier by the government and to cooperate against other defendants.

DOC.HEAD: Directors Guild Nominees Mix Popular Films With More Personal Projects
DOC.TEXT: Woody Allen, Rob Reiner, Phil Alden Robinson, Oliver Stone and Peter Weir are the Directors Guild of America's nominees for 1989 directorial achievement. Allen was nominated for ``Crimes and Misdemeanors,'' Reiner for ``When Harry Met Sally ... ,'' Robinson for ``Field of Dreams,'' Stone for ``Born of the Fourth of July'' and Weir for ``Dead Poets Society.'' ``I'm just stunned,'' said Robinson, a first-time nominee. ``I didn't think I stood a chance.'' ``I think we have some interesting choices this year,'' commented Barry Levinson, last year's winner for ``Rain Man,'' as he announced the nominees Tuesday. Reiner, Robinson and Weir were somewhat surprising choices, since several critics have overlooked their achievements in favor of such films as Paul Mazursky's ``Enemies, A Love Story,'' Edward Zwick's ``Glory,'' Bruce Beresford's ``Driving Miss Daisy'' and Spike Lee's ``Do the Right Thing.'' Said Robinson: ``Bruce Beresford deserved a nomination. I'm surprised Ed Zwick didn't get a nomination. And a lot of people were pulling for Paul Mazursky.'' ``Crimes and Misdemeanors'' is an alternately funny and haunting story of infidelity, starring Allen, Alan Alda and Anjelica Huston. ``When Harry Met Sally ...'' is perhaps the lightest movie in competition, a romantic comedy with Billy Crystal and Meg Ryan as best friends who become lovers. ``Field of Dreams,'' set in an Iowa corn field, features Kevin Costner as a baseball fan who recaptures the past by building a ballpark on his farm. ``Born on the Fourth of July'' is Stone's account of the life of Ron Kovic (played by Tom Cruise), a patriotic soldier whose life is shattered in Vietnam. ``Dead Poets Society'' casts Robin Williams as an unconventional teacher working within the confines of a conventional boys boarding school. The guild says its awards have deviated from the Academy Awards only three times since 1949. Three years ago, Steven Spielberg won the DGA award for ``The Color Purple,'' but Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences members didn't nominate him for an Oscar. The directing Oscar that year went to Sydney Pollack for ``Out of Africa.'' Some observers believe the guild's 9,000 members, all of whom have a vote, represent a more divergent electorate than the Academy. Four of the 1989 nominees have been up for the DGA award before. Allen was nominated for ``Annie Hall'' (1977), ``Manhattan'' (1979) and ``Hannah and Her Sisters'' (1986); Reiner for ``Stand By Me'' (1986); Stone for ``Platoon'' (He won in 1986); and Weir for ``Witness'' (1985). The awards will be presented at the DGA's 42nd annual dinner, to be held simultaneously in New York and Los Angeles on March 10.

DOC.HEAD: Pretrial Publicity and Financial Hardship Cited by Poential Jurors
LaserPhoto ANG1
DOC.TEXT: Some potential jurors in the criminal trial of former Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood say they already have made up their minds or could lose their jobs if picked for the jury. The Exxon Valdez rammed a charted reef March 24 and dumped more than 10 million gallons of crude into Prince William Sound in the nation's worst oil spill. Ten of the 91-member jury pool were questioned Tuesday. Four were excused. Two people said they might lose their jobs if forced to serve on a trial expected to run six to eight weeks. The other two said they had made up their minds about who was responsible for the spill. ``This would be a tough one for me,'' one of the prospective jurors, a heavy equipment operator, told the court. ``A lot of damage has been done.'' Another, who said he had caused a 10,000-gallon spill himself while working for the oil industry in Alaska, told lawyers Hazelwood should not have been charged. Hazelwood, 43, is being tried on one felony charge of criminal mischief and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating on a vessel while intoxicated. The maximum possible penalty for conviction on all counts is seven years, three months in prison and a $61,000 fine. The tanker hit Bligh Reef a few hours after taking on a load of North Slope crude oil at the trans-Alaska pipeline terminal at Valdez. Oil released by the huge gashes in its hull coated hundreds of miles of shoreline, killed thousands of marine mammals and prompted what Exxon said was a $2 billion cleanup involving thousands of workers. The trial began Monday, with Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone rejecting another round of defense efforts to get charges against the veteran seaman dismissed. Defense attorney Dick Madson had argued that charges should be dismissed because the state lacks jurisdiction. Alcohol abuse, command responsibilities and pretrial publicity are figuring heavily in jury selection. ``Have you formed any opinions of roles or responsibilities of the various parties?'' Madson repeatedly asked. Despite excusing four potential jurors, Johnstone kept the process moving. He pushed lawyers from both sides to speed their examinations. ``It's going much faster than I expected,'' said Madson, who complained the judge was limiting questioning. Asked if 12 jurors could be seated by Friday, he replied: ``If he keeps cutting off questions like he is, yes.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor: Exxon Will Not Walk Away From New Jersey Spill
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Jim Florio accused Exxon Corp. of lax handling of a 570,000-gallon oil spill in a bird and fish sanctuary, and said the state had learned from the Exxon Valdez spill not to trust the company. Exxon, responding to Florio's comments Tuesday, defended its response to the Jan. 2 spill _ and to the Valdez disaster _ and said it would fulfill its responsibilities for the cleanup. Florio said the state Department of Environmental Protection has determined that a pipeline operator and supervisor on duty at the time of the spill in the Arthur Kill lacked the certification required by New York authorities, which shares jurisdiction for the waterway. A portion of pipe will be pulled out of the waterway, which lies between New Jersey and the New York City borough of Staten Island, and transported to Ohio for lab tests that could help determine the cause of the spill, Florio said. Exxon confirmed it was removing the pipe today for tests at its expense. Florio, the Democrat elected governor last year after a strong pro-environment campaign, said New York and New Jersey authorities had mapped out a strategy to restore the important East Coast spawning ground for birds and fish, which scientists say absorbed serious damage from the spilled heating oil. No dollar figure has been assigned to the damage, nor have cleanup costs been established. ``I want to make it clear to everyone in New Jersey that this will not be another Valdez,'' Florio said, referring to the March 28 wreck that spilled more than 10 million gallons of oil into Alaska's Prince William Sound. ``Exxon will not be allowed to hit and run. ... ``My impression of what's happening in Valdez is that Exxon seems to be inclined to wipe its hands sooner rather than later,'' Florio said. ``We're not going to allow that approach to be duplicated here.'' Exxon spokesman Leo McLean defended Exxon's cleanup in Alaska and said the company was cooperating with authorities to ``assess potential impacts ... and work toward agreement'' on the Arthur Kill cleanup. Florio reiterated claims that pipeline operators ignored warnings of a possible leak. Exxon has attributed the slow detection of the pipeline's problems to equipment failure, rather than human error. Florio said James Fitzgerald, a console operator at Exxon's Bayway refinery, had not obtained the certification required of pipeline operators by the New York Fire Department. George Leth, the shift supervisor who trained Fitzgerald, also was not certified to operate the equipment, Florio said. The lack of certification ``was another piece of information we will factor into the on-going investigation the attorney general is conducting,'' Florio said. McLean said he could not confirm or deny the certification claim until the company completed its own investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Say `Killer Bees' May Arrive This Spring
DOC.TEXT: As the Africanized ``killer bees'' swarm ever closer to their long-awaited U.S. border crossing, scientists are meeting to develop a strategy for battling the invasion, which may occur by the spring. The bees were sighted recently at Soto la Marina, Mexico, about 150 miles south of the border city of Brownsville, said Anita Collins, bee reseach leader for the local Agricultural Research Service station. Scientists from the research service, the Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, and the Texas A&M Agricultural Experiment Station attended a bee strategy meeting Tuesday. ``We are trying to draft specific plans for who is going to do what and when, and how, when we start seeing bees coming across the border,'' Collins said. ``And the idea is to protect the public and the bee industry in Texas.'' There is no reason to panic, Collins said. ``It is not a black cloud about to descend on South Texas,'' she said. ``This is the natural spread of a population in small groups of bees called swarms.'' The ``killer bees'' buzz off when sprayed with insect repellent, and if no repellent is available, ``the best advice is to run, because you can outrun a bee,'' Collins said. The bees, a hybrid of the European honeybee and the pure African queen bee, gained the ``killer'' label not because their sting is more poisonous than the European bees, but because of their defensive behavior, in which hundreds or thousands of the bees attack intruders. Twenty-six Africanized queen bees that escaped a research center in Brazil in 1957 are to blame for the swarms that have crept steadily northward through Central American and Mexico. The bees spread at the rate of 200-300 miles annually, according to research by John Thomas, a Texas A&M extension entomologist. Texas A&M sought $690,000 for a control program to slow the bee spread but the state legislature turned down the request last year, said Fred Meyer of the U.S. Agriculture Department. Once the bees arrive, Meyer said, funds should be available to eradicate the hives of the Africanized bees, survey the areas where they are found, and quarantine bees in affected areas. Several swarms of Africanized bees that arrived on ships from Latin America already have been found at seaports in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Former Guam Governor Commits Suicide
LaserPhoto covering
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Bordallo is pronounced bor-DAL-yo
DOC.TEXT: A former governor of Guam facing the start of a four-year prison term shot himself to death today while draped Guam's national flag and chained to a statue in a busy intersection. Ricardo ``Ricky'' Bordallo, 63, shot himself in the head. In addition to being wrapped in the flag, he had set up four placards, one of which said: ``I regret that I only have one life to give to my island,'' according to police and witnesses. Bordallo shot himself with a .38-caliber pistol after chaining himself to a statue of Chief Quipuha, who was the first chief in Guam to adopt Christianity. He died of massive brain damage at 4:28 p.m., said a spokesman at Naval Hospital. Bordallo had been scheduled to fly tonight to Los Angeles, where he was to visit with his daughter. On Friday, he was due at the federal correctional facility in Boron, Calif., to begin a four-year prison term on witness tampering and obstruction charges. Bordallo was convicted in February 1987 of getting engineer Johnny Carpio to lie to federal officials about a $60,000 political contribution from a group of Japanese businessmen. According to trial testimony, Bordallo, a Democrat, admitted accepting the money from the businessmen, but said the money was a campaign contribution. Carpio was convicted in 1987 of extortion and bribery and placed on five years' probation. Bordallo had served as governor of the U.S. territory from 1976-80, and was re-elected in 1984. He lost a re-election bid in 1988 to Republican Joseph Ada. ``My own instincts make me believe that I will not be coming back from Boron alive,'' Bordallo said Friday in an interview with the Pacific Daily News. ``I'm not dwelling on how it will happen. I will be in the hands of people who are masters of intrigue.'' Reporters who attended a farewell party for Bordallo earlier in the day said he appeared to be in good spirits. The party was in the office of his wife, territorial Sen. Madeleine Bordallo, who is considering a run for governor this year. ``It's a very sad day for me personally ... he was a close personal friend during the early part of our lives,'' Guam's congressional delegate, Ben Blaz, said from Washington, D.C. ``I didn't think this would happen. Ricky Bordallo always seemed to bounce back from his many adversities.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Deaf Brothers Attacked; One Dead
DOC.TEXT: A group of teen-agers shot two deaf brothers, killing one, after shouting at the men during an apparent traffic dispute, police said. The victims could communicate only with sign language, and ``it is unlikely that they understood what was being said or what was happening,'' police Lt. Harvie Eubank said. ``It was just a senseless shooting.'' Cesar Vieira, 30, an unemployed carpenter and father of two whose wife is expecting a third child, died at a hospital Monday from chest wounds. Edward Vieira, 25, an unemployed auto mechanic and father of a young son, was treated for hip and shoulder wounds and released after the attack Sunday night. No arrests had been made Tuesday. ``It's like their handicap got them shot. People didn't understand them so they shot them,'' said brother Marco Vieira, 29. The two victims had visited their mother and brother and were heading home on a motorcycle when the shooting occurred, police said. At a traffic light, the brothers noticed that five young men in a car were gesturing and yelling. When the light turned green, the car followed, forcing the two into a parking lot where, after shouting, one of the passengers opened fire. ``We can only surmise that they possibly had some kind of traffic dispute,'' said police Lt. L.A. Durrer. ``But the brother who survived doesn't have any idea what they did wrong that could have caused it.'' Deaf since childhood, the brothers and their families shared a house in Palmdale, 60 miles north of Los Angeles.

DOC.HEAD: Inmates Escape Santiago Cell after Digging Tunnel
DOC.TEXT: Forty-three leftist guerrillas, some of whom tried to kill President Augusto Pinochet in 1986, were at large today after escaping from a downtown prison through a tunnel that took a year to dig. Authorities said seven other inmates who escaped Tuesday were quickly captured by police, including one who had proved too big for the tunnel's exit and was found stuck in it. Horacio Ojeda, director of the national prison system, said the inmates dug a tunnel about 300 feet long and 20 inches wide from a cell block to a nearby lot where a subway station was under construction. The tunnel passed under a busy road. The escape was discovered at 2:30 a.m., Ojeda said. Several hours later, a man who identified himself as one of the escapees called Radio Cooperativa in Santiago with details of the operation. The caller said construction of the tunnel took more than a year and that 24 inmates took part in planning and carrying out the escape. ``The tunnel has a ventilation system operated with blowers,'' the man said. ``It has electric light and a rail system we used to take out the removed material.'' ``After we left, the tunnel remained open, and we think it was used by other prisoners who were not part of our plan,'' the caller added. The details desribed by the caller coincided with what reporters saw at the prison. The entrance to the tunnel was inside a cell. The inmates used a heavy cement block to cover the hole and hide it from the prison guards. Ojeda described all the escapees as leftist guerrillas, and said several were convicted in a Sept. 7, 1986, ambush of Pinochet's motorcade southeast of Santiago. Pinochet was unhurt but five bodyguards were killed and 11 wounded in the attack, carried out by the pro-Communist Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front. Pinochet took power following a 1973 coup that topped elected President Salvador Allende. He is scheduled to turn over power to a civilian government in February. Other escapees were front members implicated in the smuggling of more than 30 tons of rifles, rockets, bazookas, grenades and other weapons into the country in August 1986, Ojeda said. A list of the escapees disclosed by prison authorities includes several top commanders of the guerrilla organization. Some belonged to other leftist groups. According to a local organization of prisoners' relatives, four of the escapees had been sentenced to death but were awaiting the outcome of appeals. Three were convicted in the Pinochet assassination attempt and the other for killing a policeman.

DOC.HEAD: Former TV Cameraman Sentenced to Die for Three Murders
DOC.TEXT: Relatives of the victims applauded as a former television cameraman convicted of strangling three women was sentenced to die in the gas chamber. Dean Philip Carter, 34, showed no emotion as Superior Court Judge Robert W. Thomas ordered the sentence Tuesday. Carter still faces trial for two other killings during an 18-day spree in 1984. A jury recommended execution after it convicted Carter of killing Culver City roommates Jillette L. Mills, 24, and Susan Lynn Knoll, 33, and their friend, Bonnie Ann Guthrie, 24, of Los Angeles. Carter stared at a wall, his arms folded, as relatives of the victims asked the judge to impose the death penalty. ``What was described as a loving father was the monster who murdered and raped my daughter,'' said Sue Mills, 55, mother of Jillette Mills. Jennifer Bollman, 32, Jillette Mills' sister, said Carter had his day in court. ``Nothing has been spared in his defense. ... He has destroyed the lives of his victims and their families and he must have death in the gas chamber,'' she said. Thomas imposed prison terms totaling 32 years for the rape counts and burglaries of the victims' homes, then stayed the sentences and issued the death sentence. Relatives applauded heartily as the sentence was announced. ``It's been a long time coming. The loss we experienced in our lives can never be replaced. Our feeling on this is that we don't want this to happen to anyone else ever again,'' said Miss Knoll's sister, Sandra Pender. Carter was already serving a 56-year prison sentence for attempted murder in Ventura County and he faces murder trials for the slayings of Tok Chum Kim in Oakland and Janette Ann Cullins in San Diego. Police said Carter knew all his victims, meeting most of them in bars and restaurants. In 1979, Carter landed a series of jobs with TV stations in Alaska, including work as a cameraman in a team that won honors for a documentary on the Eskimo heritage.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises Sharply Against Yen
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange made up most of its morning losses and ended marginally lower. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,188.95, down 26.72 points, or 0.07 percent. The index, which rose 41.97 points Tuesday, fell briefly below 37,000 in the morning, for the first time since Friday. The dollar closed at 144.40 yen, up 1.15 yen from Tuesday's 143.25-yen finish. It opened at 144.90 yen and ranged between 143.95 and 145.00 yen. Traders attributed the dollar's strength to its sudden leap in New York after the Cable News Network reported Tuesday afternoon that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev might step down as Communist Party chief. Yuji Nakao, a trader with Chemical Bank, said sales of yen for profit-taking helped the dollar maintain its strength. The dollar suddenly turned down after hitting 145 yen, he said, as the Bank of Japan was reported selling dollars to support the yen. Heavy dollar-selling by some trading companies in Tokyo also helped stem the dollar's advance, he said. Japan's central bank was seen intervening in the market at around 144.65 yen and again at around 144.25 yen. The bank does not officially comment on its exchange market activities. Nakao added that later reports by the Kyodo News Service of a Soviet denial that Gorbachev might step down calmed market players and slowed the dollar's rise against the yen. Kyodo quoted unidentified Soviet sources. ``Today's fluctuation was all because of position adjustments triggered by the rumor,'' he said. He said the dollar surged because market players sold yen in an attempt to reduce their overbought yen positions. ``But the dollar could not go on getting stronger because of the shrinking interest rate gap between the United States and Japan,'' Nakao added. On the stock exchange, dealers said the index fell as the yen's plunge discouraged Japanese stock investors. An overnight decline in the Dow Jones industrial average on Wall Street also disheartened market players, said Izumi Yazaki at Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities, Co. The index then made up some of its earlier losses as market players bought back issues whose prices had fallen, she said. ``The rumor shook a market that had been already unstable ahead of the election,'' Ms. Yazaki added. A general election for the lower house of Japan's Parliament is expected Feb. 18.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Foes Win in Wisconsin Legislature
DOC.TEXT: Legislators approved a bill early today requiring minors to get parental consent before having abortions, and defeated an effort to repeal a dormant law that penalizes doctors who perform abortions. ``This is going to be a shot heard around the world,'' said Republican Rep. Robert Welch. ``Wisconsin is a liberal state taking a moderate stand on abortion.'' The Assembly had sifted through 30 proposed amendments before its 72-24 vote early today for a bill that would require girls younger than age 18 to have the consent of at least one parent or a court. Consent would not be required of incest and rape victims. ``We're elated,'' said Barbara Lyons, executive director of Wisconsin Right to Life Inc. ``I think it deflates all the rhetoric that the pro-choice movement was sweeping the country. Pro-life isn't dead; it's alive.'' The measure is expected to go to a Senate committee, where its prospects were uncertain, Welch said. Democrats control the Assembly 55-42, but partisan affiliation had little effect because there were more anti-abortion Democrats in the Assembly than pro-choice Republicans. Assembly Speaker Thomas A. Loftus, a Democrat, said the bill ``fails in the areas of reality, compassion and common sense.'' On Tuesday, the Assembly rejected by 54-42 an amendment to the bill that would have excluded pregnant girls deemed suicidal by a professional therapist or doctor. ``That's sick,'' said Rep. Louis Fortis, a Democrat. ``How can you call yourself pro-life when you're rejecting an amendment that would save the life of a teen-age girl?'' The Assembly voted 57-39 earlier against a floor vote for a bill to repeal a law that penalizes doctors or others who perform abortions. The law was made unenforceable by the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 Roe Vs. Wade ruling that legalized abortion, but abortion foes want it kept on the books in the hope the Roe vs. Wade decision will someday be overturned. The Supreme Court's ruling in a challenge to a Missouri abortion law last summer opened the way for state legislatures to challenge existing abortion statutes. The Michigan Senate was expected to consider next week a parental consent law that has was approved in December by the state House. Pennsylvania in November approved a law that restrict abortion after 24 weeks and requires a husband's notification for abortions in most cases.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Crew Striving To Stay Financially Afloat
DOC.TEXT: Short of money and haunted by the suicide of their skipper, the crewmen of the Soviet yacht Fazisi are depending on raffle ticket sales to keep them in a prestigious round-the-world yacht race. By the time the fourth leg of the Whitbread Round the World race, 7,190 miles from Auckland to Punta Del Este, Uruguay, starts Sunday, the team hopes to have raised about $200,000 from raffle tickets for a luxury BMW. The car was donated by a New Zealand company and the raffle ends today. ``We need new sails for the voyage around Cape Horn,'' said the new skipper, Skip Novak. New Zealanders have adopted the 83-foot aluminum yacht and its mixed crew of 12 Soviets, two Americans, one New Zealander and a Frenchman. Many were touched by the crew's plight and the suicide of skipper Alexei Grishencko, who hanged himself from a tree in Punta Del Este after the first leg of the voyage. ``He walked away from the hotel and we found him two days later. He had been depressed and under pressure,'' said Novak. New Zealand yachtsmen organized a party for 1,000 people in a boatyard and raised $7,200. A local radio station is hosting a $60-a plate dinner and a fashion show Thursday night. Also helping the fundraising are sales of red T-shirts with the hammer and sickle emblem of the Soviet Union emblazoned above the yacht's name. Unlike the other contestants, Fazisi doesn't have a corporate sponsor. Pepsi Cola withdrew its sponsorship because of negative feedback over its support for a Communist yacht, Novak said. ``It wasn't the imaginative thing to do considering the changes that have been going on in the Soviet Union since we started in September last year,'' he said. The crewmen, who come from all over the Soviet Union, have found it frustrating trying to keep up with the momentous changes taking place at home. ``At sea we listen to the BBC but the guys don't get the full story. When they get to port they get all the papers,'' Novak said. Novak, 37, a professional sailor from Chicago, offered himself as a consultant to a Soviet team planning to sail in the 37,950-mile race. The yacht's construction was financed by Fazisi, a joint venture of a Soviet Georgia-based state enterprise and a West German company with interests in fishing, forestry and trade. Construction of the yacht started so late that it had to be air-freighted from the Soviet Union to Britain aboard the world's largest airplane, an Antonov 124. It was finished barely in time for the race start. Novak said Fazisi, standing eighth overall in the fleet of 23 yachts from 13 countries, is doing better on its shoestring budget than some yachts with millions of dollars in sponsorship and a year of trial racing. He estimates that the total cost of the Fazisi challenge will be $3 million, about one quarter of other challenges. The money raised in New Zealand will get them to Uruguay. ``We don't know what we do when we get there,'' Novak said. ``We are hoping that we can pick up some American sponsorship for the leg to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., so we can finish the race. ``We need another $400,000, but we are philosophical and keen to finish,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Santa Claim Doesn't Wash
DOC.TEXT: Donnie Tassie arrived for work at a real estate agency to hear a voice speaking to her from the chimney. After assuring herself the speaker was not a co-worker pulling a fast one, Tassie called for help. Police found a man stuck feet first in the chimney. Albert Valdez, 23, of Hermiston, was arrested Tuesday on charges of attempted burglary and criminal mischief, authorities said. It took three men to hoist the 170-pound construction worker from the chimney by rope. Valdez was not injured. ``He told me first he was Albert; then he told me he was Santa Claus,'' said police Lt. Grant Asher. ``Right off the bat I didn't believe he was Santa Claus.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``There's a wonderful feeling in some parts of this country, and that isn't to say there's not a lot of hopelessness and a lot of despair that goes with some of these enormous social problems. But the underpinnings of the United States, the state of the union, is not bad.'' _ President Bush.

``I regret that I have only one life to give to my island.'' _ Ricardo Bordallo, former governor of Guam, in one of four placards he unveiled before shooting and killing himself while draped in Guam's flag and chained to a statue in the capital city. He had been scheduled to leave today for Boron, Calif., where he was to begin a four-year prison term on witness tampering and obstruction charges.
``The body is ready to quit and the heart wants to keep going.'' _ Connie Walker, whose retirement from Northwest Airlines at age 70 ends the career of the nation's oldest flight attendant.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Recovering from Pipe Bomb Explosion at Church
DOC.TEXT: Federal authorities investigating the mail bomb addressed to a fundamentalist minister that blew up in his daughter's lap were skeptical of a link to earlier, apparently race-related bombings. Lisa Osteen, 31, daughter of the Rev. John Osteen of the Lakewood Church, suffered bruises and burns to her torso and upper legs when the bomb exploded Tuesday morning. She was listed in good condition at Methodist Hospital. In December, nail-studded pipe bombs killed a federal judge near Birmingham, Ala., and a black civil rights lawyer in Savannah, Ga. ``There doesn't appear to be a tremendous amount of similarities, but we're not ruling anything out yet,'' said Bob Switzer, special agent with the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. ``We have no idea what the motive is. We can't link this to anything else,'' said Switzer. ``The bomb squad is trying to piece it all together,'' said police Sgt. H.G. Welch. Ms. Osteen, director of ministries at the 10,000-member church, apparently triggered the nail-packed bomb when she unwrapped the book-size package, which was addressed to her father. ``We just thank God that she was protected. And we know the angels of God watched after her and our prayers protected her,'' said Osteen, 68, who was not at the church at the time. ``We'll pray for those who have done this,'' he added. ``We know they are sick and they need help.'' Ms. Osteen was lucky to have survived the blast that shredded her chair and damaged her office, said Dr. Paul Pepe of Houston Emergency Medical Services. Osteen backs school prayer and opposes abortion in his nationally televised church services, but he isn't a widely known public figure, said the Rev. Jim Mitchell, a religion scholar at the University of Houston. The racially mixed, non-denominational church features speaking in tongues and faith healing. Osteen's chapel, with room for 8,200 faithful, is the largest in Houston.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuits Filed Against Ex-Operators of Rocky Flats, Fernald
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of people live in fear and have a right to know if Rocky Flats has adversely effected their health, says the attorney who filed two class-action lawsuits against the nuclear weapons plant's former operators. Also Tuesday, a $2 billion lawsuit was filed in Ohio against a former operator of another federally owned nuclear factory, the Fernald uranium processing plant. NLO Inc. and its parent company were accused of subjecting employees to a hazardous, radioactive workplace. The Denver lawsuits allege that Rockwell International Corp. and its predecessor, Dow Chemical Co., were careless and negligent in the treatment of hazardous wastes at Rocky Flats. The plant, 16 miles northwest of Denver, has manufactured plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons since 1953. Energy Secretary James Watkins suspended plutonium processing operations at Rocky Flats in November. He said the shutdown would remain in effect until DOE is convinced safety and health standards are being met. The lawsuits filed in U.S. District Court seek independent study of health risks posed by the nuclear weapons plant, $250 million in economic damages for devaluation of property and $300 million in other damages. Former workers also want an unspecified amount of money because the stigma of their past employment prevents them from finding new jobs or health insurance. ``They (the plaintiffs) want to be told the truth by someone who is independent and not controlled by the government or the operators of Rocky Flats,'' said attorney Bruce DeBoskey. ``This is not a lawsuit to close Rocky Flats, but to have it run properly,'' he said. The lawsuits said that actions by Dow and Rockwell led to repeated releases of both radioactive and non-radioactive hazardous substances into the atmosphere and violations of state and federal environmental health and safety laws. Five neighbors of the plant filed one of the lawsuits on behalf of about 10,000 property owners and up to 50,000 people who live near the plant. They asked the court to halt the further releases of hazardous substances. Dow Chemical operated the plant from 1953 until 1975, when Rockwell took over. Last year, the Department of Energy replaced Rockwell with EG&G Inc. after the FBI and the Environmental Protection Agency raided Rocky Flats, looking for evidence of illegal disposal of hazardous wastes. The other lawsuit was filed by the Building and Construction Trades Department, AFL-CIO, and the Construction Trades Council on behalf of more than 10,000 current and former plant workers. That suit asks the court to order the defendants to create a fund to finance reasonable medical monitoring and surveillance, including independent scientific studies of adverse health effects. Rockwell officials in El Segundo, Calif., declined to comment, saying they had not seen the court documents. Dow Chemical officials at company headquarters in Midland, Mich., did not reply to calls seeking comment. DeBoskey said the lawsuits ``stem from people's concern and their fear over whether or not they have lost money and whether or not their health has been affected by the operations at the plant.'' ``That fear was heightened by the FBI raid last summer,'' DeBoskey said in a telephone interview. ``People are afraid. They're afraid and they want to know the truth from people other than the ones who have caused the pollution.'' DOE last year identified Rocky Flats as the most hazardous site in the nation's nuclear weapons complex, saying toxic chemicals contaminated an underground reservoir and threatened nearby city water supplies. The Ohio lawsuit, filed in U.S. District Court in Cincinnati, accused NLO and parent NL Industries Inc. of failing to properly store or contain highly radioactive substances at the Feed Materials Production Center in Fernald. The plant, 18 miles northwest of Cincinnati, processes uranium for the Energy Department's production of nuclear weapons. The lawsuit says the employees suffered loss of income, emotional distress including increased fear of cancer, and diminished ability to obtain other jobs or insurance. It seeks $2 billion in damages plus unspecified punitive damages and payment for extended medical monitoring of the employees.

DOC.HEAD: Ivy League Eating Clubs Urged to Admit Women
DOC.TEXT: A Princeton University graduate has asked the state Supreme Court to require two campus eating clubs to admit women. Sally Frank, now an instructor on discrimination cases at New York Law School, on Tuesday urged the high court to end what she called 21 years of discrimination at the Ivy Club and the Tiger Inn, which do not admit women. Ms. Frank said the clubs and Princeton University have a ``symbiotic relationship'' that removes them from protection under laws governing private organizations. But attorneys for the clubs compared the groups to fraternities and sororities, and said they have the right to choose their own members. ``We have to make the distinction between civil rights and social relationships,'' said Barbara Strapp Nelson, who represented the Ivy Club. ``Whether one should maintain a social relationship with another is not regulated by the state.'' The clubs are among 13 private eating clubs at Princeton. Most of the juniors and seniors at Princeton eat at these clubs, which are in privately-owned houses near the campus. Since Princeton began admitting women in 1969, only the Ivy Club and the Tiger Inn have refused to change their rules and admit females. The high court heard the case after a three judge panel of the Appellate Division of Superior Court last year reversed a 1987 decision by the state Division on Civil Rights. The civil rights agency had ordered the clubs to admit women. Ms. Frank, who began her protest as a junior at Princeton in 1979, said the university has billed the eating club in its publications as ``part of the Princeton experience.'' Deputy Attorney General Susan Reisner, one of several attorneys who represented Ms. Frank's case, said ``the clubs had such a close connection to Princeton, they could not claim exemption (to anti-discrimination laws) as a strictly private club.'' Attorneys for the clubs countered that the clubs are not part of the university. Russell Beatie Jr., representing the Tiger Inn, said the case pits discrimination laws and privacy laws. He accused Ms. Frank of ``seeking admission for purposes other than a true desire to be a member of the Tiger Inn,'' calling her ``energy looking for a cause.'' Attorneys for the clubs asked the court to give them another hearing to dispute facts presented by Ms. Frank's attorneys. Ms. Frank estimated after the hearing that if the court returns the matter to a lower level, it could take six more years to settle. However, she vowed to continue her fight. ``There is a continuing and ongoing interest by (female) students to join these clubs,'' Ms. Frank said.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Begins In Color Discrimination Case
DOC.TEXT: A light-skinned black woman who contends she was fired as an IRS clerk-typist because of her color said her darker-skinned boss told her that her life was too easy, an attorney said. In opening arguments Tuesday in U.S. District Court, Michael Weinstock, attorney for Tracy Lynn Morrow, said she was fired from her IRS job after she ``was harassed based on her personal physical characteristics.'' Ms. Morrow testified her IRS supervisor, Ruby Lewis, told her, ``The way you look is your problem.'' But Assistant U.S. Attorney S. Lark Ingram, representing Ms. Lewis, said Ms. Morrow's problem wasn't her skin: it was her typing, her grammar, and her attitude. Ms. Morrow is suing Ms. Lewis and the Internal Revenue Service, seeking up to $60,000 in back pay and other payments, plus reinstatement to her $14,000-a-year job with the IRS' Atlanta office, where she worked from early 1985 until she was fired in March 1986. If Ms. Morrow wins her lawsuit, she would become the first black worker to collect damages from a black supervisor because of skin-tone discrimination, according to her attorneys and federal equal-opportunity officials. Weinstock said that ``the tone of her skin'' is the central issue in how Ms. Morrow was treated at the IRS. Weinstock said Ms. Lewis made demeaning references to Ms. Morrow's status as a lighter-skinned black, such as, ``you need some sun,'' and ``you've had it too easy.'' Ms. Morrow testified that Ms. Lewis was concerned about race, telling the workers, ``We're a black office, we had to watch how white people might look at us.'' Midge L. Wilson, a professor at DePaul University who has studied intraracial bias among blacks, said both light- and dark-skinned blacks sometimes exhibit signs of discrimination against the other. ``They might create a payback situation to make life uncomfortable,'' she said. But Ms. Ingram argued that ``Ruby Lewis did not perceive the plaintiff as having different skin color from she.'' She said the issue was Ms. Morrow's job performance. From the time Ms. Morrow arrived, ``she couldn't type,'' Ms. Ingram said. ``She couldn't write simple sentences.'' Ms. Lewis and other IRS supervisors tried to work around Ms. Morrow's problems, including attempts to find her another position, Ms. Ingram said. She said it was another IRS supervisor _ not Ms. Lewis _ who decided to fire Ms. Morrow. The non-jury trial is expected to last all week.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Chills Plains; Storm Moves into Rockies
DOC.TEXT: Bitter cold shouldered its way from the Yukon today on a slow southeastern drive into the northern Plains and toward the Great Lakes. More snow was forecast today for the central Rockies' western slopes and the mountains of Arizona, and the storm was expected to join with the cold front _ the nation's largest mass of frigid air since Christmas _ to spawn blizzard conditions from Montana to Minnesota. Rain diminished along the northern and central Pacific Coast today, although more heavy rain and high winds were expected tonight. Snow advisories remained in effect for Oregon's mountains. On Tuesday, over 2 feet of snow fell in parts of New England, and arctic cold dropped the temperature in International Falls, Minn., by 46 degrees in less than 24 hours, from 35 degrees Monday to 11 below zero Tuesday morning. Strong winds Tuesday produced a wind-chill reading of 63 degrees below zero at Cutbank, Mont. In Dexter, Maine, a snow-covered department store roof collapsed late Tuesday afternoon, slightly injuring three people. The collapse followed the biggest winter storm of the season, which dumped about 14 inches of snow in the Dexter area. Today's forecast called for showers and a few thunderstorms from northwestern Florida into South Carolina. Some showers and thunderstorms were also expected over southern Florida. Tuesday's low temperature was minus 19 at Thief River Falls, Minn. Two Florida cities tied record warm temperatures for the date: Fort Lauderdale hit 83 degrees and Fort Myers reached 86, the nation's high.
