Marie 8 fair; San Antonio 44 fair. _WEST: Albuquerque 38 cloudy; Anchorage 1 windy; Boise 32 cloudy; Casper 32 fair; Fairbanks 36 fair; Great Falls 14 snow; Honolulu 73 fair; Las Vegas 53 windy; Los Angeles 52 fair; Medford 38 cloudy; Pendleton 40 windy; Phoenix 57 cloudy; Portland, Ore., 39 cldy; Reno 30 cldy; Salt Lake City 31 snow; San Diego 53 showrs; San Francisco 47 fair; Seattle 34 snow; Spokane 33 snow. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 21 partly cloudy; Montreal 27 partly cloudy; Ottawa 27 cloudy; Regina 17 fair; Toronto 30 partly cloudy; Winnipeg 14 snow; San Juan 71.

Frederick W. Winterbotham, who played a key role in exploiting broken German codes in World War II and wrote the bestselling memoir ``The Ultra Secret,'' died Sunday of natural causes at age 92. Winterbotham was a pilot in World War I, and in 1929 was made head of aerial intelligence in MI6, the British intelligence agency. In the 1930s he befriended senior Nazi figures in Germany and gleaned information about the Luftwaffe. In 1939 he helped devise a vital new method of aerial reconnaissance photography. His most important work was with ``Enigma,'' the top-secret German code system that the British had managed to penetrate. His work made him a confidant of wartime Prime Minister Winston Churchill. But he remained an unsung war hero, because the cracking of Enigma was considered so secret it was not revealed until 30 years after the war, when he published ``The Ultra Secret.''

Chesley Peterson, a highly decorated flying ace and the U.S. Air Force's youngest colonel, died Sunday in Riverside, Calif. He was 69. The retired Air Force major general had suffered from heart and lung disease. In 1940, Peterson went to England to join the Royal Air Force's Eagle Squadron, a group of foreign volunteers. Flying Hawker Hurricanes and Supermarine Spitfires in battles with the German Luftwaffe, Peterson advanced to squadron commander at age 21 and colonel at 23. He kept the rank when he moved to the U.S. Army Air Corps to fly P-47 Thunderbolts in 1943. He remains the Air Force's youngest-ever colonel. In more than 200 combat missions, Peterson claimed nine kills and nine more probable kills, twice parachuting from damaged Spitfires. He is the only American fighter pilot to win the U.S. Distinguished Service Cross and Britain's Distinguished Service Order, according to Airman magazine.

Max Gordon, former city editor of The Daily Worker who quit the U.S. Communist Party over its position on Josef Stalin, died Jan. 18 of congestive heart failure. He was 79. Gordon was working at The Daily Worker in 1958 when he quit the paper and broke with the Communists after then-Soviet leader Nikita Khruschev admitted that Stalin had committed numerous atrocities during his reign. Gordon's son, David, said his father felt Stalin had betrayed the revolution and that the American party's denial was dishonest and immoral. After quitting the newspaper, he worked as a medical writer.

Hal Draper, a socialist scholar who published a four-volume study of the political theories of Marx and Engels and founded the Center for Socialist History, died Friday at the age of 75. Draper's political involvement began in the 1930s when he became a leading organizer for the Young Peoples' Socialist League of a national strike against war. As editor of the radical periodical Labor Action, Draper and other socialists reported on revolts in Russia, Eastern Europe and China. His Trotskyist opposition to American and Soviet militarism drew some criticism from the left.

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. (AP) _ Irma Brandeis, a leading scholar on the works of the 14th-century Italian poet Dante, died Monday at her home on the Bard College campus. She was 84. Although the cause of her death was not released, she had been hospitalized recently with a blood disorder. Ms. Brandeis, who taught at Bard between 1944 and 1979, wrote ``The Ladder of Vision: A Study of Dante's Comedy'' and several shorter essays on Dante. She also edited a collection of ``discussions'' about Dante by other critics and translated several poems by 1975 Nobel Prize-winning poet Eugenio Montale, whom she first met in Italy in the 1930s. She was a second cousin of Louis Brandeis, the late U.S. Supreme Court justice.

Mirza Abdul Baqi Beg, a physicist whose theoretical work helped establish the quark model, died Tuesday of a heart attack at age 55. In the 1960s, Beg's work helped verify the modern quark model of hadron structure, which describes hadrons _ nuclear particles like protons and neutrons _ as being composites made up of smaller entities called quarks. The Rockefeller University appointed him professor in 1968. He had been a consultant at Brookhaven since 1965 and was a member of its High Energy Advisory Committee from 1975-78. Beg was also a fellow of the American Physical Society and the New York Academy of Sciences, and a trustee of the Aspen Center for Physics.

Jack L. Walker Jr., the chairman of the University of Michigan's political science department, was killed Tuesday, on his 55th birthday, in an auto accident. Walker, a fellow at Stanford University's Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences, had been a faculty member at Michigan since 1964. An internationally known expert on interest groups and their role in policymaking, he was on leave for a year to research a book on the topic.

Julia Davis Stuart, president of the League of Women Voters of the United States from 1964-68, died at home Saturday at age 79. She was known for her work for the conservation of water resources. In 1969, she was honored on the 50th anniversary of the league by President Nixon at a White House ceremony. Mrs. Stuart also served on President Johnson's 19-member Commission of Law Enforcement and Administration of Justice and on the National Citizens Commission on International Cooperation.

Gerald N. Lanier, an entomologist whose expertise on battling bark beetles was sought in countries where the insect threatens forests, died Sunday of pancreatic cancer at age 52. An expert in the management of the growth and care of American elms, Lanier offered advice on mass-trapping of bark beetles in several countries, including Norway and Sweden, where the insects threaten spruce forests. He was professor of entomology at the State University of New York College of Environmental Science and Forestry in Syracuse.

Tony Ippolito, a former high school wrestler and coach who struggled with an insurance company over an experimental transplant, died Sunday at age 33 after a 2-year bout with bone cancer. His plight was publicized in the fall of 1988 after Humana Health Care refused to pay for a bone-marrow transplant recommended by his doctors but considered experimental. The company later donated $135,000 for the procedure, which was performed at a Seattle cancer research center. Family and friends contributed $90,000 more.

Kenneth Corcoran, who coached the first eight football teams at Boys Town from 1935-42, died Jan. 15 in Kansas City, Mo. He was 80. The cause of his death was not disclosed. Corcoran served as executive director of the United Service Organizations until he retired in 1974.

DOC.HEAD: McDonald's Opens in Moscow
DOC.TEXT: With the familiar sign of the Golden Arches embellished by the Soviet hammer-and-sickle flag, McDonald's opened in Moscow today to offer Russians their first taste of Western consumerism, not to mention hamburgers. Hundreds of people tried gingerly to get their fingers around their first American hamburger. They tried eating them one-handed. They picked them apart to examine the contents. One young woman finally squashed her Big Mac in order to fit her lips around it. ``It tasted great!'' said a 14-year-old boy, a sesame seed still stuck to his nose. The restaurant ``is a lot different from a stolovaya,'' he continued, referring to the run-down, dirty cafeterias that slop out dishes like rice and fat or boiled sausage in the Soviet Union's closest approximation to fast food. The restaurant was 14 years in the making, but finally, thanks to the reforms of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, people got a first-hand look at such alien concepts as efficiency and fast, friendly service. Unlike nearly all other Western firms opening up in Moscow, McDonald's is selling for rubles, which are worthless outside the Soviet Union and won't even buy much in the shortage-plagued country. It expects to serve 15,000 people a day. Hundreds of people lined up for the long-awaited grand opening, reaching eagerly for McDonald's flags and pins handed out by the hamburger chain's brigade of workers. An hour before opening, the McDonald's crew handed out advertising leaflets at the Pushkin Square metro stop a few yards away. Normally dour-faced citizens broke into grins, catching the infectious cheerful mood from youthful Soviet staffers hired for their ability to smile and work hard. Accordions played folk songs and women in traditional costumes danced with cartoon characters. The line of about 500 people moved steadily, thanks to McDonald's decision to build and staff 27 cash registers. ``I only waited an hour and I think they served thousands before me,'' said a happy middle-aged woman from the aluminum plant on Dmitrovskoye Highway. ``And it was only 10 rubles for all this,'' she said, pointing to a bag packed with unfamiliar treats like cheeseburgers and ``Filay-o-feesh'' sandwiches. ``I'm taking it back for the girls at the factory to try.'' ``Beeg Maks'' were priced at 3.75 rubles, and double cheeseburgers at 3 rubles _ about two hours' pay for a starting McDonald's staffer or the average Soviet worker. That's a bit high compared to state restaurants but much cheaper than the private cooperative outlets that have sprung up in the past year. Three Armenian students said they flew 1,250 miles from Yerevan to Moscow just for the McDonald's opening. ``It was magnificent,'' said Ida Zakharyan, gushing over the clean, brightly colored interior and the 10-minute service she experienced. ``Well, my wife makes better food,'' said Victor Kunyasev of Moscow. ``But it was nice, a good place to take a break and grab a bite to eat.'' The restaurant, which is a joint venture of McDonald's of Canada and the city of Moscow, limited purchases to 10 Big Macs per customer to prevent a local entrepreneur from setting up an unauthorized subsidiary around the corner. McDonald's built its own factory, including a bakery, a dairy, a meat-processing plant and even a potato storage yard, to provide its own guaranteed supplies in a country where as much as 25 percent of the harvest rots on the way to the consumer. One McDonald's associate in the crowd said the firm wound up importing wooden crates from Finland for storing potatoes because ``when they went to build crates, they found there was no wood, and no nails. They found you need a permit to buy nails.'' The enormous investment of $50 million was likely balanced, however, by the free publicity the firm is receiving from an army of correspondents, who nearly outnumbered the customers at the opening hour.

DOC.SECOND: Runoff Election Necessary to Fill Slain Councilman's Seat
DOC.TEXT: A teacher and a dentist will face each other in a runoff election for the City Council seat of a civil rights attorney slain by a mail bomb. A Feb. 20 runoff election was necessary because no candidate received a majority of the 2,572 votes cast in Tuesday's election. Robert Robinson, an NAACP attorney, had two years left on his council term when he was slain by a mail bomb Dec. 18. Clifford Hardwick III finished first with 920 votes. He will face Dr. Phyllis Mack, who finished second among the eight candidates with 494 votes. Meanwhile Tuesday, a man under investigation in the mail bomb slayings last month of Robinson and a federal judge in Alabama gave samples of his blood, saliva and hair to the FBI. Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, a 46-year-old junk dealer in Enterprise in southeast Alabama, was taken by police to a hospital, where he spent 45 minutes providing samples requested in a federal grand jury subpoena issued last week. He was then questioned at City Hall for more than two hours. O'Ferrell has been questioned extensively in the FBI's investigation of the slayings of 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance of Birmingham and Robinson. Similar package bombs were discovered and defused at the 11th Circuit courthouse in Atlanta and the Jacksonville, Fla., chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Agents have confiscated typewriters from O'Ferrell. Federal sources speaking on condition of anonymity have said the printing on letters associated with the bombs matched that on a 1988 letter O'Ferrell wrote to the 11th Circuit concerning a case he lost before the court. Agents last week searched O'Ferrell's home and business and pumped out his septic tanks looking for evidence. The FBI has refused to say whether it found any clues, but dozens of agents remain in southeast Alabama. In another development, a pipe bomb mailed to a church in Houston exploded Tuesday morning, injuring Lisa Osteen, the 30-year-old daughter of the pastor, the Rev. John Osteen. Charles B. Kearney, an FBI spokesman in Houston, said there did not appear to be any similarities between the Texas bomb and the December mail bombs. However, O'Ferrell and his attorney, Paul Harden, said the Houston bombing should demonstrate that O'Ferrell, who has been under close scrutiny in Enterprise, had nothing to do with any of the attacks. ``It's a sad state of affairs, but it does in my mind show Wayne O'Ferrell, who has been in Enterprise since day one, is in no way, shape or form involved,'' Harden said. In Savannah, about 29 percent of the District 5 voters cast ballots, only slightly above the average for a special election, officials said. Councilman Willie Brown said he was disappointed by the turnout. ``I think it's a sad commentary that on the heels of what everybody has been praising Robbie (Robinson) for, that no one came out to show their respect and vote for the most worthy replacement,'' Brown said. Funeral home operator Horace Hall, who had been endorsed by Robinson's widow, Anne, finished fourth with 201 votes.

DOC.HEAD: Passenger Passes Cocaine; First Lawsuit Filed

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Crash-Helpers, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A jetliner crash survivor was charged at a hospital with drug possession after passing about 5 ounces of cocaine through his digestive tract, and what's believed to be the first crash lawsuit has been filed. Antonio Zuluaga, who was critically injured, was the second passenger from Avianca Flight 52 alleged to have been carrying condoms containing cocaine inside his body, police said. The Boeing 707, en route from Bogota and the Colombian drug capital of Medellin, smacked into a hillside Thursday night 15 miles northeast of Kennedy International Airport. The crash killed 73 people and left 86 survivors. Zuluaga was being treated at Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, for a fractured spine, broken ribs, a dislocated hip and possibly a broken knee. Each of the 19 condoms he passed had about 8 grams of the drug, police Sgt. Richard Snizek said Tuesday. Another man, Jose Figueroa, was found to have cocaine-filled condoms in his intestines when doctors operated on him the day after the crash to stop internal bleeding, authorities said. Figueroa's body may contain as many as 70 more cocaine packets of varying size and police were waiting to determine the amount before charging him, said Donald Kane, deputy chief of detectives. The U.S. District Court lawsuit, filed Tuesday by a New Jersey man who said he was disabled in the crash, seeks $202.5 million from the airline. It says Avianca was negligent because it failed to furnish a safe aircraft and a competent crew. The plaintiff, Jesus Manuel Pinzon, 31, of Elizabeth, N.J., suffered multiple broken bones, cuts and internal injuries. He was returning from a visit to relatives in Bogota. His lawyer, Robert A. Solomon, said Pinzon was permanently disabled and unable to return to his $400-a-week job at a New Jersey clothing factory. He is being treated at Elizabeth General Hospital. Pinzon's 2-year-old son, Brian, who was sitting in the seat next to his father, suffered minor head injuries and was not hospitalized. A telephone call to Avianca's offices for comment was not answered. A final report of the crash is unlikely for at least nine months. Reports so far have centered on who was responsible for the decision not to land when fuel was running low. As the plane circled around New Jersey, about 45 minutes before the crash, captain Laureano Caviedes Hoyos asked for ``priority'' to land rather than declaring an ``emergency,'' investigators said. The lead investigator, Barry Trotter of the National Transportation Safety Board, said the controllers responded to Caviedes' request by moving the flight from a holding pattern to an approach pattern, although the plane was not moved to the first slot among approaching planes. ``The pilot apparently thought when he came out of the holding pattern that he had enough fuel and that's why he appears (in taped conversations) to be calm and cool,'' Trotter said Tuesday. ``But what we don't think he was aware of is that he was going to be vectored all around Long Island for 37 minutes before being cleared for landing at Kennedy.'' Trotter said Avianca does not require its pilots to declare a fuel emergency when levels drop below a certain point, and other airline officials said it is typically up to the captain to make such a declaration. An American Airlines jet was brought in shortly before the crash when its pilot told controllers it had just 14 minutes of fuel remaining. Bad weather delayed landings at Kennedy for many flights the night of the crash. Caviedes had 17 years experience flying into Kennedy, including three trips the month before the crash, Trotter said.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Opposition Rejects Communist Offer to Share Power
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria's opposition today rejected a Communist offer to share power before the first free elections in more than four decades. Petar Beron, spokesman for the loose opposition umbrella group, the Union of Democratic Forces, spoke on Sofia radio, the state news agency BTA said. Opposition leaders have rejected previous Communist offers to enter what Communist Party chief Petar Mladenov called a ``government of national concord'' before the elections. They had called the offers a Communist ploy to get the opposition to share responsibility for four decades of mismanagement. The opposition has been holding talks with the Communists on power-sharing. Mladenov reiterated the Communist offer to share power in an opening speech Tuesday to a party congress, where he is trying to avoid a formal split between reformers and hard-liners. The congress was moved up from 1991 after Bulgaria was caught up in the pro-democracy movement sweeping Eastern Europe. Bulgaria's hard-line Communist leader, Todor Zhivkov, was outsed Nov. 10 after 35 years in power. Mladenov gave no details of how much power the Communists would have in his proposed power-sharing Cabinet. Governments dominated by non-Communists are running East Germany and Czechoslovakia prior to their free elections in March and June, respectively. Mladenov also said Tuesday that Bulgaria's first free elections should be held in May, not in November as the opposition had demanded. It was one of the few points of the party chief's speech that was applauded by the 2,752 congress delegates. According to BTA, Beron told Radio Sofia today that his group has decided to consent to May elections because it believes the present Communist-dominated Parliament simply cannot enact any substantial reforms. Reformers made a strong showing today as the Communist party congress entered its second day. Reform-minded journalist Stefan Prodev, chief editor of the weekly Narodna Cultura who was chosen two days ago to head the official Journalists' Union, said Communists could win public support only by shedding ``dogmas of a harmful ideology'' that he charged still dominated the views of most party members. Politburo member Alexander Lilov, one of the triumvirate running the country with Mladenov and fellow Politburo reformer Andrei Lukanov, said: ``While the party and country are in a crisis, we have not yet reached the climax. Our party cannot start an offensive now because of a lack of confidence.'' He said the party must be radically overhauled to win elections. Unlike their comrades elsewhere in Eastern Europe, Bulgaria's Communists face a relatively weak opposition and have not relinquished much power since Zhivkov was ousted. Leaders such as Lukanov consistently have expressed confidence the Communists can still win a substantial share of the vote, or even a majority, at the May elections. The opposition disputes that. Lilov, a possible contender for the party leadership if Mladenov gives up the post, said the party has been hurt by failing to implement reforms. ``We are lagging behind. If the programs are not competent and realistic, we will lose,'' he told the congress. He accused Premier Georgi Atanassov, a holdover from the Zhivkov era, of failing to work out an economic program. Atanassov retained his post after Zhivkov's ouster, apparently because he backed Mladenov and other Politburo colleagues who engineered the removal of Zhivkov after 35 years in power. But he has done nothing to tackle what Mladenov conceded Tuesday was mounting economic chaos. Bulgaria has been hit in the past two weeks by unprecedented labor stoppages. Teachers went on strike as the congress opened. Miners who walked off the job across the country last week resumed work, but they continued negotiations with the government for better conditions.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun's Troops Attack Forces Of Rival Christian Militia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with cease-fire called but ignored, quotes from Aoun and Geagea, police account of fighting at think tank. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Troops of renegade Gen. Michel Aoun attacked major strongholds of the rival Lebanese Forces militia today in an attempt to take control of the Christian enclave. Police reported heavy fighting with tanks, recoilless cannons, mortars and machine guns in four Christian suburbs north of Beirut. A police spokesman said some of Aoun's 20,000 troops surrounded Lebanese Forces' barracks, shouting orders through bullhorns for the Christian militiamen to surrender. It was the worst fighting between Christian forces in a year. Aoun's command and the office of Samir Geagea, the Lebanese Forces' commander, released separate statements saying a cease-fire was called for 2 p.m., but police said fighting persisted after the deadline. The intensity of the battles decreased, ``but they are still fighting,'' a police spokesman said in the afternoon. He said no casualty report was available. Earlier, Aoun's troops stormed the House of the Future think tank, operated Lebanese Forces intellectuals in the northern suburb of Dbaiyeh, and police said they were moving into a nearby militia barracks. The command of the 6,000-strong Lebanese Forces conceded the think tank had fallen to Aoun's troops. A police spokesman said the House of the Future compound ``fell to Aoun's forces in about 30 minutes. The militia force guarding it did not number more than 20 men.'' Those who escaped the fighting withdrew to the nearby barracks, he said. The Christian Voice of Lebanon radio, in a brief report, said automatic fire was also reported in the suburb of Aukar, where the U.S. Embassy is located. It gave no details. U.S. Ambassador John McCarthy and all American diplomats evacuated from the embassy Sept. 6 after pro-Aoun demonstrators demanding support for the rebellious general surrounded it. Telephone calls to the U.S. Embassy as well as to several other areas of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave were not answered. The police official, who cannot be named under regulations, said Aoun's troops surrounded Lebanese Forces barracks in Adonis and Naccache and demanded the fighters defending them give up. Tension had been rising between Aoun and Geagea since Parliament elected Elias Hrawi president Nov. 24 under an Arab League-brokered peace plan to end Lebanon's 14-year-old civil war. Geagea recognizes Hrawi, but Aoun does not, claiming he is a lackey of the Syrians, who control most of Lebanon and back Moslem militias. Aoun has pledged to keep fighting until Syria withdraws its 40,000 soldiers from Lebanon. Geagea, in an interview broadcast by the Christian Voice of Lebanon radio, said: ``We will not permit anyone to slaughter the Lebanese Forces.'' The radio, mouthpiece of the right-wing Phalange party, interrupted its programs to broadcast the interview with Geagea. The Phalange, the main Christian political group, is also at odds with Aoun. Addressing Aoun, Geagea said: ``I call on those in charge of the army to alter the policy they've been following ... we have the patience of Job, but this cannot go on forever,'' ``I've ordered all the Lebanese Forces fighters to stay in their barracks and defend them,'' Geagea said. Aoun, in a brief statement broadcast by his Radio Lebanon, spoke only of ``scattered disorders that the troops have been ordered to put an end to.'' The police official said all police patrols in Christian east Beirut were ordered back to headquarters and their stations to avoid being caught in cross-fire in case the clashes spread. The statement reflected the police concern the clashes might engulf other traditional Lebanese Forces' strongholds in east Beirut. The clashes broke out despite intensified efforts to head off a showdown between Aoun's troops and Geagea's militia for control of the Christian enclave. Aoun's troops established control Tuesday over four barracks that Geagea's militia maintained on Beirut's eastern and northern edges and later moved into a compound that commands the main coastal highway north of Beirut. Aoun said Tuesday his fighters were ordered to take over all Lebanese Forces barracks in the Christian enclave. Aoun first moved against the Lebanese forces in February 1989, when his forces flushed out the militia from the Metn mountainous regions northeast of the capital in a four-day crackdown that killed 82 people and wounded 200.

DOC.HEAD: Lawyer Says Ruling Against Hubbard Book Violates First Amendment
DOC.TEXT: A judge's decision blocking a book critical of Church of Scientology founder L. Ron Hubbard is a ``dagger in the heart of the First Amendment,'' the publisher's lawyer says. ``It really threatens to impair the right of biographers and scholars to study the works of other people who are of great public interest,'' Melvin Wulf said Tuesday after the ruling by U.S. District Judge Louis L. Stanton. Stanton said parts of the book, which is still in manuscript form, violated the copyrights of Hubbard's authorized biographer. The judge said ``A Piece of Blue Sky'' could be published after infringing passages were deleted, something he said could easily be done because much of the material was set off at the beginning of chapters. Wulf, an attorney for the publisher, Carol Publishing Group, said the judge showed a ``total misunderstanding'' of the fair use law, which says copyrighted works can be used for criticism, news reporting, teaching or research. The ruling stemmed from a lawsuit by New Era Publications International, which holds copyrights to Hubbard's private papers for the writing of his authorized biography. The company also is the publisher of Scientology books. New Era lawyer Jonathan Rubell said his client had never intended to stop the book's publication. ``It was the use of expression rather than factual presentation that we were complaining about,'' he said. Hubbard, who died in 1986, wrote dozens of books about Scientology and his philosophy. He taught that spiritual competence is achieved by ``erasing'' mental images in the unconscious mind that cause irrational behavior. ``A Piece of Blue Sky'' was written by Jonathan Caven-Atack, who became disillusioned with Hubbard's teachings after following them for nine years. According to Stanton's decision, Atack ``came to believe that Scientology is a dangerous cult and that Mr. Hubbard, far from being the gentle prophet portrayed in Church literature, was a paranoid, vindictive and profoundly disturbed man.'' After receiving permission from Stanton to review the manuscript, New Era said 121 passages, less than 3 percent of the book, were from copyrighted sources.

DOC.HEAD: Department Store Roof Caves in Under Weight of Snow
LaserPhoto BAN1
DOC.TEXT: The roof of a century-old department store caved in under the weight of the heaviest snowfall of the season, slightly injuring three people, officials said today. Two employees and a fireman who were inside when the roof gave way Tuesday were treated at a hospital and released. Firefighters had been called in shortly before accident for fear water leaking from the roof would short-circuit the lights. Jackie Knowles, a store employee who escaped, said ``something went off like a bomb'' seconds before the collapse. Part of the third floor crashed into the second floor. ``It sounded like a roll of thunder,'' said Jerry Townsend, who saw the accident from across the street. Sheriff's Sgt. Avis Merrill said the collapse was caused by a combination of ice and the 14 inches of snow dumped overnight Monday and Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Pierce Announces for Massachusetts Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: Massachusetts House Minority Leader Steven Pierce has launched his campaign for the Republican nomination for governor, declaring the state under the Democrats is ``full of problems, doubts and cynicism.'' ``Ronald Reagan put it best when he sought successfully the presidency during a time when our nation was in dire straits,'' Pierce said Tuesday. Quoting Reagan, Pierce said: ``The major issue of this campaign is the direct political, personal and moral responsibility of the Democratic Party leadership ... for the unprecedented calamity that has befallen us.'' Democratic Gov. Michael Dukakis, a frequent target of Pierce's criticism, is not seeking re-election. The Massachusetts Miracle, the economic boom that nearly carried Dukakis to the White House, has vanished in the past year, and the state is struggling with a deficit. Pierce, who represents Westfield, has been a state representative since 1978 and first elected to the House Republican leadership in 1983. Pierce and former U.S. Attorney William Weld are the leading candidates for the GOP nomination. Others include former Congressman Paul Cronin, former Metropolitan District Commissioner Guy Carbone and Len Umina, an electrical engineer. Democrats running include Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy, former Attorney General Francis Bellotti, Boston University President John Silber and state Rep. John Flood.

DOC.HEAD: West Germans Praise Gorbachev's Comments on Reunification
DOC.TEXT: West German officials and media today praised Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for softening his view on German reunification and said it could give hope to disheartened East Germans. Disgraced former Communist Party leader Erich Honecker was released from prison Tuesday night after justice officials determined he was too frail to withstand the rigors of imprisonment while awaiting trial on treason charges. Gorbachev said Tuesday in Moscow that he believed one Germany was likely in the future, but he added that Germans ``should not decide this important question on the streets.'' He referred to the growing number of demonstrations in East Germany in support of reunification. Gorbachev's statement was his most tolerant yet on the subject of a single Germany, which has been opposed by Communists for more than 40 years. East German Communists on Tuesday endorsed for reunification for the first time. In West Germany, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher told West German Radio that Gorbachev had ``correctly analyzed'' the situation and again shown his political skill. West German officials and media praised Gorbachev's view as ``realistic'' and described it as an important sign of hope for East Germans who have lost faith in their government. Communist leaders launched their uphill campaign for March 18 parliamentary elections with a news conference to unveil their ``European concept'' that aims for a united and demilitarized Europe. Party ideologist Peter Brie said the Communists support ``the togetherness of the German nation,'' and urged a thoughtful and measured approach to reunification. In an interview with the West German Bild newspaper, party leader Gregor Gysi complained that the reunification drive is moving too quickly. Asked if the Communists oppose reunification, Gysi told the newspaper: ``No, not at all. This process cannot be stopped any more. But it is irresponsible to do things in such a way now as if it were possible tomorrow.'' The reunification issue promises to dominate the election campaign that will seat a new leadership in less than seven weeks. Increasing numbers of East Germans have demonstrated for union with wealthy and prosperous West Germany as their own economy tumbles and an exodus of skilled workers continues unchecked. More than 340,000 people fled East Germany last year, having lost hope that their spartan living conditions would improve. The devastating flight has included as many as 2,500 people daily since Jan. 1. The Communists are widely distrusted because of corruption scandals that have surfaced since the peaceful pro-democracy revolt last fall, and because they carry the blame for leading East Germany into its current economic and political crises. The man most blamed for the country's problems, Honecker, was set free after an East Berlin court rejected a request that he be kept in prison until his trial in March. He was jailed Monday. The court decided that ``despite the severity of the charges against Honecker, the state of the accused's health does not permit imprisonment,'' the official ADN news agency reported. A spokesman for Chief Prosecutor Hans-Juergen Joseph promised that the investigation against Honecker would proceed. ADN said the court acted on advice from two doctors who examined Honecker independently. Honecker, 77, underwent surgery on Jan. 8 to remove a malignant kidney tumor. Honecker was ousted from the leadership on Oct. 18, after massive pro-democracy demonstrations. He was expelled from the Communist Party in December and has since been accused of treason and abusing his power.

DOC.HEAD: Cleanup Crews Wrap Up Fuel Removal From Damaged TMI Reactor
DOC.TEXT: With a final sweep of an underwater vacuum, workers at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant have wrapped up the four-year effort to remove fuel from the damaged reactor. A color monitor inspection of the Unit 2 reactor, followed by the vacuuming on Tuesday, marked the end of the project, said Mary Wells, spokeswoman for GPU Nuclear Corp., which operates the plant. Since 1985, more than 99 percent of the 100 tons of uranium fuel were pulled from the reactor and shipped to a federal laboratory in Idaho for study and disposal. GPU Nuclear said fuel removal was the heart of the $1 billion cleanup. Unit 2 was damaged in March 1979 in the worst accident ever at a U.S. commercial nuclear plant. The nuclear core lost cooling water, overheated and partially melted. The remaining fuel poses no hazard at the plant, which is scheduled to go into long-term storage beginning next year, Ms. Wells said. ``It simply could not be reached,'' she said. ``We've gone to extraordinary efforts to get the fuel out.'' The cleanup required development of new tools so workers on a shielded platform above the reactor could pick up radioactive debris through 40 feet of water. Decontamination work on other plant systems will continue for the rest of the year. GPU Nuclear is working on a system to boil away 2.3 million gallons of slightly contaminated water left from the accident and cleanup. Kay Pickering, a spokeswoman for the anti-nuclear group Three Mile Island Alert, said people shouldn't think the cleanup is finished. ``We're concerned about what happens now,'' she said. ``Our concern is that it remains a highly radioactive site.'' GPU Nuclear has asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to authorize a license change permitting the long-term storage plan. The containment building around the reactor would be sealed and monitored for several decades to allow radiation levels to drop.

DOC.HEAD: China Orders Tighter Control of Unions, Mass Groups
DOC.TEXT: China's ruling Communist Party issued stern orders today for tighter control of unions and other mass organizations and said they cannot be used as opposition bases. A party circular said officials should strengthen leadership over the unions, the Communist Youth League and women's federations ``so that these organizations keep to the correct political orientation and identify themselves with the party Central Committee in politics, thinking and action.'' ``On no account is any organization allowed to raise political advocacy against the party,'' it said. ``By no means will any political organization opposing the four cardinal principles or undermining state power be allowed to exist. It must be banned according to law as soon as it is discovered.'' The four cardinal principles of the party, set forth by senior leader Deng Xiaoping in 1979, are socialism, the leadership of the Communist Party, the people's democratic dictatorship and Marxism-Leninism-Mao Tse-tung thought. The principles are stressed most in times when political conservatives dominate policy, as they have since the June crackdown on student-led, pro-democracy protesters. The circular was approved by the party Central Committee on Dec. 21, but issued publicly only today, the official Xinhua News Agency said without giving any reason for the delay. It said the aim was to ``guard against and prevent any tendency to cast off or weaken the leadership of the party.'' All unions and mass organizations in China are set up and supervised by the state, and the government has made it clear in the past it will not tolerate unofficial worker federations such as Poland's Solidarity, which became the spearhead for revolt against Communist rule. Some officials of the national trade union federation openly supported last spring's democracy movement, but the party moved quickly to discipline them and assert its control. An independent union formed by a group of Beijing workers during the protests was declared illegal and its leaders were arrested. The Communist Youth League, a kind of junior division for young, would-be party members, donated tents to the student protesters camping in Tiananmen Square, and the All-China Women's Federation joined dozens of groups in urging authorities to hold a dialogue with students who began a hunger strike. The party circular said unions, the Youth League and women's groups must ``participate in handling social contradictions, especially unexpected public events,'' meaning they must help the party educate their members in the official position on any event. They also must ``guide workers, young people and women to subordinate their personal interests to the interest of the state.'' Finally, they should serve as ``democratic channels for the public to take part in and discuss state affairs in an organized and disciplined way under leadership,'' the circular said. Deng has said repeatedly he is opposed to Western-style democracy with uncontrolled public debate on issues.

DOC.HEAD: TV's Mob Boss Visits Reputed Real Thing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to fix typo in `Sharkey.'
DOC.TEXT: Ray Sharkey, who played a mobster on TV's ``Wiseguy,'' hugged and kissed reputed crime boss John Gotti at Gotti's assault trial. Sharkey visited the courtroom Tuesday and the pair later lunched at Giambone's, an Italian restaurant, the New York Post reported today. Sharkey, who said he has known Gotti since they were children in Brooklyn, portrayed the fictional crime kingpin Sonny Steelgrave in the TV series. Sharkey is researching a movie that deals with the Mafia, his publicist told the Post. He wished Gotti, 49, good luck, and Gotti called Sharkey ``a good friend of mine.'' Noting reporters' surprise, Gotti said, smiling, ``What do you think, Bruce Cutler is my only friend?'' Cutler, Gotti's attorney, is defending him on charges he ordered the shooting of a union official who allegedly trashed a mob-owned restaurant built with non-union labor.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Groups Wary of Government's Offer To Share Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with reaction from opposition parties. Pickup 7th, `The concessions ...'; DELETES last 5 grafs to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Major opposition parties today denounced the revolutionary government's plan to continue governing while competing in elections and warned that a new dictatorship could emerge. Opposition groups have angrily criticized the ruling National Salvation Front, which assumed power during the bloody December revolt that toppled Nicolae Ceausescu, for reneging on its promise to run Romania only until the May 20 elections. They had demanded the interim government not field candidates in elections it will oversee and accused it of trying to establish one-party rule. On Tuesday, the interim government said it would share power until the elections and split into two groups _ one to govern and the other to contest elections. The opposition National Liberal Party said the move failed to answer its objections because it would still be running the government and participating in elections. ``This is illegal. We asked the Front to transform itself into a political party,'' party spokesman Nicolae Enescu told The Associated Press. ``If it takes part in elections and represents the interests of the state, it seems like a dictatorship again.'' The other major opposition group, the 260,000-member National Peasant Party, charged that if the Nationl Salvation Front wins, it will establish another Communist dictatorship ``with a human face.'' Critics noted that the Front controls the military, bureaucracy and industry and has restricted opposition access to the mass media. Senior Front member Silviu Brucan offered the coalition government and announced the split in comments to selected reporters, a transcript of which was made avaliable to The Associated Press. The concessions follow growing public dissatisfaction with the Front's ruling tactics and international criticism of it for allowing pro-government demonstrators to besiege the headquarters of two opposition parties on Monday. Opposition leaders claimed they had been the target of government-organized harassment, noting that many of the protesters were workers who arrived in the capital in government-owned trucks and buses. On Tuesday, the U.S. State Department accused the Front of intimidating the opposition and said department human rights director Richard Schifter was in Bucharest ``forcefully stating our concerns.'' ``We are deeply troubled by what appears to be active intimidation of legitimate organizations which are seeking a legitimate, independent role in Romania's new political order,'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said in Washington. Schifter met with opposition leaders Tuesday and was to confer with key government figures today. The demonstrators Monday broke into Liberal Party headquarters and surrounded the offices of the National Peasant Party, forcing its president to flee in an armored personnel carrier provided by authorities. On Sunday, thousands of protesters had converged on government headquarters, demanding the Front share power or resign. Many opposition groups have accused the Front _ which is composed of military officers, intellectuals and disaffected Communists _ of seeking to continue Communist rule. Brucan declared Tuesday: ``We believe it is illegal for the Front to hold political power and take part in elections at the same time. ``That is why we have split into a provisional National Council, to hold legislative power on the one hand, and the National Salvation Front, which is to take part in the elections as a political organization, on the other.'' He said the government would suggest opposition parties ``take part in the provisional National Council in order to guarantee the objectivity of the elections,'' when talks between the government and opposition resume Thursday. In other developments, a military tribunal was told that Ceausescu's defense minister, Vasile Milea, was not killed on Ceausescu's orders as had been believed but killed himself rather than give orders to fire on anti-Ceausescu demonstrators. Milea has become a hero of the Romanian revolution for trying to keep the army from firing on unarmed demonstrators, as ordered by Ceausescu. His death helped turn army units against Ceausescu in the popular uprising that ended the dictator's brutal 24-year rule. At the trial of four close associates of Ceausescu, Col. Corneliu Pircalabescu testified that Milea asked him to tell his wife and children he couldn't order defenseless demonstrators killed. Minutes later, he shot himself in the heart, said Pircalabescu, head of the civilian reserve force. Pircalabescu is not a defendant in the trial. His testimony, some of the most moving in the three-day trial, contradicted an account Monday by defendant Emil Bobu that the dictator ordered the general's assassination for opposing the order to shoot. Bobu was the No. 3 official in the Ceausescu government. The trial, which began Saturday, was adjourned until Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Students Ill After Drinking Antifreeze in School's Water
DOC.TEXT: A middle school was closed today after eight students were treated for drinking water contaminated with antifreeze that had seeped into the drinking fountains. The students, who complained of headaches and stomach cramps Tuesday, were sent home after receiving hospital treatment for ethylene glycol poisoning. Tests failed to detect any of the substance in their bloodstreams, authorities said. Rodger Quist, principal at Overland Trail Middle School, said the substance is used in the building heating system. ``It's supposed to be self-contained,'' he said. ``But for some reason it got pushed into our water supply.'' He said the school would be closed today and possibly longer while engineers try to figure out how the two systems got crossed, correct the problem and flush the system. Becky Green, the school's nurse, said the water coming into the fountains was ``murky blue-green. It was really ugly and smelly.''

DOC.HEAD: This Museum Will Teach That Columbus Didn't `Discover' America
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Subs 6th graf, When completed, to correct that museum was low on space and money sted ran out of money
DOC.TEXT: If white America is shocked by what it sees, the newly authorized National Museum of the American Indian will be doing its job, says Suzan Shown Harjo. ``But I think the white majority culture is tough enough to understand that slavery and subjugation are not a good idea,'' says Ms. Harjo, former executive director of the National Congress of American Indians and a moving force in the museum's establishment. Ms. Harjo, 44, a Cheyenne and Creek who was born in El Reno, Okla., is president of the Morning Star Foundation, an organization advocating respect for the cultural rights of Indians. She was named Monday as one of the 12 Indians required by Congress to be included in the 25-member board of directors of the National Museum of the American Indian. The museum was authorized last year as the last Smithsonian museum to be built on the National Mall. It will be squeezed between the Air and Space Museum and the Capitol. A companion museum also will be built in New York City's Custom House. When completed in 1992, the museum will consolidate the Smithsonian's big Indian collection with 1 million artifacts, 40,000 books and 86,000 photos in New York City's Museum of the American Indian, which was short of space and running low on money. The New York collection is possibly the world's largest. In an interview, Ms. Harjo said the museum will acquaint white Americans with a fresh view of history ``if I have anything to do with it.'' And that view may be shocking in a capital where even the name of the professional football team _ the Washington Redskins _ is as insulting to native Americans as other epithets would be to other groups, she said. If the museum succeeds, even such a simple schoolday lesson as ``Columbus discovered America'' will have to be freshly thought through, Ms. Harjo said. With a laugh, she suggested that ``America discovered Columbus'' or ``Indians had a lax immigration policy,'' would be a more accurate way to describe what happened in 1492. Her point was that the continent called America was here _ and populated by developed civilizations _ long before Columbus' ``discovery'' 500 years ago. ``They came, we welcomed, they killed _ short history for the quincentennial,'' she said. Ms. Harjo's grievance with the way American Indians' history is presented is that it treats them as relics. ``We are not discussed in the present tense, therefore we have no future,'' she said. ``The fact is that history has never been written accurately about native peoples,'' she said. ``It is written by the colonizer and is designed to justify the land grabs and continued colonization, the subjugation of a people.'' As the result, when the Indian won a battle it was a ``massacre''; when white troops won it was a ``victory.'' ``Telling the truth doesn't mean presenting Indians always in the most positive light,'' Ms. Harjo said. ``It just means telling the truth. ... We need an educational program to humanize us in a way that will counter the dehumanizing, stereotyping and cartooning that has taken place.''

DOC.HEAD: Pope Travels To Chad, Pays Homage to Slain Missionaries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf each after 6th and 11th to ADD color, size crowd and details of papal address. Pickup 12th pvs, `The theme...
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II traveled to the Christian heartland of southern Chad today and paid homage to missionaries killed during decades of civil strife. On the last full day of his eight-day tour of Africa's Sahel region, the pontiff celebrated Mass before more than 100,000 people in this capital of the cotton-growing region where Roman Catholic missionaries set up their first base 60 years ago. He called Mondou ``the cradle of the Catholic church in Chad.'' The great majority of Chad's 400,000 baptized Roman Catholics and 153 foreign priests live in the south. Most of the nation's Moslems, who make up about 50 percent of the population of 5.5 million, live in the north. In his homily, the pope paid tribute to the former bishop of Mondou, Gabriel Balet, a Swiss national who was killed in the crash of a French airliner in Niger on Sept. 19. The UTA DC-10 exploded during a flight from N'Djamena to Paris. A bomb was suspected. ``I express again, from all my heart, my deep sympathy to the families in mourning and to the diocesan community,'' John Paul said, speaking in French at Mondou's Stadium of Peace. A highlight of the ceremony came when a chief of the Nomoate ethnic group danced up to the altar and placed a beaded cap with brown plumes on John Paul's head. The pope held the hat on his head and smiled broadly. Since becoming independent in 1960, Chad has often been torn apart by fighting between north and south, between different tribes and political factions and between Libyan-backed rebels and government forces. In August, Chad and Libya agreed to put an end to 16 years of hostility and agreed to reach a political settlement over the 45,000-square-mile Aouzou Strip that separates them. Referring to the missionaries who evangelized Chad, the pope said: ``Many of them, during the tragic events of these past years, paid with their life for their attachment to Jesus and their fidelity to the service of their community.'' He praised the catechists who traveled to areas of fighting to spread the faith. ``For this country rebuilding itself after so many ordeals, their presence and their actions are a sign of hope,'' the pope said before leaving to conduct a special service in Sarh and returning to the capital, N'Djamena. A crowd of 150,000 to 200,000 attended the Mass in a huge open field that is to be the site of a soccer stadium. The pope encouraged the faithful to fill the ranks of priests and catechists. There are only 26 Chadian priests. The theme of reconciliation and unity has dominated the pope's stay in Chad. Repression by a Christian-led government in 1965 against Moslem populations in the center and north of Chad led to fighting throughout the country that ended only two years ago. The Chadian church has placed great emphasis on the need for an Islamic-Christian dialogue. Upon arriving in Chad on Monday, the pope spoke in a cathedral that was restored after being destroyed by fighting 10 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Trial Begins Over California Campaign Spending Initiative
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf pvs, `Opposition is ...' to DELETE extraneous letters.
DOC.TEXT: A political reform initiative that won voter approval 19 months ago has wound up like many so many other California ballot measures in recent years _ in court. Testimony began Tuesday in the federal court trial of Proposition 73, the omnibus campaign cleanup measure that outlawed public financing of political races, limited contributions, and banned transfers of donations between candidates' committees. The proposition is the latest in a series of voter-approved ballot questions _ including measures dealing with insurance rate reform and toxics cleanup _ that have become ensnared in legal tangles. Opponents of Proposition 73, led by Assembly Speaker Willie Brown, the Democratic Party and several unions, want U.S. District Judge Lawrence Karlton to throw out the initiative. They contend it is unconstitutional and denies women, minorities and grass-roots groups their rights by unfairly limiting the amount of money they can raise to run against wealthy incumbents. In addition, an advocate for one of the state's most powerful and well-heeled lobbies, the 240,000-member California Teachers Association, testified that Proposition 73 has put a crimp in the teachers' political activities. Alice Huffman, who heads the association's political action committee that distributes hundred of thousands of dollars annually to legislative candidates, said the measure's contribution restraints restrict the group's contacts with its members by limiting the number of campaign endorsement letters it can send. The authors of Proposition 73 said their initiative is supported by the public and opposed only by Democratic politicians seeking to bolster their power. ``Opposition is coming from some of the most powerful politicians and special interests in California,'' said initiative co-author Ross Johnson of Fullerton, the Republican leader of the state Assembly. Those groups dislike provisions that apply the same limits to all candidates, he said. Johnson said the initiative has hamstrung runaway campaign donations, but critics, including the political watchdog group Common Cause, contend the measure has had an uncertain impact on California's high-stakes political campaigns. Joseph Garcia, an attorney for the state Fair Political Practices Commission, said the lawsuit was politically motivated and not based on merit. ``In this case, these facts are about politics and these plaintiffs are politicians,'' Garcia said. ``Not here before the court today are the three million voters who overwhelmingly approved Proposition 73 in 1988 by 58 percent of the vote.'' The measure was approved 3.14 million to 2.23 million votes. The initiative puts a $1,000 ceiling on individual contributions to a state or local candidate in a single fiscal year, $2,500 from a political committee and $5,000 from a so-called broad-based political action committee or political party. The measure put no restrictions on spending. On May 19, Karlton ruled in favor of the plaintiffs, issuing a temporary order that overturned some provisions. The judge lifted the ban on transfers between one candidate's committees, removed the limit on labor union contributions for endorsement mailings, and said candidates could use funds raised before Jan. 1, 1989, when most of the provisions took effect, to back or oppose other candidates. His order remains in effect pending the outcome of the trial. Karlton is hearing the case without a jury, and he said the trial will probably be completed by early next week. Other initiatives that have resulted in court fights include Proposition 103, the insurance reform measure backed by consumer advocate Ralph Nader, and Proposition 65, the anti-toxics clean-water initiative that was supported by environmentalists but opposed by farmers and manufacturers.

DOC.HEAD: Blacklisted Playwright Arnaud d'Usseau Dead at 73
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `The author ...' to CORRECT by deleting that McCarthy was chairman of a House committee.
DOC.TEXT: Arnaud d'Usseau, a Broadway playwright and Hollywood screenwriter who was blacklisted after a heated confrontation with Sen. Joseph McCarthy, has died at 73. D'Usseau died Monday of complications of surgery for stomach cancer in New York City, the Los Angeles Times reported today. The author of such acclaimed plays as ``Tomorrow the World'' and ``Deep Are the Roots'' was brought before McCarthy in 1953 as the senator investigated alleged communist influence in the film industry. D'Usseau refused to answer McCarthy's questions, saying he would be happy to debate the merits of communism and capitalism in another setting, but not ``where you have everything stacked.'' At one point, the Republican senator from Wisconsin threatened to remove d'Usseau from the hearing room. After his blacklisting, d'Usseau wrote for films under pseudonyms. His last play, ``Bledsoe,'' is being readied for a Broadway opening. A native of Los Angeles, d'Usseau began writing professionally in the 1930s. His films included ``One Crowded Night,'' ``Lady Scarface,'' ``Repent at Leisure,'' ``Just Off Broadway,'' ``The Man Who Wouldn't Die'' and ``Who Is Hope Schuyler?'' In 1944, Ring Lardner Jr., who became one of the so-called Hollywood 10 group of writers and directors who went to prison for their defiance of the congressional investigations of alleged communist influence, adapted d'Usseau's ``Tomorrow the World'' for the screen. Considered among the most literate of the wartime propaganda works, ``Tomorrow the World'' was about a German boy adopted by an American couple. In 1945, d'Usseau and his writing partner, James Gow, created ``Deep Are the Roots,'' which explored the then-controversial theme of miscegenation as it pleaded for racial tolerance. D'Usseau's other Broadway plays included ``Ladies of the Corridor,'' written with Dorothy Parker, and ``The Legend of Sarah'' with Gow in 1950. D'Usseau lived in New York and taught writing at New York University and the School of Visual Arts. Survivors include his wife, Marie, a son, a daughter and three brothers. Funeral arrangements were not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Speechwriters Seek New Catch-Phrases for State of Union
DOC.TEXT: Eds: Subs final graf to CORRECT name of speechwriter to Daniel McGroarty, add Sununu's role and to reflect that Ailes' role was mostly in coaching

President Bush may not outshine ``a thousand points of light'' or top ``a kinder and gentler nation,'' but he's bound to try out a new catch-phrase or two in tonight's State of the Union address. Presidential speechwriters always strive for those few pithy words or flowing lines that will live on after the applause has died. But the ghostwriter who put those earlier words in Bush's mouth and taught us to read his lips, Peggy Noonan, is now persona non grata at the White House since becoming a tell-it-all author. And neither Bush, left to his own devices, nor his current speechwriters have been having much luck at matching the old Noonan nuggets. ``The underpinnings of the United States, the State of the Union, is not bad,'' Bush told a group of newspaper publishers last week when asked to preview tonight's address. ``Not bad,'' might be an honest assessment. But it doesn't have much ring. Meanwhile, Bush's speechwriters seem to be straining for soaring passages. ``With all the flash and fluff in the world today, there's something we can't afford to lose sight of _ something deceptively simple. It's who we are that makes this nation what it is,'' was one recent offering. In his 1989 inaugural address, Bush spoke lyrically of a ``new breeze'' blowing through the totalitarian world. He promised Democratic leaders an ``age of the offered hand.'' And he summed up the nation's budget woes in six words: ``We have more will than wallet.'' Noonan, again. It was the last speech she wrote for George Bush. White House sources said there was a falling out between Noonan and White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and other top Bush advisers in early 1989, partly due to her own growing fame as a wordsmith. Noonan recounts her experiences as a speechwriter for Bush and former President Reagan in a book, ``What I Saw at the Revolution: A Political Life in the Reagan Era,'' published last week. Bush has made no secret of his disdain for insider or ``kiss-and-tell'' books written by former aides. The publication of Noonan's book did little to heal the rift. When she began writing speeches for Bush in the 1988 campaign, Noonan writes, he gave her a list of words with ``special meaning'' to him: ``family, grandkids, love, decency, honor, pride, tolerance, hope, kindness, loyalty, freedom, caring, heart, faith, service to country, fair (fair play), strength, healing, excellence.'' From those threads she began weaving Bush's speeches. But she ran up against one major obstacle: ``George Bush hated to say `I.''' ``I became adept at pronounless sentences,'' Noonan says. ``Instead of `I moved to Texas and soon we joined the Republican party,' it was `Moved to Texas, joined the Republican party, raised a family.''' Noonan suggests Bush's modesty came from his ``doughty old mom,'' Dorothy Walker Bush, ``who used to rap his knuckles for bragging, a brag apparently being defined as any sentence with the first person singular as its subject.'' She confesses visions of Bush taking the oath on the Capitol steps with these words: ``Do solemnly swear, will preserve and protect ...''' Bush's characterization of a ``kinder, gentler nation,'' contained in his acceptance speech to the Republican National Convention, has become one of the president's signature phrases. But, Noonan writes, it was just ``kinder nation'' in her first draft. She later scribbled in ``gentler.'' Bush's ``no new taxes'' line, also in the same widely acclaimed acceptance speech, was suggested by Jack Kemp, now the secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Noonan says. But she takes all the credit for ``read my lips,'' even though Bush aides took it out because ``there is no history of presidential candidates making personal-organ references in acceptance speeches.'' Bush left it in. One line he scratched out: a reference Noonan proposed to Michael Dukakis' slight stature. Noonan claims full credit for Bush's ``thousand points of light,'' but allows it might have been influenced by a line from a favorite author, Thomas Wolfe, who wrote in ``The Web and the Rock'' of a ``thousand points of friendly light.'' Bush uses the phrase to this day to praise volunteer efforts. Why a thousand? ``A hundred wasn't enough and a million is too many,'' Noonan writes. White House communications director David Demarest, in charge of White House speechwriters, says Noonan, who now lives in New York, has not worked on any recent Bush speeches and that all presidential speeches are prepared in-house. However, work on Bush's State of the Union address was partly farmed out to an old hand from the campaign: New York media consultant and image guru Roger Ailes. White House speechwriter Daniel McGroarty wrote most of the speech and White House chief of staff Sununu helped refine it. Ailes worked with Bush on Monday and again today on final preparation, sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Ends 30 Years Behind Iron Curtain With Arrest in Omaha
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT to Kephart sted Kephert.
DOC.TEXT: An American soldier who fled to East Germany in 1959 for fear a truck accident would land him in the stockade saw his family for the first time in three decades _ then was taken away as an Army deserter. Military and Omaha police were awaiting Arnold Kephart when he landed at Omaha's airport Tuesday. He saw his 86-year-old father and a sister momentarily before being led away on the 30-year-old warrant for desertion in West Germany. Kephart, 53, originally from Langdon, Mo., had escaped to the East bloc with a girlfriend and wasn't able to return to the West until December, after East Germany threw open its borders, said his attorney, James Martin Davis. In his 30 years behind the Iron Curtain, Kephart worked as a truck driver in the small city of Smalkalden, married twice and fathered a son, now 12, of whom he has custody. The boy, Frankie, came with him and is staying with his father's family. Kephart was expected to be taken to Fort Riley, Kan., today, Davis said. Tracy Andersen of Council Bluffs, one of Kephart's nieces, said she and about 30 family members came to Omaha's Eppley Airfield to meet Kephart and his son. Instead, they discovered that Kephart had been arrested by military police on the plane and taken into the airport by a side entrance. He was allowed to speak only to his father, Ernest Kephart, and sister, Mary Hartman, Anderson said. ``They just let them talk a little bit, and she came out with the boy,'' Kephart's niece said. Davis said Kephart was a corporal in Heidelberg in 1959 when he crashed a truck and was told by a sergeant that he would be thrown in the stockade and would have to pay for the vehicle on a $69-per-month salary, Davis said. The staff sergeant lied, but Kephart believed him, the attorney said. During the next three decades, Kephart tried to escape to the West three or four times but was caught at the border, Davis said. Only three or four censored letters reached his family. Kephart received custody of Frankie after divorcing his second wife. After the opening of the borders to the West late last year, Kephart and his son walked 300 miles for several weeks, eating out of garbage cans, Davis said. He got to Hamburg Dec. 15 and worked in a hotel until he was able to locate his family and obtain proof of U.S. citizenship and a passport, the lawyer said. ``He has a great difficulty speaking English,'' Davis said. ``He will frequently lapse into German. Every three of four sentences he will say that he does not know the word in English.''

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Protest Police Brutality, Rebel Cricket Tour
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of black demonstrators in two cities today peacefully protested police tactics and a boycott-breaking tour by English cricket players. Seeking to avoid a repeat of violence that marred previous unauthorized protests, the government authorized the two demonstrations _ a march in Cape Town protesting alleged police brutality and a rally in Bloemfontein outside the stadium where the English team was playing. Large police contingents watched the protests, but there were no reports of disturbances. In Cape Town, 3,500 marchers met at a Methodist church, then walked to police headquarters to present a petition condemning police actions during a protest march in the city on Jan. 23. Police had blocked the intended parade route with barbed wire, then used rubber bullets and a water cannon against the protesters, sparking a rampage in which scores of youths smashed windows of shops and cars. By contrast, today's march was peaceful. ``It has shown very clearly that if there is any violence or disorderly conduct, it is entirely the fault of the police,'' said the Rev. Allan Boesak, a prominent mixed-race activist who led the march. The government gave permission for another protest march in Cape Town on Thursday, organized to demand that President F.W. de Klerk appoint a commission to investigate allegations about police assassination squads. In Bloemfontein, 1,000 blacks arrived by bus and van to protest the English cricket team, which was in the second day of a three-day match against a team of university players. Among the spectators in the stadium were scores of black youths who had been given tickets by a group supporting the tour. The English players face bans of five years from international competition for making the trip in defiance of the sports boycott imposed to protest South Africa's racial segregation policies. Since the team's arrival two weeks ago, there have been repeated clashes between police and protesters. On Tuesday, police used batons, rubber bullets and tear gas to prevent 1,000 blacks from marching to the stadium. Some demonstrators threw stones at police vehicles and erected burning tire barricades in the streets of Mangaung township. Obed Nkosi, an organizer for the anti-apartheid National Sports Council, said 30 people were hurt. Police said 45 people were arrested and one white businessman was slightly injured when his vehicle was stoned by protesters.

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Aimed at Blacks Gone in a Puff of Smoke
DOC.TEXT: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. (AP) _ Uptown, the cigarette that was to have been aimed at blacks, will probably never rise from the ashes, says the chairman of R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. Reynolds had planned to test-market the new cigarette in Philadelphia beginning Feb. 5 but canceled out last week after the product was criticized by civic groups and Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, who is black. ``I doubt you will see Uptown on the market again,'' Reynolds chairman James W. Johnston said in a speech to local business leaders Tuesday. ``We made the decision because the issue was being turned from a smoking issue, which it is, to a racial issue. And we did not feel that was the kind of ground we wanted to have a dispute on.''

DOC.HEAD: Last of the Old Guard Resigns as Leader of Czech Republic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with premier of Czech republic resigning, talks held on restoring Czechoslovak-Vatican ties. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Deputy premier Frantisek Pitra, the last of the Old Guard Communist leaders left in power after the peaceful revolution, resigned today as leader of the Czech republic, the CTK news agency said. It was expected Pitra also would give up his Cabinet position once his resignation from the Czech post was approved by Parliament. Pitra, 57, had strong links with the orthodox Communist leadership that took over after the crushing of the 1968 reform movement and ruled until last fall's pro-democracy revolution. Pitra lost his seat on the ruling Communist Party Politburo on Nov. 24, along with hard-line party leader Milos Jakes and others closely linked to the post-1968 crackdown. However, he survived as Czech premier after revamping his republic's government to become the first in Czechoslovakia since 1948 that was not dominated by Communists. That paved the way for similar changes at the federal level. Pitra's position as the Czech premier automatically gave him the deputy premier's post in the national government. CTK did not give the reason for Pitra's resignation, which came a day after the Communists ended a 40-year dominance in the national Parliament by relinquishing more than 100 of their seats to pro-democracy groups. The realignment completed an effort to include Czechoslovakia's emerging reform groups in Parliament before free elections, which are scheduled June 8. Parliament swore in 120 new deputies Tuesday, only nine of them Communists, under an agreement to replace more than one-third of the 350-member legislature. The action sliced the Communists' representation from 242 to 139. Nearly all the new seats went to the opposition and other established political parties. More than 40 political parties have emerged in the two months since Parliament removed the constitutional provision guaranteeing the Communist Party's leading role. In other developments, Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier today met with a papal representative on restoring ties between Czechoslovakia and the Vatican, and state radio announced plans to resume broadcasting Masses and other religious programs. Dienstbier, meeting with special Papal Nuncio Archbishop Francesco Colasuonno, also discussed the visit of Polish-born Pope John Paul II, planned for April 21-22 as the new government seeks to restore sanctioned religious observances following decades of repression. The official CTK news agency said the talks concerned ``the early resumption'' of diplomatic relations between Czechoslovakia and the Vatican. Czechoslovakia broke ties in the 1950s in line with Communist dogma followed throughout the East bloc. Poland last year became the first East bloc nation to restore diplomatic ties with the Vatican. Last week, the Czechoslovak Parliament said priests no longer will have to obtain licenses from the state. The licenses had been used in the past to screen clergymen considered politically troublesome. Czechoslovakia and Israel are expected to restore diplomatic ties on Feb. 8, when Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of Israel visits Prague. Czechoslovakia, one of Israel's strongest supporters after the Jewish state was founded in 1948, broke ties after the 1967 Middle East war, when Israel captured Arab lands.

DOC.HEAD: Police Stage Stakeout at Newspaper Box
DOC.TEXT: Detectives staked out a newspaper box and nabbed three people for taking more copies than they paid for, authorities said. The stakeout Tuesday was requested by the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette because of an increase in complaints of thefts. Pedestrians stared and a Post-Gazette reporter took notes while detectives read the three their rights. Photos of the three were published in today's paper with captions such as ``Had two papers'' and ``4 Post-Gazettes, 4 USA Todays.'' One of those arrested took two newspapers after putting in just one quarter, authorities said. Each of the three was offered a choice of being charged with retail theft or enrolling in a $50 course on the evils of shoplifting. All three enrolled. Jim Logan, assistant city circulation manager, said that in an average week downtown 1,500 Post-Gazettes are stolen, or $19,500 in revenue a year. Logan said the money lost to theft must be paid by the route manager who handles the box. ``People think they're stealing from a corporation or a metal box,'' he said. ``They don't know they're stealing from a person.''

DOC.HEAD: Suspected ANC Guerrilla Found Hanged In Cell
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 7th graf, `Within a ...' to UPDATE with no indication whether inquiry prompted by reported Mandela connection.
DOC.TEXT: A black man accused of involvement in guerrilla attacks was found hanged in his cell, police said today. He reportedly was a former lover of jailed black leader Nelson Mandela's daughter. Within hours of the police announcement, President F.W. de Klerk ordered a judicial inquiry into the death, a step not taken after scores of previous incidents in which black activists died while in police custody. According to local newspapers, the 20-year-old man, Clayton Sithole, was a former lover of Zindzi Mandela and the father of her child. There was no immediate comment from the Mandelas, but associates of the family said they believed the report was accurate. Sithole and four other suspected African National Congress guerrillas were arrested Friday in Soweto, the vast black township outside Johannesburg. Police accused the group of killing 10 people, including two policemen, in attacks with hand grenades and automatic rifles over the past two years. Police said Sithole was found hanging from a shower pipe Tuesday in his cell at John Vorster Square, Johannesburg's central police station. The police said an investigation into the death had started and would include a post mortem by a state pathologist. Within a few hours of the police statement, Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok announced that de Klerk had appointed an inquiry commission headed by a judge to investigate Sithole's death. Neither Vlok nor de Klerk gave any indication whether the decision was related to the reported connection to the Mandela family. Mandela, 71, is widely expected to be freed within the next few weeks after more than 27 years in prison for his role in planning the start of the ANC's guerrilla campaign. Audrey Coleman, a prominent human rights activist, welcomed de Klerk's move, saying she could not recall such a swift and emphatic response to any of the scores of other deaths of detainees which she has monitored in recent years. She said Sithole's family, who suspected the young man had been mistreated, would hire a pathologist of their own to conduct an independent post mortem Thursday. Police said Sithole had made a confession to a magistrate prior to his death, implicating himself in several killings. About 100 ANC guerrillas and anti-apartheid activists have died in police custody in the past 25 years. According to police, suicide by hanging has been the most common cause of these deaths, but human rights groups have insisted that many of these prisoners had been mistreated by interrogators. In announcing the arrests Monday, police headquarters said officers had seized an arms cache that included a Soviet-made automatic rifle, a revolver and 27 rounds of ammunition. The African National Congress was outlawed in 1960 and the next year began a bombing and sabotage campaign intended to undermine the white-minority government. The guerrilla campaign has slackened in the past two years, with a marked decrease in the number of bombings in which civilians could be at risk. During this period, however, black policemen have remained a frequent ANC target. Police said in their daily unrest report today that a policeman was among three people killed in political violence in black townships around the port city of Durban. The report gave no details. Police headquarters confirmed that a prominent black activist, Peter Mokaba, had been detained last weekend under the Internal Security Act, which allows indefinite detention for interrogation purposes. Mokaba is a leader of the militant South African Youth Congress and a close associate of Winnie Mandela, wife of jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Leader Dismisses Report He Might Resign Party Post
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 6th, `Foreign Ministry...' to ADD Bush phoning Gorbachev. Pickup 7th pvs, `In a...
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today denied a U.S. broadcast report that he is considering resigning his post as Communist Party chief. ``No one has said this, and I certainly didn't make any such statement,'' the Soviet president and party general secretary said. ``Any such suggestions are groundless.'' The Cable News Network reported Tuesday, quoting an unidentified party source, that Gorbachev had spent eight days holed up at his country house outside Moscow with his top advisers, where he was considering resigning his leaderhip of the party.
