The source was quoted as saying Gorbachev would have retained the presidency, a government position he proposes to convert from a largely ceremonial post to a substantive one. ``I have no intention of doing so,'' Gorbachev said when asked about the report during a photo session at the start of a Kremlin meeting with President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil. Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov, speaking at a regular news briefing, also denied the CNN report. President Bush today phoned Gorbachev to discuss arms control and other issues. Asked if the two discussed the CNN report, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``The president said there was no direct discussion of that.'' The official Tass news agency said the two leaders discussed international affairs, the situation in Europe and arms control. It did not say if Bush asked Gorbachev whether he intended to resign as party chief. In a related discussion published in the Communist Party daily Pravda, four scholars urged that the presidency be strengthened to protect the head of state from efforts to oust him and allow him to act more decisively. The discussion in Pravda appeared aimed at telling readers that party power still is paramount and that the presidency is not strong enough to be the country's main leadership post. Historian Yevgeny Ambartsumov said in Pravda that Gorbachev appeared unable to take decisive action because of the threat to his position. The CNN report touched off a temporary flurry of selling on Western stock markets and sent the dollar soaring in New York and Japan. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said he did not know how to respond to what he termed ``a rumor.'' The ruling Communist Party has traditionally been the power base for Soviet leaders. However, the party has been widely blamed for failing to solve the country's dire economic crisis, and reformist lawmakers are demanding that the Communists give up their monopoly on power. The presidency has become a more visible and substantive position in recent months. Still, there is little question that the party's Politburo and Central Committee retain the political power. Gorbachev told journalists he had just returned from the south, apparently referring to his retreat on the Black Sea, where he was preparing for next week's meeting of the Communist Party's governing Central Committee, which is planning a potential critical party congress for the fall. The meeting comes at a time of political turmoil for Gorbachev and the ruling Communists. The breakaway Lithuanian Communist Party rejected Gorbachev's efforts to bring it back within the fold, and the president was forced to send troops into the warring southern republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan to restore order and crush an effort by Azerbaijani nationalists to seize power in Baku. The rumor about Gorbachev's stepping down was fed by an announcement that Baker was again postponing by a day his scheduled two-day trip to Moscow for talks with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and, almost certainly, Gorbachev as well. Initially, Baker was to go to Moscow on Feb. 6. On Tuesday, the State Department said it had suggested the visit begin on Feb. 8. Shevardnadze told The Associated Press in an interview last week there is widespread concern in the West that Gorbachev may not survive politically. But he attributed it more to a desire that Gorbachev's reforms succeed than to any real threat to the Soviet leader's political power. ``I believe that this particular preoccupation stems from sincere feelings, from sincere support for the process of perestroika that is under way in the Soviet Union,'' Shevardnadze said. ``He was the one who spearheaded this arduous but holy struggle.'' Baker, asked about the rumor on Tuesday, told reporters: ``We're following the story, as I know you are, and we'll have a comment if we ever determine it's something more than just a rumor.'' Baker said American diplomats in Moscow ``know just about the same thing that all the rest of us know right now _ that there's a rumor out there to this effect, and that's all we know.'' White House Chief of Staff John Sununu told reporters Tuesday that the administration has been ``trying for the last few hours to try and get some additional assessments, but I don't have anything at all.''

DOC.HEAD: 10 Nations Absolved of About $305 Million
DOC.TEXT: The United States will absolve 10 African countries of about $305 million in debt, the U.S. Agency for International Development announced today. The countries are pursuing economic reform programs approved by the International Monetary Fund or the World Bank. They are: Benin, Cameroon, Ghana, Guinea, Kenya, Madagascar, Malawi, Mali, Nigeria and Zaire. In some cases there will be further relief extended in stages, an AID statement said. Three other countries eligible for relief _ Ivory Coast, Niger and Uganda _ have not concluded agreements with the United States. Together, they would boost the forgiven debt relief to $745 million. Sub-Saharan African countries owe the U.S. government $6.5 billion, including $1.5 billion for economic assistance loans.

DOC.HEAD: 37 Injured in School Bus Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with apparent cause of accident, raise number of children hospitalized to 18, six in serious condition, school closed. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MDT1
DOC.TEXT: A school bus whose driver momentarily took his eyes off the road to look through the rear-view mirror plowed into two trees, injuring the driver and all but two of the 38 children aboard, authorities said today. Eighteen of the children were hospitalized after Tuesday's accident, six in critical or serious condition with head injuries, officials said. The bus, carrying kindergarteners and first-graders from the Harriman Heights Road Elementary School, sheared off its roof in the accident. State Trooper Robert Gillespie said the bus slipped into the muddy shoulder apparently after the driver took his eyes off the road for a moment. The driver, Andrew Callahan, 63, was listed in fair condition with head injuries today. Gillespie said State Police would consult with the district attorney today on whether to bring charges against Callahan. Callahan is a 23-year veteran of the district's routes and had never had an accident, said Cliff Berchtold, Monroe-Woodbury district transportation director. ``I was going home and the bus went into the ditch and I hit the seat with my head a couple of times,'' said Martin Polignone, 6, who had a bump on his head and a bruise under his eye. ``I fell into the mud head first,'' said 6-year-old Kristin Aspinwall. ``He (the driver) moved over and the wheel got off the road and the bus tipped over and the whole roof came off.'' The bus, which lacked passenger seat belts, was built a year before state law required them in 1986. The school was closed today, and Louis Ciota, assistant superintendent, said crisis counselors would be made available to students and parents.

DOC.HEAD: Rabin Halts Expulsions of Palestinians
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 3 grafs at end to UPDATE with violence and strike today in occupied lands. Recasts lead and 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin today ordered a temporary halt to the expulsion of Palestinians living in the occupied territories without residency permits, a practice that has torn apart hundreds of families. The announcement, which cited humanitarian reasons, came a day after the U.S. State Department expressed concern over the expulsions. Palestinian activists claim the expulsions have been stepped up and are part of a long-term strategy to force Palestinians out of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, where the Palestinian uprising against Israeli authority has claimed hundreds of lives over the last 26 months. Israeli officials deny the claim. According to an army official, 251 Palestinians, including 88 women and 78 children, were expelled from the occupied lands in the past year because they did not have residency permits. The official did not have figures for preceding years. Rabin told reporters today he decided to stop expulsions and review the policy to prevent ``a case in which half a family will be forced out while another part will be allowed to stay.'' He indicated, however, that expulsions would resume. ``We cannot afford, in principle, that a person who comes as a tourist or as a visitor, takes the liberty to stay forever,'' he said. The army-run government in the occupied lands has adopted stringent residency regulations under which only Palestinians who lived in the occupied lands during a September 1967 census are automatically eligible for permits. Others must apply for permits, and the vast majority of applications are turned down. Rabin told Parliament Tuesday that since 1967, military officials have received 88,429 requests for ``family reunification'' and that 13,509 of those were granted. The group most affected is Palestinian women whose families fled to Jordan when Israel seized the West Bank and Gaza in the 1967 Middle East war, and who later married men from the occupied lands. Inevitably, these women and their children become part of the demographic war between Israel and the Palestinians. Some Palestinians see increasing their numbers as a way to give weight to their argument for statehood. At the same time, Israel wants to limit the number of Arabs under its control. Wives denied residency permits usually enter the occupied lands on three-month visitor visas, and then face the choice of leaving their families and returning to Jordan or staying illegally. Palestinian human rights groups have said that in the past few months, soldiers have raided several remote West Bank villages to round up illegal residents, placed them in taxis and escorted them to the Allenby Bridge which links Jordan and the West Bank. ``The expulsions universally take place in the middle of the night, with no immediate warning,'' wrote the Palestinian news service Sanabel, which published details of several cases. Rabin's announcement of freezing the expulsions came after Statement Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Tuesday that Israeli officials are ``well aware of our concern, particularly with regard to divided families.'' The swift Israeli response came at a time when U.S.-Israeli relations are strained over differences on how to make peace with Palestinians and when some American politicians are urging cuts in aid to the Jewish state. Also today, Arab activists stabbed to death a Palestinian suspect of collaborating with Israel, and Israeli soldiers shot and wounded three Palestinians in the occupied territories, Arab reports said. A strike ordered by the PLO-linked underground leadership of the uprising brought transportation to a halt and kept students out of school. The death of 35-year-old Adwa Aziz El Masri, a taxi driver, brought to 175 the number of Palestinians killed after being accused of collaborating with Israel. At least 651 Palestinians have died of Israeli gunfire during the rebellion, and 43 Israelis have been slain.

DOC.HEAD: India Accuses Pakistan of Inciting Violence in Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: The government today accused Pakistan of encouraging terrorism and subversion in Kashmir where Indian security forces are trying to put down a Moslem rebellion. Pakistan's Foreign Minister Sahabzada Yaqub Khan on Tuesday accused India of trying to ``supress the freedom movement in Kashmir through atrocities.'' Khan's speech was broadcast by national radio and television. An Indian Foreign Ministry spokesman, Aftab Seth, said Khan's statements were ``deliberately fallacious'' and amounted to ``direct incitement to subversion, violence and terrorist activties in a part of India.'' The Indian government faces a violent Islamic separatist movement in Kashmir that has grown more strident in the past two months. In an effort to end the rebellion, Indian troops and police launched a crackdown Jan. 20. At least 72 people, most of them Moslem protesters shot by Indian security forces, were killed in Kashmir between Jan. 20 and Jan. 25, according to figures compiled from government spokesmen, police sources and witnesses. The government says there have been no deaths since Jan. 25. Khan had claimed in his speech that thousands of Kashmiris were being detained and hundreds have died in the crackdown. India has often accused Pakistan of aiding the militants in order to annex the Kashmir Valley, a predominantly Moslem region sandwiched between northwestern India and northeastern Pakistan. India and Pakistan fought wars in 1965 and 1971 over border disputes in the region. Pakistan denies helping the militants but says it supports Kashmiri separatism, calling it a movement for self-determination. Seth said Khan's speech indicated that ``his government persists in its efforts to involve itself in our internal affairs. We would like to firmly reiterate that Kashmir is and will continue to be an integral part of India.'' A portion of Kashmir has been under dispute since 1947 when India and Pakistan were partitioned on gaining independence from Britain. India controls most of the mountainous region, and Pakistan occupies a smaller sector. Seth said ``the only issue that remains to be resolved in Kashmir is the vacation by Pakistan of territory illegally occupied by it.'' He said Khan's efforts to justify Pakistani policies will fuel tension in Kashmir. Kashmiri separatists, who earlier demanded union of Kashmir with Pakistan, now demand independence and the formation of a neutral country.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb Kills Six, Injures 122 in Kabul
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded in Afghanistan's capital today, killing six people and injuring 122, official Radio Kabul said. No one immediately claimed responsibility for the blast, but the report, monitored in Islamabad, blamed U.S.-supported Moslem rebels. The explosion destroyed several nearby cars in central Kabul and damaged buildings within a 220-yard radius of the car bomb, the report said. Most of the injured were hit by shattered window panes. The Moslem rebels have been fighting Soviet-backed governments in Afghanistan for 10 years. They control most of the countryside and regularly attack government-held Kabul with rockets and other explosives. The Soviet Union completed its troop withdrawl in February 1989, but Moscow continues to supply the government with arms and food.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Blood Pressure Drug May Reduce Hip Fractures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 6 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Older people who take one variety of commonly used blood pressure pills called diuretics may reduce their risk of hip fractures by one-third, according to a study. The study found that people over 65 who used the type of diuretics known as thiazides appeared to suffer significantly fewer broken hips than nonusers. They said that if the medicines work the way they believe, 21,600 hip fractures might be avoided annually if all older Americans took the medicine. However, they cautioned that more study will be needed before the drugs could be prescribed solely to prevent fractures. They said experts will have to be sure that the benefits of this treatment outweigh the potential hazards. Experts long have known that thiazides can prevent the body from losing calcium. However, the medicines also can have unwanted side effects, including potassium deficiency and high cholesterol. The study, directed by Dr. Andrea Z. LaCroix of the Group Health Cooperative of Puget Sound, was published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. The study was based on a four-year follow-up of 9,518 men and women who lived in Boston, New Haven, Conn., and rural Iowa. When the study began, about one-quarter of them were taking thiazide diuretics for high blood pressure.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Destroys Fire Department
DOC.TEXT: The Volunteer Fire Department couldn't do much to fight a major blaze _ it was their building and all their equipment was inside. The fire Tuesday destroyed the building, two trucks, breathing equipment, hoses and records, Fire Chief Eddie Joe Meredith said. ``Everything we had is gone,'' Meredith said. ``I'd cry if it would help.'' He said firefighters couldn't retrieve any equipment because they couldn't get through the electrically operated doors. They broke through a wall to try to save their records, but flames beat them to the filing cabinet. Meredith said several neighboring departments tried to save the building. The department was building a third truck, with help from the Delaplaine High School's shop program, but Meredith said it's not ready for service yet. He declined to speculate on the cause of the fire. He said the building was insured for $25,000 and the two trucks for $13,000 each.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Snow Blankets Korea
DOC.TEXT: Up to 5 feet of snow blanketed parts of South Korea on Wednesday, paralyzing traffic in the capital and isolating villages. No weather-related deaths had been reported as of late Wednesday but weathermen posted severe snow warnings for the entire nation. They forecast 4 to 8 inches of new snow by Thursday. Kimpo International Airport outside Seoul stayed open but six domestic airports along the east and southern coasts were closed. All outbound inter-city buses from Seoul were canceled. Thousands of boats were forced to take shelter in port beause of high waves churned by gale-force winds, maritime police said. More than 9.8 inches of snow accumulated in Seoul by Wednesday, snarling traffic on icy streets. The east coast was hit hardest with 5 feet of snow that cut off mountain roads collapsed dozens of slate roofs. In Seoul, subways were overcrowded and vehicular traffic moved at a snail's pace. All government workers were asked to report to work an hour late to try to reduce congestion. About 3,000 city employees were mobilized to control traffic and clear streets of snow.

DOC.HEAD: Slavs Rally Against Ethnic Albanians; More Unrest in Kosovo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 18 grafs to UPDATE with Slav protests in at least three cities, demands for halt to Albanian unrest. Pickup 13th pvs, `Kosovo is...' Delete last 2 grafs to trim.
DOC.TEXT: More than 100,000 Slavs, some firing guns in the air, demonstrated in at least three Yugoslav cities today to demand a halt to protests by ethnic Albanians in the ethnically troubled province of Kosovo. New protests by Albanians were reported today in at least five Kosovo cities, a day after unrest claimed five lives. A speaker at the biggest anti-Albanian rally, in the capital of the Montenegrin republic, said volunteers were signing up to fight ethnic Albanians themselves unless authorities ``use all available methods, including repression'' to end ``the Albanian uprising.'' Belgrade television showed footage of the huge rally in Titograd. The commentator estimated the crowd at 100,000. In the Montenegrin town of Ivangrad, 10,000 people demonstrated against ``Albanian separatists and Slovenian and Croatian leaders supporting them,'' the official Tanjug news agency reported. The reformist leaders of the republics of Slovenia and Croatia have supported the ethnic Albanians' demands for more autonomy in Kosovo. In Belgrade, the federal capital, tens of thousands of people rallied in what also was billed as a demonstration against the ethnic Albanians. But shouts of ``Down with Communism'' also were heard. Earlier, 5,000 students gathered outside Parliament in Belgrade demanding weapons to defend Slavs in Kosovo, where five people were reported killed in clashes Tuesday between the ethnic Albanian majority and police. Official media said the situation in Kosovo was approaching civil war. Since the latest clashes broke out Jan. 24, official media have reported 13 deaths. The Albanians want to regain the autonomy lost when the Serbian republic took control of Kosovo's police, judiciary and education last year. Kosovo is a province within Serbia and borders Albania. The Slav minority, which includes Serbs and Montenegrins, contends the Albanians were trying to force them from their homeland and that increased control over the region was necessary. Belgrade radio said today that at Vucitrn, 20 miles northwest of the Kosovo capital of Pristina, five demonstrators sustained unspecified injuries, apparently in clashes with police. About 3,000 demonstrators assembled in Podujevo, the scene of a major clash Tuesday, and approximately 1,000 others rallied at Streoci. Police used tear gas to prevent 200 demonstrators from joining another crowd of protesters on the streets of Titova Mitrovica, and an unspecified number of protesters rallied in Ada. At Malisevo, where two deaths were reported Tuesday, thousands of ethnic Albanians turned out for the funerals of three of their brethren killed in the unrest. The students in Belgrade proclaimed a general strike and demanded the resignation of the ``highest organs of the federation'' unless what they termed ``nationalist and vandalist rioting of (ethnic Albanian) terrorists'' in Kosovo is not halted within 48 hours. ``We shall give our lives, but not Kosovo!'' they chanted. They also chanted ``Hang Azem Vlasi!'' referring to the former Communist leader of Kosovo who is on trial for allegedly inciting ethnic Albanians to riot nearly a year ago. ``Kosovo is closer to civil war that it was ever before,'' said the Oslobodjenje daily in the city of Sarajevo. ``Whether Kosovo will become even bloodier is a question which no one can answer. The situation is dramatic and uncertain, and it is hard to predict what will take place within an hour or two, not to mention tomorrow.'' The pro-Serb Communist leadership of the Kosovo town of Titova Mitrovica said, ``Unless steps are taken for suppression and protection from terrorist actions of Albanian nationalists and separatists, the situation threatens to grow into civil war.'' Serbs and ethnic Albanians were reported confronting each other in the town of Kosovska Vitina on Tuesday, the first time this has happened. A number of Serbian villages have organized vigilante patrols armed with shotguns and pistols.

DOC.HEAD: The National Debuts With Gossip, Jock Stocks
LaserPhoto NY54
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with comments from editor and publisher; PICKS UP 5th graf pvs, `With a ...'; A version also moving on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: The National, the nation's only all-sports daily, hit the newsstands today, tempting sports-hungry Americans with a 48-page menu that included everthing from statistics to gossip, ``jock stocks'' and a weather map. The 50-cent tabloid was distributed to vendors in New York, Los Angeles and Chicago. Plans are to expand to other big cities such as Detroit, Dallas, Philadelphia, Boston and San Francisco, with a target of 15 cities by the end of 1990. Publisher Peter O. Price and Editor Frank Deford said at a news conference that the first issue got out with few glitches. Price said about 250,000 copies were distributed and that he had been told many New York newsstands sold out fairly quickly. Price conceded that there was a ``novelty effect'' to the first-day sales but said he was convinced there was ``immense demand'' for the paper anyway. Deford said he expects the paper to be so successful that someone may try to imitate it. The National is owned by National American Sports Communications L.P., a partnership that includes Price and Mexican media baron Emilio Azcarraga. Deford, a former Sports Illustrated writer, heads the 125-person editorial staff. While initial sales plans are limited to single-copy sales at newstands and in vending boxes, Deford said the paper hopes to offer mail-delivery subscriptions later this year so more people can get it. With a startup cost of $25 million, the partnership has acknowledged that it may take several years before the newspaper turns a profit. Price said Azcarraga was prepared to spend $100 million to put it in the black. Today's edition contained 36 pages of editorial material and 12 of advertisements, many of them color. Among the advertisers were CBS Sports, MCI Communications, Toyota, the Trump Shuttle and Nike, whose centerfold ad read: ``Halftime.'' Inside were a variety of stories, analysis, color photos and slickly presented statistics. The weather map detailed conditions in cities where games and other sporting events are being held. A ``playground'' section featured a crossword puzzle and comics. The paper also included a gossip column and even a brief listing of stocks of sports-oriented companies, labeled ``jock stocks.'' The newspaper claimed two ``exclusives'' _ one dealing with rightfielder Darryl Strawberry threatening to leave the Mets and the other reporting Florida running back Emmitt Smith's decision to turn pro. News outside the sporting arena was not totally ignored. The first issue devoted a half page to the ``Real World,'' led by a brief story on the rumor that Mikhail Gorbachev plans to resign his post as leader of the Soviet Communist Party. The ``real'' news also featured briefs on Zsa Zsa Gabor and Bob Dylan. The paper is being published Sunday through Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Fire on Ferry Carrying 285 People in Irish Sea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with boat being towed to shore, CORRECTS number of people on board. Deletes outdated material. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Fire broke out aboard a ferry carrying 285 people across the stormy Irish Sea today, but the blaze was brought under control by firefighters who were airlifted to the vessel, the coast guard said. No injuries reported, and passengers remained on board rather than be evacuated by helicopter, said Sealink U.K. Ltd., the ship's owner. ``There is no danger to passengers or anyone on board,'' said a spokesman for Sealink, speaking anonymously in keeping with British custom. ``It was quickly contained, the fire, fortunately.'' The fire in the engine room was put out by 14 firemen who were airlifted by three helicopters to the 8,000-ton ferry, the St. Columba. The ferry drifted without engine power in gale-force winds 12 miles off the Welsh coast before a tugboat arrived and began towing it to the port of Holyhead. A coast guard lifeboat and helicopters escorted the tugboat and ferry, with passengers, crew and firefighters on board, on the four-hour trip to shore. ``The winds don't make it any easier,'' said a coast guard spokesman, who was not identified in keeping with British custom. The ferry left Dunlaoghairem, Ireland, this morning for the journey across the Irish Sea. The coast guard said the fire started in the port side of the engine room. The ship's master declared an emergency and contacted the coast guard at Holyhead, which sent a boat and alerted other ships in the area.

DOC.HEAD: Few Blocks from McDonald's, The Fare is Standard Soviet
With AM-Soviet-McDonald's, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As thousands enjoyed their first Big Macs from Moscow's new McDonald's, dozens of others stood at tiny tables in a dim, dingy cafeteria a few blocks away Wednesday and ate the standard fare of meat and potatoes. But for all its problems, the popular Zelyeny Ogonyok, a snack bar on Pushkin Street, does have a few things McDonald's doesn't: low prices, experienced workers and a solid reputation. ``This is a good place. I come here whenever I can,'' said Alexei, a middle-aged construction workers, who sipped cabbage soup. He admitted he'd rather be at McDonald's, which opened for business Wednesday on Pushkin Square. Zelyeny Ogonyok, Russian for ``green light'' in keeping with its predominant clientele of taxi drivers, is reputed to be one of Moscow's best snack shops with good food and service. It even has its own golden arches of sorts: cylindrical signs outside painted gold and green. But the decor and ambiance leave something to be desired. There's no place to hang a coat or hat, so diners must wear them. There's no place to sit, so they must stand. The small chandeliers are so weak customers can barely see what they're eating _ which may be a good thing. A popular main dish Wednesday was a large meatball, served cold with beads of fat inside. The price: just 28 kopecks, or about 10 minutes' pay for an average worker, compared to 3.75 rubles for a Big Mac _ more than two hours' pay. The most expensive item on the menu was a meat stew, priced at 43 kopecks, or 15 minutes' work. The cheapest was a piece of Russian black bread for 1 kopeck. Elderly women in white smocks and caps scurried around clearing tables and serving food behind a counter. There were few smiles or greetings that are musts for McDonald's employees, but customers with good eyesight could make out ``spasibo'' Russian or thank you, on each cash register receipt. Alexei and several workers of Zelyeny Ogonyok said they had heard reports about the new McDonald's, which has gotten a big dose of free publicity on state-run TV and in such publications as Pravda, Izvestia and Moscow News. ``We're waiting for them to invite our entire work collective, 120 people,'' joked Alexandra S. Bobrova, the director of Zelyeny Ogonyok.

DOC.HEAD: Couple Arrested in Schoolyard Muggings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS throughout with couple tied to nine other robberies sted 89. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A couple arrested on charges of robbing three girls in a schoolyard are also suspected in as many as nine other schoolgirl muggings, some at gunpoint, since December, police said today. Victor Gonzalez, 23, and his girlfriend, Denise Aponte, 24, were charged with robbing three girls, ages 6, 8 and 11, of their earrings and rings on Tuesday, said police spokesman Sgt. Nick Vreeland. The couple told police they were drug users and had sold the stolen property for narcotics, Vreeland said. Gonzalez and Aponte are also suspected of robbing as many as nine other girls, ages 6 to 14, since Dec. 3, Vreeland said. The Police Department originally said Gonzalez was suspected in as many as 89 other schoolgirl muggings, but Sgt. Peter Sweeney later said a police spokesman had misunderstood ``eight or nine'' robberies as ``89'' in a phone conversation.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. Jan. 30 The Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, Miss., on Bush's budget: President Bush's budget is sure to get reworked by Congress and one area that can be targeted is reducing the nation's military expenditures overseas. ... For example, CIA Director William Webster has told Congress the intelligence agency concludes that the Soviet threat to the United States and its NATO allies has diminished due to the democratizing changes in Eastern Europe. That echoed remarks by Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff. After an unprecedented meeting in Vienna of Western and Warsaw Pact top military brass, he said: ``There is nothing sacrosanct about the number of American troops stationed in Europe.'' ... Czechoslovakia and Hungary already have said they want Soviet troops off their soil this year. East Germany has proposed that all foreign troops leave both Germanys by 1999. And Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev has already said it is his goal to pull all Soviet troops off foreign soil. Savings from further trimming the overseas military budget could be used in reducing the federal deficit. We now have a chance to start turning some spears into plowshares to make America even stronger.

Jan. 30 Los Angeles Times on Bush's budget: If nothing else, President Bush's budget should stifle the notion that talk is cheap. It mentions by name one serious problem after another, yet makes clear that most of them will be around long after Washington spends the allotted $1.23 trillion. ... The White House has doctored forecasts of economic growth and interest rates to make it seem as if the deficit will shrink from $100 billion to a mere $64 billion. Economists generally think that the national debt could well grow by as much as Bush promises it will shrink, leaving the world's most prosperous nation still living way beyond its means. ... The president again puts politics and a campaign promise ahead of smart policy and rules out even minimal increases in taxes that could get government out of the red. Congress may fuss at Bush for capricious bookkeeping, but it knows as well as he that voters are less likely to punish politicians for higher deficits than for higher taxes. ... Even in the absence of new taxes, Congress and the White House will find ways to keep busy. Bush's proposal to shut down 35 military bases, each of them in the home district of some member of Congress, is bound to provide weeks or even months of argument over whether closing some other base would yield greater savings. Congress probably will cut the $4.5 billion the White House wants for ``Star Wars'' research, fight to spare domestic programs Bush would fold and quarrel over the proper level of environmental protection. But these are the ragged edges of government's obligations compared with the challenges of the national debt, the future of Social Security, rising health-care costs, education, cleaning up nuclear waste and other gathering storms.

Jan. 26 The Pioneer, Bemidji, Minn., on Social Security: The debate over the use of excess Social Security funds is an interesting dilemma for policy makers and one that the Bush administration is going to lose in the national public opinion polls. Most people weren't aware until recently that the Social Security account has been showing a positive balance ever since the program was re-engineered by Congress. The fund balance has been invested in U.S. Treasury notes, Savings Bonds and other types of government investment programs and, as a result, the federal deficit has been reduced by almost $1 billion a week over the past year. That's a $50 billion reduction in the trade deficit. Opponents are saying that the funds should stay in the Social Security Trust Fund. What these individuals fail to understand is that these funds are ultimately better being invested rather than laying dormant. However, we also feel that, if investments are to be made, there are far better choices than government securities. Private programs are administered for much higher returns.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Backing Launched for Cambodian Peace Formula
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs new with vote, quotes; picks up 6th graf pvs, The draft.
DOC.TEXT: Two House subcommittees today endorsed legislation supporting a plan by the major powers aimed at ending the fighting in Cambodia with United Nations peacekeepers and administrators. ``This represents the last, best chance for peaceful settlement of the Cambodian conflict,'' said Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-NY, sponsor of a resolution supporting the plan. Solarz' House subcommittee on Asian and Pacific affairs and the subcommittee on human rights approved the resolution with unanimous voice votes and sent it to the full Foreign Affairs Committee. Failure to implement the formula by the five permanent Security Council members to strengthen the U.N. presence in Cambodia ``could produce results almost too awful to contemplate ... return of the Khmer Rouge,'' blamed for more than a million Cambodian deaths during their 1975-78 rule over the Southeast Asian country, Solarz said. ``Anything less than a strong international presence could pave the way for a return to power of the genocidal Pol Pot,'' leader of the Khmer Rouge, said human rights subcommittee Chairman Gus Yatron, D-Pa. Yatron also urged that the administration and Congress prepare to contribute to new U.N. peacekeeping costs. President Bush's 1991 budget presented to Congress this week provides for full payment of unpaid dues to the U.N. The resolution backs the Cambodian peace formula developed by the five permanent U.N. Security Council members in Paris in mid-January along lines earlier proposed by Australia. It says China, the Soviet Union and Vietnam can improve relations with the United States by cooperating in support of the plan. The five permanent Security Council members are the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France. The draft declared that Soviet support ``for the concept of a U.N.-supervised interim administration for Cambodia and its active cooperation in facilitating an agreement will constitute new progress in U.S.-Soviet efforts to resolve regional conflicts by political means.'' It added that Chinese support and cooperation ``will help to make possible a significant improvement in U.S.-China relations,'' which soured, especially at the Congressional level, after Beijing's crackdown last summer against the pro-democracy movement. With the same promise of improved relations, the resolution invited cooperation from Vietnam, which last September declared an end to its 11-year occupation of Cambodia and has been seeking normal diplomatic relations and trade with the United States. The Soviet Union has backed Vietnam and the Vietnamese-installed Cambodian government in Phonm Penh that is not recognized by the United States, Western Countries or ASEAN, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. China long backed the communist Khmer Rouge, blamed for more than 1 million Cambodian deaths during their 1975-78 rule over Cambodia and now threatening a comeback in a revived, escalating civil war within Cambodia.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: higher returns.
DOC.TEXT: Jan. 30 Central Maine Morning Sentinel, Waterville, Maine, on drug abuse: The probable political demise of Washington Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. carries with it more than a lesson about the consequences a public official faces when he or she does not live by the law. Barry's arrest on cocaine charges, and his subsequent public confession, also demonstrates the hold drugs can have over an otherwise intelligent and rational person. Drug addiction is nothing new, of course. Indeed, by many reports, Barry's more serious problem is alcoholism, a disease that has brought about the downfall of countless people over the decades and even centuries. But in U.S. society today, no drug carries a heavier social stigma than crack cocaine. And few cities are more quickly linked to crack than Barry's own Washington. For that half-hour high, Barry risked a long and illustrious career. He knew that drug use was suspected by police, political foes and the press. Yet Barry chose to risk the personal tragedy we have all witnessed for the brief euphoria that crack brings. That is the drug's power. It is no wonder that so many people who have less to risk, who see little hope for prosperity or success or fame, turn to cocaine for relief.

Jan. 28 The Milwaukee Journal on a homeless shelter across from Watergate: Egads! That word encapsulates the reaction of many condo owners at the posh Watergate in Washington, D.C., to a planned homeless shelter across the street. The area is already riddled with ``opportunists'' who sit on grates and ask passing motorists for money, griped one homeowner. ``These are the people we'd like to get rid of.'' The owners have filed suit, claiming the shelter will lower their hefty property values. The apartments range in price from $179,000 to nearly $2.7 million. Actually, such juxtaposition of luxury and hardship has much to recommend it. It better enables the well-heeled to face up to the fact of poverty, which often results from public policy they may have supported or even helped shape. As they peer into the spartan quarters from their ritzy pads, perhaps they will learn that driving away poverty pays more than driving away the poor.

Jan. 24 Burlington County Times, Willingboro, N.J., on semiautomatic rifles ban: Gun makers are shooting holes in the Bush administration's ban on imports of semiautomatic assault rifles. Not only does the administration allow such rifles made by U.S. manufacturers to continue to be sold, but foreign companies are increasing exports of military-style assault pistols to the United States. At least five types of semiautomatic assault pistols are being imported. In a petition to the government to extend the ban to assault pistols, Handgun Control Inc, said: ``In fact, because semiautomatic pistols have similar firepower but are more concealable than their assault rifle conterparts, they present an even greater danger to public safety.'' That's a loophole that ought to be closed.

Jan. 27 The Keene (N.H.) Sentinel on Japanese computer business: American industry is enthralled by the short term. Within hours of the demise of U.S. Memories (a computer chip consortium that decided to buy cheaper Japanese chips after American firms would not finance it), every one of Japan's largest makers of memory chips announced plans to cut back on production. ... They didn't want to be accused of ... selling goods at below cost to keep a market share. So, while U.S. manufacturers were unable to get together to take even the most elementary steps to stay in the memory chip business, Japanese companies were marching in lock step, in their own interest.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: own interest.
DOC.TEXT: Jan. 28 The Providence (R.I.) Sunday Journal on Eastern Europe: Western politicians and journalists sometimes talk as if the revolutions in Eastern Europe had been won. To put it politely, their celebrations are premature. There are at least three preconditions for the success of democracy in the Soviet Union's erstwhile satellites: Free elections, the ouster of communists from control of the security apparatus and the departure of Soviet troops. None of these developments has occurred. There is a good chance that something like free elections will be held, but the other two factors make the durability of any post-election democratic governments problematical.

Jan. 27 Philadelphia Daily News on Bush and China: President Bush calls the craven Senate decision to let his craven China position stand a mandate. It is no such thing. It is merely proof that Republicans can be just as cowardly as Democrats when a vote on principle comes up. As Republican Minority Leader Robert Dole put it: ``It's not China policy. It's American politics.'' Bush happily accepts the underserved mantle of hero for invading a third-rate satellite, but continues to grovel at the feet of elderly Chinese murderers. In a non-political context, this would correctly be called cowardice.

Jan. 25 Democrat-Herald, Baker City, Ore., on spelling errors: General Motors Corp. and the San Jose Public Library recently were embarrassed in separate situations because of the problem that afflicts all of us from time to time: The inability to spell correctly. Unfortunately for those two organizations, the media found out about the errors and published stories. In one linguistic gaffe, the world's largest automaker named its latest show pickup the Mahalo. GM told those attending the North American International Auto Show the wor meant ``hang loose.'' Wrong, said Nohea Lani Wallace, an instructor at the Center for Hawaiian Studies at the University of Hawaii. He said the word ``mahalo'' frequently appears on trash cans in Hawaii. It means ``thank you'' to encourage people not to litter. ... That wasn't nearly as funny as the mistake made on a banner outside the San Jose Public Library in California. The banner, which cost $10,000 and took three months to finish, was supposed to say ``welcome'' in 27 languages. It did, in 24, but ``welcome'' was misspelled in Swedish, Dutch and Tagalog, the chief native language of the Philippines. Apparently the errors in the European languages weren't particularly embarrassing, but in Tagalog, the banner said ``circumcision.''
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Church Official Defends Shelter Given Ousted Former Leader
With AM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: A clergyman said Wednesday that his church offered lodging for Erich Honecker because the ousted East German leader was homeless, the ADN news agency reported. Justice authorities freed Honecker from prison on health grounds Tuesday, and the 77-year-old former leader who faces a treason trial in March was taken to the home of Lutheran pastor Uwe Holmer in Lobetal, near Bernau. Some parishioners were angered by Holmer's action and threatened to leave the congregation, church official Hans-Otto Furien told ADN. Furien said the church decided to give Honecker and his wife, Margot, refuge because they were ``in effect, homeless.'' The church ministers to the weak and down-and-out, and ``Honecker, who a short time ago appeared powerful, is now among them,'' ADN quoted Furien as saying. Honecker is one of about two dozen senior officials of the disgraced former leadership awaiting trial on charges of corruption and misuse of office. The man who ruled East Germany for 18 years before his ouster during a pro-democracy uprising in October was jailed Monday, immediately after he left East Berlin's Charite hospital, where was recuperating from cancer surgery. But an East Berlin court refused to issue a detention warrant, noting Honecker's ill health, and he was freed Tuesday night. Christian Naecke, a church official in Dresden, said he had received many insulting calls because Honecker had been given refuge by a fellow pastor.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Soaring Rhetoric Left Along With Speechwriter Noonan
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's State of the Union speechwriters had a hard act to follow: matching nuggets once provided by wordsmith Peggy Noonan, who coined ``a thousand points of light'' and ``read my lips'' but who now suggests her job was neither kind nor gentle. Noonan has been out of favor at the White House since she left last year to write a book about her days as a speechwriter for both Bush and former President Reagan. She says aides to both men continually pounced on her words and sought to do major overhauls on her speeches, that Bush balked at reading any lines that contained the word ``I,'' and that Reagan, the ``Great Communicator,'' was at a loss for words when she asked what moved him in his eight years as president. White House officials say Noonan, who lives in New York, has not been asked to work on a Bush speech since last year's inaugural address because of a new policy to do all speeches ``in house.'' Aides privately say that Noonan was getting a trifle too famous for a speechwriter who is supposed to be, well, mostly anonymous. But they also concede Bush hasn't sounded quite so striking since she stopped putting words in his mouth. ``The underpinnings of the United States, the state of the union, is not bad,'' Bush told a group of newspaper publishers last week when asked to preview his Wednesday night address. ``Not bad,'' might be an honest assessment. But it doesn't have much ring. In Bush's 1989 inaugural address, he spoke of a ``new breeze'' blowing through the totalitarian world. He promised Democratic leaders an ``age of the offered hand.'' And he summed up the nation's budget woes in six words: ``We have more will than wallet.'' Vintage Noonan _ and the last speech she wrote for him. Noonan recounts her experiences as a speechwriter for Bush and Reagan in her book, ``What I Saw at the Revolution: A Political Life in the Reagan Era,'' published last week. Bush has made no secret of his disdain for insider books written by former aides, and the publication of Noonan's book hardly helped to heal any rift between her and the White House. When she began writing speeches for Bush in the 1988 campaign, Noonan writes, he gave her a list of words with special meaning to him: ``family, grandkids, love, decency, honor, pride, tolerance, hope, kindness, loyalty, freedom, caring, heart, faith, service to country, fair (fair play), strength, healing, excellence.'' From those threads she began weaving Bush's speeches. But she ran up against one major obstacle: ``George Bush hated to say `I.''' ``I became adept at pronounless sentences,'' Noonan says. ``Instead of `I moved to Texas and soon we joined the Republican Party,' it was `Moved to Texas, joined the Republican Party, raised a family.''' Noonan suggests Bush's modesty came from his ``doughty old mom,'' Dorothy Walker Bush, ``who used to rap his knuckles for bragging, a brag apparently being defined as any sentence with the first person singular as its subject.'' She confesses visions of Bush taking the oath on the Capitol steps with these words: ``Do solemnly swear, will preserve and protect. ...''' Bush's characterization of a ``kinder, gentler nation,'' contained in his acceptance speech to the Republican National Convention, has become one of the president's signature phrases. But, Noonan writes, it was just ``kinder nation'' in her first draft. She later scribbled in ``gentler.'' Bush's ``no new taxes'' line, also in the same widely acclaimed acceptance speech, was suggested by Jack Kemp, now the secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Noonan says. But she takes all the credit for ``read my lips,'' even though Bush aides tried to take it out because ``there is no history of presidential candidates making personal-organ references in acceptance speeches.'' Bush left it in. One line he scratched out: a reference to Michael Dukakis' physical stature. Noonan claims credit for Bush's ``thousand points of light,'' but allows it might have been influenced by a line from a favorite author, Thomas Wolfe, who wrote in ``The Web and the Rock'' of a ``thousand points of friendly light.'' Noonan, who also wrote Reagan's farewell television speech to the nation, says she had trouble drawing out the ``Great Communicator'' in five drafting sessions she had with him in the last two months of his term. When she asked him what his most difficult day was, Reagan responded: ``Oh well, I don't know.'' She then asked Reagan if he sometimes felt like the ``boy in the bubble?'' ``Who was that?'' Noonan says he asked. ``The boy who had no immune system, so he had to live in a plastic bubble where he could see everyone and they could see him but ... he couldn't touch them,'' she tells him. Reagan's reply: ``Well, no.'' Bush's White House now has five speechwriters _ Mark Davis, Mark Lange, Daniel McGroaty, Edward E. McNally and Curt Smith _ who make a point of maintaining low profiles, refuse to be interviewed and aren't even well known to other White House staffers. McGroaty, 32, who was a speechwriter for defense secretaries Caspar W. Weinberger and Frank C. Carlucci, did the initial draft of Wednesday's State of the Union address. It was refined by Chief of Staff John Sununu and White House communications director David Demarest. New York media consultant Roger Ailes, who worked for Bush's 1988 campaign, worked with Bush Tuesday and Wednesday on preparation.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Bypasses Ivory Coast's New Basilica
With AM-Pope
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II's tour of impoverished Sahel nations this week bypassed this city, which is home to the newly built and largest Roman Catholic basilica in the world. Ivorian President Felix Houphouet-Boigny donated the basilica to the Roman Catholic church, and met with John Paul last year to urge him to consecrate it during his current African trip. The government-controlled news media has waged a campaign to win support from Roman Catholics, who comprise 15 percent of the West African nation's population, for the basilica. The president has been shown attending Roman Catholic events and praising the pope. But the basilica has been criticized as a waste of resources in a country suffering from shortages of basic medicines, crowded classrooms and an economy reeling from depressed prices for its agricultural exports. Houphouet-Boigny defends construction of the basilica, which officially cost about $130 million, saying he built it with his own funds. Independent assessments put the cost at possibly twice that amount, and the use of government departments in construction makes an accurate estimate difficult. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro defended the pope's decision not to consecrate the Ivorian basilica. ``The pope cannot consecrate every basilica in the world. Every year he gets thousands of invitations and he cannot satisfy everyone,'' Navarro said last month. The basilica, with air-conditioned pews, has seven acres of Italian marble tiles and four times more stained glass than the French cathedral at Chartres. It is designed to hold 300,000, and dwarfs other structures in the president's native village, which he has declared the national capital. A papal visit would have been a sharp constrast to the desperately poor villages he visited an hour's jet ride to the north in Burkina Faso and Mali. Meanwhile, the basilica, completed in September, awaits consecration. The government-published daily Fraternite Matin reported last week that the Roman Catholic episcopate will report on the basilica to the pope later this year. The newspaper said the pope will include Ivory Coast on a trip to Africa planned for later this year, but it did not say if he would consecrate the basilica. The episcopate has agreed to accept the basilica, but diplomatic sources said that in addition to the question of propriety, the church was concerned about the millions of dollars it would cost annually for maintenance. Even if Houphouet-Boigny, 84, is prepared to pay these costs, the question was whether future governments would honor such a commitment.

DOC.HEAD: Squatter Ordered Evicted From Ramshackle Home
DOC.TEXT: A judge today ordered the eviction of a 72-year-old woman who has been living for nearly 20 years in a ramshackle homestead on the proposed site of a state park. Doris Gagnon was granted an automatic 20-day stay, and Superior Court Judge Judge Karen Sequino said it is likely the woman will be found eligible for a stay of up to nine months. ``I am sorry our system is this way and our average citizen cannot get justice,'' Gagnon said after her defeat. During a hearing Tuesday, Gagnon said she preferred to live with dozens of animals at her makeshift home on state property than move to senior citizen housing. ``I'm not a bingo player. I can't sit around all day,'' she said. State attorneys had said Gagnon and her neighbors in the city of Milford would be better off if she were evicted from the site where she has lived without electricity, running water, a phone and adequate sanitation. Gagnon has been fighting the state ever since the mid-1960s, when efforts began to establish a park on the 200-acre site along Long Island Sound. Her cottage was demolished in 1971, but she refused to leave the area, living out of her car for a year before erecting a tin shed. For the past decade, she has lived in dilapidated trailers and makeshift structures along with a menagerie that now includes three cats, three dogs, two geese, 12 ducks and about 50 chickens. The state moved to evict Gagnon last year as a result of a complaint filed by the Milford health department, which said it found bags of human sewage piled up behind her living quarters. Gagnon's attorney, Karen Torre, said she planned to ask the judge to give her client, who has been battling cancer, at least three more years on the land. Although a $5 million project to seal a landfill in the northern section of the proposed park and create an access road is scheduled to get under way next month, further development of the park so that it can be used for recreational purposes is still two to three years away, state officials have said. Gagnon, who sported an ``Enjoy Your Age'' button on her short-sleeve white-and-blue sweater, told the court Tuesday she could not leave her animals. ``When the city was doing things to me, they were my only consolation outside of my friends,'' she said. She denied having regularly dumped bags of sewage outside her trailers. But Gagnon also testified that she had never had the sewage tanks in her trailers cleaned out, and a witness recalled her saying she dumped all the waste in a garbage bin.

DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb in Kabul Kills Six, Injures 122
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded in the central business district in Afghanistan's capital of Kabul on Wednesday, killing six people and injuring another 122, Afghanistan's official radio reported. ``The material used in the explosion was provided by Pakistan and the United States,'' said the Radio Kabul broadcast monitored in Islamabad. The broadcast blamed the U.S.-backed guerrillas for the bomb, although no group claimed responsibility. Most of the anti-Communist guerrillas who have been fighting for more than 11 years to topple successive communist governments are based in Pakistan. The United States sends guerrilla fighters an estimated $500 million worth of military supplies annually through Pakistan. Moscow sends about $300 million to its allies in Kabul. The Kremlin ended nine years of direct military intervention in Afghanistan in February 1989. Radio Kabul estimated property damage in Wednesday's blast at $2,000. Scores of people have been killed and hundreds more injured in rocket attacks on Kabul in the past several months. Radio Kabul has blamed the Moslem insurgents. Guerrilla fighters claim their rockets and bombs are directed at military installations, not civilian targets. They admit that stray rockets sometimes land in residential areas, but often charge the Kabul government with rocketing its own people to turn the population against the guerrillas. Claims made by either side often are impossible to verify.

DOC.HEAD: President Carlos Andres Perez Completes Difficult First Year
DOC.TEXT: President Carlos Andres Perez was elected by a landslide, but has angered nearly everyone during his first year with economic reforms that provoked bloody riots and drove up the cost of living. Many foreign dignitaries attended his lavish inauguration Feb. 2, 1989, including President Fidel Castro of Cuba, Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez of Spain and Vice President Dan Quayle of the United States. His victory reflected the popularity gained in his first term as president, in 1974-79. The approval evaporated when Perez imposed the austerity demanded by foreign lenders in return for help with Venezuela's debt of $33 billion. A week of riots against price increases for food and public transport cost 300 lives. Thousands of people were injured and thousands of businesses set afire. Perez now faces severe criticism from just about every sector of Venezuelan politics, including leaders of his own social democratic party, Democratic Action. ``His heart's not in it,'' an American businessman said privately. ``I've been amazed to see him carry out these reforms against all the odds.'' A new round of criticism began when Perez said new increases were planned in the price of gasoline produced by state-owned oil conglomerate Petroleos de Venezuela. Venezuela is a major oil producers and its gasoline prices have been among the lowest in the world. Even after last year's increases, a gallon of regular costs the equivalent of only 13 cents. When reporters asked Perez recently whether he would go ahead with new increases despite protests, he responded: ``My God, if were up to me I would dissolve our agreements with the International Monetary Fund. But we live in the Western world, and in order to live in the Western world and get agreements with Western banks, we have to do certain things.'' The IMF, World Bank and other lenders, agreed to provide $8 billion to $10 billion over five years to support the economic reform program and help Venezuela pay its foreign debt. Reforms include ending gasoline and other subsidied; tariff reforms aimed at increasing both imports and exports; making state enterprises more efficient, and other free-market measures. A recent poll conducted by the newspaper El Universal indicated 55 percent of Venezuelans favored a return to the old system of subsidized prices and economic regulation, while only 28 percent approved of the reforms. Of those polled, 32 percent said Perez was doing an average job, 21.7 percent said his performance was poor and 18 percent found his conduct of the presidency to be good. Fifteen percent rated him ``very bad'' 6.5 percent ``very good.'' rating. The U.S. businessman said: ``Perez is doing very well. The steps he's taken so far show he's willing to hold out against the opposition, even in his own party, to his economic program.'' Nearly everyone has been effected by changes that have shrunk the economy by 8.1 percent and pushed inflation to a record 80.7 percent in 1989. Poverty and unemployment have increased. Labor leaders claim the unempoloyment rate is 20 percent, more than double the official figure. ``My balance of the year is totally negative,'' said Cesar Olarte, head of the Confederation of Venezuelan Workers. ``Perez promised growth without inflation, and look what we've got: inflation and recession.'' His organization, long an ally of governments that have employed one-quarter of the nation's 6 million workers, recently decided to step up protests of the economic program. Olarte said the austerity plan ``has only brought misery and suffering. It has to be stopped, or at least implemented more gradually. Perez is being insensitive. He should know, as a politician, to listen to the people instead of his advisers. Democracy could be in danger.'' In contrast, Tomas Paez, planning director of the Development Ministry, said: ``Critical poverty and unemployment are nothing new in Venezuela. They are not the product of the reforms, but the other way around. ``The reforms are trying to change an industrial system that was inefficient, could not compete, depended on government protection and only generated 5,000 jobs a year.'' Economists say it will take two to five years for the reform program to start benefiting the average Venezuelan.

DOC.HEAD: Experts Call for Wider Distribution of Anti-AIDS Drug
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to specify early stages; SUBS 6th graf, Last August, to add that trials included HIV-infected people with no symptoms; SUBS 8th graf, The drug, to correct that T-4 cell counts under 200 signal advanced stage of disease, not necessarily full-blown AIDS
DOC.TEXT: A panel of experts is recommending that the anti-AIDS drug AZT be prescribed more widely for people in early stages of infection by the virus that causes AIDS. Research has ``clearly established'' that AZT, or zidovudine, delays the onset of AIDS in people infected with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, the Food and Drug Administration advisory committee said Tuesday. But the committee also emphasized ``the need to carefully study and document the potential risks associated with prolonged zidovudine therapy, especially those related to the drug's cancer-causing potential, and any possible unique effects on women's fetuses and children.'' AZT is approved for use in patients who have full-blown AIDS, but a government-sponsored study has shown the drug can prolong the lives of people in earlier stages of the disease. Some physicians already prescribe the drug for people with early or no symptoms of AIDS. Last August, officials at the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases announced that clinical trials showed AZT significantly slows progression of AIDS in patients with early symptoms and no symptoms. The results were so promising that of officials stopped the clinical trial and began offering AZT to all patients in the study, including those who had been receiving placebos for comparison. The Antiviral Drugs Advisory Committee unanimously agreed the FDA should recommend use of AZT in people with levels of critical immune system cells, called T-4 cells, under 500 per cubic millimeter. The drug is now recommended for use in people whose T-4 cells are below 200. Disease in such patients is considered to be in an advanced stage and many such patients have full-blown AIDS. AZT, made by Burroughs Wellcome Co., is the only FDA-approved drug that combats the AIDS virus directly. It is being used by more than 40,000 people in the United States. As many as 500,000 of the estimated 800,000 to 1.3 million people in the United States infected with HIV, the virus that causes AIDS, are believed to have T-4 cell counts between 200 and 500, according to the Public Health Service. However, many of these people do not know they are infected with HIV. Two weeks ago, the FDA cut in half the recommended dose of AZT for AIDS patients who are on the medication for more than a month. The agency cited studies showing the half-dose regimen was less likely to produce side effects but just as effective as the higher dose in prolonging survival and reducing the frequency of infections that often kill.

DOC.HEAD: Relief Agency to Increase Food Deliveries to Southern Sudan
DOC.TEXT: A relief agency said it plans to increase food deliveries Thursday to the beleaguered southern Sudan town of Juba, where civilians are reported starving while war rages around them. The Lutheran World Federation's office in Nairobi said it would add a chartered Hercules C-130 to the Boeing 707 it already leases from Sudan Airways for the relief flights. ``What it means is that we will be able to deliver food there daily, without interruption,'' said Bob Koepp, who is in charge of the Lutheran group's activities in southern Sudan. Koepp said Wednesday the addition of the Hercules will bring to 64 tons the amount of food being delivered daily to Juba by the group. Koepp said the Hercules would hasten the delivery of 2,000 tons of corn donated by the Italian government that has been sitting at Nairobi's airport. The Sudanese government banned relief flights into southern Sudan on Nov. 3 after a cease-fire with the rebels broke down, and Juba's only source of food since then has been the flights from the Lutheran World Federation. Koepp appealed to rebel and government forces to ``please respect and allow the aircraft and its crews free and safe passage.'' But the rebel Sudan People's Liberation Army, which has sporadically bombarded Juba with artillery fire, was noncommittal. ``This is the first time I have heard of the additional aircraft,'' said Lam Akol, a rebel spokesman. ``In any case, they go in at their own risk.'' Only the Lutherans have delivered non-Sudanese government food supplies to Juba since Sudan's government banned relief flights Nov. 3 after an informal cease-fire with the rebels broke down. Relief workers evacuated from Juba this week described a city of panic. They said thousands of people are starving but cannot leave the city of 300,000 because it is ringed with mines laid by government troops and the rebels. The mines ``have weekly claimed the lives of people searching for firewood and-or food,'' says an American Catholic priest in a letter to colleagues in Nairobi and Washington D.C. The clergyman, the Rev. Todd Riebe of Indianapolis, is a high school principal in Juba and has opted to stay. He appealed for international pressure to halt ``the impending massacre'' of Juba's people. ``We are facing a human tragedy of immense proportions,'' Riebe wrote in the letter, which was made available to The Associated Press. The Sudan People's Liberation Army launched its rebellion in early 1983, demanding greater autonomy and economic reforms in the three southern provinces of Bahr el-Ghazal, Upper Nile and Equatoria.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Wants to Make Sure Poor Get Rebates
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of church, labor and policy groups launched a nationwide education effort Wednesday to ensure that more than 11 million low-income families receive a tax rebate for which they are eligible. ``It's a crime to think that this money is available and so many people are not taking advantage of it and they have earned it,'' said James Moran, mayor of Alexandria, Va. Most low-income people know about Medicaid, public assistance, food stamps, school lunch and other government programs for the poor, but significantly fewer have heard of the earned income credit, said Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, an independent research group. ``This is not a public assistance program. It's not a welfare program,'' Greenstein said. ``It is an earned benefit that only families which work are eligible for and only families who live with and care for their children may receive.'' The earned income tax credit was created by Congress in 1974 to offset the impact of Social Security payroll taxes on the working poor. Families with at least one child living at home for half the year and earned or adjusted gross income of less than $19,340 in 1989 are eligible. Organizers didn't estimate how many families are eligible for the credit, but said 11 million taxpayers received $6 billion in credits last year. The groups planned to distribute 11,000 information packets through churches, civic groups and state and local government offices. The AFL-CIO also has produced a public service announcement in Spanish. The credit varies with individual households. With annual income of between $6,500 and $10,240, a parent taxpayer is eligible for a $910 credit. Families with income less than $6,500 are eligible for a credit equal to 14 percent of that incoe. The credit decreases once income exceeds $10,240 and phases out at $19,340 earned or adjusted gross income. Rural and Hispanic families, who make up a disproportionate number of low-income wage earners and don't owe income tax, will be a special target for the campaign. ``The concern is that these families, owing no federal income tax ... may believe that there's no need to file an income tax return,'' Greenstein said. ``They may think that if they don't owe any income tax they can't get credit, but the IRS will mail them a check for the full amount of the credit for which they are eligible.'' If they don't file the return, they lose the credit, Greenstein said. Eligible workers can receive the credit in their regular paychecks throughout the year by filing a W-5 form with their employers. Other groups in the coalition include the National Council of La Raza, U.S. Catholic Conference, the National Governors' Association, the United Way and the National Restaurant Association. Coalition members said they chose Wednesday to begin their campaign because it marked the unofficial start of the 1989 income tax season and the last day for employers to mail W-2 income withholding statements to workers.

DOC.HEAD: West Germans Praise Gorbachev Statement on Reunification
With AM-Yugoslavia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West German leaders on Wednesday praised President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's apparent acceptance of reunification as a signal that may instill hope in East Germans fearful of the uncertainties of reform. Chancellor Helmut Kohl called the Kremlin chief's latest comments on German unity ``encouraging,'' and Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Gorbachev had ``correctly analyzed'' the volatile situation in East Germany. East Germany's official news agency ADN said that by making clear his change of mind on the German question, Gorbachev ``once more confirmed for all the world his reputation as a politician of realism.'' Support for union with prosperous West Germany has surged among East Germans in recent weeks as the depths of their political and economic crises have become clear. East German Premier Hans Modrow acknowledged in a speech to Parliament this week that the nation was on the verge of economic collapse, and said mounting tensions forced him to move up free elections to March 18. As many as 2,500 East Germans have been leaving each day, convinced that they stand a better chance starting over in the West than trying to rebuild their nation driven to the brink of destruction by 40 years of Communist mismanagement. Anti-Communist sentiment has swelled among the population of 16 million, sparking mass demonstrations and labor strikes to protest the distrusted party's continued hold on the reins of power. A Lutheran pastor gave refuge to former leader Erich Honecker after he was released from prison Tuesday, and church officials reported Wednesday that their humanitarian action prompted insulting phone calls and threats by parishioners to leave the church. Honecker, who ruled for 18 years before being forced out of office in October by the peaceful pro-democracy uprising, faces trial in March on a treason charge. Modrow, a reformer who is more trusted than most of his fellow Communists, was forced by the growing hostility toward his still-dominant party to bring nine opposition representatives into his Cabinet. The pro-democracy forces joining Modrow were to submit their proposed ministers by Wednesday, and three of the parties publicly announced the names of the representatives they put forward. The Social Democrats, who were hesitant to enter into a coalition with the political parties blamed for East Germany's current crises, nominated Walter Romberg, who has not played a prominent role in the party to date. The Initiative for Peace and Human Rights proposed Gerd Poppe and Democracy Now offered Wolfgang Ullmann. Poppe and Ullmann are negotiators for their respective groups at the weekly talks that advise Modrow's interim government. In Bonn, Kohl devoted much of his address at a Cabinet meeting to the issue of German unity and the exodus of East Germans that is inflicting social and economic strains on both sides of the border. Government spokesman Hans Klein, a member of the West German Cabinet, said Kohl found Gorbachev's views on reunification ``encouraging.'' Gorbachev commented during talks with Modrow in Moscow on Tuesday that a single German state was likely in the future, although he cautioned that East Germans ``should not decide this important issue on the streets.'' Weekly pro-democracy rallies in Leipzig and other major cities have taken on a clear pro-reunification atmosphere recently. West German newspapers reported Gorbachev's comments prominently and hailed his apparent acceptance of German reunification as coming to grips with reality. ``Gorbachev has once again shown himself to be a politician of realism who has correctly analyzed the developments in East Germany and the will of the people,'' Genscher told West German Radio. Klein quoted Kohl as telling his Cabinet that Gorbachev's tentative approval of eventual reunification could give East Germans hope of better days to come and halt the exodus. ``We want all people in East Germany to find their opportunities in life in their own land,'' Kohl said, according to Klein. ``Resettlement must be left as a last resort. Jobs and homes are in limited supply in West Germany.'' The West German Constitution recognizes all ethnic Germans as citizens and provides them with generous resettlement aid when they immigrate. But the influx of more than 340,000 East Germans last year and an exit trend that threatens to drive a million more to the West this year has heightened social tensions in West Germany. Kohl suggested Gorbachev had eased the fears of East Germans by making clear that the Kremlin would not stand in the way of reunification.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Indicators Up, But Analysts Say Economy Still Weak
DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge rose in December at its fastest pace in eight months, the government said Wednesday, but analysts suggested the economy remains weak athough able to avoid a recession. The Commerce Department said the Index of Leading Economic Indicators rose 0.8 percent last month, helping to inch the forecasting gauge up 0.4 percent for the year. It was the weakest increase since the index actually fell 1.5 percent in 1984. And since the index rose just 0.4 percent for the year, compared with an increase of 3.9 percent for all of 1988, it suggests the economy could be more sluggish this year than in 1989. The index is designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months in the future. ``The leading indicators were essentially flat for most of 1989,'' noted Kevin Logan, chief economist for the Swiss Bank Corp. in New York. ``They basically moved sideways and that's the situation for the economy at the moment.'' David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, had a similar assessment, saying the December increase ``really overstates the economy's strength over the near term, the next 6 to 12 months.'' Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, also cautioned against reading too much into one month's change although he said the administration believes the economy will be improving through the year. Boskin spoke to reporters after an appearance before the House Budget Committee in which he defended the administration's economic forecast for 1990, which projects the overall economy will grow by 2.4 percent while interest rates will come down _ a projection questioned by many private economists. In another report, the department said new home sales, pinched by severe weather, declined 9.6 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 629,000 units in December. That put sales for the year at 650,000, down 3.8 percent from 1988 in large part because of high mortgage interest rates. It was the slowest pace since 1984, when 639,000 new homes were sold. Analysts agreed that most of the increase in the December leading index came from unfilled aircraft orders, partly due to a strike at the Boeing Co. and partly because such orders often take months to fill after they are made. But many, like Berson, also agreed with Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, who told Congress on Tuesday that the economy is unlikely to fall into a recession. ``We're not going to have a recession,'' Berson said. ``There's still a risk, but most likely the economy will strengthen a little bit in the first quarter and more by the middle of the year.'' Others were more concerned. ``I think that we're very, very close'' to a recession, said Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic adviser for the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``I mean, we're as close to being in a recession without being in one as you can be.'' In addition to the backlog of manufacturers' unfilled orders, other contributors to the December increase were an increase in plant and equipment orders, higher stock prices, a rise in the money supply, an increase in building permits and a gain in an index measuring consumer confidence. A drop in the price of raw materials was the major negative factor in the index. While such a decrease is considered good news for inflation prospects, it is counted as a negative in the index because it also can reflect declining demand. Other negatives were an increase in weekly unemployment claims, a decline in orders for consumer goods and a speedup in business delivery times. The average work week was unchanged. The various changes left the index at 145.7 percent of its 1982 base of 100. For the year, the index posted increases in seven months: January, April, July, August, September, November and December. It declined in February, March, May, June and October.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial Priest Defies Request to Resign from Service
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS that priest not suspended but asked to refrain from performing priestly duties, UPDATES with priest's remarks to newspaper, bishop saying priest resigned from Oasis ministry. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A gay Episcopal priest who caused an uproar with his comments on celibacy and monogamy says he will not honor a request that he refrain from priestly duties while the diocese investigates his views. Bishop John S. Spong asked the Rev. Robert Williams not to function as a priest while the Commission on Ministry reviews the screening process that led to his ordination, Assisting Bishop Walter Righter of Newark said Tuesday. ``It means he doesn't have a job in the church,'' Righter said.
