However, in an interview from Texas on Tuesday with The Star-Ledger of Newark, Williams, 34, said Spong would have to bring him to an ecclesiastical trial to strip him of his duties. ``If he wants to spend another quarter-million dollars, he can take me to trial,'' Williams said. He said complying with Spong's request would ``keep me from exercising the ministry I've been called to do.'' Church officials are investigating whether Williams misled the commission about his views during the screening process. He told the newspaper he was never questioned about his views on monogamy before he was approved for ordination. Spong said Williams has resigned at his request from his position as executive director of The Oasis, a Hoboken ministry for gay men and women, following comments he made at a Jan. 13 church forum in Detroit in which he said ``monogamy is as unnatural as celibacy.'' Williams, a Texas native, was asked not to conduct Mass this weekend for a homosexual group in Dallas called The Integrity, The Dallas Morning News reported. Keith Hobbs, secretary of the group, said members did not want their goal of working within the church to be ``clouded over by some of these issues.'' Williams was ordained Dec. 16 by Spong despite objections from many church conservatives. The homosexual priest has lived with James Skelly, 39, a hospital administrator, for four years. Spong has asked Williams to apologize for his statements on monogamy and celibacy. Williams said he will look at other options, including another church, if his ministry is permanently suspended. ``Bishops don't ordain people,'' Williams told The Dallas Morning News. ``The Holy Spirit does. My ministry to the gay and lesbian community will continue whether or not it's in the Episcopal Church.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Hijacker Appeals for Political Asylum
DOC.TEXT: A Chinese man who hijacked a Chinese airliner to Japan in December asked Wednesday for political asylum, saying the act was his last-ditch attempt to flee political persecution. Zhang Zhenhai, of China's Hebei province, said in a statement released through his Japanese lawyers that he would face the death penalty in China because he had joined in the pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing last June. Zhang, who faces possible repatriation under international law, said that before the hijacking, he had failed twice to escape China by land due to tight security after the bloody suppression of pro-democracy demonstrators. ``Please do not send me back to China,'' his statement asked of the Japanese government. ``Please give me freedom ... or repatriate me only after my execution (in Japan).'' Zhang, 35, hijacked the plane on Dec. 16, threatening to blow it up with a bomb that he did not actually have. The Boeing 747, on a flight from Beijing to New York with 233 people aboard, flew to Fukuoka in western Japan after South Korea refused to let it land there. After landing, Zhang was shoved out of the plane by a crew member and was hospitalized with a broken pelvis. The plane was returned to China on Dec. 17 with 208 passengers on board, including Zhang's wife and 13-year-old son. Zhang was transferred from a hospital to a jail in Fukuoka on Dec. 31, and sent to a detention house in Tokyo Jan. 11. The Tokyo High Public Prosecutors Office is studying what action to take against Zhang. Action is likely in March, when his condition is expected to improve, said Masahiro Sumita, one of Zhang's three Japanese lawyers. China has demanded Zhang's return, and China's state-run TV has carried brief reports on the hijacking, adding that Zhang had been arrested in October on charges of embezzling from a factory. Japanese officials, including Chief Cabinet Secretary Mayumi Moriyama, have maintained that even if Zhang's claim is true, hijacking is still a serious crime. Kazuyo Iwaki, another Japanese lawyer, has said that Zhang claimed he had been arrested twice in connection with pro-democracy demonstrations in China. On Wednesday, Sumita, Ms. Iwaki and a third lawyer, Yaeko Takeoka, notified the prosecutors office that they would represent Zhang until the Tokyo High Court decides whether to sent him back to China. ``Next week we will apply to the court for Zhang's status as a refugee,'' Sumita said. Sumita said he and the other two lawyers have volunteered to represent Zhang free of charge ``for humanity's sake.'' In a case like Zhang's, each of the three lawyers normally would charge about $7,000 in fees if the case were settled in a few months, he added.

DOC.HEAD: Interior Panel OKs Settlement of Damages Due Seminoles
DOC.TEXT: The House Interior Committee voted Wednesday to settle a 14-year-old dispute among the Seminole Indians by giving 73 percent of about $50 million in federal damages to the Oklahoma tribe and 27 percent to Seminoles in Florida. The distribution differs from legislation passed in November by the Senate that calls for an approximately 75-25 split, but it represents a compromise in the House, where the Florida delegation was seeking 30 percent of the money for its branch of the tribe. The bill now goes to the full House for a vote and, if approved in the form passed by the committee, will go to a conference committee to work out differences with the Senate version. Originally, the Florida Seminoles pushed for a 50-50 distribution, leading to a disagreement that the Indians could not settle among themselves. The dispute began in 1976, when the Seminoles were awarded $16 million for Florida lands taken during the 1823 relocation of most of the tribe to Oklahoma. The money, which has been held by the Treasury Department because of the disagreement over its distribution, grew to $50 million through years of accumulated interest. In the absence of agreement among the Seminoles, the government worked out the 75-25 split based on population figures that counted 2,146 Seminoles in Oklahoma and 700 in Florida. The government also found the Oklahoma tribe to be poorer, with only about 380 acres of tribally owned land, while the Florida branch, which includes the Miccosukee Tribe of Florida and the unaffiliated Seminole Indians of Florida, has about 80,000 acres.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Will Seek Retrial in McMartin Child-Molestation Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details, quotes, motion for new judge. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors today said they will retry Raymond Buckey on the 13 conspiracy and child-molestation charges on which a jury deadlocked during the marathon McMartin Pre-school trial. Superior Court Judge William Pounders accepted the decision to go forward with a new trial and urged that it begin quickly because ``the range of emotions is very high.'' Pounders set a trial date of March 9. Deputy District Attorneys Lael Rubin and Roger Gunson ended the suspense that had surrounded the case since Jan. 18, when the jury in the longest and costliest criminal trial in U.S. history acquitted Buckey and his mother on 52 molestation charges but deadlocked on 13 counts against Buckey. Prosecutors had the option of dismisssing the remaining counts but after days of meetings with District Attorney Ira Reiner decided to proceed. Buckey, 31, and his 63-year-old mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, had been accused of molesting 11 children at their Manhattan Beach preschool during a five-year period. In the two weeks since the acquittals, the preschoolers' parents, the children and rgwue allies have appeared on national television, called news conferences, collected letters of support and enlisted politicians in support of a retrial. ``This is a positive step for us,'' said Mary Mae Cioffi, a McMartin parent who has led the campaign to retry Buckey. ``I'm going to run home and tell my kids we get another chance.'' The trial lasted nearly three years and cost taxpayers more than $13 million. Buckey spent nearly five years in jail before he was released on $1.5 million bail last February. The future of the case was complicated by a motion filed by Buckey's attorney claiming Pounders is biased against the defendant and should be removed from the case. Defense attorney Danny Davis said Pounders had made comments throughout the trial indicating his belief that the defendants were guilty and had expressed prejudice against Davis himself. Pounders denied the allegations and said he would file a response proving he is unbiased and able to preside at the new trial. The judge said he knew of no other judge who would want to take over the controversial case.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Church to Silence Bells that Annoy Neighbors
DOC.TEXT: A judge who said a church's electronic bells inflicted ``harm and damages'' on neighbors has ordered them silenced until a court hearing helps the two sides reach a compromise. A lawyer for Bellshire United Methodist Church said the church had turned down the carillon to 50 percent of its power and was preparing to move its speakers higher on the steeple to further reduce the sound. Vaughan Pritchett, one of three neighbors who sued Dec. 18 to stop the bells, said lowering the power did not help. ``Noise alone may be a nuisance to those affected when, because of its volume, character, proximity or unreasonableness, it causes material distress, discomfort or injury,'' Chancellor C. Allen High wrote in his opinion Monday. After the lawsuit was filed, the chimes sounded nine times a day into the early evening. Pritchett said they could not be heard Wednesday. He said residents were not protesting the content of the music, only its loudness. Church attorney George Cate Jr. said Bellshire United would request another hearing soon. The carillon was installed in September with $7,700 donated by a former church member in memory of her son, said the Rev. Stephen Smith, pastor at Bellshire.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk Orders Probe Into Jail Hanging
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk ordered a judicial inquiry Wednesday into the death of a 20-year-old black man found hanged in his prison cell. The man was arrested Friday along with four others accused in the slayings of 10 people in guerrilla attacks over the past two years. He reportedly was a former lover of jailed black leader Nelson Mandela's daughter. Clayton Sithole was found hanging from a shower pipe Tuesday at John Vorster Square, Johannesburg's central police station, police said. Shortly after Sithole's death was announced, de Klerk ordered a judicial inquiry, a step not taken after scores of previous incidents in which black activists died while in police custody. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok expressed condolences to Sithole's family. According to local newspapers, Sithole was a former lover of Zindzi Mandela and fathered one of her three children. There was no immediate comment from the Mandelas, but associates of the family said they believed the report was accurate. A family friend of the Mandelas, who requested anonymity, said Sithole belonged to a controversial group of young men who served as Winnie Mandela's bodyguards. Nine people associated with the group have been in custody for months awaiting trial for the death of a young black activist. Neither Vlok nor de Klerk indicated whether the decision to launch an investigation was related to Sithole's reported connection to the Mandela family. Mandela, 71, is widely expected to be freed in the next few weeks after more than 27 years in prison for his role in planning the guerrilla campaign of the African National Congress. The organization is the main black group fighting the white-led government. Denis Worrall, co-leader of the anti-apartheid Democratic Party, welcomed de Klerk's swift response. ``It is surprising that President de Klerk would do this,'' Worrall said. ``I'm quite sure that a judicial commission of inquiry would be justified.'' Audrey Coleman, a prominent human rights activist, said Sithole's family suspected the young man had been mistreated and would obtain its own pathologist to conduct an independent post mortem. Police said Sithole confessed to a magistrate before his death, implicating himself in several killings. Police reportedly were investigating whether Sithole and the other suspects were ANC guerrillas. About 100 ANC guerrillas and anti-apartheid activists have died in police custody in the past 25 years. According to police, suicide by hanging has been the most common cause of these deaths, but human rights groups have insisted interrogators mistreated many of these prisoners. In other developments Wednesday: _ About 3,500 demonstrators in Cape Town peacefully marched on police headquarters to present a petition condemning police actions in a Jan. 23 protest, which was broken up by rubber bullets and water cannon. _ In the central city of Bloemfontein, about 1,000 blacks arrived by bus and van to protest against a boycott-breaking English cricket team, which was in the second day of a three-day match against a team of university players. _ Police said a policeman was among three people killed in political violence in black townships around the port city of Durban. _ About 4,500 blacks marched on municipal offices in the black township of Daveyton, east of Johannesburg, smashing windows and setting furniture afire, police said. The protest followed a rumor that a child was killed when authorities dismantled squatter shacks. Police said they had no evidence a child was killed.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Fires on Freighter Suspected of Carrying Drugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to ADD number of rounds fired, CORRECTS that Cuba charges attack took place in Mexican waters; PICKS UP 9th graf pvs, `Cuba's official ...'
DOC.TEXT: A Coast Guard cutter fired cannon and machine-gun rounds at a Cuban-operated merchant ship suspected of carrying drugs in the Gulf of Mexico today, but the vessel escaped into Mexican waters, officials said. The 250-foot Panamanian-registered freighter Hermann took at least two direct hits without stopping, said Coast Guard spokesman Joe Gibson. There was no word on injuries. ``We were in international waters,'' Gibson said. ``We cannot pursue vessels into other country's waters.'' Gibson said the Coast Guard asked the Mexican government to board the ship and inspect its cargo. Capt. Aristides Palma Palma, harbormaster in Tampico, Mexico, said by telephone that the Hermann would dock there later in the day. The Cuban Embassy in Mexico City charged that the Hermann was attacked in Mexican waters, but that was denied by Mexico's Foreign Ministry and the U.S. government. The U.S. Embassy in Mexico City said in a statement that the vessel fit the profile of a narcotics-smuggling ship. It did not elaborate. The Coast Guard fired 130 rounds from a 20mm cannon and 250 to 300 rounds of .60-caliber machine-gun fire, including warning shots, Gibson said. The freighter was hit in the engine compartment and at the rudder post, he said. Before firing, the Coast Guard asked Panama through diplomatic channels for permission to use disabling fire and it was granted, Gibson said. He said it is protocol to ask a ship's country of registry for permission to stop a vessel. Cuba's official news agency Prensa Latina said the Hermann had a cargo of 10 tons of chromium. It said the ship has a 12-man crew and is operated by the Guamar Shipping Co. of Cuba. Before firing, Gibson said, the Coast Guard took elaborate steps to stop the freighter, which was spotted by the cutter Chincoteague early Tuesday and was followed until just before dawn today, when it was 45 miles east of Tampico, on the central Mexican coast. ``We got on the radio, we asked them to stop, we used a signal light, we used a blue light, we used a flag hoist, we sprayed water onto the vessel and we sprayed water down into the stacks,'' Gibson said. ``Nothing worked, so we fired warning shots over the bow. They continued, and we asked the Panamanian government for permission to use disabling fire. The Panamanian government said do it.''

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Snow Means Starving Moose Calves
DOC.TEXT: Many Susitna Valley moose calves weakened by this winter's heavy snow are starving to death in yards and driveways, and some people are feeding the animals despite caution from wildlife biologists. ``I've got a couple moose in front of my house right now, and the mama looks OK, but the baby is sure looking poorly. It looks sick. It's frosted all over,'' said resident David Spain. Spain said a moose calf walked into the shop where he works as a mechanic and died, after hanging around outside for four weeks. Snow is nearly 5 feet deep at Willow in the Valley 55 miles north of Anchorage, the National Weather Service says. Moose numbers normally decline during severe winters because young, weak animals must struggle harder to find food and move through the snow. But the Susitna Valley has not had a winter this bad in years, and the moose population was especially high when this year's heavy snow began. The snow has also led to more moose deaths on highways. Police logs have shown up to 22 moose accidentally killed in a single night. There is no count of how many calves have died of starvation. ``We're so swamped with calls that if we get somebody's name and get them down in our notebooks, we're lucky,'' said Fish and Wildlife Protection Trooper Sgt. Richard Graham. Bill Collins, a Fish and Game wildlife biologist, said his Palmer office receives a dozen calls a day from residents who want to know what to do about hungry moose. ``Once the moose are fed, they are extremely reluctant to leave that area,'' Collins said. ``When conditions improve, they'll still stay around.'' If the feeding area is near where people live, the moose can be dangerous, Collins said. ``The more a wild animal becomes accustomed to human beings, the more likely it is to bridge the gap between standing off and staying away or thrashing someone,'' Collins said. He said a moose that had been fed tried to push its way into a woman's house recently. In another case last week, a calf tried to get into a house, then trampled a woman when she got out of her car. Collins said the 300-pound calf threatened to attack him, too, and he had to kill it. ``I've been hit and kicked down a couple of times already this year,'' Graham said. If a calf cannot move, Graham shoots it, he said, because otherwise it will only suffer and die slowly. Forest Richey said his pickup truck was attacked by a large bull moose that wouldn't leave his driveway in Willow. Richey was trying to push it out of the way when the moose got mad. ``I made the mistake of leaving enough distance that he could turn around and charge, and he charged and he came right up over the hood,'' Richey said. Richey and Spain both blame the fall cow moose hunting season for lowering the survival rate of calves. Collins said calves whose mothers were killed by cars, trains or hunters are less likely to survive, because they do not have the larger parent to break a path through the snow or defend them from dogs. Spain is a hunter and said his large family lives on the meat that moose provide in September. But he said that is not why he is worried about the moose now. ``I feel for the moose themselves right now,'' he said. ``They're having a hell of a time. And for the past 15 years they haven't had a winter like this. ``A guy just needs to get out and look at them to see how bad they are.''

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas Promise to Lift Exit Visa Requirement for Some
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Sandinista National Liberation Front fired another salvo Wednesday in the election campaign, promising to loosen exit visa requirements in a move sure to gain sympathy among voters. Nicaragua, Cuba and Bolivia are believed to be the only countries in the Western Hemisphere where citizens need Soviet-style government permission to travel abroad. Following a promise this week by President Daniel Ortega to free 1,044 political prisoners, the exit visa announcement ``is just another electioneering maneuver by the Sandinista government to gain votes,'' said Luis Sanchez, spokesman for the United National Opposition coalition, or UNO. Ortega is running for another six-year term in the Feb. 25 general elections against UNO's Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, his top challenger. In promising to free the prisoners, Ortega took the wind out of Mrs. Chamorro's sails, whose campaign is badly lagging behind a vigorous Sandinista effort. Mrs. Chamorro had repeatedly promised to ``open the jails'' if elected. Speaking to Finance Ministry workers, Interior Minister Tomas Borge said the Sandinistas would introduce to the Sandinista-dominated National Assembly a bill that would eliminate the exit visa requirement for women over 18 and men over 25. The visas, which are intended in part to prevent draft dodgers from leaving the country, will still be required for other Nicaraguans. The announcement was meant to take some of the sting out of the Sandinistas' refusal to do away with the draft. Mrs. Chamorro has promised to ban the draft, obligatory for two years for all 16-year-old males. That is one of UNO's top drawing cards, along with promises to inject new life into a moribund economy. Ortega, however, has said the draft is needed to defend Nicaragua against what he calls ``Yankee aggression'' and an allegedly planned U.S. invasion that has failed to materialize in more than 10 years of Sandinista rule. Many Nicaraguan parents have sent their sons abroad to live with friends or relatives, rather than allowing them to be drafted. A report on Borge's speech, published Wednesday in the pro-government newspaper El Nuevo Diario, did not say when the bill on exit visas would be introduced, nor did it say when Borge met with the workers. It was the first time news of such a bill was public. Nicaragua's immigration department comes under the Interior Ministry. When they ousted dictator Anastasio Somoza in July 1979, the Sandinistas removed a restriction banning Nicaraguans from travel to communist countries, but they kept the exit visa requirement.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Ronald Reagan, criticized during his administration for his response to the AIDS epidemic, says he's become more understanding about the disease. ``We all grow and learn in our lives,'' Reagan says in a public service announcement for the Pediatric AIDS Foundation. ``And I've learned that all kinds of people can get AIDS. Even children.'' The 30-second television spot was directed by former ``Starsky and Hutch'' star Paul Michael Glaser, whose wife and son have tested positive for the AIDS virus and whose 7-year-old daughter died of the disease. Elizabeth Glaser, one of the foundation's founders, was exposed to the virus through a blood transfusion. The disease of AIDS is frightening ``not the people who have it,'' Reagan says in the spot to be aired this month. ``You can't catch AIDS from hugging someone.'' ``I'm not asking you to send money,'' he says. ``I'm asking for something more important. Your understanding. Maybe it's time we all learned something new.''

Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto has named her week-old daughter Bakhtawar, which means ``one who brings luck'' in Persian, it was announced Wednesday. The second child of Ms. Bhutto and husband, Azif Zardari, was born Jan. 25 in the southern port city of Karachi. Ms. Bhutto was the first elected leader of a modern government to give birth while in office. The 36-year-old prime minister's first child, a son named Bilawal, was born Sept. 21, 1988, two months before the first free elections in 11 years that installed Ms. Bhutto as prime minister. Ms. Bhutto campaigned until the final days before Bilawal's birth and was back on the hustings a week later. Two days before her daughter's birth, the prime minister traveled to a dusty rural village near Karachi to distribute thousands of acres of government land to peasants. Opposition leaders were critical of the prime minister's decision to have a second child, claiming the country would be leaderless while she recovered. Ms. Bhutto transferred authority to her mother, Nusrat Bhutto, a senior minister without portfolio, elected member of the National Assembly and co-chairperson of the populist Pakistan People's Party.

Bette Midler told interviewer Connie Chung that life in the fast lane isn't for her. ``I just do what I think you oughta do,'' she said in a taped segment for Saturday Night with Connie Chung that is to be broadcast this weekend. ``I lead a moderate life, I volunteer, I do charities. And I know I sound really square because I don't drive a fast car and burn a lot of fossil fuel.'' When Chung mentioned that Midler brought $300 million in gross revenues to Disney Studios with five films, Midler joked: ``What, that much? I'll kill 'em. Where's mine? You know, they never give you a nickel at the end. Well, sometimes they give you a watch, you know, it has Mickey Mouse on it.'' Midler's latest film is ``Stella.''

It was family reunion time when dancer Mikhail Baryshnikov showed up at a private bash to celebrate Jessica Lange's new film ``Men Don't Leave.'' Lange brought along Baryshnikov's 9-year-old daughter, Alexandra, who lives with her mom and playwright-actor Sam Shepard on a farm in Virginia. Lange and Shepard have a daughter Hannah Jane, born in 1986, and a son, Samuel Walker Shepard, born in 1987. The party Monday night was for about 30 people at the Regency Hotel.

Country music singer Donna Fargo, who was diagnosed with multiple sclerosis in 1978, will be ``walk ambassador'' for the National Multiple Sclerosis Society this spring, the group announced Wednesday. Fargo, 44, of Nashville has maintained her singing career and the disease apparently has gone into remission, society spokeswoman Shari Fried said in New York City. Fargo will rally support for fund-raising walks for the society across the country March 31 and April 1. Volunteers receive pledges of money for participating in the walks. An estimated 100,000 people in more than 140 cities will be involved, Fried said. Fargo is best known for her hit records in the mid-1970s, ``Happiest Girl in the Whole U.S.A'' and ``Funny Face.''

Comedian Redd Foxx has lost to the IRS an expensive gold watch given him 13 years ago by the late Elvis Presley. Foxx was ordered to hand over the watch, which attorneys said has a value in the high six figures, during a hearing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court here. The IRS seized Foxx's Las Vegas home, several cars, personal belongings and expensive jewelry in a raid on his home Nov. 28. The Internal Revenue Service wants to sell the belongings to help pay nearly $900,000 in taxes, penalties and interest it claims Foxx owes the government. The IRS planned to auction the property last Saturday, but Foxx's attorneys went to bankruptcy court last week and obtained a 30-day stay on the sale. His attorneys claim the IRS sale would conflict with the bankruptcy court efforts to satisfy creditors. Foxx filed for bankruptcy in 1983 and some of his property has been liquidated over a period of years to pay creditors.

DOC.HEAD: Rock Star's Junk-Food Diet Too Restrictive for Gourmet Chef
DOC.TEXT: Rock star Prince's fondness for macaroni and cheese and canned cake frosting was too much for his chef, who quit after only a month on the job. ``He eats a lot of junk food. I have the feeling it's going to catch up with him,'' Carmen Bonilla of Minneapolis said Wednesday of the svelte Prince. Bonilla, 36, a professional chef for 10 years, said she began working for Prince just before Christmas. Her last day on the job was Wednesday. ``He hasn't had the opportunity to develop his palate,'' Bonilla said of the reclusive rock star. ``He doesn't eat out very much because he's shy and he hates the public. ... He wants the comfort food he grew up on.'' That means macaroni and cheese and cake mixes and canned frosting, said Bonilla, who prefers cooking Mediterranean cuisine. ``Basically it was too restrictive for me as a personal chef,'' she said. Although he professes to be a vegetarian, Prince won't eat salads and vegetables but he will eat chicken, likes fresh fish and ``adores'' pasta, Bonilla said. ``I was trying to do the middle-of-the-road stuff between being a gourmet and opening a box,'' she said. ``I never got myself to open a box.'' Bonilla said she would serve an afternoon dinner to Prince and actress Kim Basinger at Prince's Paisley Park Studios in the Minneapolis suburb of Chanhassen. She described the 31-year-old Prince as ``a very quiet, very shy type of person'' who ``likes to keep people at a distance,'' while Basinger was ``real cordial'' and had ``great social skills.'' Prince publicist Jill Willis declined comment on Bonilla's resignation.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Says Iran Ready to Pursue Hostage Release
DOC.TEXT: A Kuwait newspaper said Iranian leaders believe Westerners held by Shiite Moslem extremists in Lebanon have no more political value and are willing to help secure their release. A senior Iranian envoy close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani ``recently met with an American personality in Geneva and discussed the hostage issue with him,'' the daily Al-Qabas said in a dispatch Tuesday from Paris. Rafsanjani and close aides ``are convinced the value of the American and Western hostages is decreasing by the day,'' the paper said, quoting West European sources it did not identify. ``The hostages are no longer a pressure or bargaining card,'' it quoted the sources as saying. No independent confirmation was available, but speculation has grown that Rafsanjani, leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists, wanted the hostages freed as part of an effort to improve relations with the West. It appears, however, that Rafsanjani's room for maneuver has been curtailed by a power struggle with former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, a radical with close links to the Lebanese Shiites believed to hold most of the captives. Eight Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman are missing in Lebanon and believed held hostage. Held longest is Terry A. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985. Al-Qabas said its sources attributed the shift in Iranian policy to the refusal of governments to bargain for the hostages, the changing political and security situation in Lebanon and international developments caused by the changes in Eastern Europe. ``The Iranian leadership is apparently prepared to facilitate the release of American hostages provided this will lead at a later stage to a gradual improvement in Iranian-American relations,'' the paper reported. It said the U.S.-Iranian meeting in Geneva was the most important of several, and that the previous encounters took place in Paris and a West German city left unidentified. None of the officials was identified, but Al-Qabas said the Americans were diplomats or private citizens and the Iranian in Geneva was ``formerly in charge of the file of Western hostages in Lebanon and played a key role in the Iranian-French relations that led to the release of French hostages.'' Although it quoted the sources as saying they had no ``certain information that the two sides have reached a final formula on the fate of the hostages,'' the paper added: ``The sources do not exclude the possibility of the Americans and Iranians having reached a secret formula whereby the American and Western hostages will be freed in one batch or several batches, provided the Bush administration met such a step by opening up to Iran and starting a gradual normalization process between the two countries.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Call for Deeper Troop Cuts in Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs files; inserts 3 grafs with CBS report, Bush reaction after 3rd graf, The proposed; cuts from end to shorten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush prepared to deliver a State of the Union address tonight that administration sources said will call for deeper cuts in Soviet and American troops in Europe. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Bush called Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to advise him of ``some announcements'' he would have in tonight's speech. The White House said Bush and Gorbachev discussed arms control. The proposed cuts would go beyond a troop-reduction plan that Bush offered in 1989 and which is still under negotiation, said the sources, who demanded anonymity. Last year's proposal would cut troops on each side t 275,000, which would require a 30,000-person reduction in U.S. combat troops and a 325,000-person reduction in Soviet forces in Eastern Europe. CBS News reported that Bush would use the speech to unveil a proposal to reduce U.S. and Soviet troops in the central zone of Europe to 195,000, a drop of 80,000 from the 1989 proposal. Bush told reporters, ``The speech comes on at 9 o'clock tonight and there's going to be a lot of surprises there _ maybe. I'm not going to discuss in advance what I want to say. I want the surprise factor.'' ``There are some things that we don't discuss ahead of time,'' he said. Referring to Bush's call to Gorbachev, Baker said, ``It had to do with some announcements that the president will have tonight in his State of the Union message, and beyond that I am not going to say anything further.'' Similarly, White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``The president's State of the Union will deal with arms control, but I cannot confirm nor deny'' any specifics of his proposal. Arms control aside, Bush told Republicans that his speech would register objections to any cutback in Social Security taxes, and proclaim the nation in good health. Bush also said he would set new goals in education, and sources said he would call for American students to be first in the world by the year 2000 in science and mathematics, two areas where they have ranked near the bottom in international testing. Bush will address a joint session of Congress in a nationally broadcast appearance at 9 p.m. EST. It will be his maiden State of the Union address, although he went before Congress with a budget and deficit-reduction package last February. The president gave a preview of his speech to Republican members of Congress during a morning meeting at the White House. Later, House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., said he was happy that Bush said he would use the speech to voice opposition to a plan by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to roll back a Social Security tax increase that took effect Jan. 1. Referring to Moynihan's proposal, Michel said, ``It just means it's a no-no as far as our party's concerned. We've made that decision earlier on to fund this program adequately into the next century. And to do violence to that ... just really undermines our credibility.'' The administration has argued that Moynihan's plan would lead to either an increase in other taxes or a reduction in Social Security benefits. Moynihan has said his proposal was prompted by concern that the growing Social Security trust fund reserves are being used to mask the true size of the federal deficit. He says the financial soundness of the system would be protected under his proposal and there would be no risk to benefits. At the top of Bush's wish list for lawmakers are leftover bills dealing with clean air, crime, child care and cuts in capital gains tax rates. White House chief of staff John Sununu said chances for action are better this year because of the November elections. ``I think all of a sudden about April or May, it will dawn on Congress that it's a congressional election, not a presidential election year, and that failures to get things done will be seen as failures of the Democrat leadership in the House, the Democrat leadership in the Senate,'' he said. ``And I think at that time, maybe we'll get them back to a bipartisan perspective and get some legislation passed,'' Sununu added. Bush also has the momentum of strong support from Americans. Surveys taken after the invasion of Panama showed Bush with a job-approval rating of 79 to 81 percent, higher than former President Reagan ever attained. Much of the suspense of Bush's address was dampened by the unveiling of his $1.2 trillion budget plan, which outlined new initiatives where he wants to spend more money and areas where he wants to cut. ``So all the details of the programs are really on the table right now,'' Sununu said. Generally speaking, Bush requested more money for education, space, the environment and drugs while proposing cuts for Medicare, college student loans, mass transit and farm subsidies. White House officials said there were no major initiatives or surprises remaining for Bush's speech. ``Obviously, we don't want to overstate expectations, don't want anyone to overexpand an agenda,'' said Sununu. The challenge to improve students' math and science skills was hinted at in Bush's budget. Without mentioning the math and science goal, the budget proposes $230 million _ a 70 percent increase _ in funds for states to improve the abilities of teachers in those two disciplines. In addition, National Science Foundation programs for science, math and engineering education would receive a $100 million increase, to $460 million, under Bush's proposal. Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos, citing results of an international comparative study of students in more than a dozen industrialized nations, complained in a speech that U.S. students consistently ranked near the bottom in math and science Bush has previewed his address with a series of speeches this year, warning the democratic reforms in Eastern Europe will not produce a ``peace dividend'' of defense savings for the United States. While Democrats are hoping to cut Pentagon spending, Bush said at one outing he would not ``naively cut the muscle out of our defense posture.''

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: The Collurafici family is 2-for-2 with Super Bowl babies. While the New York Giants defeated the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XXI on Jan. 25, 1987, Theresa Collurafici gave birth to Amanda Lauren. On Sunday, in Super Bowl XXIV, the San Francisco 49ers trounced the Broncos and Mrs. Collurafici, 30, delivered 7-pound, 5-ounce Marissa Erin. ``I don't know what's going on here,'' said Anthony Collurafici, 30. ``It just seems kind of strange, you know?'' As he was preparing to watch Sunday's game, Collurafici said his wife warned him their baby would be born that night. He said he replied, `You're kidding.'' ``In between contractions, we watched some of the game,'' at the hospital, which had a television in the labor room, said Mrs. Collurafici. Collurafici said he had placed a small wager on the game and won. ``I came up a winner in more ways than one, I guess,'' he said.

For just $20, you can be mayor for a day at Wray. The power and prestige of governing this northeastern Colorado town of 2,200 is available for a $20 donation to the Wray Rehabilitation and Activities Center. You don't even have to be a resident to qualify for the one-day tenure. Dan Wisdom, a career Navy officer in Hawaii, purchased the mayor's duties Wednesday and declared it ``Pat Your Neighbor on the Back Day.'' More than 60 days have been sold, said Mike Wisdom, head of the recreation board and brother of Wednesday's mayor. ``Mostly, people are buying their birthdays,'' he said. The center is a $4 million project, including $1.8 million in building funds, that the community is funding through donations and matching grants. Construction starts in April. Locals joked about ``Wraygate'' after Mayor Jack Sloniker granted the recreation board rights to his office during 1990. ``People out here are not into problems. They're into solutions,'' Mike Wisdom said of the novel fund-raising approach.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Calls Gorbachev About State Of Union Speech
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today to provide him with advance word on several announcements he will make in his State of the Union address, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said. Among them, administration sources told The Associated Press, is a proposal for deeper cutbacks in U.S. and Soviet troops in Europe. NATO and the Warsaw Pact are negotiating over a proposal by Bush last year to establish ceilings of 275,000. But since then, Soviet allies in Eastern and Central Europe have called for Soviet troop withdrawals, and Moscow appears receptive. As a result, said the sources, who demanded anonymity, Bush will call for even deeper reductions. Baker, meanwhile, again discounted as ``just a rumor'' a television report that Gorbachev would surrender his leadership of the Soviet Communist Party. ``We said yesterday that we thought that that was just a rumor, and indeed it proved to be just a rumor,'' Baker said. ``I can't make judgments about rumors, whether they surface in the Soviet Union or over here. It was a rumor.'' There was no ``direct'' discussion of the report in Bush's telephone call to Gorbachev, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. ``It had to do with some announcements that the president will have tonight in his State of the Union message, and beyond that I am not going to say anything further,'' Baker said in a brief exchange with reporters at the State Department. Gorbachev earlier today emphatically denied the report by the Cable News Network. Fitzwater said, ``The president called him this morning to talk about arms control. I don't know how long. (It was) early this morning.'' Asked if they had talked about the rumors Gorbachev might surrender his party post, Fitzwater said, ``The president said there was no direct discussion of that.'' Baker, who is going to Moscow next week, will see Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze _ and possibly Gorbachev _ on Feb. 8-9. The talks were rescheduled a second time to avoid interfering with a meeting of the party's Central Committee. The postponement coincided with a report by CNN that Gorbachev had spent the past eight days at his country home, considering whether to resign as head of the Soviet Communist Party. ``No one has said this, and I certainly didn't make any such statement,'' the Soviet president and party general secretary said. ``Any such suggestions are groundless.'' Asked about the resignation report during a photo session at the start of a Kremlin meeting with President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil, Gorbachev said, ``I have no intention of doing so.'' Bush administration officials and intelligence sources told The Associated Press there has been speculation for weeks that Gorbachev would yield his party post _ while retaining the presidency _ but they had no information he would take the step. ``All I can tell you ... is that it's a rumor, and therefore it's not something that I think that we should respond to or react to,'' Baker told reporters on his way to a meeting with President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya. ``We're following the story, as I know you are, and we'll have a comment if we ever determine it's something more than just a rumor.'' Baker said American diplomats in Moscow ``know just about the same thing that all the rest of us know right now _ that there's a rumor out there to this effect, and that's all we know.'' White House Chief of Staff John Sununu told reporters the administration has been ``trying for the last few hours to try and get some additional assessments, but I don't have anything at all.'' Issues to be discussed by Baker and Shevardnadze include arms control and the war in Afghanistan between the Soviet-backed government and U.S.-armed rebels. Initially, Baker was to go to Moscow on Feb. 6-7. Then the date was changed to Feb. 7-8. And on Tuesday the State Department announced the shift to Feb. 8-9, saying it was suggested by the U.S. side. ``It simply makes more sense to have the Soviets complete their plenum before beginning this important ministerial,'' said Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman. Baker also is expected to make a brief visit to Czechoslovakia, although there has been no announcement on that. The Soviet news agency Tass reported the delay of Baker's visit in a one-paragraph story from Washington but gave no reason. CNN, quoting a ``well-informed and usually reliable'' party source, said from Moscow that the re-emergence of Gorbachev on television on Tuesday did not rule out a dramatic resignation when the policy-setting Central Committee meets next Monday and Tuesday. Before the TV appearance on Tuesday, Gorbachev was last seen in public Jan. 20 explaining why Soviet troops had been sent to the Azerbaijan republic. According to the unnamed source, Gorbachev had resisted sending troops into Baku, the capital of the republic, and was suffering severe depression over the action, CNN said.

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Slain Drug Suspect Had Cocaine in System
DOC.TEXT: A suspected drug dealer who was beaten to death while in the custody of six undercover detectives used cocaine shortly before he died, a medical examiner's report said. ``He had used cocaine probably within two to three hours prior to the time that he died,'' Dr. Lee Hearn, chief toxicologist for the Dade medical examiner's office, said Tuesday. There was cocaine in Leonardo Mercado's urine, nasal passages, blood and brain, the report said. ``The concentrations are not by any means exceptional,'' Hearn said. ``They're actually quite low.'' But defense attorneys say that whatever the amount, the cocaine could have been a factor in the confrontation between Mercado and the officers. Mercado died Dec. 16, 1988, while in the custody of six officers from the street narcotics unit. The officers go on trial April 2 on federal charges of violating Mercado's civil rights. Witnesses told investigators that officers found Mercado on the street, pulled him inside his house and hit, kicked and beat him. The finding of cocaine in Mercado's system is ``an extremely significant point for the defense,'' said Richard Sharpstein, an attorney for one of the officers. But Hearn said the presence of cocaine in Mercado's bloodstream does not mean he was prone to violence. ``He probably was feeling some effects from cocaine, but probably not very intensely at that point,'' Hearn said. ``Different people react different ways. ... Some people become violent, some just become happy. You really can't say based solely on a toxicological test result.''

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Abortion Group Closing National Office
DOC.TEXT: The national Operation Rescue organization is shutting down because of debt but local affiliates nationwide will continue their anti-abortion efforts, founder Randall Terry said Wednesday. Terry made the announcement at a news conference a day after he was released from a Georgia prison where he had spent nearly four months in custody on charges of criminal trespass and unlawful assembly. He said a $50,000 fine imposed by a New York court in a lawsuit filed by the National Organization for Women hurt Operation Rescue's fund-raising efforts and helped put the group $70,000 in debt. The fine is being appealed, but the judgment in the New York case ``unfortunately has driven us to the brink of bankruptcy,'' he said. Terry said that because of the fine the organization had been unable to raise money to pay salaries and carry on the operations of the Binghamton, N.Y., headquarters, which had employed 23 people. ``It is unprecedented in American history for government to go after any group with such Draconian fines,'' he said. ``As a result of the lawsuit, we don't have any option but to close our doors.'' However, Terry said, the 125 local Operation Rescue groups across the country will continue their direct-action efforts to shut down abortion clinics. ``We are confident these groups will continue doing what they're doing,'' he said. ``The movement is bigger than the office in Binghamton and will carry on with or without us.'' Terry was released Tuesday from a Fulton County, Ga., minimum-security prison camp after an anonymous person paid his $500 fine and a $50 special assessment. He said he did not know who had paid the fine. ``I'm happy I'm out,'' he said. ``I'm glad I did the time ... and I'm also glad I'm out.'' Terry said his immediate plans ``are to go home and spend some time ministering to my wife and family.'' But he said he plans to continue his anti-abortion activities. ``You'll see me out there kicking,'' he said. ``I'm not dead. Once I get my bearings, I will still be speaking, traveling.'' He said he stopped in Washington, at a conference of religious broadcasters, on his way home because he wanted to express his outrage at the prison sentences that are being handed out to members of Operation Rescue around the country. Pro-life activists, he said, are being jailed more often and held longer than demonstrators for other causes. ``This is politics,'' he said. ``There's no other explanation.'' Terry, a born-again Christian and former car salesman, was arrested during an Operation Rescue demonstration outside the Atlanta Surgi-Center in 1988. He was ordered to pay the fine, agree to stay out of metropolitan Atlanta for two years and abide by Georgia law. Terry refused and was jailed Oct. 5, saying he was prepared to serve out the two-year sentence. Operation Rescue is a loose-knit organization Terry founded in 1987, three years after he and his wife began standing outside a Binghamton clinic trying to discourage women from having abortions.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Expects U.S. Troops Withdrawals
DOC.TEXT: South Korea expects to sign agreements for the withdrawal of 3,000 more U.S. forces in 1990, a senior official indicated Wednesday. Such agreements would bring reductions to 5,000 this year, to a total of roughly 38,000. All of the American personnel withdrawn are expected to be non-combatants, said the government official, who discussed the issue on condition he not be identified. U.S. Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney said earlier this week three U.S. Air Force bases in South Korea would be closed and 2,000 air support personnel withdrawn in a cost-saving effort. Cheney's announcement signaled the first U.S. military cutback in South Korea in more than 10 years. ``It's a readjustment. We don't think the U.S. is pulling out,'' said the Korean official, who has high-level government responsibilities with both the foreign and defense ministeries. He said the government views the basic U.S.-South Korea defense agreement as being untouched and said Korean officials are confident further reductions will involve only support personnel, not combat-ready troops. The official said the two nations are expected to formalize an agreement later this year. He indicated that would bring U.S. forces to 1980 troop strength of roughly 38,000, or 5,000 less than today's number. The U.S. 2nd Infantry Division, the only American division in South Korea, is deployed along the Demilitarized Zone separating North Korea and South Korea, and is not expected to be affected by cuts, he said. The 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea are under a mutual defense pact to deter aggression from communist North Korea. South Koreans view national security as their top national priority and citizens have been jittery over the prospect of American withdrawals. The peninsula was divided into the communist North and capitalist South in 1945 and the two sides fought a bloody three-year war in the early 1950s that ended with an armistice, but not a peace treaty. Cheney is to visit Seoul Feb. 14 for negotiations with his Korean counterparts and a discussion of ground troops is expected to be on the agenda. U.S. and Korean officials said no decisions would be made on troop reductions without the agreement of both nations. The last U.S. cutbacks were in the late 1970s when several hundred troops were withdrawn to fulfill a campaign promise made by President Jimmy Carter.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Deciding Whether Infant's Suffocation Qualifies for Death Penalty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with jury deliberating whether crime qualifies for the death penalty. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The jury that convicted a woman of suffocating one of two infant daughters she claimed were abducted three years apart by masked gunmen deliberated today whether the crime qualifies for the death penalty. Assistant State's Attorney Donald Weber argued that Paula Marie Sims' crime was especially brutal and cruel _ the grounds necessary to bring the death penalty. But defense attorney Donald Groshong told jurors, ``In the pecking order of evil ... smothering is usually considered more merciful than other forms of killing.'' Mrs. Sims, 30, was convicted Tuesday in the April 29 death of 6-week-old Heather Lee Sims. A finding by the jury that Mrs. Sims is eligible for the death penalty would send the trial into a third phase, in which jurors would decide whether to actually sentence her to death. Groshong today argued that Ms. Sims maintains her innocence, and he added, ``We cannot say the death of this child was premeditated, prolonged or torturous.'' Mrs. Sims claimed a gunman abducted the infant from the family's southern Illinois home in Alton. In 1986, Mrs. Sims gave a nearly identical account in the death of 13-day-old Loralei Marie. The Simses were living in rural Brighton at the time. Mrs. Sims has not been charged with killing that child. The jury deliberated for 10 hours over two days before reaching the verdict. Mrs. Sims broke down as guards led her back to jail. Weber said he thought the jury was strongly influenced by evidence that Mrs. Sims and her husband, 37-year-old Robert, wanted only male children. ``She didn't like little girls and neither did Robert,'' Weber said. Sims has not been charged in either case. But Weber said because of the verdict against Mrs. Sims, prosecutors are considering seeking indictments against him. Sims and Groshong refused to comment. Mrs. Sims faces trial on charges of obstruction of justice and concealment of a homicide in Loralei's death. Mrs. Sims has been jailed since July. Sims has had custody of the couple's son, Randy, who turns 2 on Thursday. The trial was moved to Peoria from Edwardsville because of intense pretrial publicity.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Concerned Over Shamir's Remarks After Visit to Moscow
DOC.TEXT: A minister from a pivotal religious party on Wednesday admonished Israeli leaders against making comments that could delay Soviet Jewish immigration. Religious Affairs Minister Zevulun Hammer was reacting to a statement made by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who suggested that Israel needed to keep the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to settle an expected wave of Soviet immigrants. Speaking to reporters one day after his return from the Soviet Union, Hammer said he did not expect the Soviet immigration wave to be halted because of Shamir's comments. But he said, ``We have to act with much caution, and we have to avoid saying anything that could cause any kind of delay in emigration.'' Soviet and U.S. officials oppose resettlement of immigrants in the occupied lands, saying it is an obstacle to making peace with Arabs. The Soviet Union broke ties with Israel after the Jewish state captured the territories from Jordan and Egypt during the 1967 Middle East War. Low-level relations were resumed in 1987. Hammer is a member of the National Religious Party, which is crucial in deciding whether the political left or right could rule in a coalition government. It had been in coalition with the left-leaning Labor Party for the country's first 30 years until it sided with the right-wing Likud bloc after Likud's victory in 1977 national elections. Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader and Shamir's main political rival, told a private meeting of the inner Cabinet on Wednesday that Shamir's remark was ``a fatal mistake regarding immigration, and I can hardly restrain myself from saying this in public,'' Israel TV reported. Hammer said Anatoly Adamishin, a Soviet deputy foreign minister, told him Shamir's remarks had ``created difficulties ... at home and abroad.'' The Soviet Union issued an official protest of Shamir's statement. In response, a top Shamir aide said Israel had no policy of directing immigrants to the occupied territories, where Palestinians are fighting for an independent state. Israeli officials say the immigrants are free to settle either in Israel or in the occupied lands, where 1.7 million Palestinians live. Meanwhile, former Soviet refuseniks appealed to the Israeli government to implement ``the evacuation of Soviet Jewry'' because of alleged growing anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union. About 50 refuseniks, who waited years to obtain exit visas from the Soviet Union, protested across from Shamir's office in Jerusalem. ``We need to evacuate them because they are threatened. There is a real danger,'' said Ida Nudel, who waged a 16-year fight for an exit visa before finally being allowed to come to Israel in 1987. ``Unfortunately we know everything retrospectively. We remember what happened in Germany. ... It's the same conditions today.'' Israel has said it expects up to 300,000 Soviet Jews to immigrate to Israel in the next three years. In January, 4,600 Soviet Jews came to Israel, according to the government. Workers at the Absorption Ministry, which handles the influx, declared a 24-hour strike beginning at midnight Wednesday. Hanna Bazana, chairwoman of the workers' committee, said the strike was to demand salary increases and more workers since ``350 workers cannot absorb 100,000 immigrants expected.'' The Absorption Ministry said it would employ temporary workers to handle two planeloads of immigrants due to arrive early Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Expanded Ruling Party to Seek Better Relations With Moscow
DOC.TEXT: A former opposition leader now allied with the governing party said Wednesday he would seek better relations with the Soviet Union as a means of easing tension with North Korea. Kim Young-sam, whose Reunification Democratic Party joined another opposition group last week in a merger with the governing Democratic Justice Party, said better relations with Communist allies of North Korea would help lead to reunification. He plans to visit the Soviet Union in mid-March. Kim's comments reflected the policy of President Roh Tae-woo, who has sought better relations with North Korea's allies in hopes they would preach moderation in Pyongyang. After years in the opposition, Kim became a government leader overnight when his party and the New Democratic Republican Party agreed to the merger. They ranked second and third in the opposition behind the leftist Party for Peace and Prosperity led by Kim Dae-jung. At a news conference Wednesday, Kim Young-sam said: ``I would actively push the ... policy of improving relations with the Soviet Union, China and other socialist nations, thus laying a solid foundation for national unifification.'' The merger is to become formal in mid-February, but already is considered in effect. The alliance is tentatively named the Democratic Liberal Party. Because of the merger, Kim Young-sam has become a possible successor to Roh, whose single five-year term expires in early 1993. He said he proposed the merger to Roh last year as a way of ending South Korea's faction-ridden politics ``once and for all.'' That contradicted widespread speculation that the Roh's party initiated the merger. Newspapers said Kim, 62, probably will meet in Moscow with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other top officials interested in improving relations with South Korea. An aide said privately: ``Last June, Mr. Kim went to Moscow as an opposition leader, but this time he is going there as a potential ruler ... and I am sure they would consider the change in his status.'' News reports said Kim also might speak with North Korean leaders while in Moscow, but the aide denied it. During the June trip to Moscow, Kim met with Ho Dam, former foreign minister of North Korea. South Korea has established full diplomatic relations with Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia and has consular ties with the Soviet Union, with hopes of raising them to the ambassadorial level. Korea was divided in 1945, at the end of World War II. The two nations fought a three-year war that ended in 1953, but no peace treaty has been signed.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislators to Visit U.S. Military Installations
DOC.TEXT: Members of the Soviet Union's national legislature will visit the Pentagon and several U.S. military installations as part of a 12-day trip to the United States, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee said Wednesday. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., said the delegation from the defense and state security committee of the Supreme Soviet will arrive Feb. 7 for a trip similar to the one members of the House panel took to the Soviet Union last August. Among the stops on the Soviets' itinerary is a tour of the Pentagon and a meeting with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Los Alamos National Laboratories in New Mexico, the Midgetman II missile site and B-1B bomber, the Strategic Air Command at Offutt Air Force Base in Nebraska, the U.S. Navy base in Norfolk, Va., and the General Dynamics F-16 fighter plant. The Soviets will also visit the Army armored division at Fort Hood, Texas, and the Army chemical weapons facility at Fort McClellan, Ala. _ two sites slated for closing or realignment in Cheney's base closure plan. The Soviet delegation will be headed by Vladimir Lavrentyevich Lapygin, the committee's chairman, and Col. Valeriy Nikolayevich Ochirov, the vice chairman. Lapygin participated in the design of the Soviet space shuttle. Ochirov is an Air Force officer and helicopter pilot who holds his country's highest decoration for valor. The delegation also will visit the Kennedy Space Center and Disneyworld in Florida and New York City.

DOC.HEAD: President Honors Domestic Volunteer Corps
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday honored the 25th anniversary of VISTA, saying the service organization's volunteers are embarked on ``a great mission.'' Bush joined his wife Barbara at a brief ceremony in the White House to swear in five new volunteers in Volunteers in Service to America (VISTA), the domestic counterpart of the Peace Corps. ``You impart to so many disadvantaged Americans the means to build pride, to earn a degree or skill, to believe in themselves,'' Bush told a group of VISTA guests. He called the volunteers ``true activists. ``You don't often see them because they're off helping others in the unlikliest places. You don't often hear from them because they're too modest to brag. And you don't often notice them at work because theirs is a quiet mission.'' Since it was started under President Johnson, VISTA has dispatched some 100,000 volunteers to community projects across the country. The first projects, which began Jan. 31, 1965, were in Appalachia and among migrant farm workers in California. Today, some 3,000 volunteers work in 660 VISTA projects in the 50 states, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. Their mission, Bush said in brief remarks, is ``to guide the young, to comfrort the sick, to encourage the downtrodden, to teach the skills which may lead to a more rewarding life. VISTA projects include working with the homeless, senior citizens, iliteracy programs, alcohol and drug abuse prevention, agricultural cooperatives and job counseling. Attending the White House ceremony were Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., and Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson, both former VISTA volunteers.

DOC.HEAD: Mediators Arrive for Armenian-Azerbaijani Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Mediators arrived Wednesday to prepare peace talks between Armenian and Azerbaijani representatives that bypass the Kremlin and underscore the growing importance of the grassroots movements in the Baltics. Rein Veidemann and Arvo Junte of the Estonian People's Front arrived from Tallinn, while Vytautas Landsbergis, head of a similar group in Lithuania, was expected later. Nine mediators are to take part in the talks in Riga, the Latvian capital, organized by the Baltic Council, a grouping of the region's people's fronts. The discussions are aimed at ending bloodshed in clashes between Armenians and Azerbaijanis that have wracked the Soviet Caucasus for two years. The tension escalated Jan. 13 when Azerbaijanis attacked Armenians in the Azerbaijani capital Baku, and when Soviet troops stormed into the city a week later. Officials report nearly 200 deaths. Official news reports Wednesday said no shots were fired in Baku the previous night and that 80 percent of the businesses in the capital and other major cities of Azerbaijan were working. The others are on strike. Among the areas plagued by work stoppages is the disputed territory of Nagorno-Karabakh, the region in Azerbaijan that is populated primarily by Armenians. The Baltic Council stepped in because the Kremlin's efforts to resolve the bloody ethnic dispute have largely failed. Latvian organizers say two representatives of Azerbaijan's People's Front are expected to reach Riga Thursday, while the three-man delegation from the Armenian All-National Movement is being hindered by lack of flights out of their capital, Yerevan. Because of the transportation problems, organizers do not know when the talks will start. The Baltic Council, which groups People's Front leaders from Lithuania, Lativa and Estonia, is scheduled to meet Thursday to prepare for the talks. The Armenians and Azerbaijanis have agreed to discuss the presence of Soviet troops in their republics, refugees and other humanitarian questions. The Latvian Women's League, a faction within the People's Front, is pressing the Soviet military for news on the whereabouts and well-being of the estimated 500 native Latvians sent into Azerbaijan to keep order. ``If the state can't resolve those problems, why should an 18-year-old lose his blood?'' asked Anita Stankevic, a Women's League representative. ``We don't want our sons serving against their will in other republics,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Another View of the State of the Union
With AM-State of the Union, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While President Bush offered his view of the State of the Union, America's preoccupation with taking its own temperature yields another snapshot of the national condition. A glimpse of how the country measures up, down and sideways, from recent polls, surveys and statistical compilations by industry and government: _Percent of professors who say colleges are forced to teach what high schools should have: 68. _Percent of people who work Saturdays: 25. Sundays: 12.5. _Who work ``regular hours'' _ 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. weekdays: 22. _With more than one job: 5. _Percent of Americans regarded as ``significantly obese'' (30 percent above ideal for age, stature, gender): 20. _Acres of forest land that are not replaced each year: 700,000. _Amount by which the national debt grows each minute: $480,000. _Each family's proportionate share: $42,000. _Number of McDonald's franchises in the United States as of 1988: 6,165; of Diet Center franchises: 2,300. _Percent of Americans who say they walk for exercise: 26.8. _Who start their daily meals saying grace: 48. _State with the highest percentage of smokers: Kentucky, 37.9 percent. _With highest percent of ex-smokers: Maine, 20.3 percent. _Tons of sweet corn grown in the United States: 3.6 million. _Number of gallons of coffee consumed per adult in 1987: 26.5. _Of beer: 34.4. _The president's popularity in recent polls: 71-79 percent, depending upon the survey. _Percent of people in a November survey who thought ``communism is dying'': 52. _Who said Bush is smarter than Mikhail Gorbachev: 39. _Who said Gorbachev is smarter than Bush: 21. _Who said it's likely a woman will be president in the 1990s: 38. _Who said U.S. poverty will likely be eliminated in the '90s: 7. _Percent of workers who say they would work harder if paid more: 40. _If assured of more recognition: 31. _Weekly earnings of the average working woman: $320, 70 percent of what the average man makes. _Percent of people's take-home pay that is immediately earmarked for installment payments: 18.5. _Number of golfers: 21.7 million. Outboard motors owned: 10.4 million. _Percent of people who call themselves religious: 49. _Who call themselves environmentalists: 39. _Percent of college men who chew tobacco or use snuff: 22. _Percent of people who grow vegetables: 33. _Number of homeless: 735,000 on any given night, by one study. _Number of Americans who have died of AIDS since June 1, 1981: 70,313. _What it costs the IRS to collect $100 in taxes: 54 cents. Amount assessed in taxes and penalties in 1988 through 1.03 million field and office audits: $19.2 billion. _Projected decline in the number of farmers between 1986 and 2000: 28 percent. _Number of patents issued to inventors in 1987: 89,400. _Percent who think it was right to drop the atomic bomb on Hiroshima, Japan: 60. _Number of abortions likely to be performed among every 100 women in the United States (with some having more than one): 76. _Percent of abortions performed on unmarried women: 63.3. _Percent of out-of-wedlock first births among white women under age 30: 32.8. Black women: 78.8. Hispanic women: 42.7. _Life expectancy for men age 85: 5.2 more years. _For women that age: 6.4. _Percent of stolen TVs recovered by police: 5. _Number of murders in Washington, D.C., this year: 50. January 1989: 52. All of 1989: 438. _Percent of medical care paid for by patients: 29. By insurance: 31. By government: 39. _Percent of men age 40-44 currently divorced: 10.5. Women: 14.8. _Percent who said in an August 1989 poll that Pete Rose, although banished from baseball, should be admitted to the Hall of Fame: 66.

DOC.HEAD: Networks To Air State of the Union Message
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS name of Spanish network in 3rd graf to Univision, sted SIN.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-State of Union, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's State of the Union message will be aired live tonight on the major networks. Bush's address will be broadcast at 9 p.m. EST on ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN and C-Span, followed by a Democratic response from House Speaker Thomas S. Foley. Some local affiliates of PBS and Univision, a Spanish international network, also will carry the address and response, either live or as a tape-delayed broadcast. C-Span will rebroadcast the address at 11:30 p.m. EST.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Denies Resignation Report Amid Growing Worries
LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday denied a report he might resign as head of the Communist Party while remaining Soviet president, and a leading newspaper called him too valuable to risk losing. Another newspaper, the party daily Pravda, urged authorities to strengthen the powers of the presidency to protect Gorbachev from efforts to oust him. Correspondents covering Gorbachev's meeting with Brazilian president-elect Fernando Collor de Mello asked about a Western television report that he was considering quitting the party leadership. ``All this is groundless,'' Gorbachev said in remarks that led the Soviet television news Wednesday night. ``It is in someone's interest to propagate such things.'' He added that similar rumors are becoming common in the Soviet Union, and ``it demonstrates that we are a different country, a different society. Everything is discussed, and discussed openly.'' Gorbachev has strengthened the presidency and tried to shift power from the ruling Communist Party to the elected government. But it is far from clear whether the reforms have gone far enough for him to dare relinquishing the top post in the party, which has been the source of power for all previous Soviet leaders. The Pravda article, based on a debate among prominent figures, appeared to tell readers that party power still is paramount and that the presidency is not strong enough to be the country's main leadership post. The political turmoil comes while the Soviet Union is torn by nationalist and ethnic violence in Azerbaijan, drives for independence in several republics and an economic crisis. It also comes just five days before what is expected to be a fiery meeting of the party's Central Committee _ the one body with the official power to remove Gorbachev as party leader. Progressives hope to present an alternative party program at the meeting. In addition, it is likely to be the hard-liners' last chance to make a power play before the voters decide on their future in local and republic-level elections in February and March. Gorbachev told journalists he had just returned from the south, apparently referring to his retreat on the Black Sea, where he was preparing for the Central Committee meeting. Cable News Network reported Tuesday, in an account attributed to an unidentified party source, that Gorbachev had spent eight days sequestered outside Moscow while he considered quitting. President Bush telephoned Gorbachev Wednesday, but White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said there was no ``direct'' discussion of the rumors. Fitzwater said the two leaders talked about arms control. Secretary of State James A. Baker III discounted the TV network report as ``just a rumor.'' In Moscow, U.S. Ambassador Jack Matlock received an audience in the Kremlin, the Tass news agency said. However, it said he and Politburo member Lev Zaikov talked about Soviet-U.S. relations. Matlock said the meeting was scheduled months earlier and the topics were ``not connected to any other events.'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady I. Gerasimov also denied the reports. ``In the long run, power will belong completely to the soviets (elected councils) and the party will exercise its influence through its members in the soviets, which is the usual way for every democracy,'' Gerasimov said. Komsomolskaya Pravda, the party's youth daily, noted that the Communist Party is splitting into factions, under such forces as the independence movements in the Baltics, the violence in Azerbaijan and recent ousters of local party chiefs by impatient reformers in Tyumen, Volgograd and Chernigov. ``To fix on pseudo-unity is a dangerous thing, at least because responsibility for everything boomerangs to the very top,'' said the article signed by managing editor Alexander Drozdov. ``We cannot, we do not have the right to risk Gorbachev, simply because he inherited such a heavy ideological and personnel burden,'' he continued, referring to hard-line holdovers from the Communist Party's decades of dictatorship. ``Today only he is in a position to become the center of gravity and a mediator between the many political and social forces,'' Drozdov wrote. Drozdov also said in his front-page article that ``it is high time for all influential participants in the political process to sit down at a `roundtable,''' in obvious reference to negotiations in Poland, in which Communists agreed to loosen their control over the country. The talks led to the election of the Soviet bloc's first non-Communist prime minister. Drozdov said the people's fronts, which in some Soviet republics rival the party in public support, ``should be included in the orbit of the government and political life on an equal footing with the ruling party.'' Drozdov told The Associated Press other editors cut from his article a suggestion that Gorbachev divide his posts, retaining the presidency and surrendering the party leadership. He said in an interview he believes this issue will come to the fore soon, and that ``as president, he would have much more trust than as head of the party, of this party.'' Drozdov declined to say who changed it, but other sources said the decision was made inside the newspaper, not from higher up. As printed, the editorial said simply, ``In the end, he is our president. And more than anything, he is our president.'' In Pravda's report on a discussion by four scholars, historian Yevgeny Ambartsumov said Gorbachev appeared unable to take decisive action because of the threat to his position. Ambartsumov said the country's president has few legal guarantees of his position, even though the Congress of People's Deputies elected Gorbachev last May to a five-year term. ``There is no guarantee that the Congress of People's Deputies, in a left or right mood, would not demand his replacement,'' Ambartsumov said. Theoretically, he added, the Communist Party could recall him as well, because Gorbachev was elected to one of the party's 100 guaranteed parliamentary seats. Parliament spokesman Eduard Kovalev said lawmakers are considering a law exempting the president from recall. Lawyer Mikhail Krutogolov referred in Pravda to the Communist Party as the ``fourth power'' of the Soviet Union, whose authority is greater than the judiciary, the legislature or the government's executive branch.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Tells Young Peasants to Help Land Prosper
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II urged young Chadians on Wednesday to fight the temptation of the city and concentrate instead on farming their thirsty land to help Africa overcome its poverty. The pontiff, nearing the end of his African tour, rode to the Sarh hippodrome in the back of an open pickup truck along dusty streets lined with mango trees. Women dressed in brightly printed cloth bearing the likeness of the pope greeted him with ululations typical of the sub-Saharan, or Sahel region. ``Learn the old and the new methods, work to create productive fields and resist the temptation to abandon the land for an uncertain future in the cities,'' the pontiff told a crowd of some 10,000 who gathered in the southern agricultural city of 700,000 people. The pope was accompanied by Monsignor Mathias Ngarteri, the only Chadian bishop. Earlier in the day in the cotton-growing town of Moundou, John Paul encouraged young Chadians to join the priesthood. There are 26 Chadian priests and 153 foreign priests in Chad. The pope also praised the labors of the expatriate priests and missionaries who established the first Roman Catholic foothold in Chad 60 years ago in Moundou. In addition to its pastoral activities, the church in Chad is deeply involved in education and rural development. In a speech welcoming the pope Tuesday, President Hissene Habre, a Moslem and former guerrilla leader, made a point of thanking the expatriate priests and nuns working as teachers, nurses and rural extension agents. Development aid officials say Chad, one of the world's 10 poorest nations whose fragile economy was shattered by more than a decade of civil strife, is nevertheless capable of feeding itself, given sufficient rainfall. U.S. AID officials said last year's harvest of 800,000 tons of cereal grains, including mainstays sorghum and millet, is about enough to feed the nation. Chad was the final stop on John Paul's visit to the Sahel. He also visited Mali, Cape Verde, Guinea Bissau, and Burkina Faso. Since his first visit to the drought-plagued Sahel a decade ago, John Paul has repeatedly called on wealthy nations to help the Africans of the region overcome their poverty. On Thursday, the pontiff is to deliver a speech at a Roman Catholic-funded development planning center in the Chadian capital, N'Djamena, in which he is expected to stress once again that the developed world must not leave Africa behind. Before leaving for Rome, he will meet with Moslem leaders. About 50 percent of Chad's estimated 5.5 million inhabitants are Moslems. There are 400,000 baptized Roman Catholics.

DOC.HEAD: TV News Anchors Reported Missing Are Found to Have Run Off Together
DOC.TEXT: The story of two local television anchors reported missing but later found to have left town together is a hot topic in this small city. When Wendy Sheldon, a weekday anchor of KWTX-TV, didn't show for work on Friday, her husband, a production manager at the station, reported her missing.
