Mike Reeder, the weekend anchor, also was reported missing by the station manager. His wife told police that some of his clothes were missing. After the Waco Tribune-Herald published a news item Sunday based on the police blotter, the station announced on the air later that day that Ms. Sheldon had called to say she was fine _ and also that she was accompanied by Reeder, whose company car had been found abandoned. Local officials said the two were in Albuquerque, N.M. Neither had returned to work Wednesday. At first, some residents of this Bible-belt city _ home to Baptist-run Baylor University _ wondered if it was all a publicity stunt, said a clerk at the Sears catalog center who would identify herself only as Mary. But as the Waco Tribune-Herald published updates on the case, that thought diminished, she said. Then on Tuesday the incident was featured on the nationally syndicated show ``A Current Affair.'' ``I thought that was hilarious _ `a current affair,''' said a Waco woman who works at the Texas State Technical Institute who would identify herself only as Jan. ``But I can't understand why anybody outside of Waco cares.'' A deputy court clerk for McClennan County said the disappearance has the courthouse abuzz, and she expects she may be indirectly involved at some point. ``None of those involved have come in here yet,'' said the clerk, who handles divorce case filings. ``But it wouldn't surprise me.'' Sammy Citrano, the general manager of the Elite Cafe, said Ms. Sheldon and Reeder were occasional customers and ``both good people.'' ``It's not that big a deal. It's their personal lives,'' Citrano said Wednesday. ``They're just somebody that got caught.'' Citrano said both were respected and that Ms. Sheldon was active in community service projects. An administrative assistant at the Baylor University Baptist Student Center said although the town's many church people carry a lot of influence, she has heard only comments of curiosity and sympathy and anticipates no push to have the anchors taken off the air. ``We have tolerance _ a lot of tolerance,'' said the assistant, who would not give her name. She said many people who know the two and their families were concerned about their well-being and think they are being dragged through the mud. Virgil Teter, vice president for news at KWTX-TV, declined to say whether the two would retain their jobs. Police in Waco, a city of about 112,000 people between Dallas and Austin, said they have removed Ms. Sheldon from the missing persons files. Dennis O'Brien, the producer of ``A Current Affair,'' told the Waco newspaper the show will continue covering the anchors' disappearance.

DOC.HEAD: After Public Outcry, Police Ordered to Preserve All Files
DOC.TEXT: The government Wednesday ordered police and security officers nationwide to halt any destruction of files and other official records. The order, issued by Interior Minister Czeslaw Kiszczak, was in response to a request for such an edict Friday by Solidarity members of parliament who feared police were destroying evidence of past misdeeds, the state PAP news agency said. With Solidarity in control of the government and slowly tightening its hold on lower-level offices, there have been press reports about bonfires of police and Communist Party records in cities around the country. Interior Ministry Col. Kazimierz Piotrowski, director of the central police archives, said Tuesday that routine destruction of files had been carried out in recent weeks in accordance with the law, Solidarity's Gazeta Wyborcza and the government-owned Rzeczpospolita newspapers reported. Piotrowski said it is normal practice that after a certain period of time, police materials are destroyed unless they are of historical interest. A relaxation of censorship means the public will have access to part of the archives, Piotrowski said. But the files of police informants ``will never be disclosed to the public for obvious reasons.'' ``The SB (Security Service) is covering its tracks,'' said one article in Solidarity's Gazeta Wyborcza last week. Piotrowski denied any abuses. ``We are in telephone contact with chiefs of local archives and we are doing everything we can to preserve valuable materials.'' But he conceded that documents of the now-liquidated Security Service department that conducted surveillance on Roman Catholic priests considered a threat to the government were among those being destroyed if local departments consider them without historical value. Some documents concerning surveillance of the political opposition, many of whose members now occupy the parliament and high positions in government, also were destroyed, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Decries `Crisis' in Carryout Out Death Penalties
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said Wednesday there is a crisis over delays in carrying out the death penalty and he urged streamlining appeals procedures for death row inmates. ``Delay in the review and execution of capital sentences in this country has reached crisis proportions,'' he told a committee studying federal court reform. ``The average delay from time of conviction and sentence to time of execution of sentence in 1988 was six years and eight months.'' Thornburgh endorsed proposals of a committee headed by retired Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell calling for curtailing appeals in capital cases. The Powell committee also would give death row inmates a broader right to be represented by a lawyer at taxpayer expense. The Powell committee rcommended that states enact laws to limit death row inmates to two rounds of appeals in state and federal courts. One round would challenge a verdict directly; the second round would be based on alleged violations of the condemned individual's rights. The current systems permits indefinite appeals in federal courts. The attorney general said it is urgent to address ``the particularly acute problems of dilatory defense tactics and repetitive litigation in capital cases.'' Thornburgh also said he opposes plans to limit the power of federal courts to deal with drug law violations and shift enforcement to state courts. ``It is becoming increasingly clear that many local drug networks have national, sometimes international, roots that demand a coordinated federal response,'' he said. Thornburgh testified before the Federal Courts Study Committee, created by Congress to come up with plans by April for dealing with a host of problems and recommending changes. The committee, consisting of 15 members appointed by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, heard testimony in a Supreme Court conference room from numerous judges, public officials and lawyers. The panel called for comment on a 140-page draft report it released in December. It hopes to have a final report in April to be submitted to Congress, President Bush and Rehnquist. Wednesday's session focused in part on the committee's criticism of new sentencing guidelines in federal criminal cases. Thornburgh, among others, supported the guidelines and urged the committee to abandon its call for giving judges more freedom to depart from the guidelines. ``While the guidelines do restrict the range of appropriate sentencing more than some judges might prefer, that is the whole purpose'' of having them, he said. William W. Wilkins Jr., a federal appeals court judge who headed the commission that devised the guidelines, said the Federal Courts Study Committee is proposing to abandon the guidelines based on flimsy evidence. ``Congress may have underestimated the need for more resources to implement guidelines sentencing,'' Wilkins said. ``The answer to that problem would appear to be for this committee to recommend more judicial resources, not to call for virtual repeal'' of the law that authorized the new procedure. The Supreme Court last year upheld the constitutionality of the guidelines. Some judges say the new system gives prosecutors too much power to coerce guilty pleas while stripping judges of authority to use discretion in sentencing.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says He Will Keep Plugging Away On Negotiations
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III dismissed on Wednesday as ``a good example of a rumor'' reports that he is ready to set up Mideast negotiations. ``We are continuing to try to work on this problem,'' Baker said. ``I have had some discussions in recent days with both Israelis and Egyptians, and we are going to just continue to try and plug away and see if we can make progress.'' According to the reports, Baker is about to open the negotiations, either while he is in Europe next week on his way to Moscow or soon thereafter in Washington. ``That's a good example of a rumor,'' he told reporters in a brief exchange. Baker has been trying to set up a three-way meeting with foreign ministers Esmat Abdel-Meguid of Egypt and Moshe Arens of Israel for several months. The secretary said that he had talked recently with Egyptians and Israelis, but gave no indication that he has made any headway. The three-way session would be the first step towards holding elections among Palestinian Arabs on the West Bank and in Gaza. That, in turn, would lead to limited self-rule for the Palestinians under a plan proposed by Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and endorsed by Baker. On another subject, Baker reiterated U.S. opposition to Israel's settlement of Soviet Jewish refugees on the West Bank and in Gaza. He repeated the U.S. position that the settlements were ``an obstacle to peace'' and that none of the $3 billion in annual U.S. aid to Israel could be used for them. There are about 70,000 Jews living on the West Bank and in Gaza among an estimated 1.4 million to 1.75 million Arabs. About 1,000 Soviet Jews arrive in Israel weekly. Only 2 percent or less are settled on the West Bank and in Gaza.

DOC.HEAD: Oilseed Lobby Seeks Planting Fexibility
DOC.TEXT: A new lobbying group representing oilseed producers, processors and users called Wednesday for legislation to guarantee farmers a choice in what they produce under federal crop programs. The Oilseed Council of America said ``genuine planting flexibility'' would help solve a decline in the competitiveness of the U.S. oilseed industry. Oilseeds are led by soybeans, but also include cottonseed, sunflowers and canola. Lowell Wilson of Primghar, Iowa, co-chairman of the council, said current commodity programs have ``dramatically reduced acreage planted to oilseeds by requiring producers to plant commodities supported by target prices'' to protect crop program base acreages used to compute benefits. Wilson said there is genuine planting flexibility when federal programs are neutral in their effect on farmers' planting decisions. According to a study released here by the council, demand for protein meal and oil produced when oilseeds are crushed is growing at the rate of 4 percent a year. World trade in oilseeds and their products, the report said, has increased twice as fast as trade in wheat and feed grains. Despite the growth, the study reported that the U.S. share of global oilseed production has dropped to 24 percent from 39 percent six years ago, and that the U.S. share of oilseed trade has declined to 45 percent from 75 percent. Floyd Anderson of Bismarck, N.D., president of the National Sunflowerseed Association and co-chairman of the council, said planting flexibility would let farmers take advantage of the world demand for oilseeds by basing planting decisions on market situations as well as natural factors. The formation of the group coincides with moves in Congress to write new farm legislation to replace the 1985 law, which expires at the end of the 1990 crop season. But Anderson said in a statement the council does not advocate any specific programs and that there are a number of policy approaches that will give producers ``genuine planting flexibility'' and continue farm income protection.

DOC.HEAD: Maynard Jackson III Pleads No Contest to Marijuana Possesion
DOC.TEXT: Maynard Jackson III, the son of Atlanta's mayor, was fined the maximum $150 after he pleaded no contest to a misdemeanor charge of marijuana possession. The action came Tuesday in Atlanta Traffic Court. The younger Jackson also was found guilty of a charge of following too closely, and Judge Andrew Hairston fined him $60 on that charge. The judge ordered Jackson to report back to court in 30 days to pay the fines. Jackson was charged after a Jan. 9 traffic accident in Atlanta's Buckhead neighborhood, a day before his 19th birthday. Police said they found several marijuana cigarettes in his car. Mayor Maynard Jackson had said he wanted his son to receive no special treatment by city authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Just Another Inmate in Federal Prison
DOC.TEXT: Deposed Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega is ``just another inmate'' with a window in his cell, library and commissary privileges, and standard cafeteria food at a federal prison, officials say. But he cannot come in contact with other inmates and must wear dark green coveralls, not khaki, to distinguish him as a security risk at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in suburban Miami. Noriega, facing federal drug charges, was held for three weeks in a basement apartment in the downtown federal courthouse before his move Sunday. ``He's just another inmate as far as we're concerned,'' said spokesman Charles Davis. Noriega's cell measures 86 square feet, the same as the other cells. But most other prisoners have roommates because of crowding in the pretrial detention center. His cell is lighted with fluorescent bulbs and has a bed, wool blanket, chair, writing table and a partition in front of the commode and sink. Writing paper is provided. Like other inmates, Noriega will be allowed to submit a list of potential visitors for approval by prison officials. He and other inmates considered security risks ``are locked in their cells the entire day with the exception of an hour, an hour and a half for showers and exercise,'' Davis said. Most prisoners eat three times a day in the prison cafeteria, but guards pick Noriega's meals from the standard fare and deliver them to his cell. He is allowed to buy items from the commissary or check out library books, but only from afar. Noriega can shower whenever he wants, but the allotted five hours of outdoor exercise a week will be at varying times in a caged 20-foot-by-20-foot yard. A guard has been posted outside Noriega's cell, but no surveillance camera is used in the cell, Davis said. A camera has been installed in a nearby interview room for meetings with attorneys or visitors. Defense attorney Steven Kollin wouldn't comment on the new living conditions, but he renewed his contention that Noriega is a prisoner of war who should be released to a third country. A hearing on that claim is set for Feb. 8 before U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler.

DOC.HEAD: House Brushes Off Complaints About Voter Bill
DOC.TEXT: The House on Wednesday brushed aside efforts to delay a bill to ease voter registration procedures as what lawmakers had once billed as bipartisan harmony dissolved into party-line bickering. The House, on a key procedural vote, upheld 254-166 a rule requiring critics to tie all of their proposed amendments to the legislation into a single bundle. The House will then hold just one vote on the whole package next week when it turns to the legislation itself. ``And so begins the great voter registration debate of 1990,'' said Rep. Lynn Martin, R-Ill. ``Except that it won't be that great a debate.'' The so-called ``motor voter'' bill would make voter registration automatic for any eligible American applying for a driver's license. Other provisions would allow registration by postcard and at various government offices. Critics, spurred on the Bush administration, object to the rule giving them just one floor vote on all proposed amendments. Led by House Minority Leader Robert H. Michel, R-Ill., they want to junk restrictions on the offering of floor amendments. Such an ``open rule'' would give individual amendments a better chance of being adopted and also slow down House action on the bill. ``On Monday, the minority leader swooped into town and trashed the entire agreement,'' declared Rep. Al Swift, D-Wash., a chief sponsor of the bill. Swift blamed Michel for the collapse of what he called a bipartisan agreement fashioned in the Government Operations Committee to go forward with the bill. A number of Republicans had backed the measure. ``I feel you have made a major attack on the spirit of bipartisanship in this Congress,'' Swift said. He said the ``the minority leader has hung out to dry his whip, his conference chairman, his ranking member, the speaker of the House, the majority whip and me, and he says now he hopes this will not hurt the spirit of bipartisanship in this body. ``There's an old rule that says, fool me once shame on you ... I do not propose to be fooled again,'' Swift said. He said the episode could cut into cooperation between the parties on a major campaign finance reform package they are attempting to fashion jointly. ``Let's look before we leap and we're leaping here today,'' said Rep. Gerald B.H. Solomon, R-N.Y. Rep. Pat Roberts, R-Kan., urged lawmakers to ``look under the hood of motor voter before we end up in a ditch.'' Michel was not present for most of Swift's remarks, but came to the floor to answer the complaint, saying, ``I may have to share some of the blame for missed communication on my side, but I have not been kept as well informed (on voter registration) as I have on campaign reform.'' `` ... I'm sorry the gentleman should have this feeling because, boy, there was nothing intended on my part to gut the gentleman and turn things on their head here,'' Michel said. Numerous Republicans trouped to the microphones to complain about the rule, saying they needed more maneuvering room to combat what they described as burdensome procedures that will be imposed on the county clerks in their districts as well as substantially higher election costs on their states.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Votes Subpoenas in HUD Probe
DOC.TEXT: With a decision due on a special prosecutor for former Secretary Samuel R. Pierce Jr., a House subcommittee made plans Wednesday to resume hearings on the HUD scandal and issued subpoenas naming two former officials. The panel subpoeaned personal bank records of Lance Wilson, a former executive assistant to Pierce. It also voted to subpoena James Hammernick, former director of the office of insured multifamily housing develoment at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, to appear at a hearing Monday. The House Government Operations subcommittee on employment and housing, meanwhile, set two hearings on the HUD scandal for next week while it awaited word from Attorney General Dick Thornburgh on whether he will ask a federal appeals court to name a special prosecutor to investigate Pierce. Responding to a formal request by Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee last fall, Thornburgh opened a preliminary inquiry into whether a special prosecutor was warranted. The 60-day period for that inquiry expires Wednesday. There was speculation Thornburgh could ask the court for more time before deciding whether to seek the appointment of a prosecutor, called an independent counsel under the law. Wilson and Pierce both invoked their Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination and refused to testify before the subcommittee in hearings last fall, as did other former top HUD officials. Congressional investigators have been interested in Hammernick's relationship with Wilson after Wilson left HUD and became a private housing consultant and developer. Wilson's expense accounts filed with his employer, Paine Webber Inc., showed that he reported spending more than $1,000 entertaining Hammernick during one month in 1987. Hammernick and his attorney, John McCahill, did not return telephone calls seeking comment. Raymond Banoun, Wilson's attorney, could not be reached immediately for comment. The panel also voted to subpoena bank records involving accounts at two New York banks held by Wilson. The panel voted 5-0 to issue the subpoenas. Stuart Weisberg, subcommittee staff director, said the panel is continuing its investigation into allegations of fraud, mismanagement and influence-peddling at HUD during the Reagan administration. The panel's chairman, Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., said last fall that he was ready to end the panel's inquiry, which took up much of last year. Weisberg said the panel was awaiting Thornburgh's decision, however. He said the panel held open the possibility of scheduling more hearings and taking steps to compel testimony if Thornburgh decides against seeking a special prosecutor to investigate Pierce. The panel could grant immunity to compel testimony from witnesses who refuse to testify on constitutional grounds. Weisberg said McCahill had informed the subcommittee that his client would invoke a House rule allowing him to prohibit cameras and microphones from recording his subpoenaed appearance. Both Wilson and Pierce invoked that rule when they invoked the Fifth Amendment.

DOC.HEAD: Author of Trade Restrictions Law Says It Should be Waived
DOC.TEXT: A chief architect of U.S. trade restrictions against the Soviet Union and its allies said Wednesday they should be lifted immediately but not repealed outright. ``The rest of America is not yet prepared to consider anything more for the Soviet Union than a waiver'' despite the crumbling of the Iron Curtain and the massive changes taking place behind it, former Rep. Charles A. Vanik, D-Ohio, told the House Ways and Means Committee. Then chairman of the panel's trade subcommittee, Vanik and the late Sen. Henry Jackson, D-Wash., in 1974 co-authoried the Jackson-Vanik Amendment barriers imposing high tariffs on imports from the Soviet Union and its allies and denying them export credits to buy U.S. goods. Vanik said repealing the law entirely, as U.S. business leaders have urged, is unlikely because 20 percent of the public and Congress remain ``opposed to any relationship with the Soviet Union on the unrealistic basis that evil empires never change.'' However, he disagreed with President Bush's insistence that Moscow first put into law its recently adopted free emigration policies before granting the waivers conditionally promised to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Malta summit in December. ``I judge the Soviet Union by the deed more than the statute,'' Vanik said of recent Soviet emigration policies. ``The process appears to be a well-established, non-reversible course.'' He said U.S. slowness in normalizing trade relations with Moscow and the newly reincarnated governments of Eastern Europe risks losing those fledgling free markets to other Western powers such as Japan and West Germany. ``No other nation in the world stands to lose so much if it continues to stand still,'' he said. House Democrats expressed frustration that the adminsitration has not moved faster to lower the barriers to expanded trade with the Soviets and other East Europeans. ``We're worried, we don't see any actual planning for this,'' said Rep. Sam Gibbons, D-Fla. ``We don't spot the administration doing a lot.'' The Jackson-Vanik law was enacted largely to stop former President Nixon's efforts to conclude a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement in the early 1970s and to pressure Moscow to lift restrictions on the emigration of Soviet Jews and other dissidents. Since 1986, Soviet emigration has climbed from just under 2,000 to approximately 195,000 last year. Vanik said waiving the restrictions in his law ``is perhaps the best available official signal we have in our system ... to acknowledge what President Gorbachev has done (and) to acknowledge that we like what is going on.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Math, Science Education Lacking
DOC.TEXT: Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos discussed the solar system with fourth graders at a suburban Roman Catholic school Wednesday, hours before the president challenged American students to excel in math and science. ``Who can name the planets in the solar system?'' Cavazos asked the nearly two dozen youngsters at St. Camillus, an elementary school in Silver Spring, Md. ``We learned a sentence to help us know them,'' 9-year-old John Oduroe informed him. ``It goes, `My Very Energetic Mother Just Served Us Nine Pancakes.''' The boy then began to tick off the names of the planets as other classmates joined in _ Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune and Pluto _ showing they could be among the nation's better students. The visit by Cavazos, a former teacher who had served as president of Texas Tech University before joining the Reagan administration, underscored a message of President Bush in his State of the Union address _ American students must be first in the world by the year 2000 in science and math. Cavazos and other education officials have repeatedly that studies show: _Just 40 percent of American 13-year-old students could solve a two-step problem in math, compared with 72 percent of the South Korean students. _Only 42 percent of 13-year-old U.S. students could successfully analyze experiments, compared with 72 percent of the South Korean students. _Singapore ranks first in 12th grade biology, while America is dead last among 13 countries. _Fewer than 1 percent of U.S. students take physics and chemistry, while up to 25 percent of 18-year-olds in Canada and Norway take the two subjects for two years each. _Japan and Korea tie for first in general science for 10-year-olds, while America ranks eighth. However, officials of the National Catholic Educational Association are quick to show that Catholic math students score 3.6 percent to 5.46 percent better than public school students and Catholic school science scores are higher that public schools by 4.39 percent in the third grade, 6.36 percent in the seventh grade and 3.76 percent in the 11th grade. ``The solution of American problems will not be solved by one educational system alone, but every system working together,'' Cavazos told an audience that included the 278 St. Camillus students, some of their parents and Catholic education officials. The selection of St. Camillus served a variety of purposes during celebration of ``National Appreciation Day for Catholic Schools.'' Besides having high-achieving youngsters, Principal Suzette Chagnon estimates her students come from families originating in at least 25 countries. The Bush administration has been bombarded with suggested ways to improve academic achievement, especially among members of minority groups, since President Bush called the nation's governors to an education ``summit conference'' last year. The ideas are to be distilled into national goals by late February. American students attend school about 180 days per year, while Europeans typically attend 220 days, the Japanese 240 days and South Koreans 250 days per year, Senate Democratic leader George Mitchell has pointed out. Scott Thomson, executive director of the National Association of Secondary School Principals, says that in Germany, radio and television programs on math and science supplement school work. In South Korea, 71 percent of the 13-year-old students watch science programs compared with only 37 percent in America. ``At about that age, many American students fail to keep an active interest in science,'' said Thomson. ``Schools need to work harder to make science attractive, but other institutions in society must support this effort.'' Thomson added that in a 1987 survey of 3,000 high school sophomores who were asked whether, ``my parents think science is a very important subject,'' 57 percent said ``no.''

DOC.HEAD: Trucking Group Wants to Ban Alcohol Sale at Stops
DOC.TEXT: The American Trucking Association said Wednesday that it will campaign to ban the sale of alcohol at truck stops across the country. Thomas J. Donahue, president of the trade group, said the step, which would require action by the states or cooperation by truck stops, is part of an industry effort to identify and fire truckers who drink or use drugs while driving. But Donahue acknowleged at a news conference that the industry is trying to avoid the imposition of federal regulations mandating the use of expensive Breathalyzers to detect alcohol consumption. In comments filed Wednesday with the Department of Transportation, the association said that compelling all trucking companies to buy individual Breathalyzers to test drivers could cost from $510 million to $850 million. Attaching Breathalyzers to the ignition on each truck to prevent use of the vehicle if alcohol consumption was detected could cost ``close to $2 billion,'' the association said. Donahue said alcohol and drug testing should be conducted during state-mandated roadside checks. ``Blowing in an apparatus (installed in the truck) to see if you can drive doesn't make sense,'' he said. ``Cost is a huge factor,'' Donahue said, adding that alcohol and drug testing conducted solely by trucking companies would also prove to be a considerable administrative burden. ``We want the roads safe. That's good business, good politics for us. But we don't want it stupid. ``The American people have the right to believe that the driver of an 80,000 pound vehicle is sober,'' Donahue said, adding that the 5 million truckers already are forbidden to drink or use drugs on the job or to have alcohol in their trucks. ``It doesn't make sense to sell it to them,'' he said about sales at truck stops. ``It's an unnecessary temptation to the drivers.'' Donahue said the association will seek the support of the National Association of Truck Stop Operators at its annual convention in Las Vegas on Thursday. He said he believes that alcohol and drug abuse is a relatively small problem in the trucking industry, far less than for drivers as a whole. But he said there was room for improvement and that the industry should show no tolerance for those who break the rules.

DOC.HEAD: 3 Arrested During Incident at Capitol
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested three people Wednesday after demonstrators protesting the plight of the homeless threw what they said was blood on the U.S. Capitol hours before the president's State of the Union address. The demonstrators were identified as members of the Community for Creative Non-Violence, an organization that runs a 1,400-bed shelter for the homeless near the Capitol. ``The state of the union as we view it is very different than the way President Bush sees it,'' said Mitch Snyder, a leader of the organization. ``We felt compelled to communicate that view of the state of the union.'' Red liquid was splattered on outdoor pillars and steps on both the Senate and House sides of the building. The acts were committed simultaneously about noon while Congress was in session. A spokesman for the Capitol police, Dan Nichols, said two women and a man were arrested. They were identified as Elizabeth Mastropierro, 22, and Rachel Frankel, 30, both of Washington. Each was charged with injuring government property, a federal felony carrying a maximum penalty of a $10,000 fine and 10 years in prison, and committing an act of physical violence on U.S. Capitol grounds, a federal misdemeanor that carries a maximum penalty of a $50 fine and six months in jail. Nichols said that when police tried to cordon off the area so that it could be cleaned, a man identified as Charles O'Lare, 22, of Washington refused to leave and was charged with unlawful entry, a District of Columbia misdemeanor carrying a maximum sentence of a $500 fine and six months in jail. While workmen scrubbed the building clean, Rep. Dan Burton, R-Ind., took the floor of the House to express his outrage over the vandalism. He likened the incident to desecration of the American flag and said Congress should act to protect its symbols. ``Some people threw what appears to be blood on the outside of the U.S. Capitol,'' he said. ``All of us ought to be indignant.''

DOC.HEAD: Prices Farmers Receive Rise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial circuits
DOC.TEXT: Prices farmers get for raw products rose 2.7 percent from December to January, leaving the monthly average also 2.7 percent above the year-ago level, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Higher prices for tomatoes, lettuce and broilers mostly were responsible for the increase from December, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report. ``Tomato prices more than doubled due to short supplies brought on by the freeze in Florida in December,'' the report said. ``Lettuce prices were nearly double for the same reason.'' Commercial vegetables as a group were up 68 percent from December and 32 percent from a year ago. Lower prices were reported for soybeans, strawberries and oranges. Milk prices at the farm, which had risen to record levels late last year, were unchanged in January. Department dairy economists have forecast that milk prices would level off this year. Prices paid by farmers to meet expenses, meanwhile, were up 1.1 percent from October, the previous reading, and averaged 2.9 percent above a year ago, the report said. The ``prices paid'' index is revised every three months. The report said prices for feeder cattle and calves, feeder pigs, diesel fuel and LP gas were up from October. Department economists say the net cash income of farmers in 1990 may be in the range of $52 billion to $57 billion, compared with about $53 billion in 1989. Net cash income is the money nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. In another method taking into account changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during a calendar year shows that 1990 net farm income may be in the range of $44 billion to $49 billion, compared with $48 billion last year. Consumer food prices are estimated by department economists to have risen about 5.7 percent this year, the sharpest rise since 1981. They project food prices may rise 3 percent to 5 percent in 1990. Based on the preliminary figures, the January price index for livestock and poultry was unchanged from December but averaged 7.6 percent more than a year ago. Crop prices, overall, rose 6.3 percent from December but averaged 4.3 percent below a year ago. The sharp rise in the price of commercial vegetables caused most of the increase from December, the report said. The fruit index dropped 9.3 percent from December and was 9.8 percent below a year earlier. ``All fruit prices used in the index were down from last month except for apples and lemons which were up slightly,'' the report said. ``Oranges and strawberries had the largest downward influence on the index.'' The report said: _Cattle averaged $71.60 per 100 pounds of live weight nationally, up from $71 in December and $70.60 in January 1989. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. _Hogs averaged $46.90 per 100 pounds, compared with $48.20 in December and $40.90 a year earlier. _Corn, at $2.26 a bushel, edged down from $2.27 in December and was down from $2.60 a year earlier. _Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $3.83 per bushel, compared with $3.80 in December and $4.02 a year earlier. _Rice averaged $7.11 per 100 pounds, up from $6.95 in December and $6.58 in January 1989. _Soybeans were $5.52 per bushel, down from $5.64 in December and far below the year-earlier mark of $7.69 per bushel. _Upland cotton was reported at 60.2 cents per pound, down from 61.4 cents in December but above the average of 54.7 cents a year earlier. _Eggs were 83.8 cents per dozen, up from 82.8 cents in December and 63.9 cents a year earlier. _Milk was $16.10 per 100 pounds, unchanged from December but above the year-earlier average of $13.40. _Broilers were 30.7 cents per pound, live weight, up from 28.6 cents in December but down from the 35.3 cents of a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Chairman Lends Name to North Fundraiser
DOC.TEXT: Republican National Committee chairman Lee Atwater, saying ``I make no bones about'' supporting Oliver L. North, is allowing his name to be used in connection with an upcoming fund-raising affair for the convicted Iran-Contra figure. Atwater is one of 25 people _ including conservative fund-raiser Richard Viguerie and Equal Rights Amendment foe Phyllis Schlafly _ on the host committee for the March 3 ``Salute to Oliver North.'' The event is organized by the Legal Affairs Council of Chantilly, Va. North was convicted last May of three felonies in the Iran-Contra affair. Arguments in his appeal will be heard Tuesday in federal appeals court in Washington. ``I don't mind at all being counted among his supporters; I make no bones about it,'' said Atwater. Atwater, who won't be able to attend because of ``a long-time speaking engagement'' that day in Puerto Rico, said he hasn't donated money to the event and ``hadn't thought about'' doing so. The RNC chairman said that he ``was frankly not sure what my name would be used for'' when he was approached recently by organizers of the event ``but I didn't hesitate and I don't hesitate now.'' North is ``a good man ... a well-meaning man ... a true patriot,'' who ``may have made some mistakes,'' said Atwater, adding, ``I don't know anybody who hasn't.'' A separate congressional host committee for the event lists 40 representatives and 11 senators, including Sens. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. Forty-one conservative groups are co-sponsoring the event. Tickets for the reception and dinner sell for $150 apiece. The Legal Affairs Council, which staged a ``salute'' barbecue for North last September, has raised and contributed $315,000 to the former National Security Council aide, the organization said in a Jan. 16 mailing addressed to ``Friends of Oliver North.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Magazine Delayed in Customs Because of Disputed Kashmir Map
DOC.TEXT: Distribution of this week's edition of Newsweek magazine has been delayed because a map depicts large parts of the Jammu-Kashmir region as Pakistani territory, a senior customs official said Wednesday. India and Pakistan both claim Jammu-Kashmir. The 43-year-old dispute heated up again when India launched a crackdown Jan. 20 against Kashmiri Moslems who want to secede from India. The customs official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the 10,000 copies of Newsweek that arrived at Bombay airport early Wednesday have not been impounded. But he said a process often used to speed up clearance for weekly magazines is not being used to clear the Newsweek issue. Normally, consignments must be cleared against a bill of entry, a procedure that can take up to two days. In cases considered urgent, the consignments are cleared faster with an understanding that bill of entry formalities will be completed later. ``This is a facility extended in rare cases, not as a matter of right but for convenience,'' the customs official said. In previous disputes over maps in foreign publications, India has allowed the books or magazines in question to enter the country after stamping them with notations that the borders are ``neither correct nor authenticated.'' There was no indication whether this would happen to the Newsweek map. Newsweek is distributed in India by Living Media India Ltd. A company spokesman declined comment on the customs action.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Legislation Prefers U.N. Plan Over Sihanouk, Hun Sen Proposals
DOC.TEXT: The major powers' new blueprint for peace in Cambodia through U.N.-supervised disarmament and preparation for free elections won initial backing in Congress Wednesday. Two House subcommittees endorsed a resolution strongly supporting the proposal for interim U.N. supervision and administration after chairmen of both panels described it as the best hope for ending Cambodia's bloodshed and blocking the return of the communist Khmer Rouge. The legislation was sent with unanimous voice-vote endorsements to the full Foreign Affairs committee on what congressional aides called a ``fast track'' aimed at getting approval of both houses of Congress before Secretary of State James Baker's February meeting in Moscow with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Sheverdnadze. The resolution would have Congress reject major rival proposals that deadlocked last summer's international conference on Cambodia, allowing the Southeast Asian country to slide into revived civil war. One would have given Cambodia a four-faction interim government led by U.S.-backed Prince Norodom Sihanouk and including the Khmer Rouge, blamed for more than 1 million Cambodian deaths during their 1975-78 rule. The other would have allowed Premier Hun Sen's Vietnam-installed government in Phonm Penh to continue ruling until the elections. Sihanouk's four-party proposal ``is not an acceptable basis for negotiations because it would legitimize the Khmer Rouge,'' and allow it to subvert the interim government, said the resolution. It added that letting Hun Sen's regime to stay in power ``would legitimize an illegitimate government'' and undermine confidence in the elections. ``Anything less than a strong international presence could pave the way for a return to power of the genocidal Pol Pot,'' leader of the Khmer Rouge, said the Human Rights subcommittee Chairman, Democrat Gus Yatron. The resolution might produce ``some positive action'' by Sihanouk to end his controversial alliance with the Khmer Rouge, or ``it could maybe mean the end'' for him, Yatron said in answer to a reporter. Asian-Pacific subcommittee Chairman Stephen Solarz was chief sponsor of the resolution backing the U.N. formula framed by the five permanent Security members meeting in Paris two weeks ago along lines proposed by Australia. The five permament members are the United States, Soviet Union, China, Britain and France.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Objector Cause of Band's Rift with American Legion
DOC.TEXT: An American Legion post is dropping its sponsorship of a bagpipe band after 42 years because a band member was a conscientious objector to the Vietnam War. Charlie McElwain, 43, a Seventh Day Baptist, requested medical or non-combat duties instead of military service when he was drafted. His draft board instead asked him to work two years at Memorial General Hospital in Elkins. American Legion Post 29 learned last year that McElwain was a conscientious objector and in August asked him to withdraw from the 27-member West Virginia Highlander Bagpipe Band. ``The state and national constitutions of the American Legion say that no person can be associated with the American Legion who has not offered himself to the military in an unqualified state,'' said Post 29 band committee chairman Robert Magos. ``If you go in there and say, `I won't do this and I won't do that and I won't fight and I won't carry a gun,' then you do not qualify under the Constitution of the American Legion,'' Magos said. ``I believe it's discrimination against my religion and my freedoms as an American,'' said McElwain, who said his ancestors came to this country in 1745. The band marches in parades and has played at everything from funerals and weddings to the Apple Blossom Festival in Virginia. Last month, the post passed a set of rules the band would have to live by for continued support, including one that all band members be approved by Legion members. Band members refused and Post 29 dropped its sponsorship, including the band's right to hold a weekly bingo game at the Legion hall under the Legion post's state bingo license. Band pipe major Tom McLaughlin said the bingo game, which Post 29 has taken over, raised about $15,000 a year. McElwain said the community stands behind him in the dispute. ``Everybody I've talked to has supported me. One fellow I work with was a full colonel in one of the services. He said he supported me 100 percent,'' McElwain said. Magos said the Legion post had to take over the band's Saturday night bingo fund-raiser in October to ensure that it was run according to state law. ``People were getting paid to run the bingo games, which is outside the state law,'' Magos said. ``We repeatedly told the band not to do it any more, to no avail, and we had to take some action.'' But McLaughlin said post officials were just looking for an excuse to take over the game. ``We never broke the law. They just wanted the money from the bingo game,'' McLaughlin said. ``I don't think Charlie's conscientious objector status has a thing to do with what they're doing,'' he said. ``I think that was just a smoke screen to get at the money. McLaughlin said inquiries have been made about other groups sponsoring the band, but nothing has been signed. ``We're trying to set ourselves up just to keep ourselves going, and anything beyond that we give that back to charity,'' he said. ``I think at the beginning, my status was a way of getting at the money, but I think they eventually decided they needed to get me, too,'' McElwain said. Despite the dispute, the American Legion has continued to let the band use its hall for practice.

DOC.HEAD: Three Largest Parties Agree on Coalition Cabinet
DOC.TEXT: The three largest political parties agreed Wednesday, in an apparent effort at national unity, that the next president should have a coalition Cabinet. The agreement among the Liberal, Conservative and Patriotic Union parties will apply to the person who is elected May 27 and takes office Aug. 7. President Virgilio Barco, a Liberal, has earned international praise for his war on drug traffickers, but squabbling among the three parties has cost him support at home. Colombia's constitution limits a president to one term of four years. Former President Misael Pastrana, head of the Conservative Party, proposed the coalition Cabinet earlier this month. Former President Julio Cesar Turbay of the Liberals and Diego Montana Cuellar, leader of the Patriotic Union, sent open letters of agreement Wednesday. Nothing has been said about how many of the 13 Cabinet posts each party would get. In 1958, in an effort to end a civil war that had taken more than 200,000 lives, the Conservatives and Liberals agreed to alternate in the presidency for 16 years. After the 1976 presidential election, the two parties continued with another part of the agreement that assured both of Cabinet representation. Barco ended that last year when he reorganized the Cabinet and gave all the ministries to Liberals. The Patriotic Union is a Marxist coalition organized five years ago by leftist guerrillas who accepted pardons from the government of President Belisario Betancur. When he proposed the coalition Cabinet, Pastrana also suggested a national plebiscite on constitutional reforms. Political leaders have suggested reform of Colombia's court system and allowing the president more power in emergencies like the drug war. There also have been proposals that presidents be allowed more than one term. Montana Cuellar said in his letter to Pastrana that he supported a plebiscite, but Turbay of the Liberals said he doubted agreement on what should be included could be reached before the May 27 election. In London, Amnesty International expressed concern Wednesday about the increasing number of people missing in Colombia, including 42 farm workers reported kidnapped Jan. 14. It said the workers were seized by 40 armed men, some wearing military uniforms, at Pueblo Bello in northwestern Colombia. The village is in the Uraba banana plantation, scene of heavy fighting the past few months between government forces and leftist guerrillas. Amnesty said the workers were tied up and loaded into two trucks, which drove away. Witnesses said the assailants set fire to several houses and other buildings before leaving, the statement added. Gov. Herran de Montoya of Uraba said the kidnappers apparently were guerrillas, but Colombian radio networks that sent reporters to the town said they appeared to be members of a right-wing death squad. There has been no word on the fate of the kidnapped people. Death squads have killed more than 1,000 people the past four years. A government investigation determined there were more than 100 such squads in Colombia and most were run by drug traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's New Budget Already Under Congressional Attack
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's 1991 budget came under renewed congressional attack on Wednesday with critics brandishing figures that called into question $37 billion of the deficit reduction being claimed by the administration. The analysis, done by the bipartisan Congressional Budget Office, said that the deficit for next year, without policy changes, would total $138 billion, not the $101 billion claimed by the administration. CBO Director Robert D. Reischauer said that $26 billion of the higher deficit estimate was accounted for by using a less optimistic forecast on economic growth and interest rates. The other $11 billion was attributed to higher projections on government spending in such areas as the savings and loan bailout and health care. The growth forecast is critical to the government's revenue assumptions while the interest rate forecast affects estimates of how much the government will have to spend to finance the $2.8 trillion national debt. By using higher growth and lower interest rate assumptions than the CBO and most private economists, the administration was able to come up with a starting deficit of $101 billion next year, compared to the CBO's $138 billion figure. That means that the administration was only required to produce $37 billion in savings to meet the legal requirement of proposing a budget with a $64 billion deficit in the 1991 budget year, which starts next October. By using the CBO's assumptions, which track the consensus forecast of private economists, the administration would have had to double the amount of spending cuts or tax increases needed to meet the Gramm-Rudman deficit target. House Budget Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said that he could not remember such a wide disparity between the administration's economic assumptions and the CBO. ``We are facing a terrible credibility problem with the American people on the base of these estimates,'' Panetta said. Congress is free to adopt either the CBO estimate or the assumptions in the Bush budget in drawing up its own spending plan, but the administration's economic assumptions are required to be used in determining whether across-the-board spending cuts will be triggered if the deficit is not reduced enough. Both Budget Director Richard Darman and Michael Boskin, chairman of the president's Council of Economic Advisers, were sharply questioned about the economic assumptions during separate appearances on Thursday. Boskin, appearing before the House Budget Committee, said that the economy was going through a sluggish period at present, with growth slumping to an anemic rate of just 0.5 percent in the final three months of 1990, but he predicted a rebound would occur in coming months. He did not rule out, however, the possibility that growth as measured by the gross national product, might dip below 1 percent in the current January-March quarter. Under the Gramm-Rudman law, two consecutive quarters of growth below 1 percent would require lawmakers to vote on suspending the deficit reduction targets for 1991. Boskin said Congress should not suspend the deficit targets, especially if there were signals that growth was beginning to rebound, because it could send a signal that the government's deficit-fighting resolve was weakening. ``A suspension of Gramm-Rudman could have very unfavorable impacts on financial markets and cause interest rates to rise,'' he said. Darman, testifying before the Senate Budget Committee, was hammered by Democrats, who described the budget as unrealistic in its economic assumptions and in its call for $292 billion for the military. ``This is a menu of Cold War leftovers and warmed-over Reagan,'' said Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the committee. ``I'm not at all sure we are going to get a budget (agreement) unless the rhetoric turns down,'' said Sen. Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, senior Republican on the panel. Darman denied the budget ignores the movement toward democracy in Eastern Europe, which many lawmakers view as requiring less military spending. ``The reality is that this is a budget which proposes a 2.6 percent real cut (in military spending) in the first year and a 2 percent real cut every year thereafter,'' he said. ``I do not regard this as a serious budget,'' said Sen. Bennett Johnston, D-La. He asked Darman: ``When do we get down to the serious business of getting together with the White House'' and negotiating a compromise? ``We'd be prepared to start at 10 o'clock tonight after the president's speech,'' Darman replied, referring to Bush's State of the Union address.

DOC.HEAD: Ringed Seal Flown to Colder Waters
DOC.TEXT: A ringed seal not usually found in the warmer ocean along the New Jersey shore was flown Wednesday to colder waters off Massachusetts. The 36-pound, 9-month-old seal that washed ashore last week in Sandy Hook was flown by Robert Kindle, a Wildwood automobile dealer who donated his six-passenger plane, said Sheila Dean, co-director of the Marine Mammal Stranding Center here. Center director Robert Schoelkopf also went on the flight, Ms. Dean said. The seal was to be flown to Provincetown, Mass., where it will be placed in the water, Ms. Dean said. The seal gained 5{ pounds in its stay at the stranding center, feeding on minnows and shrimp. Center officials bleached a number on the seal's back in case it washes ashore again, Ms. Dean said. The seal is too small to carry a radio tag to monitor its whereabouts, Ms. Dean said.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant Skips Court Minutes Before Acquittal
DOC.TEXT: If Michael Leonard Jackson had waited a few minutes more he could have walked out of court a free man. But he didn't wait, and he became a wanted man. Jackson, 26, of Pensacola left the Escambia County Judicial Center on Jan. 24 just before jurors found him innocent of burglary and theft. Circuit Judge Nickolas Geeker ordered his arrest for failure to appear in court. Formal charges were filed Tuesday; Jackson remained at-large Wednesday, authorities said. Gary Suttles, Jackson's lawyer, said he has talked to his client since he left the courtroom and that he knows he was acquitted. He refused to discuss why Jackson, who was free on bond during the trial, left. Suttles and Jackson had returned to the courtroom after being told the jurors would announce their verdict momentarily. The lawyer said that before the judge and jury filed into the courtroom Jackson asked if he could go to a snack bar in the building to get his girlfriend. ``When he went downstairs, he did not return,'' Suttles said. Geeker noted the defendant's absence and read the jury's verdict.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Abortion Forces Claim Two Victories in Wisconsin
DOC.TEXT: The Wisconsin Assembly approved a parental consent bill for minors obtaining abortions Wednesday, a day after it defeated an attempt to repeal a dormant law that penalizes doctors who perform abortions. Anti-abortion forces said the two votes were overwhelming victories for their national movement, but pro-choice leaders, while conceding defeat, predicted the actions would help them unseat lawmakers in the fall elections. ``We will remember in November,'' Denise Matyka, a pro-choice leader and past president of Wisconsin National Organization for Women, told a rally outside the Capitol hours after the consent bill was approved. ``We will show the politicians that a vote against reproductive choice is a vote against the will of the people.'' The consent bill, which requires girls under 18 to get the permission of at least one parent or a judge before having an abortion, now advances to the Senate where lawmakers warned it likely would be stalled in committee. ``We will not move too hastily on this matter,'' Senate President Fred Risser said Wednesday, noting the nine-week legislative session ends March 23. Susan Armacost, legislative director of Wisconsin Right to Life Inc., said the Assembly vote to delay the repeal bill and pass the consent measure was ``obviously a bitter defeat for pro-abortion forces.'' She said her group would press for Senate action on the parental consent measure. ``This bill is too important to be delayed. It already has been delayed too long.'' But state Rep. Robert Welch, an anti-abortion leader in the Assembly, said he wasn't optimistic about winning Senate approval this session. Assembly Speaker Thomas A. Loftus criticized the consent bill. ``It fails in the areas of reality, compassion and common sense,'' Loftus told the Assembly before the final vote. ``It's designed to get this state to the extreme side of the anti-abortion movement.'' Loftus said a provision in the bill defines abortion for minors differently than it is defined in other statutes. Abortion is the use of any instrument, medicine, drug or any other substance or device with intent to terminate the pregnancy of a minor, the bill said. ``This bill is designed to outlaw contraceptives,'' Loftus said, adding that the provision would include experimental drugs such as a French pill to induce abortion and the ``morning-after'' pill. The Assembly voted 57-39 Tuesday against repealing a dormant state law that provides criminal penalties for performing abortions. The law was rendered unenforceable by the U.S. Supreme Court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade ruling that legalized abortion. Abortion opponents said they want to keep the law on the books in hope the Roe vs. Wade decision will someday be overturned. Welch said the votes on the two bills were important because they marked the first time a state legislature acted on the abortion issue since the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in a Missouri case last summer that states could have greater latitude in regulating abortions. ``This sends a clear signal nationally because it marked such a resounding victory,'' Welch said. ``I think this was a shot heard round the world.'' But state Rep. David Clarenbach hailed the repeal vote despite the defeat, saying a year ago the same bill would have received far fewer votes in favor. ``The trend is running against abortion opponents,'' said Clarenbach, the Assembly's president pro tem. ``The Legislature is in the process of becoming pro-choice.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Wants More Time Before Romanian Elections
LaserPhotos XBUC3,5
DOC.TEXT: The major opposition party warned Wednesday that Romania will wind up with a new communist dictatorship unless elections set for May are delayed four months to give people time to absorb all the changes. The reaction from the National Peasants Party was wary, and from some other opponents downright hostile to Tuesday's announcement by the revolutionary government that it planned to keep on governing while competing in elections. The self-appointed National Salvation Front offered to share power and establish a separate political wing to represent it in Romania's first free elections since World War II. ``This is illegal, ''said Liberal Party organizer Nicolae Enescu. ``If it takes part in the elections and represents the interests of the state, it seems like a dictatorship again.'' Valentin Gabrielescu, chief spokesman for the Peasants Party, said the elections should be postponed from May 20 until September ``in order to try to educate the Romanian people about the electoral process.'' ``After half a century of dictatorial rule, these people are completely confused. It will take time to educate them,'' he added. Growing political anxiety has replaced the euphoria that followed the ouster of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, overthrown in a popular uprising last month and executed Dec. 25 with his politically powerful wife, Elena. The tensions were highlighted by pro- and anti-government demonstrations this week, sychronized attacks on 27 Peasants Party headquarters nationwide on Monday, and political arguments that continue to draw crowds on Bucharest's freezing street corners. The opposition lays much of the blame on the National Salvation Front, ruling by decree since it took power in the chaos that followed the revolution ending Ceausescu's 24-year rule. Enemies of the Front claim its 11-member ruling council has manipulated the electorate through its control of the news media and all other organs of the state, seeking an edge in advance of the May elections. ``Maybe in the fall, we'll be able to win the election. Otherwise, we will have a new communist government and (interim President Ion) Iliescu will be one of the `most beloved sons of the country,'' Gabrielescu said, derisively using the term the prerevolutionary press frequently bestowed on Ceausescu. ``The way is very difficult because we have 40 years of political vacuum,'' concurred Peasants Party President Corneliu Coposu, a 74-year-old church canon lawyer who was imprisoned from 1946-74 by successive Communist leaders. In a response to criticism, the Front disclosed Tuesday it had split in two, creating a Provisional National Council to run Romania until the elections in tandem with other political parties, and converting the Front into a political organization to field candidates. ``The Front will participate in the vote,'' senior Front official Silviu Brucan said in an interview in Wednesday's Romania Libera daily, reiterating his organization's intention to run the elections. It was the Front's reversal of its pledge not to run in elections, and questions about whether it could fairly administer an election in which it was also competing, that drew heavy fire, including condemnation from potential Western aid donors. Ana Blandiana, a leading poet and former dissident, resigned from the Front, citing ``shattered illusions,'' Romania Libera said. She was the fourth leading Front member to step down. While the National Peasants Party branded as ``impudent'' the Front's transformation into both a political party and a government, it also called it a gain for the opposition. ``Our proposal was agreed to in principle, so the first point is a win,'' said Gabrielescu. He said the next major battle for the opposition will be to win two-thirds of the seats in the projected 100-seat Provisional National Council. ``The most important thing is simply the presence of parties in the council,'' agreed Sergiu Cunescu, president of the Social Democratic Party. He expressed optimism that splitting up of the Front would ease political tensions. The Peasants Party, the Social Democrats and the Liberals _ the three major opposition groups _ say most of the 30 or so opposition parties that have sprung up since the revolution are fakes, backed by the Front to tout its party line under other names. With 260,000 members, the Peasants Party is the largest opposition organization. The United States took aim at the National Salvation Front on Tuesday. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said in Washington, ``We are deeply troubled by what appears to be active intimidation of legitimate organizations which are seeking a legitimate, independent role in Romania's new political order.''

DOC.HEAD: Silent Screen Actress Helen Jerome Eddy Dies
DOC.TEXT: Silent screen star Helen Jerome Eddy, known for her portrayals of high-class heroines in such movies as the 1916 version of ``Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm,'' has died of heart failure. She was 92. Miss Eddy died Saturday at the Episcopal Home, spokeswoman Nancy Potthast said Wednesday. There was no funeral. Raised in Los Angeles, Miss Eddy was attracted to films by the old Philadelphia-based studios of Siegmund Lubin, which had just opened a Los Angeles lot in her neighborhood. Her first film in 1915 was ``The Red Virgin.'' She moved from there to Paramount Studios and began to portray the roles for which she became known. In addition to ``Rebecca of Sunnybrook Farm,'' those roles included ``The March Hare'' in 1921, ``The Dark Angel'' in 1925, ``Camille'' in 1927 and ``The Divine Lady'' in 1927. Her last movie, a talkie, was ``Strike Up the Band'' in 1940, in which she played Mrs. Brewster, the mother of one of Mickey Rooney's friends. Miss Eddy never married and leaves no known survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Set-Aside Reduced
DOC.TEXT: Rice farmers will have to idle only 20 percent of their acreage to qualify for this year's price support program instead of the 22.5 percent announced on Jan. 3, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Wednesday. Yeutter said the lower set-aside, which means farmers can plant more for the 1990 harvest, was decided after reviewing recent projected rice supply-and-demand figures. The figures showed the U.S. rice inventory will be drawn down to 19 million hundredweight by Aug. 1, the lowest reserve at the start of a new rice marketing year since the 1980 crop. The inventory last Aug. 1 was 26.7 million hundredweight.

DOC.HEAD: Chief Congressional Tax Writer Sees No Need for Tax System Changes
DOC.NOTE: For Release 8 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, the senior tax writer in Congress, said Wednesday he remains to be convinced that the federal tax system is in need of any major change. Rostenkowski, an Illinois Democrat who chairs the House Ways and Means Committee, cited a cut in the capital-gains tax _ a major goal of President Bush _ as a prime example of something he feels is not needed. In a speech to the Tax Council, a business group, Rostenkowski compared advocates of a lower capital-gains tax to ``fuzzy-minded peace advocates who think that we could somehow wish the creation of a stable world that would allow us all to disarm.'' ``Both have a deep faith that belies historic experience,'' he said. ``Both have a fervent belief that the wish is the father of the deed. And, unfortunately, both are dead wrong.'' Capital gains are profits from the sale of stock and other investments. Since a lower tax rate for capital gains was repealed in 1986, Rostenkowski noted, the value of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange has risen 40 percent. ``I am not claiming that our tax laws have boosted the market,'' Rostenkowski said. ``To the contrary, I am arguing that the market has a dynamic of its own that is generally independent of our tax laws.'' The chairman also expressed his distaste for special tax breaks offered as incentives to encourage saving. ``I've become convinced ... that most tax incentives simply don't work,'' he said. ``And the few that do work, don't work very well.'' Bush is asking Congress to create a new savings plan that would allow a couple with income of $120,000 or less to avoid tax on interest earned on special accounts held at least seven years. Other savings plans built around tax breaks have done little to boost the nation's low rate of personal saving, Rostenkowski said. Rostenkowski said he is open to suggestions for modernizing the tax law. ``But I am not convinced that our tax system is fundamentally broken,'' he said. ``Thus I have little sympathy with those who keep coming up with plans to fix it.''

DOC.HEAD: Kenya Seeks Help From Jewish Lobby
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `arap' is cq
DOC.TEXT: Kenya's President Daniel arap Moi urged American Jewish leaders Wednesday to use their influence in Congress to increase U.S. aid for his country. Moi, speaking to representatives of 50 major Jewish organizations, also said Jewish leaders should influence the U.S. government to provide funding to projects for developing semi-arid areas in Kenya with expertise from Israel. ``I know your influence is tremendous,'' Moi said. Kenya last year resumed diplomatic relations with Israel, which had been severed in 1973 under heavy pressure from the Arab world. Moi is in Washington on a private visit to attend Thursday's National Prayer Breakfast. President Bush will be the keynote speaker at the interdenominational gathering, which has been held each year since World War II and is attended by religious and political leaders. Moi said relations between his country and the United States had improved greatly under the Bush administration, but that Kenya still needs help in improving contacts with Congress. U.S. aid to Kenya has declined in recent years. Some members of Congress have sharply criticized Kenya for its human-rights record, but Moi called the accusations ``imaginary things.'' Moi is scheduled to meet Thursday with Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., the powerful chairman of the House foreign operations subcommittee who has been a frequent critic of Kenya's human-rights record.

DOC.HEAD: Transit Authority Appeals Ruling Against Begging Ban
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with judge issuing partial stay on injunction, reax from Port Authority. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced Wednesday that the MTA is appealing a judge's decision that struck down a rule against panhandling in the subways. Begging ``lends an air of disorder'' said MTA Chairman Robert Kiley. U.S. District Judge Leonard Sand then issued a partial stay on an injunction that barred the MTA from enforcing the rule. Sand put back into effect, pending the appeal, one of his earlier orders that allowed begging in the subway system except on subway cars, narrow platforms and 25 feet from token booths. Kiley said he believes Sand was wrong when he decided Friday that begging in public places is free speech protected by the First Amendment. The ruling, Kiley said, was ``incorrect, unreasonable and insensitive of the rights of the millions of passengers who use the subways.'' The MTA set into motion the appeal process by filing a notice of appeal with the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. A motion to stay the order is pending before Sand, who was to hear arguments later Wednesday. Sand's ruling stemmed from a class-action lawsuit brought in November by the Legal Action Customs official said Wednesday. India and Pakistan both claim Jammu-Kashmir. The 43-year-old dispute heated up again when India launched a crackdown Jan. 20 against Kashmiri Moslems who want to secede from India. The customs official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the 10,000 copies of Newsweek that arrived at Bombay airport early Wednesday have not been impounded. But he said a process often used to speed up clearance for weekly magazines is not being used to clear the Newsweek issue. Normally, consignments must be cleared against a bill of entry, a procedure that can take up to two days. In cases considered urgent, the consignments are cleared faster with an understanding that bill of entry formalities will be completed later. ``This is a facility extended in rare cases, not as a matter of right but for convenience,'' the customs official said. In previous disputes over maps in foreign publications, India has allowed the books or magazines in question to enter the country after stamping them with notations that the borders are ``neither correct nor authenticated.'' There was no indication whether this would happen to the Newsweek map. Newsweek is distributed in India by Living Media India Ltd. A company spokesman declined comment on the customs action.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders of Czechoslovakia, Poland to See Bush; Baker Going to Prague
DOC.TEXT: The president of Czechoslovakia will meet with President Bush at the White House on Feb. 20 and the prime minister of Poland will visit in March, the White House announced Wednesday. Both Eastern European leaders will be on official visits at Bush's invitation, Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said in a statement. At the State Department, meanwhile, Secretary of State James A. Baker III confirmed Wednesday that he would visit Czechoslovakia next week. Baker is going to Europe primarily to hold talks in Moscow with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Baker provided no details of the visit to Prague, nor would he say if he would make other stops in Europe. Baker is known to have Romania under consideration, but turmoil in the country may rule out a trip to Bucharest. Czech President Vaclav Havel's visit to Washington will include meetings and a working lunch with Bush. He also will travel to New York for a private schedule of events, Fitzwater said. Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki will visit the capital in March. No specific dates were announced.

DOC.HEAD: Government Proposes Fuel Economy Standards for Trucks
DOC.TEXT: The government Wednesday called for slight increases in average minimum gasoline mileage for pickup trucks, vans and utility vehicles for the 1992 through 1994 model years. The proposed standards, announced by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, would apply to vehicles with gross weight ratings of up to 8,500 pounds. Currently, each company's light truck fleet manufactured in the 1990 model year must average 20 miles per gallon. The required average for the 1991 model year is 20.2 mpg. The agency proposed a 1992 model year standard between 20.2 and 21 mpg, a 1993 standard between 20.2 and 21.5 mpg, and a 1994 standard between 20.2 and 22 mpg. The announcement opens a 30-day period for public comment, after which the agency will make a final decision on fuel economy standards for the three years. ``We have taken a careful look at the manufacturers' fuel economy capabilities and have analyzed their current projections and underlying product plans,'' administrator Jerry R. Curry said. ``We are asking for more information on possible technological improvements, such as in engines and transmissions.'' Federal law requires the agency to establish average fuel economy standards for light trucks each year. A manufacturer that fails to meet the standard, after taking credits into account, is subject to civil penalties. The agency is required to set standards at the ``maximum feasible level'' after considering economic practicability, technological feasibility, the need to conserve energy and the effect of other federal motor vehicle standards on fuel economy. The highway safety agency also said it would stop setting separate standards for two-wheel-drive and four-wheel-drive fleets because nearly all manufacturers have chosen a combined fleet standard.

DOC.HEAD: Raise for Legislators Takes Effect
DOC.TEXT: A pay raise goes into effect Thursday for members of Congress, with the Senate receiving a slightly higher boost than the House. Federal judges and senior executive branch employees also will be getting cost-of-living increases at the same rate as House members, about 8 percent. Rank-and-file House members' salaries will go from $89,500 a year to $96,600. Senators, now paid the same as House members, will get a raise to $98,400. The reason for the difference is that the House last year approved a comprehensive pay-and-ethics package that includes an additional 25 percent pay boost effective next year in return for the elimination of the widely criticized practice of lawmakers accepting speaking fees from interest groups. But when the measure went to the other side of the Capitol, senators balked and wound up accepting instead a 10 percent raise and a cut in the limit on their speaking fees from $35,800 to $26,568. For this year, House members can keep $26,850 in honoraria, the same as in 1989. While senators are slightly ahead in the salary game for now, the House will leap ahead on Jan. 1, 1991, when its next raise _ carefully timed to come after November's elections _ takes them to $120,700, plus a yet-to-be-determined cost-of-living increment. Many in Congress believe that the discrepancy will prompt the Senate to address the poltically painful pay issue again this year.

DOC.HEAD: Reformers and Conservatives Vie in Party Congress
DOC.TEXT: Some liberal Communists indicated Wednesday there may be a split in the party, but one said his reformist wing would not leave ``until the Stalinists throw us out.'' On the second day of a party congress, the reformers faced a large conservative majority that entrenched itself during the 35 years Todor Zhivkov ruled the country before his downfall in November. Uncertainty also appeared in the fledgling non-Communist opposition, an alliance called the Union of Democratic Forces, which seemed divided over when free elections should be held. The Communists insisted they take place no later than May, but many in the Union want more time to organize. Labor unrest continued, emphasizing the urgency of economic and social problems. Most of the unprecedented strikes are for higher pay. Teachers walked out as the congress opened Tuesday. Miners who struck last week resumed work Wednesday, but continued negotiations with the government. Doctors struck for one hour Tuesday, two hours Wednesday, and announced plans to quit working for three hours Thursday. They want the health minister and his deputies to resign. State television said elevator engineers planned to strike, but gave no details of their demands. Official media carried a report quoting agricultural workers as saying they would strike Feb. 5 unless the state paid adequate prices for their crops. Party chief Petar Mladenov and other leaders held out the possibility Wednesday of sharing some power with the oppposition and called for a government of ``national concord.'' Unlike their comrades elsewhere in rapidly changing Eastern Europe, Bulgaria's Communists face a relatively weak opposition and have not relinquished much power since Mladenov replaced Zhivkov on Nov. 10. At the congress, party reformers appeared undecided on strategy. Dragomir Draganov, whose reformist wing is called Democratic Forum, told reporters his group would stay in the party ``until the Stalinists throw us out,'' but Nikolai Vassilev of the Alternative Socialist Association left open the possibility of a split after the congress. ``We cannot give a positive answer,'' Vassilev said. He added that the Alternative Socialists would decide what to do at a separate conference Feb. 11. Delegate Petar Emil Mitev of the reformist group called Road To Europe said: ``Nothing fatal will happen if we (the Communists) go into opposition for a while. Socialism will not die.'' Where the opposition stood on the election was equally unclear. A statement carried by radio said Petar Beron, a leading member of the Union of Democratic Forces, agreed to elections in May. A subsequent Union statement read on television by spokesman Stefan Stoyanov, however, said conditions were not right for elections to be held so soon. In the statement read by Stoyanov, the Union said its demand that the old party system be separated from the state had not been fulfilled. The Union, which is engaged in negotiations with the Communists and other groups, said the Communist Party must create ``real conditions'' for an end to its monopoly on culture and the economy. On possible particiaption in a provisional coalition before elections, it said the terms and the power of such a government must be clarified. Party leaders moved the party congress up from 1991 after Bulgaria was caught up in the tide of political change sweeping Eastern Europe. It is scheduled to end Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Study Outlines Nursing Problems at VA Center
DOC.TEXT: Relations between management and registered nurses at the VA hospital in Albuquerque, N.M., have become so bad that outside counseling is needed, according to a report released Wednesday.
