The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said in its report that there had been progress in a number of areas that registered nurses had complained about _ shortages of nurses, pay problems, excessive overtime, lack of promotions and excessive disciplinary actions. However, two years of conflict means ``it will be difficult to make the participants believe they can deal with the issues and each other in an effective manner,'' the report said. ``To facilitate this process, we believe than an independent human resource specialist should be brought in to enhance the dialogue between the two groups,'' it said. Hospital spokesman Ron Lopez said officials there had not seen the GAO report and he could not comment on whether recommended changes had been implemented. Veterans Secretary Edward J. Derwinski said in a statement included in the report that some of the problems the nurses have complained about deal with the rights of management and fall outside union-management bargaining. Among the issues Derwinski said the VA had no obligation to negotiate with the nurses over were temporary assignment to another unit or ward for eight hours or less and the system of classifying patients according to their nursing care needs. The report was requested in October 1988 by Sen. Pete V. Domenici, D-N.M., as a result of complaints by nurses who are members of Carpenters Union Local 2208. The hospital serves an area of New Mexico and western Texas that serves about 200,000 veterans. The GAO study was done in the first six months of 1989. Administrator Andrew Montano has resigned since then, but no permanent director has been appointed.

DOC.HEAD: 1989 New Home Sales Worst in Five Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf pvs `Yet sales ...' with 1 graf to CORRECT that sales were down 1.5 percent in the West, sted Midwest
DOC.TEXT: New homes sales in 1989, held back in part by a 9.6 percent decline in December, posted their worst record in five years, the government said Wednesday, but some analysts said falling mortgage rates should boost sales in 1990. ``The year wasn't a gangbuster by any means,'' said Richard Peach, an econmist for the Mortgage Bankers Association. ``But I wouldn't characterize it as a disaster either.'' Peach and others said they were ``confident that rates will be coming down in the not too distant future,'' resulting in renewed sales. The Commerce Department said new single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 629,000 units in December after jumping 9.3 percent in November. Analysts said December's decline was due to severe weather in much of the country and to a correction from November's unsustainable pace. December sales brought to 650,000 units the total sold in 1989, the worst year since 639,000 homes were sold in 1984. The 1989 total was 3.8 percent less than the 676,000 units sold in 1988. The construction industry was hampered through much of 1989 by high interest rates. The Mortgage Bankers are forecasting sales in the 670,000-680,000 range this year, ``predicated on further declines in mortgage rates,'' Peach said. But rates were again on the rise in January. David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, said the rates probably would hold down any January improvement. Robert Villanueva, director of forecasting for the National Association of Home Builders, had similar worries. ``Our concerns are not really with December (sales), but with the fact that interest rates have moved up rather smartly in January,'' he said. On a regional basis, new home sales in December rose at an annual rate of 4 percent in the Northeast to 105,000 units, but fell elsewhere. Sales plummeted 28.3 percent to 91,000 units in the Midwest and were off 9.1 percent to 190,000 units in the West and 6.2 percent to 243,000 units in the South. Yet sales for the year were up 6.2 percent to 103,000 units in the Midwest, but down 11.9 percent to 89,000 units in the Northeast, 6.2 percent to 259,000 units in the South and 1.5 percent to 199,000 units in the West. The Commerce Department also reported the median price of a new home rose 4.1 percent in December to $130,100, and 6.7 percent in 1989 to $121,000. The median means that half of the homes cost more, half less. On the other hand, the average price of a home in December rose 5.1 percent to $159,800. It was up 8 percent to $147,700 for the year. In another housing report Wednesday, the National Association of Realtors said December declines in mortgage rates helped boost its index measuring the ability of the typical American family to buy an existing home. The index measured 108.2 in December, meaning that a family earning the national median income of $33,600 had 108.2 percent of the income needed to qualify for conventional financing covering 80 percent of a home priced at $92,500, the median existing home price for that month. The index was at 105.5 in November.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun's Forces Battle Militia for Control of Christian Zone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with 35 dead, 85 wounded, Lebanese Forces claiming they captured some of Aoun's military bases, details; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun's soldiers attacked the Lebanese Forces militia Wednesday to try to gain full control of the Christian zone. Police reported scores of casualties, and a nurse described a morgue ``packed'' with bodies. Police said at least 35 people were killed and 85 wounded in daylong tank and artillery battles that sent stray shells crashing in Moslem west Beirut and its southern slums, which were not involved in the fighting. Reports indicated Aoun's 20,000 troops, led by the U.S.-trained 8th Brigade, had the upper hand in tank and artillery battles in the 310-square-mile enclave, where 1 million Christians live. Police said the militia's overland supply lines were cut, but it has sea links between its headquarters in east Beirut and the ports of Byblos and Jounieh north of the capital. The Lebanese Forces however said in a late-night communique it had captured Aoun's naval base in Kaslik and the Sarba helicopter base near the port of Jounieh. Meanwhile, Shiite Moslem militias fought in southern Lebanon, continuing the latest round of their intermittent struggle for supremacy among the 1.2 million Shiites, Lebanon's largest sect. Four people were reported wounded, raising the toll to 98 killed and 280 wounded in the battle that began Dec. 23 between the fundamentalist Hezbollah, which is loyal to Iran, and Amal, a mainstream militia backed by Syria. The fighting in the Christian zone was the worst since February 1989, when Aoun's troops last moved against the Lebanese Forces, the main Christian militia led by Samir Geagea. More than 80 people were killed and 200 wounded in that four-day conflict. Aoun's gunners in the hills east of Beirut hammered Geagea's seafront headquarters in the Karantina district with heavy 155mm howitzer barrages. Geagea's fighters hit back with salvos of rockets from launchers that spat 40 missiles a minute on the shell-wrecked presidential palace in suburban Baabda, where Aoun has his headquarters. Police said both leaders were reported to be unharmed. Exploding shells and rockets streaked over the burning Christian sector of the city and lighted up the night sky. A police statement said at least 28 people were killed and 69 wounded from fierce daylong battles with tanks and artillery in the Christian sector and north Lebanon. ``This is an initial count. The toll is definitely much higher as scores of other casualties were still bleeding in embattled areas that ambulances and rescuers could not reach,'' the statement said. At least seven civilians, including a 6-month-old baby, were killed and 16 wounded by stray shells that exploded in west and south Beirut, the city's Moslem sectors, police said. Hospitals broadcast appeals over all Christian radio stations for urgent blood donations to cope with what one nurse at the Hotel Dieu French missionary hospital, the biggest in east Beirut, called a ``deluge of casualties.'' ``The morgue is packed and dozens of wounded are bleeding on stretchers in corridors,'' said the nurse, who asked not to be identified. Stray shells exploded around the ports of Beirut and Jounieh, forcing 18 ships to steam for open sea, police said. One of the injured was news photographer George Samarejian of the independent An-Nahar daily. Police said Samarejian, 45, was shot in the head and taken to the Saint George Hospital. But no surgeon was immediately available to operate on him. A police spokesman reported house-to-house combat in some residential areas of Christian east Beirut. Geagea said his 6,000 men were fighting ``for our survival.'' ``We shall respond to each shell with 10 shells,'' he said in a statement broadcast by Christian radio stations. ``We shall not allow those blinded by the lust for power to slaughter the Lebanese Forces.'' Both sides ignored cease-fire appeals from the Vatican and Lebanon's Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir. Aoun's headquarters said in a communique that his troops overran the Lebanese Force's seaside barracks at Safra, Fanar, Mar Roukos and Nahr Ibrahim, a cluster of towns along a 10-mile stretch of the highway north of Beirut. Geagea's headquarters denied Aoun's claim and the militia's TV station showed footage of its fighters controlling Aoun's main air force base in Halat and the general's Sabra barracks and Kaslik naval base. Whoever wins, the battle could break the stalemate over an Arab League peace plan aimed at ending a 15-year-old civil war that has cost 150,000 Lebanese their lives. Aoun opposes the accord worked out in October because it does not guarantee withdrawal of Syrian forces, which he calls an occupation army. Aoun also refuses to recognize President Elias Hrawi, who was elected as part of the accord. Geagea has neither accepted or rejected the peace accord, but has recognized Hrawi as president. He and other right-wing Christians oppose Aoun's rebellion. Aoun, increasingly isolated and facing the prospect of a Syrian-backed assault by the 22,000 soldiers loyal to the Hrawi government, apparently felt he had to secure control of the Christian sector. Fighting began when Aoun's troops attacked the Lebanese Forces after skirmishes Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Develops in Southwest, North-Central U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A cold front brought snow to parts of the Southwest on Wednesday, and snow also developed along a cold front curving through the north-central United States. Snow and high winds swept through parts of Arizona, with Flagstaff receiving 8 inches of snow and winds at Show Low gusting to 54 mph. Snow also fell in parts of the northern Plains region and Rockies. Wolf Creek Pass in Colorado got 7 inches of snow. A winter storm warning was issued for Oregon's Cascade Mountains, and a high-wind warning was posted for the Oregon coast. The storm stirred up rough seas off the California coast, and a coastal flood warning was issued along the state's central coast where waves swelled up to 29 feet. Showers and a few thunderstorms developed in south Texas and the southern Plains, while dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation, with abundunt sunshine abundant in the Ohio Valley and the mid-Atlantic coast. Strong northerly winds ushered arctic air into the north-central United States. Temperatures were below zero across much of Montana and North Dakota Wednesday afternoon, and wind-chill readings in the northern Plains were close to 40 degrees below zero. Cut Bank, Mont., reported a temperature of 17 degrees below zero and a wind chill of 50 below. Mild weather prevailed across much of the East, with readings in the 50s in the Mid-Atlantic states Wednesday afternoon. Temperatures in southern Florida rose to the mid-80s. The nation's low Wednesday was 22 degrees below zero at International Falls, Minn.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Reorganizes slightly in first 21 grafs; picking up 21st graf pvs; now 22rd graf: ``However, John;'' INSERTS antepenultimate graf with example
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, preparing to deliver his first State of the Union address, telephoned Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday to propose deeper cuts in U.S. and Soviet combat troops in Europe, officials said. Bush was to announce the plan formally in a nationally broadcast appearance before a joint session of Congress. The proposal, to reduce forces of each country to 195,000 in the affected area, was described by senior administration officials as a response to the ``rapidly falling deck of cards'' in Eastern Europe amid the collapse of hardline communist regimes. The proposal won immediate praise from Democrats, including Sen. Sam Nunn, chairman of the Armed Services Committee, who said it fit ``the changing circumstances in Europe and the fiscal pressures at home.'' The troop-cutback plan was the surprising centerpiece of a speech in which Bush also was to proclaim the nation in good health, set lofty goals for America's schools and warn Democrats not to cut Social Security taxes. Moreover, Bush was to prod Congress again for action on capital gains tax cuts and legislation dealing with clean air, child care and crime, all of which are pending from last year. The plan would force a cutback in the more than 265,000 U.S. troops in Western Europe and the 565,000 Soviet forces in Central and Eastern Europe. However, there are an additional 40,000 U.S. troops in Britain, Italy, Greece and Turkey who would not be affected by the latest plan. Last May, Bush proposed a 275,000 ceiling throughout all of Europe on U.S. and Soviet forces and said negotiations to reach that goal should be wrapped up within a year. The administration said Soviet and U.S. negotiators should proceed with talks to reach the 275,000 level while holding parallel discussions on the deeper cuts. A senior official said, ``We see no reason there has to be an interference'' with reaching the 275,000 level. ``If there is, we will put it on the back burner until we can get there.'' Before now, Bush has said he would not support further cuts until the current talks were wrapped up. But, a senior administration official said, ``Events were running ahead of the negotiations.'' The 1989 proposal, still under negotiation, would require the United States to withdraw 30,000 combat troops and force the Soviets to reduce their troops by about 325,000. The official, who briefed reporters on Bush's speech on condition of anonymity, called the collapse of the Soviet empire ``a rapidly falling deck of cards.'' On Capitol Hill, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said that ``very substantial reductions are not only possible but I think inevitable.'' Bush sent Lawrence Eagleburger, his deputy secretary of state, and Robert Gates, the deputy national security adviser, to present his plan and seek approval from the leaders of England, France, Germany and Italy. They returned Tuesday evening with endorsements of Bush's package, the official said. With that, Bush then called Gorbachev to inform him of the proposal. ``He was very appreciative of the president's phone call and thought that this was the kind of attitude that was very conducive to good relations and he said, of course, that they would study the proposal,'' the official said. Bush has repeatedly cautioned that there would be no immediate budgetary ``peace dividend'' of military savings from the changes in Eastern Europe. The senior administration official said the deeper troop reductions would not affect that position since any cutbacks would have to be negotiated. Many analysts have said it costs about as much to maintain troops in Europe as it does in the United States and real savings must come from a smaller military establishment. The first hint of a new proposal came from Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Discussing Bush's conversation with Gorbachev, Baker said, ``It had to do with some announcements that the president will have tonight in his State of the Union message, and beyond that I am not going to say anything further.'' Baker will see Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and possibly Gorbachev in Moscow on Feb. 8-9. On the domestic front, Bush's proposal for a capital gains tax cut had been criticized by Democrats as merely a tax cut for the rich. However, John Sununu, Bush's chief of staff, said, ``I think all of a sudden about April or May, it will dawn on Congress that it's a congressional election, not a presidential election year, and that failures to get things done will be seen as failures of the Democrat leadership in the House, the Democrat leadership in the Senate,'' he said. Bush gave a preview of his speech to Republican senators and House members during a meeting at the White House. Afterward, House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., said Bush pledged to point out in his speech that he is opposed to a rollback in Social Security taxes, as proposed by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y. Referring to Moynihan's proposal, Michel said, ``It just means it's a no-no as far as our party's concerned. We've made that decision earlier on to fund this program adequately into the next century. And to do violence to that ... just really undermines our credibility.'' Moynihan has said his proposal was prompted by concern that the growing Social Security trust fund reserves are being used to mask the true size of the federal deficit. Seeking to redeem his pledge to be ``the education president,'' Bush was setting a goal of lifting American students to first place internationally in math and science, two subjects where they traditionally rate poorly. For example, one study has shown that 72 percent of South Korean 13-year-olds can solve a math problem that only 40 percent of Americans that age can solve. There was a hint of this in Bush's budget, which proposes $230 million _ a 70 percent increase _ in money for states to improve the abilities of teachers in those two disciplines. In addition, National Science Foundation programs for science, math and engineering education would receive a $100 million increase, to $460 million, under Bush's proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Leak from Liberian Freighter Contaminates Waters off Japan
LaserPhoto TOK9
DOC.TEXT: At least 10 birds were found dead and seaweed farms were damaged after fuel oil leaked from a 7,000-ton Liberian freighter that ran aground and broke in two off western Japan, officials and fishermen said Wednesday. An official of the Maritime Safety Agency, Japan's coast guard, reported a 660-by-70-foot oil slick off Ine, about 490 miles southwest of Tokyo. He said the agency set up a barrier to keep the spill offshore. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Maritime Gardenia struck a rock last Thursday in rough seas a mile off the coast. All 23 Filipino and Chinese crewmen were rescued by a helicopter, but the ship broke in two and an estimated 900 tons of fuel oil leaked, the official said. He said the Maritime Gardenia, owned by International Maritime Carriers Co. of Hong Kong, was heading for another dock after unloading lumber from Malaysia when it ran aground. Yoshiyuki Hamano, an official of the fishermen's cooperative in Ine village, said 10 sea birds coated with fuel oil were found dead on the coast and seaweed farming was damaged, but the full extent of the damage was not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Three Ethnic Albanians Killed in Kosovo; 100,000 Slavs Rally
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new violence reports, Slavs volunteer to fight ethnic Albanians, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos PRI1,3
DOC.TEXT: Three ethnic Albanians were reported killed in riots Wednesday in Kosovo, and more than 100,000 Slavs rallied at anti-Albanian protests elsewhere in Yugoslavia, some demanding arms to fight in the province. At least 16 people have died in ethnic riots that began eight days ago in the poor southern province adjacent to Albania. Among Kosovo's 1.9 million inhabitants, ethnic Albanians outnumber Slavs 9-1. A federal police official said the actual toll was ``much higher.'' He insisted on anonymity and gave no figure. State-run TV described the situation as on ``the verge of civil war.'' Up to 100,000 Slavs, some firing into the air, staged a rally in Titograd, capital of the Montenegrin republic. Some demonstrators volunteered to go to Kosovo and fight ethnic ``Albanian nationalists.'' Kosovo is an administrative part of Yugoslavia's largest republic of Serbia. Its ethnic Albanians want more autonomy, a stop to political trials, release of political prisoners and lifting of a year-old state of emergency. The state news agency Tanjug said three people were killed and five injured Wednesday in Glogovac, a village 12 miles south of Pristina, capital of Kosovo. It said police used a helicopter to disperse ``several thousand aggressive'' protesters there. Belgrade TV showed the huge rally of Slavs in Titograd. Gunfire could be heard and speakers implored demonstrators to stop firing handguns. One speaker said Montenegrin volunteers were signing up to fight in Kosovo unless the authorities there ``use all available methods, including repression,'' to end ``the Albanian uprising.'' At Ivangrad, a Montenegrin town, 10,000 people demonstrated against ``Albanian separatists and Slovenian and Croatian leaders supporting them,'' Tanjug said. In Belgrade, the federal and Serbian capital, crowds estimated by reporters to be in the thousands held rallies. The demonstrations were purportedly anti-Albanian, but protesters also chanted ``Down with Communism!'' and ``Down with Tito,'' the late Yugoslav president held responsible by the Serbs for originally giving wide autonomy to Kosovo. Up to 5,000 students assembled before the federal Parliament building at midnight Tuesday demanding weapons to fight for the minority Slavs in Kosovo. They proclaimed a general strike and demanded the ``highest organs of the federation'' resign unless ``nationalist and vandalist rioting of (ethnic Albanian) terrorists'' stopped within 48 hours. The Kosovo conflict arises from ethnic friction between majority Albanians and minority Serbs and Montenegrins. The republics of Slovenia, and to a lesser extent Croatia, have sided with the ethnic Albanians and the rally in Titograd had anti-Slovene overtones. Ethnic Albanians began protesting a year ago when Serbia made constitutional changes to take firmer control of the autonomous province. At least 28 people died in violence in Kosovo over the issue last year. Demonstrators shouted Wednesday for the resignation of Yugoslavia's collective presidency and its current leader, Janez Drnovsek, a Slovene. The presidency issued a statement assuring Yugoslavs ``that the country possesses the means and force to carry out its obligations and prevent all forms of terrorism.'' It said ``the situation in Kosovo is deteriorating,'' and warned of the threat of ``bloody clashes among nationalities.'' As violence spread through Kosovo on Wednesday, protesters called for military intervention to end ``the Albanian uprising.'' At Vucitrn, 20 miles northwest of Pristina, five demonstrators were reported injured, apparently in clashes with police. Violent clashes were reported in Lipljan, Titova Mitrovica, Klina, Prizren, Kosovska Kamenica and Gnjilane. Authorities warned that ``traveling through Kosovo is extremely dangepous.'' Young ethnic Albanians, armed with guns, were reported to be stopping cars and checking identities. About 4,000 demonstrators assembled in Podujevo, the main hotspot 20 miles north of Pristina. About 3,000 others rallied in Pec, 30 miles northwest of the provincial capital. Media reports said police guarded all Serb and Montenegrin communities in Kosovo. At Malisevo, where Radio Pristina reported two deaths Tuesday, three ethnic Albanians were buried Wednesday at a ceremony attended by 2,000 people. Police using tear gas prevented 200 ethnic Albanians from joining 200 others in the streets of Titova Mitrovica, 25 miles northwest of Pristina, and a protest was reported in Ada, 10 miles west of the provincial capital. Strikes were reported at several factories in support of the protesters.

DOC.HEAD: Prominent Businessman Convicted for Looting
DOC.TEXT: A St. Croix businessman has been convicted of looting a grocery store after Hurricane Hugo struck in September and selling the food in his restaurant. Michael Harris, 46, a native of New York who owns the Ritz Cafe, faces a possible 50 years in prison for grand larceny and burglary. The verdict was delivered Tuesday night in a federal court and no date was set for sentencing. Harrisk was the third prominent resident of St. Croix convicted for looting, which was widespread after Hugo devastated the island on Sept. 17. ``We as a community can say to the rest of the world that has looked down on us that we have respect for law and order,'' U.S. Attorney David Nissman told the court Tuesday night. The trial of police Capt. Adelbert Bryan, a former territorial senator, began Wednesday in U.S. district court. He is accused of stealing gas lanterns and lumber from a hardware store. Nissman said his job was to ``restore order, restore confidence in the legal system and to bring significant looters to trial.'' He said of Harris: ``This is a case of a prominent businessman who acquired a lot of property he did not pay for and sold it at a very high profit.'' In his defense, Harris told the court he donated 750 meals to military and federal emergency personnel in the days after the storm. Early in January, the owner of an electronic supply store was convicted of possessing stolen property acquired after the storm and a First Federal Bank executive was convicted of trying to steal goods from a department store. Hugo destroyed most homes on St. Croix and caused an estimated $1 billion in damage in the Virgin Islands, a U.S. territory in the Caribbean with a population of 110,000.

DOC.HEAD: Solti Sets Sights on Soviet Union in Final Season With Chicago Symphony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Spelling of `Georg' in 1st graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Sir Georg Solti, the famed conductor who has won more Grammy Awards than anyone, unveiled plans Wednesday for his farewell season with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, including a hoped-for tour of eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. ``America has here a messenger, in this orchestra, that is unparalleled by any politician, unparalleled by any ambassador,'' the 77-year-old Solti said at a news conference, which he attended despite a lingering case of flu. ``What is essential that we show them what we can produce _ not in armaments, and not in missiles _ but in Beethoven and Shostakovich.'' The trip would be the group's first to the Soviet Union _ either to Moscow or Leningrad _ and would include performances in Vienna and Budapest, Solti's birthplace, orchestra officials said. ``Logistical problems,'' including uncertainties over lodging and food, have made the plans tentative so far, but the orchestra hopes to reach a decision within two weeks, officials said. If all three stops cannot be arranged, the tour will not take place, they said. The trip would come during the group's centennial season, which will run from September 1990 through April 1991. ``Something is quite wonderful, to be part of an orchestra which will be 100 years old,'' said Solti, who will have headed the group for 22 years. ``One-fifth of the existence of this orchestra, I have been honored to be its music director,'' he said. ``It's remarkable, and I feel very, very rich.'' The program for the centennial season, which runs from September 1990 to April 1991, will be crowned by Verdi's opera ``Otello,'' with Luciano Pavarotti performing the title role for the first time, Solti said. Solti, who has won 29 Grammys, six more than the No. 2 lifetime winner, the late concert pianist Vladimir Horowitz, also announced the Chicago Symphony Orchestra will make its third trip to the Orient this spring. Six conductors, including Solti, and Daniel Barenboim, his successor-designate at the Chicago Symphony beginning in the 1991-92 season, will lead 12 concerts in Japan during April. The trip will be funded largely through a $750,000 gift _ the single largest corporate donation the orchestra has ever received _ from Motorola Inc., said Richard L. Thomas, chairman of the Orchestral Association. Solti said Japanese audiences were marvelous to the orchestra during its previous trips to their country, the last in 1986, and he loves the opportunity to showcase U.S. orchestral excellence. ``In many fields, to my great sadness, America is going down,'' he said. ``Here is where neither the Japanese nor the Germans can compete with us, and this is one point when we should feel very proud.''

DOC.HEAD: El Salvador's Cristiani Meets U.N. Chief in Peace Talks Bid
DOC.TEXT: President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador said U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar agreed Wednesday to try to restart peace talks between the government and rebels in the Central American nation. ``We feel positive and hopeful that we will be able to re-establish the dialogue process and that hopefully we will find that political solution that we are all anxious for in our country,'' Cristiani told reporters after meeting the U.N. chief. Cristiani did not make clear if he sought a U.N. role in mediating if agreement is reached to resume negotiations that broke off last November. He said only that Perez de Cuellar ``will personally make all efforts possible to have the dialogue process reinitiated in order to look for a political solution to the Salvadoran conflict.'' A U.N. spokesman said ``the secretary-general has been entrusted with the task of helping them clear the way for negotiations.'' Asked if that would involve a direct mediation role, he said, ``This is an internal Salvadoran problem. It is for the parties of El Salvador to negotiate a settlement.'' Earlier Wednesday, protesters urging an end to U.S. aid to El Salvador confronted Cristiani's motorcade as it arrived at the United Nations. He entered the building from the underground parking garage instead of the main entrance. Police arrested 28 people on charges of disorderly conduct for blocking the street in front of the United Nations, a New York City police spokesman said. About 200 demonstrators had gathered, carrying banners and chanting slogans denouncing U.S. aid to El Salvador and accusing the Cristiani government of sponsoring death squads. El Salvador received $378 million in U.S. aid last year, including $80 million in military aid. Over the past eight years, the United States has provided more than $3.2 billion to El Salvador, including $1 billion in military equipment. Cristiani is due to meet President Bush in Washington Thursday. U.S. officials said they will discuss the case of six slain Jesuit priests, which drew a world outcry and prompted demands from some U.S. lawmakers that aid to Cristiani's government be cut off. Cristiani's government says army members killed the six Jesuits, their housekeeper and her daughter in San Salvador on Nov. 16 _ days after guerrillas of the leftist Faribundo Marti National Liberation Front, or FMLN, launched an offensive in the capital. Cristiani said Wednesday his government has ``given a clear sign to anybody that likes to take violence in his hands to solve problems that the present government of El Salvador is not willing to accept violence as a means to solve any problems.'' Negotiations between the government and rebels broke off after a union headquarters was bombed and the FMLN mounted the major assault in November. More than 1,000 people died in the fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Confirms Helicopter Delivery To Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: EDs: Leads with Soviet confirmation of helicopter delivery, editing changes thruout; adds byline

The Soviet Embassy on Wednesday confirmed that it has shipped four MI-17 helicopters to Nicaragua recently but said the aircraft were built for civilian use. The embassy statement, issued in response to news reports about the shipment, did not rule out the possibility that the helicopters may be diverted for military use. But hours earlier, Secretary of State James A. Baker said the Soviets have given assurances that helicopters sent to Nicaragua will not be outfitted for military purposes. The Soviet statement reaffirmed the Soviet position that Moscow has sent no weapons to Nicaragua since early 1989. The helicopter delivery was completed last week. The shipment initally was to have been made in December but, for undisclosed reasons, the vessel carrying the aircraft returned to a Soviet port and delivery was delayed by more than a month, officials said. Baker said that MI-17's in the past have been used by Nicaragua for military purposes _ ``refitted and weapons put on them.'' ``We have ... received some assurances from (the Soviets) that that is not going to be the case with respect to the helicopters in question. If it were the case, as far as we are concerned, the Soviet Union would not be keeping with the pledge that it has given us that it is not going to continue to supply lethal weapons to Nicaragua.'' The Soviet statement took note of the news reports about the shipment, pointing out that some had claimed the helicopter delivery violated a Kremlin moratorium on arms shipments to the Sandinistas. ``In fact, in accordance with the agreement between the governments of the USSR and Nicaragua concluded in February 1988, the Soviet Union has delivered to Nicaragua four MI-17 helicopters built for civilian use,'' it said. ``Therefore, the shipment of these helicopters doesn't go beyond the framework of usual commercial practice based on the existing obligations for supplies of civilian property.'' On a related issue, Baker said he intends to discuss with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze a recent Soviet shipment of MiG-29 jet fighters to Cuba. Columnists Rowland Evans and Robert Novack said in their column Wednesday that six of these aircraft left for Cuba in early January by sea and that 30 more will be sent at a later date. Baker holds talks with Shervardnadze in Moscow next week.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Takes Step He Balked at 8 Weeks Ago
An AP New Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Lightning change in the Soviet bloc has prompted President Bush to take a step he balked at just eight weeks ago, proposing further cuts in the number of superpower troops in Central Europe. ``Events in Eastern Europe, with the collapse of communist regimes,'' pressure from the allies and a domestic clamor for the ``peace dividend'' persuaded Bush to use his State of the Union address to offer sharper reductions than envisioned in multilateral talks now underway in Europe, a senior administration official told reporters Wednesday. Troops are the costliest item in the Pentagon budget, especially those stationed overseas, and are expected to be a prime target of congressional budget cutters reviewing Bush's new 1991 spending plan in hopes of finding money for favored domestic programs. With his proposal, Bush also demonstrates anew that he is capable of springing the type of surprise he delights in. Superpower talks on cutting conventional armies in Europe have quickened over the last 13 months, after being stalled for 14 years while NATO and the Warsaw Pact dickered over how many of what were stationed where. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev shifted the talks into high gear in December 1988 with his surprise announcement that he was cutting global Soviet troop strength by 10 percent and withdrawing six tank divisions from Europe. NATO leaders told Gorbachev they wanted much sharper Warsaw Pact cuts in Europe. Last May, Bush proposed that the Americans and Soviets set a ceiling of 275,000 troops apiece. More than 265,000 U.S. troops are in Western Europe, and 565,000 Soviet forces are in Central and Eastern Europe. There are an additional 35,000 U.S. troops in Britain, Italy, Greece and Turkey that would not be affected by Bush's latest plan. Additionally, Gorbachev has agreed to a step that analysts consider more important in assuring that the Soviets would not be able to launch a surprise attack. He has accepted a NATO proposal to cut the number of Soviet tanks in Central Europe from 53,000 to about 20,000, while the Western alliance reduces its tank arsenal from 23,000 to 20,000. At their Malta sumit in December, Bush and Gorbachev said they hoped to sign the conventional force in Europe talks _ known as CFE _ by the end of the year at a summit involving leaders of the 16 NATO and seven Warsaw Pact nations. Bush's proposal would be part of follow-up negotiations, known among arms-control specialists as CFE-2. At a news conference after the Malta summit, Bush said he wanted to complete the first treaty before discussing its successor. But since then, Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia have announced troop cuts of their own and asked the Kremlin to withdraw all its forces from their territory. And the leader of East Germany has said that all superpower troops could be out of Europe by the year 2000. It became apparent, a senior administration official said, ``that events in Eastern Europe, with the collapse of Communist regimes, with discussions with Eastern Europeans suggesting the Soviets ought to pull their troops out and so on, that the CFE proposal we made last May at NATO and is now being negotiated was perhaps not where we ought to be at the present time.'' ``It appeared that in the area of arms control, specifically conventional arms control in Europe, that events were running ahead of the negotiations,'' said the source, speaking on condition he not be further identified. ``So the president asked for a review of what made sense and, following discussions with his advisers and military leaders, he came up with a proposal which would be designed to maintain U.S. interests in Europe,'' said the official. Bush's new plan brought immediate applause from Capitol Hill. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga. and chairman of the Armed Services Committee, called it ``very positive,'' noting that last December he advocated a troop-level reduction to between 200,000 and 225,000. ``The Senate will be receptive to it,'' Nunn said of the Bush proposal. The long feared Soviet potential to launch a surprise attack has virtually disappeared over the last year, said Ted Warner, a military analyst at the Rand Corp. The Soviets have completed about half the troop and tank reductions that Gorbachev announced in December 1988, according to Warner and an administration analyst who also spoke on the condition he not be further identified. Moreover, the collapse of hardline Communist regimes means that the Warsaw Pact ``could by no means count on any contribution from its East European allies to mount an offensive against NATO,'' Warner said. ``When all is said and done, they have lost a great deal of armored striking power,'' he said. As a result, Bush has decided that means U.S. troops stationed in Europe during the Cold War can begin to come home. -----
Bryan Brumley covers diplomatic affairs for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanon Panel Reportedly Proposes Emergency Arab Summit
With AM-Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: The three Arab countries that brokered a Lebanese peace plan want an emergency summit to discuss Christian Gen. Michel Aoun's refusal to recognize Lebanese President Elias Hrawi, an Arab diplomat said Wednesday. The diplomat, Rafik al-Natsheh of the Palestine Liberation Organization, spoke a day after an Arab League panel of the three countries _ Saudi Arabia, Algeria and Morocco _ circulated its latest report. Al-Natsheh, recognized as the ambassador of Palestine by Saudi Arabia, said by phone from Riyadh that the group proposed an emergency Arab summit to discuss Aoun's stand. Aoun says the peace plan reached in October does not contain a clear timetable for full withdrawal of the 40,000 Syrian troops in Lebanon, who originally entered the country in 1976 under a peacekeeping mandate from the 22-member Arab League. Hrawi, a Moslem elected to lead the new government formed under terms of the peace accord, was quoted in a Beirut interview as saying he welcomed a summit to consider the crisis. Other diplomats said the proposal was expected to pick up steam in coming days and that a date and venue would be decided in contacts by the league headquarters in Tunis with Arab capitals. There were persistent reports in pro-government newspapers in the Persian Gulf Arab countries that Egypt was likely to host the summit in February or early March. The same diplomats said a summit would also deal with Egyptian plans for a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue to break the stalemated Middle East peacemaking process. Also on the agenda is the outcry from the PLO and Arab states against resettlement of Soviet and Eastern European Jews in the Israeli-held West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Arab League peace plan was endorsed by the Lebanese Parliament members at a three-week conference in the Saudi mountain resort of Taif in October. Parliament then met in Lebanon to elect a president of the republic, Rene Mouawad, and swiftly re-convened to elect Hrawi after Mouawad was assassinated by remote-controlled bomb. When the Taif agreement was concluded, Saudi leaders pledged in the name of the three-man committee to remain in close touch with Lebanese leaders until a full settlement was reached. They affirmed that Syria had insisted it was not interested in remaining in Lebanon indefinitely. They said the panel would work to have an Arab summit conference guarantee full implementation of the Taif accord, implicitly meaning the Syrian pullout.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Finds Sims Eligible for Death Penalty
DOC.TEXT: Jurors on Wednesday found Paula Marie Sims eligible for the death penalty for the murder of her 6-week-old daughter, and now must decide whether to sentence her to death by lethal injection. A red-eyed Mrs. Sims, who contends a masked gunman abducted Heather Lee Sims last year as well as her firstborn daughter in 1986, displayed no reaction when the decision was announced. The Madison County Circuit Court jury, which deliberated about two hours, will hear further arguments before considering whether to impose the death penalty or a lesser sentence. This third phase of the trial begins Thursday, and will center on any mitigating or aggravating circumstances, said Assistant Madison County State's Attorney Donald Weber. Weber and defense attorney Donald Groshong both declined to comment on Wednesday's decision. Weber argued Wednesday that the death penalty was warranted in the April 29 suffocation of Heather Lee Sims because the slaying was planned and the crime was ``cruel, brutal, grossly ruthless and devoid of mercy and compassion.'' Under Illinois law, prosecutors may seek the death penalty under certain circumstances, including cases in which the victim is under 12 years old and the killing is particularly brutal, or in which there are multiple victims. Mrs. Sims, 30, of Alton contends a masked gunman abducted Heather Lee and, three years earlier, 13-day-old Loralei. No murder charges have been filed in Loralei's death, but Mrs. Sims faces trial in Jersey County on charges of obstruction of justice and concealment of a homicide in connection with the death. Mrs. Sims continues to maintain her innocence, Groshong told the panel Wednesday. But he also argued, ``We cannot say the death of this child was premeditated, prolonged or torturous. ... In the pecking order of evil ... smothering is usually considered more merciful than other forms of killing.'' The jury Tuesday found Mrs. Sims guilty of first-degree murder, obstructing justice and concealing a homicide in Heather Lee's death. Mrs. Sims and her husband, Robert, reported Heather abducted April 29 from their home. Her body was found May 3 in a trash barrel across the Mississippi River in nearby West Alton, Mo. An autopsy indicated she had been suffocated and that her body was then frozen.

DOC.HEAD: Last of Old Guard Resigns as Leader of Czech Republic
DOC.TEXT: Frantisek Pitra, the last old guard Communist left in power by the peaceful revolution, resigned Wednesday as leader of the Czech republic, the official news agency CTK reported. The 57-year-old Pitra also is expected to give up his job as deputy premier after Parliament approves his resignation from the Czech post. He had strong links with the orthodox Communist leadership that ruled from 1968, when Soviet tanks crushed a reform movement, until the pro-democracy revolution last fall. He lost his seat on the party Politburo in November, along with party leader Milos Jakes and others. Pitra survived as Czech premier, however, after making his republic's government the first in Czechoslovakia since 1948 that was not dominated by Communists. That paved the way for similar changes at the federal level. The Czech premier automatically is deputy premier of the national government. CTK did not give the reason for Pitra's resignation, which came a day after the Communists ended 40 years of dominance in Parliament by giving more than 100 of their seats to pro-democracy groups. The realignment completed an effort to include those groups in Parliament before the free elections set for June 8. Parliament swore in 120 new deputies Tuesday their troops out and so on, that the CFE proposal we made last May at NATO and is now being negotiated was perhaps not where we ought to be at the present time.'' ``It appeared that in the area of arms control, specifically conventional arms control in Europe, that events were running ahead of the negotiations,'' said the source, speaking on condition he not be further identified. ``So the president asked for a review of what made sense and, following discussions with his advisers and military leaders, he came up with a proposal which would be designed to maintain U.S. interests in Europe,'' said the official. Bush's new plan brought immediate applause from Capitol Hill. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga. and chairman of the Armed Services Committee, called it ``very positive,'' noting that last December he advocated a troop-level reduction to between 200,000 and 225,000. ``I believe that it makes the arms control proposal that we have on the table much more relevant to the changing circumstances in Europe,'' Nunn said. ``The Senate will be receptive to it.'' The long-feared Soviet potential to launch a surprise attack has virtually disappeared over the last year, said Ted Warner, a military analyst at the Rand Corp. The Soviets have completed about half the troop and tank reductions that Gorbachev announced in December 1988, according to Warner and an administration analyst who also spoke on the condition he not be further identified. Moreover, the collapse of hardline Communist regimes means that the Warsaw Pact ``could by no means count on any contribution from its East European allies to mount an offensive against NATO,'' Warner said. ``When all is said and done, they have lost a great deal of armored striking power,'' he said. As a result, Bush has decided that means U.S. troops stationed in Europe during the Cold War can begin to come home.
Bryan Brumley covers diplomatic affairs for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Chief Quits Following Guerrilla Escape
DOC.TEXT: The chief of the nation's prisons quit Wednesday following the escape of 49 leftist guerrillas who spent a year secretly tunneling their way to freedom. Six were captured shortly after they fled Tuesday but police continued to search for the 43 others, who included several guerrillas who tried to kill military President Augusto Pinochet in 1986. The Supreme Court appointed a special investigator, Justice Juan Araya, who said he started his work ``immediately.'' Justice Minister Hugo Rosende said the government ``immediately accepted'' the resignation submitted by prison chief Col. Horacio Ojeda. Rosende did not elaborate but it appeared Ojeda took responsibility for the jail break. The guerrillas fled through a 100-yard-long tunnel below a wide avenue, across the street from the national investigative police headquarters in downtown Santiago. Adm. Jose Toribio Merino, commander in chief of the navy, said on television that he believed some prison guards helped the escapees. ``Imagine, they spent a full year digging a tunnel and no one saw anything,'' Merino said. ``Where did they put all the material they removed?'' The government said it ordered an internal investigation of prison personnel. The Santiago newspaper La Segunda reported that the officer in charge of the prison at the time of the escape was warned by some guards that ``something abnormal'' was happening, but that he paid no attention. It said the officer, identified only as Lt. Gutierrez, ordered the guards to retrieve the cartridges from their automatic rifles after one guard fired a warning shot into the air. Authorities did not comment on the paper's report. Police searching for the guerrillas set up roadblocks and increased security at airports and borders points. National police director, Fernando Paredes, appealed to ``all citizens to help us providing whatever information they think may be useful.'' Police also were seen watching many embassies in Santiago, apparently in an effort to prevent the escapees from seeking asylum. Most of them were members of the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, an urban guerrilla gang that has claimed responsibility for a number of armed attacks against Chile's military regime, including the attempt on Pinochet's life on Sept. 7, 1986. Pinochet was unharmed when his motorcade was ambushed in the Andes foothills near Santiago, but six of his bodyguards were killed. Pinochet took power following a 1973 coup that topped elected President Salvador Allende. He is scheduled to turn over power to a civilian government in February.

DOC.HEAD: Buckey Faces New Trial on 13 Molestation Counts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-4, bgn `The parents...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Reiner's comments that he was not influenced to seek new trial and that 6,000 claimed letters actually totaled 200. Picks up 5th graf pvs, ``Everybody, the ...' ^By LINDA DEUTSCH
DOC.TEXT: The final defendant in the McMartin preschool molestation case will be retried on the 13 counts of child molestation and conspiracy that left jurors deadlocked, prosecutors announced Wednesday. The decision to retry Raymond Buckey came after long meetings with District Attorney Ira Reiner and after a loud public campaign by parents whose children attended the McMartin nursery school. The parents appeared on television, called news conferences, enlisted politicians and solicited letters supporting Buckey's reprosecution. ``This is a positive step for us,'' said Marymae Cioffi, a McMartin parent who led the campaign to retry Buckey. ``I'm going to run home and tell my kids we get another chance.'' Reiner said that neither the orchestrated outcry nor by his stated ambition to run for California attorney general had any influence on his decision to seek a new trial. ``This is not a political matter and it is not going to be treated as such,'' he said. Reiner said he did not watch the sensational TV talk show appearances by parents and children. He added that boxes of letters carried into his office this week by a delegation of parents contained only about 200 letters rather than the 6,000 they claimed to have collected. ``The boxes were filled with rolls of paper,'' he said. ``Only the top row were letters. There's a little bit of that going on.'' ``Everybody, the public and the families involved, is entitled to a resolution of this case,'' Deputy District Attorney Lael Rubin told reporters. She and coprosecutor Roger Gunson insisted the blitz of publicity did not influence their decision to go forward. Buckey's civil attorney, Scott Bernstein, said outside court the decision was ``outrageous'' and ``a combination of pressure and politics.'' The prosecutors could have dismissed the 13 counts after Buckey, 31, and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, 63, were acquitted Jan. 18 by a jury on 52 other molestation charges. Their trial, which took nearly three years, was the longest and costliest in U.S. history. Superior Court Judge William Pounders said the facts involved in the remaining 13 counts ``mitigate in favor of a long second trial.'' He said he hoped the charges could be ``scoped down'' to shorten the proceedings. Pounders, who said he agreed with the decision to go forward with a new trial, urged that it begin quickly because ``the range of emotions is very high. ... There are a lot of people still sitting in agony. We should seek an end to this as soon as possible.'' He set a March 9 trial date, but conceded that could be complicated by a motion filed Wednesday by Buckey's attorney, Danny Davis, charging Pounders with prejudice against the defense and asking that he be removed from the case. Pounders said he would challenge the motion, telling Davis: ``I do not feel I'm biased against you or your client.'' The McMartin case has been in the Los Angeles courts for six years and originally included seven defendants. Charges were dismissed against five defendants after an 18-month preliminary hearing. Only Buckey and his mother stood trial. The case cost taxpayers over $13 million. Buckey spent nearly five years in jail before he was released on $1.5 million bail last February. Buckey was released Wednesday on his own recognizance pending a new trial. Jurors who spent nearly three years hearing the case said the prosecution failed to prove 52 of the molestation counts. They said their votes on the deadlocked counts weighed on the side of acquittal. Some jurors said they believed children were molested but weren't convinced it happened at the McMartin school.

DOC.HEAD: Military Tribinals Established to Try Civilians
DOC.TEXT: A Sudanese judge on Wednesday ordered the establishment of 18 military tribunals to try civilian cases, the Middle East News Agency reported. The action follows reports of unrest, including threatened strikes by trade unions, professional syndicates and others who oppose the military rule of Lt. General Omar Hassan el-Bashir, who lead a successful military coup June 30. In a dispatch from the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, the Egyptian news agency said the new courts will examine cases ranging from disobeying authorities to breaking laws concerning prices, alcohol sale and prostitution. It said a decree by the Sudanese head judge, Gallil Aly Lutfy, also established a court of appeals for sentences issued by the new military tribunals. Abdel-Gallil Adem Hussein, whose name was not preceded by any military rank and so was presumed to be a civilian, was appointed head of the appeals court. The news agency did not explain why the decision was ordered by a civilian and not military authorities, what prompted the decision or give any other details. It was not immediately known what happened to Sudan's civilian judges. El-Bashir established special military courts throughout Sudan shortly after he came to power at head of a 15-man military junta mainly to try those considered involved in the ``corrupt regime'' of ousted civilian Prime Minister Sadek el-Mahdi. A military court sentenced to death by hanging the head of the doctors' union for signing a statement calling for a strike. It was reported that el-Bashir suspended the execution due after international calls to do so. Civilian courts were known to function and deal with charges mentioned by the new decision. A Sudanese was hanged last month for dealing in narcotics. There are two others on the death row, for dealing in hard currency and the black market.

DOC.HEAD: Yugoslav Town Buries Massacre Victims in Sadness and Fury
An AP Extra
With AM-Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: Long columns of ethnic Albanian mourners buried three of their dead in Malisevo on Wednesday, their sadness mixed with fury at riot police they accused of machine-gunning unarmed townspeople. The mourners, many wearing traditional white domed caps, trudged down muddy paths toward a small Moslem cemetery overlooking the rolling hills of some of Yugoslavia's best wine country. Most of the town's 4,000 inhabitants went to the burial. Dozens milled around journalists, jostling each other in their eagerness to describe these claims of massacre: A Soviet-built armored personnel carrier raced through the town Tuesday morning, its turret rotating wildly, its 14.5mm anti-aircraft machine gun firing indiscriminately at passers-by. Close behind came two police trucks. Policemen in the backs of the trucks, in flak jackets and helmets, fired AK-47 assault rifles at people racing for cover. A grocer was killed sitting in his store; another man died as he walked toward the bus stop, and a youth was wounded emerging from the police station, Ahmed Berisa, a City Council member, said. Dried blood stains marked the shooting sites. Berisa did not say how the third victim died. At least 15 people were wounded in the two minutes of shooting, and three were not expected to survive, Berisa said. An ethnic Albanian policeman pointed toward bullet holes around the station's entrance, saying he was fortunate to be alive becuse he had been standing directly behind the boy who was hit. ``They wanted to kill us all,'' said merchant Sadri Mazreku, pointing to the riddled metal grating on his storefront. ``They even shot at the local police post because the officers there are ethnic Albanians.'' Kadri Krasnici, the local Communist Party chief, said a full-scale massacre in Malisevo, 12 miles west of Kosovo's capital of Pristina, was ``avoided by sheer luck because only a few people were on the streets at the time of the attack.'' Children pointed out more than 100 bullet holes on the walls of buildings lining the town's main street. Metal railings on a bridge over a small stream were split by the impact of bullets. Several people alleged that the attack against Malisevo and similar ones on two nearby villages, which resulted in no casualties, were revenge on the part of Serbian police. They said that ethnic strains motivated the attacks, aggravated by a clash with Albanian demonstrators that injured a police officer. Thousands of riot police from Yugoslavia's largest republic of Serbia have been deployed over the past week in Kosovo to help control huge demonstrations by ethnic Albanians demanding more autonomy for the region. The province is administrativaly a part of Serbia, which exercises pervasive control. Serbia accuses ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.9 million people, of harassing the Serbian minority to drive them out and of wanting to join neighboring Albania. Krasnici read a statement to journalists that said a riot police unit had ``executed an unprovoked armed attack on Malisevo. What happened here is without precedent in postwar Yugoslavia. ``Malisevo and two neighboring villages were attacked by terrorists and criminals, who cannot remain in the security forces of Yugoslavia.'' Krasnici said local authorities had contacted Yugoslav President Janez Drnovsek to demand an official inquiry. The shooting was ``possibly caused by a desire for revenge'' by a group of Serbian police who earlier clashed with rioters six miles east of Malisevo, town official Ibis Taci said. An officer apparently riding in one of the two trucks was seriously wounded, Taci added. Sgt. Adem Salja, commander of the local police station, said, ``There was no unrest in Malisevo and we had certainly not asked for any reinforcements.'' On Wednesday, hundreds of youths with scarves over their faces flashed V-for-victory signs on the main road linking the town with Pristina. They chanted ``Democracy, democracy!'' at cars slowing down to get past stone and wood barricades they erected. Harried-looking riot police, clutching automatic rifles and tear gas grenade launchers, did not interfere.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Approves Liberlized Press Laws
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Wednesday liberalized media laws and gave citizens the right to operate newspapers and radio and television stations, the official MTI news agency said. The changes amend a 1986 law that will be scrapped altogether when the Justice Ministry completes work on a new statute. Under the previous law, only state bodies and other legal entities could operate newspapers and broadcast stations. The new law says the only requirement for starting a newspaper is reporting the plan to authorities and requesting resigstration, according to MTI. ``Practicing the freedom of the press cannot lead to the violation of the law or incitement thereto. Neither can it go against individual rights,'' the law says. It also says public morals and decency should not be violated, MTI said. The law also regulates press violations of individual rights and allows juries to order a newspaper to pay damages up to $8,300 in civil cases. However, all damages will go into the public treasury, not to the winner of the case.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Calls for Halt to Coup Rumors; Bishops Denounce Coup Attempts
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino called Wednesday for an end to coup rumors, saying they are undermining the government's efforts to restore stability. ``I believe we should stop emphasizing these alleged plots,'' Mrs. Aquino said in a statement Wednesday. ``We will never be able to accomplish the task of national development if this is all we are going to highlight every day.'' Mrs. Aquino made the statement after unconfirmed media reports that the military went on full alert earlier this week to prevent an attack on the presidential palace. Rumors of a new coup have been sweeping the Philippine capital since the the Dec. 1-9 coup attempt by thousands of mutinous troops, the sixth and most serious bid by right-wing military officers to topple Mrs. Aquino. At least 113 people were killed and more than 500 wounded in the fighting. On Tuesday, American officials and lawmakers said in Washington the Aquino government still faces the threat of a new coup attempt and is encumbered by widespread corruption. ``The political situation remains unsettled and ... many wonder whether the government can recover from the blow sufficiently to restore popular confidence and make lasting strides toward stability,'' Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Carl W. Ford told the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific. ``We are hopeful that the near loss of hard-won democracy will energize the Philippine public and private sectors to work even more closely and effectively,'' he said. During the same hearing, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State David Lambertson said he came back from Manila ``impressed again with the determination and resilience of the government and its people.'' But ``the danger of another coup attempt exists,'' he said. He said Mrs. Aquino must regain confidence by eradicating corruption and improving inefficient government services to avert another coup attempt. ``Corruption remains a real problem in the Philippines and its corrosive effects hamper government operations,'' he said. ``President Aquino is fully aware of the problem and has made efforts to deal with it'' both by example and by exhorting her people. Also Wednesday, the country's influential Roman Catholic hierachy deplored the ``climate of violence'' and warned against ``foreign interests'' seeking to foment unrest. The statement by the Catholic Bishops Conference of the Philippines did not identify ``foreign interests'' but the declaration followed media speculation that conservative groups in the United States may be working with Filipino dissidents to topple Mrs. Aquino. In a pastoral letter read over the church-run Radio Veritas by the conference president, Bishop Leonardo Legazpi, the Catholic leadership denounced coup attempts as ``immoral'' and ``unjust.'' The pastoral letter, the first since December's failed coup, was issued at the end of the two-day annual meeting of the conference, the highest policy-making church council in this predominantly Roman Catholic nation. It is to be read during church services nationwide over the weekend.

DOC.HEAD: AFL-CIO Backs Moynihan's Social Security Proposal
DOC.TEXT: The AFL-CIO on Wednesday backed a plan by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan to return Social Security to a pay-as-you-go basis and take its surplus off the federal budget. ``This plan would reduce the tax burden on working men and women, whose tax share has become disproportionate to that of the wealthy,'' the federation of 14.1 million union members said in a statement. ``As it is, the growing Social Security surplus is being used to mask budget deficits that have been exacerbated by unbalanced and unwise spending and revenue policies. The Moynihan proposal has exposed this scam for all to see.'' The endorsement came hours before President Bush was to attack the plan in his State of the Union address. He already voiced his opposition to the idea, which has generated heated debate since Moynihan, D-N.Y., first announced it in late December. Moynihan said he was heartened by the federation's support, which came after a meeting Wednesday with 20 member union leaders. ``The issues are tax fairness for American workers and the integrity of Social Security,'' he said. ``I am not the least surprised and (am) most gratified that (federation President) Lane Kirkland and the AFL-CIO insist on both.'' Last week, Moynihan introduced a bill to cut the Social Security tax from the current 6.2 percent to 5.1 percent by next year. This would cost the Social Security trust fund $55 billion but would save a working couple up to $600 a year. The measure would stop building up a huge trust fund surplus which Moynihan says is wrongly being used to mask the true size of the federal deficit. The AFL-CIO differed with Moynihan over how much the trust fund surplus should be allowed to grow before repealing the Social Security tax increase. The federation believes the surplus should reach 125 percent to 150 percent of one year's benefits while Moynihan's legislation would make the cuts when the fund reaches 100 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Admits False Statements on Northern Ireland Dirty Tricks
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Wednesday she wrongly denied the existence of a ``dirty tricks'' campaign in Northern Ireland in the 1970s, but blamed information she received from civil servants. On Tuesday, Armed Forces Minister Archie Hamilton confirmed that a covert program codenamed ``Clockwork Orange'' had existed to feed lies to journalists covering the Northern Ireland conflict. In 1987, Mrs. Thatcher rejected claims by former army press officer Colin Wallace that such a program existed. Wallace says he was dismissed from the Civil Service in 1975, four years before Mrs. Thatcher took office, for threatening to expose the program. Mrs. Thatcher's admission was published as the government promised a statement to the House of Commons on Thursday by Defense Secretary Tom King. The government has already begun a new inquiry into Wallace's dismissal. Until Tuesday, allegations of disinformation and cover-ups in Northern Ireland were always denied. Wallace says ``Clockwork Orange'' began as an attempt to discredit the Irish Republican Army through false stories such as the claim that the guerrillas had Soviet rockets armed with unstable explosives. He alleges that elements within MI5, the military counterintelligence agency, later took over the program and set out to smear politicians and prominent Protestants in Northern Ireland. The IRA has fought an urban guerrilla war since 1970 to end British rule in Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland and unite it with the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Irish Republic. In a letter to a lawmaker from her Conservative Party, Mrs. Thatcher said: ``I regret to say that a re-examination of departmental papers has brought to light information which shows that there were a number of statements in my letters, and in other ministerial statements and official correspondence, which were incorrect or require clarification. ``Inquiries are being made to establish how these errors in the handling of departmental papers occurred. ``But of course the matters with which they deal originated under previous administrations, and present ministers can only deal with them on the basis of information made available to us.'' Former MI5 agent Peter Wright spoke in his book ``Spycatcher'' of an MI5 plot to undermine Harold Wilson's government. Mrs. Thatcher's denial of any such plot came in a public debate about government efforts to suppress Wright's book. At the time Wallace was fired, Wilson was prime minister of a Labor Party government, though Wallace's allegations also involve the years of Edward Heath's Conservative government of 1970-74. Hamilton, the armed forces minister, said no evidence was found of any plot to discredit politicians, and he said the program had been terminated. ``It has not since the mid-1970s been the policy to disseminate disinformation in Northern Ireland in ways designed to denigrate individuals and-or organizations for propaganda purposes. That remains the case,'' he said. Tony Benn, a former Labor Cabinet minister, told Commons Wallace should testify before a parliamentary committee, free from the threat of prosecution for discussing state secrets. ``For over 20 years disinformation has been issuing from government ... disinformation now admitted for the first time ever by the government,'' Benn said. ``A Clockwork Orange'' is the title of a novel by Anthony Burgess, published in 1962, about extreme forms of mind-control in a totalitarian state. A film based on the book appeared in 1971.

DOC.HEAD: Army Steamrolls 3,500 Weapons Seized from Sinhalese Radicals
DOC.TEXT: Troops on Wednesday ran a steamroller over 3,500 weapons, mostly unserviceable shotguns, that they said were seized from Sinhalese extremists trying to topple the government. The crushed weapons were to be dumped in the sea. Three thousand other captured weapons were found to be in working order and will be put to unspecified use, military officials said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The government also reported 697 Sinhalese radicals surrendered in December and January and were taken to rehabilitation centers. The announcement gave no indication how long they will be held. It also said four Sinhalese civilians were killed by the extremists Tuesday in two attacks in southern Sri Lanka. The steamrolling of shotguns and other weapons symbolized the force the government has employed to halt attacks by the People's Liberation Front, which has been attacking government officials and supporters since 1987. In December about 8,000 shotguns and rifles were steamrolled in the first such action. At least 6,000 people have been killed in the struggle between the People's Liberation Front and the government. The front launched its campaign after July 29, 1987, when the government signed a peace accord designed to end a Tamil separatist revolt that has claimed 11,000 lives since 1983. Sinhalese control the government and the military and make up 75 percent of the country's population of 16 million.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Fires on Freighter Suspected of Carrying Drugs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE that chase lasted 26 miles. SUBS 6th graf, `No Mexican ...,' to UPDATE with Mexican navy escorting ship to Tampico, search of ship under way; SUBS 18-24, `The incident ...,' with 8 grafs to ADD time, distance of chase, details, quote; picks up 25th graf, `The Hermann ...'
DOC.TEXT: A Coast Guard cutter sprayed a Cuban-operated freighter with machine-gun fire and shells Wednesday when the ship refused to stop for a drug inspection, but the vessel escaped into Mexican waters, officials said. The 250-foot Hermann took several hits from the cutter Chincoteague as it was chased for more than 26 hours across the Gulf of Mexico, said Coast Guard spokesman Joe Gibson. Coast Guardsmen saw no evidence of casualties aboard the freighter, said Jack O'Dell, a Coast Guard spokesman in Washington. When the Panama-registered ship reached Mexican waters, the 110-foot Coast Guard cutter held fire and asked the Mexican government to take over and determine whether the vessel was carrying drugs, Gibson said. ``We were in international waters,'' Gibson said. ``We cannot pursue vessels into other countries' waters.'' The Hermann steamed on unaccompanied toward the central Mexican coast. Later, two Mexican navy vessels escorted the ship to the port of Tampico, and authorities began searching the vessel, the Foreign Ministry said. The inspection was expected to take at least 24 hours. The official Cuban news agency Prensa Latina reported that the ship, with a 12-man crew, was carrying 10 tons of the element chromium and was operated by the Guamar Shipping Co. of Cuba. Gibson, however, said the Coast Guard talked to the ship's master by radio and the captain claimed the vessel had no cargo. He said the Coast Guard's law enforcement division believes the ship carried chrome, which can be either chromium or an alloy of the element. An official at the Cuban diplomatic mission in Washington called the incident a provocation. In a report monitored in Mexico City, Prensa Latina quoted another official as saying, ``This deed demonstrates once more that the United States intends to behave as owner of the world and with its proverbial barbarism appears willing to obstruct normal commerce between Cuba and Mxico.'' U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III disagreed. ``It was not an attack and a provocation,'' Baker told reporters. ``We were engaged in a legal law enforcement activity.'' State Department, Defense Department and National Security Council officials held three meetings before giving permission to use disabling fire against the Hermann, said O'Dell. The Coast Guard obtained permission from Panama to fire on the ship, Gibson said. He said it is protocol to request permission to stop a vessel from its country of registry. The Cuban Embassy in Mexico City charged that the Hermann was attacked in Mexican waters, but that was denied by Mexico's Foreign Ministry and the U.S. government. Prensa Latina said the Hermann's captain, Diego Sanchez, was in contact with Cuba throughout the incident, and was told not to allow the Coast Guard to board and to fight until the end. ``The occupants of the merchant ship were ready to stop them with machetes, knives, hatchets and other tools,'' Presna Latina said. The 335-mile chase began at 4:30 a.m. Tuesday, when the Chincoteague spotted the Hermann about 120 miles north of Merida on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula, said Coast Guard Lt. Steve Koska. The Coast Guard decided to check the Hermann because it fit the profile of a narcotics-smuggling ship, he said, refusing to be specific. The cutter tried repeatedly to stop the freighter peacefully, Gibson said. ``We got on the radio, we asked them to stop, we used a signal light, we used a blue light, we used a flag hoist, we sprayed water onto the vessel and we sprayed water down into the stacks,'' he said. ``Nothing worked, so we fired warning shots over the bow,'' Gibson said. ``They continued, and we asked the Panamanian government for permission to use disabling fire. The Panamanian government said do it.'' The Chincoteague opened fire on the Hermann at 5:08 a.m. Wednesday about 45 miles east of Tampico, Koska said. The ship entered Mexican waters at 6:43 a.m. ``The bottom line is that we weren't able to disable the vessel,'' Koska said. Including warning shots, the cutter fired 130 rounds from a 20mm gun and 250 to 300 rounds from an M-60 machine gun, Gibson said. The Hermann took hits in the engine compartment and the rudder post, O'Dell said. The ship was belching black smoke and might have been taking on water. The cutter lost sight of the ship, but the Hermann's master was heard on the radio asking Mexican officials for permission to enter the Tampico harbor. The Chincoteague, based in Mobile, Ala., has a crew of 16, two M-60 machine guns and one 20mm gun on the forecastle.

DOC.HEAD: A Bolshoi Mac Attack in Moscow as First McDonald's Opens
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 6th `Big Macs' to ADD official exchange rates. Pickup 7th `Half the...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB4,6
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of queue-hardened Soviets on Wednesday cheerfully lined up to get a taste of ``gamburgers,'' ``chizburgers'' and ``Filay-o-feesh'' sandwiches as McDonald's opened in the land of Lenin for the first time. The world's largest version of the landmark American fast-food chain rang up 30,000 meals on 27 cash registers, breaking the opening-day record for McDonald's worldwide, officials said. The Soviets, bundled in fur coats and hats, seemed unfazed, lining up before dawn outside the 700-seat restaurant, the first of 20 planned across the Soviet Union. The crush of customers was so intense the company stayed open until midnight, two hours later than planned. ``I only waited an hour and I think they served thousands before me,'' said a happy middle-aged woman who works at an aluminum plant. ``And it was only 10 rubles for all this,'' she said. ``I'm taking it back for the girls at the factory to try.'' Big Macs were priced at 3.75 rubles and double cheeseburgers at 3 rubles _ about two hours' pay for a starting McDonald's staffer or the average Soviet, but much cheaper than other private restaurants that have sprung up recently. The official exchange rate is $1.59 per ruble but foreign visitors can buy rubles for 16 cents each, about what the currency is worth on the black market. Half the day's sales were donated to the Soviet Children's Fund, which provides medical care and assistance to orphans and disadvantaged children, Gary Reinblatt, senior vice president of McDonald's Canada, said from Toronto. The restaurant, built by the company in a joint venture with the city of Moscow that began 14 years ago, brought to 52 the number of countries where McDonald's operates. The previous opening-day record for sales was in Budapest, company officials said. Besides its restaurants in the United States, the leading number of McDonald's are in Canada and Japan, the officials said. Soviets got a first-hand look at such alien concepts as efficiency and fast, friendly service. Normally dour citizens broke into grins as they caught the infectious cheerful mood from youthful Soviet staffers hired for their ability to smile and work hard. Accordions played folk songs and women in traditional costumes danced with cartoon characters, including Mickey Mouse and Baba Yaga, a witch of Russian fairy tales. One Muscovite, accustomed to clerks who snarl if they say anything at all, asked for a straw and was startled when a smiling young Soviet woman found him one and popped it straight into his drink. For most customers, it was their first experience with a hamburger. Sandwiches were served in the familiar bag marked with the golden arches, but were packed in wrappers bearing Cyrillic letters, approximating ``gamburger.'' They tried them one-handed. They picked their sandwiches apart to examine the contents. One young woman finally squashed her ``Beeg Mak'' to fit her lips around it. ``It tasted great!'' a 14-year-old boy said. ``It's a lot different from a stolovaya,'' he continued with a smile, referring to the much cheaper but run-down dirty cafeterias that slop rice and fat or boiled sausage.
