Under the sign of the golden arches, accented by the Soviet hammer-and-sickle flag, hundreds lined up for the long-awaited grand opening at 10 a.m. on Pushkin Square, reaching out excitedly for McDonald's flags and pins as the hamburger chain's army fulfilled the Soviet penchant for souvenirs with Western logos. Publicity-conscious managers had the staff shout ``Good morning, America!'' in English and Russian, for an American TV network. McDonald's of Canada Chairman George Cohon, the man behind the deal, said many people were buying multiple orders and the restaurant served 15,000 to 20,000 people in just the first five hours of operation. The restaurant limited purchases to 10 Big Macs per customer in hopes of preventing burger-scalping. McDonald's built its own factory, including bakery, dairy, meat-processing plant and even potato storage yard, to provide its own guaranteed supplies in a country where up to 25 percent of the harvest rots en route to the consumer. One McDonald's associate said the company wound up importing wooden crates from Finland for storing potatoes because ``when they went to build crates, they found there was no wood, and no nails. They found you need a permit to buy nails.''

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Assembly Prepares to Vote on Two Abortion Bills
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 15th graf, `Some of...,' to UPDATE with drawn-out debate on second bill.
DOC.TEXT: State lawmakers decided Tuesday not to vote on a measure to repeal unenforceable criminal penalties for doctors who perform abortions, but they continued debate on a bill to require minors to get permission for abortions. The Assembly voted 57-39 to keep the repeal bill in the amendment stage and not bring it to the floor for a final vote, a move that pro-choice lawmakers said effectively killed the measure. ``It's dead,'' Rep. Rebecca Young, a Democrat, said minutes after the vote. ``This is the end of the bill for this session.'' The bill would have repealed an outdated state law that provides criminal penalties, including prison terms, for doctors who perform abortions. The law has been unenforceable since a 1973 U.S. Supreme Court ruling legalized abortion nationwide. Abortion-rights lawmakers said they want to remove the law from the books in case the high court should overturn Roe vs. Wade. Abortion opponents said the law should be kept for the same reason. The second bill, backed by abortion opponents, would require minors to obtain permission from at least one parent or a court order before having an abortion. If the second bill is approved by the Assembly, it would require approval by the Senate and Gov. Tommy G. Thompson before becoming law. Rep. David Clarenbach, a pro-choice Democrat, said he had expected the repeal bill to be set back Tuesday, but predicted it would pass some day. ``This Legislature is in the process of becoming pro-choice,'' he said. ``Today, many of you are risking your political careers by failing to take a pro-choice stand.'' Assembly Speaker Thomas Loftus, also a Democrat, said the repeal measure is not dead and could be brought up again later this week if two-thirds of the Assembly voted to do so. ``You have to live with these votes for the rest of your political life,'' Loftus had said earlier. Before deciding not to vote on the repeal bill, the Assembly rejected an amendment by Democratic Rep. Thomas Seery to alter the measure so that doctors who performed abortions and women who obtained abortions after the 18th week of pregnancy could still face criminal penalties. ``What I'm trying to do is find a middle ground,'' Seery said. ``What I'm trying to do is determine when life begins.'' Lawmakers scrambled Tuesday before the floor session began to introduce amendments to the second bill, which would require minors to get permission before having an abortion. Some of the estimated 21 amendments hadn't even been drafted shortly before the 99-member Assembly began debate Tuesday afternoon. By 9 p.m., the Assembly had acted only two of the amendments, increasing chances that the session would go into Wednesday. The proposals include provisions to require teen-agers to obtain the consent of one parent before carrying a child to full term and to require parents of teen-age mothers to support their grandchildren. Democrats control the Assembly 55-42, but Republican Rep. Robert Welch had said partisan affiliation would have little effect because there are more anti-abortion Democrats in the Assembly than pro-choice Republicans. Welch also disagreed with Loftus that the lawmakers' votes on the two bills would make or break their careers. ``I don't think there's a single person in the state Assembly who will get defeated because of the abortion issue, no matter what their stand is,'' Welch said.

DOC.HEAD: Bologna, a Communist Showcase, Turns to Private Enterprise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES extraneous letter `c' in lead and 6th graf, `The proposal...'; b0127 sent Jan. 25 for use today.
DOC.TEXT: If Communists had a heaven, it might look like Bologna. Orange buses glide through a huge historic district closed to other traffic. Senior citizens take government-subsidized vacations on the Riviera. Half the city's youngsters attend low-cost day-care centers. ``The Red Disneyland,'' as the Italian press calls it, has long been considered the showcase of communism Italian-style. So when the government recently suggested turning city services over to private enterprise, it left many Italians in shock. ``The proposal coming from Bologna is, in some measure, revolutionary,'' columnist Miriam Mafai wrote in the national newspaper La Repubblica. ``All previous ideas are being erased from the slate, not only for the Italian Communist Party, but for all the left.'' The proposal put forth for the northern Italian city is considered symbolic of the new directions being pursued by the Italy's national Communist Party, the largest in the West, as it seeks to overcome an electoral decline and the specter of Communist failure in Eastern Europe. ``I don't want to be reduced to a souvenir of a past era,'' said Bologna's 45-year-old mayor, Renzo Imbeni, an energetic Marxist with a bushy black mustache. ``I want to be here when the history of tomorrow is written. The change stems from this need.'' With a population of 417,000, Bologna is the biggest city in the Italian ``Red Belt,'' a communist-governed region that has become one of the country's wealthiest areas. After World War II, when voters turned to the party that helped lead the anti-fascist resistance, Bologna became Italy's first large city to elect a communist administration. It earned national fame for its ``do-it-all governments'' which set up pharmacies in poor neighborhoods, paid the rent for low-income elderly citizens and offered free bus transportation during rush hours. When buildings decayed in the portico-lined historic district, the government spent millions of dollars to restore them _ then moved the working-class residents back in. To help women work, it set up a day-care system that even today charges the equivalent of only $65 to $150 a month for children up to 5. ``There is a rather high level of social protection,'' Mayor Imbeni said in an interview in the Communal Palace, a 15th-century building surrounded by bulletin boards featuring the communist daily newspaper, L'Unita. ``But it's not written anywhere that we will be able to guarantee this also in the future.'' He noted that the welfare-state system had deteriorated in many countries due to stagnant revenues, an increase in the number of needy and a shrinking pool of young people _ all problems in Bologna. ``Because of this, the choice was made ... for a requalification and a renewal of the welfare state we have locally,'' Imbeni said. What Bologna is proposing to do is sell off its slaughterhouse and 21 city pharmacies and transfer such services as the cleaning of schools, provision of student lunches and street maintenance to a mixed public-private concern. It also is discussing private management of the hundreds of city-owned offices and apartments. The money saved would be devoted to priority areas such as the increasing number of elderly and Third World immigrants and the environment. The plan has won praise from business executives, average citizens and the national Communist Party, which is Italy's second-biggest party. The main critics are rival political parties, which charge the project is merely a maneuver to win votes in municipal elections this coming May. ``If it's real and concrete, this is an interesting, stunning new initiative _ an initiative that will be taken as an example by other city governments,'' said Gianandrea Rocco di Torrepadula, head of the local Industrialists Association. ``In comparison to other cities, this one is run OK,'' said Marco Bassi, 46, who owns a newsstand in the working-class Little Bologna neighborhood. ``But things always go better in the private sector.'' Imbeni insists that the communists are not doing an about-face. ``People say the concept of state ownership is part of the communist culture,'' he said. ``But for the communists of Bologna, this isn't true. And for the Italian communists, that was years ago.'' Indeed, Bologna and the rest of the ``Red Belt'' are known for their citizens' entrepreneurial spirit, illustrated by the network of cooperatives _ most linked to the communists _ which do everything from producing Parmesan cheese to running restaurants. The national Communist Party is hailing the Bologna plan an example of its own ``new course.'' The party has long embraced parliamentary democracy but has been kept out of the government for four decades. In line with its new program, the party has called an extraordinary congress for March to decide whether to become a new leftist umbrella group _ and perhaps even drop the communist name and hammer-and-sickle symbol. While the Bologna proposal was described as a ``revolution'' in national newspapers, it will leave many city services intact. The government refuses to privatize the day-care system and the vast bus network, although it has abolished the free rush-hour rides. The low-income elderly will still have a taxi service, domestic helpers, 32 social centers and subsidized vacations on the Italian Riviera. The government will also continue to provide low-cost study vacations for teens in England and on the French Riviera. ``We don't want to change because there's a black spot on the soul of our past,'' Imbeni said. ``We must change because we want to be here in the year 2000 ... with the name we have today or another. I want to be here.''

DOC.HEAD: ADA Attacks Study on Fluoridation
DOC.TEXT: The American Dental Association scoffed at a recent study that found highly fluoridated water caused a rare form of bone cancer in some rats and reaffirmed its support of the anti-cavity treatment. ``It is totally inappropriate to draw any conclusions from this single study or to suggest that it is applicable to human beings,'' said Dr. Enid Neidle, director of scientific affairs for the ADA. One rat among a group of 50 developed bone cancer after consuming fluoridated water in a concentration of 45 parts per million over two years, according to preliminary data from a study conducted by the National Toxicology Program. Four rats in another group developed the cancer after drinking fluoridated water with a concentration of 79 parts per million over the same period, the study found. But the Chicago-based ADA said Tuesday the public should not fear sodium fluoride because humans ingest much smaller amounts of the chemical. The average person drinks about eight glasses of water a day, the ADA said in a press release. A person would have to drink 380 glasses each day to obtain the same concentration of fluoride as that in the first group of rats, and about 700 glasses a day to obtain the same concentration of fluoride as that in the second group of rats, the association said. Fluoride, a natural chemical that appears in some waterways, has remained a controversial issue for many American communities since 1945, when it was artificially introduced into the public water supply in Grand Rapids, Mich., and Newburgh, N.Y. People who favor fluoridation as the best way to prevent tooth decay say it prevents about two-thirds of all cavities and is almost completely safe. Those who oppose the fluoridation process say the treated water stains teeth, could harm bones and may cause certain forms of cancer. Public water systems in the United States last year served about 213 million people, but only 61 percent of them drink fluoridated water. In 1989, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Portland, Ore., and San Antonio still were without fluoridated water, according to the National Institute of Dental Research. Many other local and state governments require fluoridation by law.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Determines Coleman Can Take Care of Himself
DOC.TEXT: Actor Gary Coleman scored a victory over his mother Wednesday when a judge ruled the 21-year-old former ``Diff'rent Strokes'' star was mentally capable of handling his $7 million in holdings by himself. ``The very things you claim he doesn't have, he's got,'' Superior Court Judge Martha Goldin told an attorney for Coleman's mother, who had asked that a court conservator take over the diminutive actor's finances. Edmonia Sue Coleman contended her son was unable to make his own decisions rationally because of the effects of kidney disease and the influence of a close friend and adviser who lives with him in Denver. Coleman said at a court hearing earlier this month that his mother's effort for conservatorship was an ``attempt to control my life.'' Coleman, who played the precocious Arnold Jackson on the hit TV show, filed a lawsuit that alleges his parents and former business manager mishandled his money and funneled away more than $1 million for themselves. The lawsuit has yet to come to trial. Goldin said she relied on findings in a court-ordered report detailing Coleman's condition in ruling against ordering a conservatorship hearing. The judge sealed the report. Coleman declined to comment. His attorney, Charles Wake, said the actor was pleased. ``It was an emotional experience for him,'' said Wake. Coleman's mother said she remains concerned about her son and continues to feel he is getting poor advice from his friend and former chauffeur, Dion Mial. ``Gary is my son and I love him very much, regardless of what Mr. Wake says,'' said Mrs. Coleman. ``And what I have done has been in Gary's best interest.'' Coleman was born with an atrophied right kidney and lost the other one when he was 5. He underwent transplants in 1973 and 1984, both of which failed. He took immunosuppressive drugs for his condition and they stunted his growth at 4 feet, 8 inches.

DOC.HEAD: Israel, East Germany End Preliminary Talks on Relations
DOC.TEXT: Diplomats from Israel and East Germany concluded preliminary talks Wednesday on establishing formal relations and settling the issue of moral responsibility for the murder of 6 million Jews in the Nazi Holocaust. Talks were adjourned after three days, but both sides said they would resume later. The Israeli delegation said the central issue was the question of East Germany's accepting ``its share in the moral and historical responsibility for crimes perpetrated by Germans against Jews during the Nazi regime.'' West Germany has acknowledged guilt of the German people and has paid $47 billion in indemnities to Holocaust victims and their families. Previous Stalinist governments in East Germany denied any responsibility for the Holocaust, arguing that the Communists represented the anti-Nazi resistance and bore no blame. East German chief delegate Reinar Neumann, chief of the Foreign Ministry's Middle East desk, indicated the new, reform-minded government would review its position. Prime Minister Hans Modrow said last week East Germany was willing to discuss the question of reparations, and sought relations with all nations. The Israeli statement said Israel wanted ties with all countries regardless of ideology. ``Relations with Germany, however, present Israel with difficulties, as could be appreciated by everyone familiar with 20th century history.'' Israel said East Germany asked for the talks. Michael Shiloh, the Foreign Ministry's adviser on Jewish diaspora affairs, led Israel's delegation. Israel and West Germany established diplomatic relations in 1965. The Jewish state and East Germany have never had diplomatic relations. It was not clear if either side raised the parallel issue of fears voiced by Israeli officials over possible reunification of East and West Germany. A newspaper in Munich reported Wednesday that West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl was ``infuriated'' by Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's reservations. The two leaders have had ``a sharp exchange of letters,'' the paper Sueddeutsche Zeitung reported.

DOC.HEAD: Police Release Tape of Child's Call Relating Family's Death
DOC.TEXT: A 7-year-old boy told a police dispatcher that his mother stabbed his two sisters to death and then forced his brother to kill her, according to a wrenching police tape of the conversation. The triple slaying occurred one day last October while the children's father, Christopher King, was at work. King has since reached an agreement with the state child welfare agency to begin intensive counseling before pursuing custody of his two surviving sons. The call began with David King telling the Metro-Dade police dispatcher, ``My mommy killed my sisters. ... Then mommy said to kill her back. ... Then Junior did. Now Junior's crying. Junior's crying.'' The dispatcher asked, ``Is your mother still breathing?'' David said, ``No, I don't see her breathing.'' Pursuing the same question, the dispatcher asked, ``Is she still living?'' David said he thought so, then ordered his 8-year-old brother, Christopher King Jr., ``Junior, go see if mommy breathing.'' The caller came back on the line to say, ``My mommy ain't breathing.'' Christopher Jr. already had called his father to tell him about the bloody scene, and King called police for help saying, ``My son just called me and told everybody at home is dead.'' Police arrived along with King to find the bodies of Marie King and her daughters, 4-year-old Grace and 3-year-old Sarah. Autopsies showed each had been stabbed more than 20 times. The tape was released Tuesday by the Dade County State Attorney's office.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE Washington
Former Mexican Officials Indicted in Drug Agent Slaying
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to DELETE extraneous material from lead, add background on those indicted, earlier convictions. Edits throughout. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The former head of the Mexican Federal Judicial Police and four others were indicted by a federal grand jury Wednesday on charges of participating in the murder of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena Salazar. Manuel Ibarra Herrera was among five defendants named in the indictment returned by a federal grand jury in Los Angeles, the Justice Department said. Also indicted was Miguel Aldana Ibarra, the former head of the Mexican branch of Interpol, the international law enforcement agency, and Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, whose extradition to the United States sparked deadly riots in Honduras in 1988. The five were among 19 people named in a superseding indictment Wednesday that updates charges related to the February 1985 torture murder of Camarena and his Mexican pilot and the killings of two U.S. citizens in Guadalajara. The indictment charged that Ibarra Herrera, Aldana Ibarra and Matta Ballesteros participated in the killing to protect the operations of the Guadalajara cocaine and marijuana cartel, according to a Justice Department news release. Others were indicted on charges of kidnapping and drug trafficking. If convicted, the defendants could receive life sentences. Camarena and his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar, were killed after the agent led a series of raids on marijuana plantations allegedly operated by Rafael Caro Quintero, who allegedly ran the drug ring. Camarena's body was found March 5, 1985, on a ranch 65 miles southeast of Guadalajara. The Drug Enforcement Administration has vowed that it will prosecute all connected to the case. Aldana Ibarra was quoted extensively in Mexican newspapers in January as saying that Camarena was alive and living in La Jolla, Calif. His comments came after NBC-TV aired ``Drug Wars,'' a three-part movie focusing on Camarena's killing. Matta was sentenced Jan. 16 in Los Angeles to life in prison without possibility of parole following his conviction of conspiracy, possession, distribution of narcotics and running a criminal enterprise. The charges stemmed from a cocaine ring Matta ran that distributed the drug in Los Angeles. Matta's forced extradition to the United States in April 1988 sparked riots that left five dead in Honduras and torched the U.S. Embassy annex there. Also charged with participating in the Camarena slaying were Miguel Angel Felix Gallardo and a Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain. Considered one of Mexico's biggest drug lords, Felix Gallardo's arrest in April 1989 on drug trafficking charges was considered a sign by U.S. officials that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari was serious about cracking down on drug trafficking. Ibarra Herrera headed a law enforcement agency that is the equivalent of the FBI in the United States. He and Aldana Ibarra are among 15 defendants named in the indictment who are not in U.S. custody. Killed with Camarena was Alfredo Zavala Avelar, a pilot who assisted the DEA in Mexico. The Justice Department release did not specify who was accused in his slaying, although the killing was a subject of the indictment. Caro Quintero and Ernesto Fonseca Carrillo were sentenced in December to 40 years in prison without parole for their role in Camarena's slaying. Ten other men already have been prosecuted and sentenced in Mexico for the killings. U.S. officials have said they believed that some higher-level Mexican authorities were involved in protecting the drug traffickers and covering-up the crime. ``We want the message to be clear that anyone who kills one of our agents will be hunted down and brought to justice by the DEA,'' said Ralph Lochridge, DEA spokesman in Los Angeles. Lochridge said a DEA task force based in Los Angeles was investigating the alleged role of others in the slaying. He declined to identify them. The indictment also charges Antonio Vasquez Ochoa with two counts of committing violent crimes in aid of racketeering in connection with the Jan. 30, 1985, killings of Americans John Walker and Alberto Radelat, who were living in Guadalajara. The indictment charges the killings were carried out by Vasquez Ochoa and others to protect the operation of the Guadalajara-based cartel. Already in custody are Ruben Zuno Arce, who was arrested Dec. 9; Javier Vasquez Velasco, arrested Oct. 12; and Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, arrested July 27. Zuno Arce, the brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria, faces federal charges of conspiracy, kidnapping and violence in aid of racketeering in connection with Camarena's slaying. Bernabe Ramirez also is charged with conspiracy to kidnap a federal agent and is in custody. Vasquez Velasco is charged with two counts of committing violent crimes in aid of racketeering in connection with the murders of Walker and Radelat.

DOC.HEAD: Baltic Environmental Ministers Appeal for Help
DOC.TEXT: The environmental ministers of the Soviet Union's three Baltic republics said Wednesday their regions have been seriously polluted and they need help from the West in cleanup efforts. Indulis Emsis of Latvia said the port of Ventspils, for example, is a ``gigantic powder keg'' because of the large quantities of chemicals and minerals dumped into the sea. ``An accident there would threaten inhabitants and neighboring countries,'' he said. The ministers of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania were in Stockholm on a five-day official visit they hope will lead to cooperation in environmental research and cleanup projects. The Swedish government has pledged $160 million to help the republics. ``We are intent on helping, as a gesture of solidarity, but also because it benefits Sweden,'' said Environment Minister Birgitta Dahl. The Baltic officials said their new leaders have broken with the past and made environmental issues a top priority. Estonia's Tiit Nuudi said his republic was creating a system of fees for consumers of natural resources and fines for polluting activities.

DOC.HEAD: What Do Children Think?
DOC.TEXT: Given the chance, 65 percent of high school students would cheat on an important exam, according to a national survey released Wednesday that questioned American children on their beliefs and moral values. The survey also showed that 37 percent of junior and senior high school students interviewed said they would have sex with someone they love. The survey interviewed 5,012 students in grades 4-12 from 233 public, private and parochial schools from Sept. 14 to Oct. 30. Among its other findings: _ When asked how they would advise a pregnant friend, only 12 percent of respondents said they would tell her to have an abortion, while 57 percent advised having the baby. Black and Hispanic children were significantly more likely to recommend having and keeping the baby over abortion or adoption. Seventy percent of students surveyed said a pregnant girl should have the final say on having an abortion; 13 percent gave that say to the parents. _ Among their major concerns, respondents most often (24 percent) listed pressure to do well in school or sports, followed by what to do with their lives (17 percent), drug use (13 percent), lack of close friends (8 percent) and teen-age pregnancy (6 percent). As for the pressures they feel a lot, obeying parents and teachers led the list (80 percent), followed by the pressure to get good grades (78 percent), not to take drugs (77 percent), to prepare for the future (69 percent) and to earn money (62 percent). Just 6 percent named the pressure to take drugs. _ Nearly half of those surveyed (45 percent) said they rely on their own personal experience when deciding what is true, compared to just 3 percent who believe science is the most believable authority in such matters. The survey was conducted for the Girl Scouts of the United States of America in partnership with the Lilly Endowment and the C.S. Mott Foundation. It was done by Harris-Scholastic Research, a division of the Louis Harris and Associates Inc. polling firm, in collaboration with Harvard child psychiatrist Robert Coles, sociologist James Davison Hunter of the University of Virginia and John Seel of the Williamsburg Charter Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Governor Says Much of Prince William Sound Remains Oiled
DOC.TEXT: Much of Prince William Sound remains polluted from the nation's worst oil spill, and the cleanup must resume when the weather improves this spring, Gov. Steve Cowper said Wednesday. About 117 miles of shore throughout the sound remain oiled from the Exxon Valdez spill, including 85 heavily oiled areas, according to a state survey released by Cowper. While much of the surface oil is gone, in 224 locations oil was found up to 28 inches deep in the rocky beaches, he said. ``The evidence is that the problem will not go away by the end of this winter, and that we are going to have to return to the beaches of coastal Alaska to clean up this mess,'' Cowper told a news conference. He also called on Congress to pass pending legislation that would require oil tankers using U.S. ports to have double hulls and double bottoms within several years. Nearly 11 million gallons of North Slope crude gushed from the Valdez after it ran aground March 24. The state Department of Environmental Conservation surveyed the shores in October and November after Exxon Corp. halted its cleanup due to severe winter weather. The data took some time to assemble, state officials said, and the survey was not completed until last week. The news conference came as jury selection was under way in Anchorage in the criminal trial of Joseph Hazelwood, former captain of the Exxon Valdez. Cowper spokesman David Ramseur said reporters covering the trial were invited to take part in the news conference by telephone. Exxon officials did not dispute the survey's findings, but said nature has removed oil from many shores since the information was collected last fall. ``We know that in the high-energy areas that the winter storms are having a dramatic effect,'' said Don Carpenter, Exxon's operations and logistics manager in Anchorage. ``The 32 miles in the sheltered areas we have more concern about, but there's evidence that the effect of nature's forces is dramatic there, too.'' But recent spot checks found continued heavy oil accumulations, Cowper said, showing reporters a two-minute video with scenes of oiled beaches shot in the past three days. The scenes confirm the fall survey's results, he said. ``The reason why we are presenting this beach survey is not to criticize the efforts that have been made so far,'' he said. ``The point is to show the amount of work that has to be done as soon as the weather clears.'' Exxon and several government agencies will put together a spring cleanup plan after another survey is conducted in April. Exxon spokesman Perry Smith said a determination of what cleanup measures, if any, are needed will be made by May. Cowper said his administration decided to support the proposed requirement for double-bottomed, double-hulled tankers despite the estimated $10 million a year it would cost the state in reduced oil revenues. The industry's cost of upgrading the Alaska tanker fleet is a transportation expense that would be deducted from the wellhead price of Alaska oil, on which the state bases its taxes and royalties. ``We think that it's worth it,'' Cowper said. The tankers used in the Alaska trade are aging and will have to replaced eventually anyway, he said. A Coast Guard study estimated the Exxon Valdez would have released about 60 percent less oil if it had a double bottom.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says 100s of Schools Destroyed by War
DOC.TEXT: A guerrilla war has destroyed nearly one-third of the country's primary schools, the Mozambican news agency reported Wednesday. The news agency AIM said Fatima Carrilho, a senior Ministry of Education official, told a conference 32 percent of the 5,709 primary schools that existed in 1981 had been decimated by fighting. Ms. Carrilho said the poor southern African nation was facing an education crisis with just half the schools offering a full five-year primary education, the report said. The nation's schools only had enough room for 40 percent of children of school age, it said. The government lacks the money to build schools and improve education, with just 225 new classrooms being constructed in 1989, the report said. The leftist government of the former Portugese colony is fighting a 13-year-old insurgency by the Mozambique National Resistance. The war has devastated large areas of the country, with the death toll estimated at up to 500,000.

DOC.HEAD: Snowfall Leaves 27 Dead in South Korea, 18 Injured in Japan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with more than two dozen dead from snow in South Korea, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Snow blanketed much of Japan and South Korea on Thursday, snarling transportation and leaving more than two dozen people dead and hundreds injured this week, officials said. Tokyo, a city unused to anything more than a dusting of snow, woke up to find nearly 3 inches on the ground and more falling. By dawn, more than 3 inches had fallen in adjacent Yokohama and 7{ inches in Mito, 63 miles northeast of Tokyo, the Meteorological Agency said. In South Korea about 10 inches of snow fell by early Thursday in Seoul, the capital city of 10 million people. Police reported hundreds of casualties in snow-related traffic accidents, including 27 deaths on Tuesday when snow began piling up. Damage was estimated at $6 million nationwide. Villages along the east coast and nearby mountains were hit hardest with up to 5 feet of snow since Tuesday afternoon. The international airport at Narita, 35 miles northeast of Tokyo, was closed at 8:00 a.m. for snow removal but was scheduled to reopen about an hour later. At Tokyo's Haneda airport, 43 domestic flights were canceled due to snow, affecting 5,000 passengers, Kyodo News Service reported. Another domestic airport at Sendai, in northwestern Japan, was also closed due to snow, Kyodo said. In Tokyo, 18 people were slightly injured after they fell on slippery roads or were involved in snow-related traffic accidents, said Sabuto Nakane, a spokesman for the Tokyo Fire Department. There were no reports of deaths or injuries elsewhere. Meanwhile, the bullet trains were running at a reduced 106 mph due to snow, railway officials said. The intercity trains usually run at 130 mph. About 40,000 government officials and police were ordered out Thursday to clear Korean streets of snow and open traffic to isolated villages after forecasters lifted snow warnings, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges Troop Cut in State of Union Speech: ``Time is Right''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Wrapup lead; Bush describes Gorbachev reaction, CORRECTS Panama troops to 14,000 sted 13,000. Editing throughout to tighten.
DOC.TEXT:
President Bush, acclaiming the ``revolution of '89'' in Eastern Europe, proposed a sharp new cut in U.S. and Soviet combat forces Wednesday night and told a joint meeting of Congress that ``the time is right to move forward'' in Europe. In his first State of the Union address, Bush also announced plans to withdraw _ ``well before the end of February'' _ the last 3,000 troops from a force of 14,000 sent to Panama to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Democrats and Republicans alike, assembled in joint session of Congress to hear the president, stood in ovation when Bush said, ``One year ago, the people of Panama lived in fear, under the thumb of a dictator. Today, democracy is restored, Panama is free.'' Hours before he delivered his address, Bush telephoned Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to advise him of his proposal to cut U.S. and Soviet forces in Central Europe to 195,000 on each side. Later Bush charcterized Gorbachev as ``receptive'' and willing to consider the proposal. The cuts would be nowhere near equal since the Soviets have a huge advantage in European military force. The United States has 305,000 troops in Europe, compared to 565,000 Soviet forces. Last May, Bush proposed a 275,000-troop ceiling and he had said he would not seek deeper cuts until U.S.-Soviet negotiators had finalized that agreement. Wednesday, the administration said it wanted parallel discussions on the deeper cuts. Why the shift? A senior U.S. official said, ``Events (in Europe) were running ahead of the negotiations.'' The European troop offer was the surprising _ and popular _ centerpiece of a speech in which Bush also proposed lofty goals for American schools and prodded lawmakers to approve his plans for a capital gains tax cut and bills dealing with clean air, child care, crime and drugs. In reaction, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley embraced the troop reduction plan but said Democrats would offer a domestic agenda of their own. With ambassadors from across the world in attendance, Bush said, ``With communism crumbling, our aim must be to ensure Democracy's advance ... We are in a period of great transition, great hope, yet great uncertainty.'' Bush said, ``The events of the year just ended _ the revolution of '89 _ have been a chain reaction, change so striking that it marks the beginning of a new era in the world's affairs. ``Think back,'' Bush asked Congress and his national broadcast audience, ``to the world we knew as 1989 began.'' In the year since, Communist governments gave way in Poland, East Germany, Romania, Bulgaria and Czechoslovakia. In such locations, Bush said, ``the idea called America is alive.'' On his return to the White House, Bush was asked by reporters how Gorbachev reacted. ``I can't characterize it, but I can just simply say that he was receptive, but I don't know whether he's supportive or not. I just told him about it and so we have to wait,'' Bush said. ``You can't _ something as complicated as that and serious, obviously they need to consider it. So that's about all. But it was a friendly and I think productive conversation.'' In his speech, Bush said: ``We recognize that the Soviet military threat in Europe is diminishing but we see little change in Soviet strategic modernization. ... But the time is right to move forward on a conventional arms-control agreement to move us to more appropriate levels of military forces in Europe.'' His troop cutback proposal won immediate praise from Congress. Sen. Sam Nunn, Democratic chairman of the Armed Services Committee, said it fit ``the changing circumstances in Europe and the fiscal pressures'' at home. ``It's time to act together,'' Bush said in a speech intended to help set an election-year agenda for a Democratic-run Congress. Even so, partisanship was clear when Bush extolled his ``no new taxes'' budget plan. Republicans erupted with applause. Democrats didn't. Bush was welcomed warmly as he entered the packed chamber, where congressional aides stood three deep around the walls and spectators filled even the aisle stairs in the visitors' galleries. A cheer went up as Foley, D-Wash., introduced the president as ``our former colleague.'' Barbara Bush stood in the balcony with hands clasped in front of her during the 2{-minute welcoming ovation. Nearby sat Marilyn Quayle and next to her, evangelist Billy Graham. In all, there were 35 interruptions for applause. Foley agreed with much of what Bush said, but said that on some points, Democrats disagree. Foley said Bush cannot become the ``education president,'' if his budget for fiscal 1991 includes only a 2 percent increase in spending for education. The speaker also said Democrats will fight the administration on child care, clean air legislation, capital gains and the issue of abortion. In his speech, the president condemned racially motivated mail bombings, saying the nation ``must confront and condemn racisim, anti-semitism, bigotry and hate.'' And he said, ``Our hearts go out to our hostages -- our hostages who are ceaselessly on our minds and in our efforts.'' ``... And let me say that so long as we remember the American idea _ so long as we live up to the American ideal _ the State of the union will remain sound and strong,'' he said. Confronting a sensitive issue, Bush brushed off a proposal by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., to roll back a Social Security tax increase. ``The last thing we need to do is mess around with Social Security,'' Bush said. Republicans rose in applause, followed by Democrats, including a broadly-grinning Moynihan.

DOC.HEAD: Troop Cuts Would Hit West Germany Hardest; Unity Drive Could Benefit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT graf after 6th graf, There was ... UPDATING with Bonn spokesman saying details awaited there. Picks up 7th, Late-night television ...; ADDS 4 grafs on Genscher military compromise proposal for united Germany.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-State of Union, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Large-scale U.S. troop cuts in Europe at the level President Bush discussed with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev Wednesday would deal an economic blow to West Germany. Bush proposed that U.S. and Soviet troops be reduced to 195,000, officials in Washington said, and he was to announce the plan formally in his State of the Union address before a joint session of Congress Wednesday night. Bush's proposal was described by the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, as a result of the collapse of hard-line communist governments in Eastern Europe. The plan would cover more than 265,000 U.S. troops in Western Europe and 565,000 Soviet forces in Central and Eastern Europe. About 250,000 U.S. servicemen are based in West Germany alone. There was no immediate reaction from West German officials to Bush's plan. Foreign Ministry spokesman Rainer Mueller said in Bonn that details of the Bush proposal were not yet available, and that they would have to be studied by high-level officials before any comment could be made on the plan. Late-night television newscasts reported briefly, without comment, that Bush was expected to call for deeper troop cuts. The Cologne-based German Economics Institute reported in a July study that West Germany earns $5 billion a year from U.S. military expenditures. It warned that a troop pullout would mean ``economic collapse'' for regions that are heavily dependent on the American presence. An extensive analysis of the U.S. bases was undertaken because of the growing public tendency to see American troops as a burden, institute director for economic and scientific affairs Otto Vogel said at the time. There has been increasing support in recent months for troop cuts as a way to reduce tensions in Europe and move the German states closer to reunification now that the Communists in East Germany no longer have a monopoly on power. East Germany is the Kremlin's most critical military ally, and about 400,000 Soviet troops are stationed in the country. The Kremlin does not want to lose its front-line bases in East Germany, but it has indicated it could accept a neutral state. West Germany is under pressure to remain in NATO and keep troops as part of its commitment to the Western defense alliance. The troops, however, are an obstacle to reunification. Last May, Bush proposed a 275,000 ceiling on U.S. and on Soviet forces and said negotiations to reach that goal should be wrapped up within a year. Before now, Bush has said he would not support further cuts until the current talks were wrapped up. But, a senior administration official said, ``Events were running ahead of the negotiations.'' West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said on Wednesday that a reunited Germany could stay loyal to NATO without drawing the territory now comprising a crucial Moscow ally into the Western military alliance. Genscher outlined in a speech to the Evangelical Institute in Tutzing, near Munich, what he sees as a security guarantee for Moscow and a compromise that could also assuage the United States. The foreign minister suggested that the territory now constituting West Germany could remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, while the area east of the Elbe River, East Germany, would not contain military facilities. U.S. and West European allies have indicated they would accept reunification as long as Germany stays within NATO.
Here, at a glance, are the highlights of President Bush's State of the Union address:

EAST-WEST RELATIONS: Bush saluted changes in Eastern Europe as ``the revolution of '89'' and said the crumbling of hardline communist governments should open the way for more U.S. and Soviet troop cuts in the region. He proposed cutting forces in the ``Central Front'' area to 195,000 per side _ down from 265,000 U.S. troops and 565,000 Soviet troops there now.

PANAMA: Some 4,000 remaining additional U.S. troops will be brought home from Panama ``well before the end of February,'' leaving the U.S. presence at the pre-invasion level of about 13,000 troops. At the peak of the U.S. intervention last month, 27,000 U.S. troops were there. The United States has already brought 10,000 home. ``Democracy is restored, Panama is free,'' Bush declared to a standing ovation.

EDUCATION: Goals include an attempt to make U.S. students ``first in the world in math and science'' by the year 2000 and increase the high school graduation rate to ``no less than 90 percent.'' Now only about 70 percent graduate on time.

SOCIAL SECURITY: Bush brushed off a proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan to reduce Social Security taxes, saying ``the last thing we need to do is mess around with Social Security.'' He mentioned in passing his propsal to use surplus Social Security funds to help pay off the national debt _ but only after the budget is balanced, suposedly in 1993.
RACISM: Bush said the nation ``must confront and condemn racisim, anti-semitism, bigotry and hate.'' He said he had been ``appalled at the recent mail bombings across our country.''

UNFINISHED AGENDA: Bush prodded the Democratic-controlled Congress to act on measures he proposed last year that are still languishing, asserting ``it's time to act together.'' He mentioned his battle for a lower capital gains tax rate and child care, anti-crime, housing and environmental proposals.

HEALTH CARE: He said Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan would lead a Cabinet-level review of ``the quality, accessibility and cost of our nation's health cvare system,'' saying he was determined ``to bring the staggering costs of health care under control.''
STATE OF THE UNION: Bush pronounced it ``sound and strong.''

President Bush, trying to forge an election-year agenda for a Democratic-run Congress, presents a State of the Union address tonight offering an upbeat picture of the nation's health while prodding lawmakers to approve legislation they ignored last year. Bush also will issue a challenge to make American students first in the world by the year 2000 in science and math, two areas where they have ranked near the bottom in international testing, officials said Tuesday. Bush will address a joint session of Congress in a nationally broadcast appearance at 9 p.m. EST. It will be his maiden State of the Union address, although he went before Congress with a budget and deficit-reduction package last February. At the top of Bush's wish list for lawmakers are leftover bills dealing with clean air, crime, child care and cuts in capital gains tax rates.

A former governor of Guam facing the start of a four-year prison term shot himself to death today while draped Guam's national flag and chained to a statue in a busy intersection. Ricardo ``Ricky'' Bordallo, 63, shot himself in the head. In addition to being wrapped in the flag, he had set up four placards, one of which said: ``I regret that I only have one life to give to my island,'' according to police and witnesses. Bordallo shot himself with a .38-caliber pistol after chaining himself to a statue of Chief Quipuha, who was the first chief in Guam to adopt Christianity. He died of massive brain damage at 4:28 p.m., said a spokesman at Naval Hospital. Bordallo had been scheduled to fly tonight to Los Angeles, where he was to visit with his daughter. On Friday, he was due at the federal correctional facility in Boron, Calif., to begin a four-year prison term on witness tampering and obstruction charges.

Diary entries by former President Reagan contain ``information of significance'' for John Poindexter's Iran-Contra trial, a federal judge says in ordering the excerpts turned over to the defense. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene on Tuesday ordered the former president to provide diary excerpts from more than 29 different dates by next Monday, but said he will conduct a lengthy review process if Reagan invokes executive privilege. Such a step could delay the scheduled Feb. 20 start of the trial, which already has been moved back a month due partly to Poindexter's efforts to subpoena documents and testimony from Reagan. Reagan, in Las Vegas for a speech Tuesday night, told reporters he would not comment on the judge's order.

The resignation of Peter A. Cohen as head of the nation's second-largest brokerage capped a career that exemplified Wall Street's no-holds-barred expansion in the 1980s as well as its recent decline. Cohen stepped down under fire Tuesday as chairman and chief executive officer of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which had grown under his leadership from a medium-size retail brokerage into one of the nation's most powerful investment houses. The resignation derailed at least temporarily Shearson's plan to raise capital to shore up its balance sheet and preserve its solid credit standing. Cohen's departure also culminated a shakeup of senior management in recent months brought on by the tough times facing the securities industry.

DOC.TEXT: An Episcopal diocesan task force on the relevance and meaning of the Bible in the modern world has completed its work after two years, concluding that the ``Bible is the word of God.'' A 45-page report steers clear of either liberalism or fundamentalism about the Bible. Instead, the commission recommends a ``narrative approach'' which sets aside historical analysis to focus on the meanings inherent in the texts, letting the texts speak for themselves and taking the Bible at face value. Bishop John Shelby Spong has endorsed the work, saying ``this committee once more puts the church's book into the center of our life.''

PROVIDENCE, R.I. (AP) A U.S. district court judge has ruled that invocations and benedictions in which ``a deity is invoked'' are improper at public school graduation ceremonies and have the effect of establishing religion.

When two Roman Catholic priests staged an anti-nuclear protest at the U.S. Stratgegic Air Command headquarters, more than 30 peace advocates offered support. Three hours later that same day when the same priests were arrested outside an abortion clinic, six of the same peace advocates demonstrated against the priests. A Justice and Peace Center spokeswoman said both actions of the priests reflected a ``consistent ethic'' of concern for life.

Guatemala's Roman Catholic archbishop says that because he was unable to find anyone willing to risk staffing a church human rights commission amid his nation's tide of violence, he took the job himself. Archbishop Prospero Penados del Barrio told Catholic News Service that other prospective staffers ``were afraid they'd be killed'' and so bowed out. He said he has received numerous death threats, including a ``Christmas present'' of a blood-stained handkerchief.

The Rev. Frank Heinze, 68, for 22 years news and information officer for the former United Presbyterian Church, U.S.A., died Monday following bypass heart surgery. A much-decorated veteran of World War II, he afterward entered the ministry and was widely known among Presbyterians and religion reporters for his pithy wit about church life. At Presbyterian assemblies, he wrote a daily column called, ``Frankly Speaking.'' He retired in 1983.

A letter from the Latin American Council of Churches released here condemns the U.S. invasion of Panama as a violation of international law and the right of the small countries to ``make their own decisions.'' Meanwhile, the United Methodist Council of Bishops appealed to the U.S. government for immediate and generous financial aid to Panama.

Protestant, Jewish and Roman Catholic leaders at an interreligious convocation urged more joint theological and community efforts to end what they called the ``cold war'' among religions. ``The creation of a world at peace is one of the foundation stones of both Judaism and Christianity,'' but their ``cold war'' undermines credibility of that message, said Rabbi A. James Rudin, interreligious affairs director of the American Jewish Committee. The Rev. John B. Cobb Jr., a United Methodist theologian of Claremont University, said a step toward ending the ``war'' was to bring out ``new overlaps among our faiths'' to inform public life and public schools. He said American society ``has not faced up to the difficulty of transmitting values apart from schools whose ethos is formed by particular religious tradtions. What is needed is open interaction from which would emerge agreements on values that all can support.'' He urged ``rethinking of our theology so that the most wholehearted commitment to Christ will be the strongest reason for the full acceptance of Judaism as a companion in the service of God.''

DOC.HEAD: Interfaith TV Network Doubles Size In First Year
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: American churches, which largely lost their free public-service television outlets on networks when broadcasting was deregulated, now have a fast-growing network of their own. They had been virtually silenced in that powerful medium as national channels began selling time to money-soliciting ``televangelists,'' some of whose lapses tainted religion itself. But the major faith groups, Protestant, Roman Catholic, Eastern Orthodox, Jewish and Mormon, have teamed up in developing a cable network that in its first year has more than doubled its reach. VISN, standing for Vision Interfaith Satellite Network, is now distributed on 38l cable systems across the nation, some serving several communities, and reaching 7 million households, up from 3 million at the outset. It also has more than tripled its programming time on the air from five hours to 18 hours daily. ``One of the things we've had going for us is the terrific cable network interest in the breadth of sponsoring religious groups,'' says Jeff Weber, the network's executive vice president. The main religious denominations had virtually been ``left out in the cold'' by the profusion of contributions-seeking individual preachers buying commercial time, but the new network is counterbalancing that scene. ``Our programs are for faith groups that represent the broad concerns and interests of the American people,'' he added in an interview. ``The way we're geared up gives them an opportunity to use TV in ways not done before.'' A wide variety of values-oriented programs are offered, dramas, magazine-style shows on various issues, problem counseling, select movies with discussion before an after, call-in talk shows, religious news, documentaries and others. Also included are cartoons and other children's programs and even a couple of comedy series about bumbling and silliness within the religious fold. ``The last thing the network wants to be is heavy-handed,'' Weber said. ``There's plenty of room for laughter in heaven.'' The network prohibits proselytizing for particular denominations or soliciting funds. That has been ``abused in the past,'' Weber said. ``We're not in the business of taking money out of the local church.'' The Rev. Wilford V. Bane Jr. of Nashville, Tenn., a United Methodist and the network's general manager and president, said, ``We want to stimulate people to get involved in their own communities.'' However, he said ``we can provide a perhaps larger perspective and put faith in a context beyond local experience. TV can add dimensions that challenge folks.'' He recited a list of renowned religious thinkers who have appeared on shows discussing such questions as ``Who is God? Who is Jesus? What does prayer mean? Why evil?'' and added: ``Persons of that stature talking in one's living room about questions of that depth certainly adds a dimension to people's religious experience.'' The coalition of 22 denominations owning the year-old network includes most major U.S. religious bodies, Episcopal, Lutheran, Jewish, Presbyterian, American Baptist, Methodist, Roman Catholic, Greek Orthodox and Mormon. Smaller groups such as the Mennonites, Moravians, Seventh-day Adventists and Salvation Army also are participants. Weber, 42, a Presbyterian layman who previously worked in commercial television, said, ``We want to reach people who wouldn't watch the typical TV religion fare which offers prepackaged answers. ``We want to help focus on the questions themselves. There are a variety of ways of doing it, dramas, documentaries, call-in shows, profiles of characters, dealing with the kinds of questions that are being asked. ``We want to help people in their own struggle with questions of faith.'' But the fare also entertains, particularly the dramas and music. About half the programs are produced by participating denominations, including some worship services but mostly different kinds of shows, the other half obtained from other producers in this country and abroad. Denominations pay costs of their own productions, supplying them free to the network, which thus is able to operate on a relative small central budget of about $6 million annually, most of it for satellite transmission. About a third of this, a steadily growing proportion, now is covered by fees from cable systems, the rest in subsidized funding from the cable industry guaranteed through the next two years and renewable. By that time, the network expects to be doubled again in size, reaching more than 15 million homes, and self-supporting. It is beginning to sell selective advertising, but that source still ``is minimal,'' Weber said. The network, with a small central staff of 15, operates at studios in Trinity Church in downtown Manhattan. Bane said the varied programming sparks religious concern, sometimes in ``almost invisible ways,'' and should help bring ``a resurgence of Judeo-Christian values back into mainstream thinking.'' Added Weber: ``The timing is right. The decade of the '90's is going to see a turning back to faith in meaningful ways.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeks Social Security `Integrity Fund'
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: President Bush wants to set up a Social Security integrity fund, a budget proposal that sounds a bit like conscience money. It is his alternative to a bill that would cut Social Security taxes, a measure on which the administration still worries about an election-year congressional runaway. The integrity fund idea has the ring of virtue, with a lobbying purpose. It would be phased-in virtue, supposedly taking full effect to make payments against the national debt in 1996. For Bush budget-makers, there's an advantage in delay. For the next two years they can continue counting the booming Social Security reserve fund, growing at about $1 billion a week, against their estimates of the federal budget deficit. That will offset about $60 billion in deficit spending over the next year, even though the money can't be used directly to pay for current budget demands. The government has a way around that. It borrows the Social Security money. Budget Director Richard G. Darman calls the integrity fund plan a responsible way to protect the future benefits of the people who are paying into the Social Security system now. ``But Social Security is a notoriously volatile subject when it enters the political arena, and whether rationality will prevail remains to be determined,'' Darman said in the budget essay he sent Congress. That volatility shows in the sudden rise of Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security taxes, choking off the surpluses that are being borrowed to pay for other government spending. The New York Democrat says that's the only way to end misuse of the trust fund reserves. He said he'd been trying for two years to get the administration to leave the trust fund alone, with no success. Moynihan said the government should be forced to stop using Social Security reserves now, before it becomes totally dependent on them. ``You wait five years ... and they will have a $3 billion-a-week habit,'' Moynihan said. But Darman said the proposal would hurt today's taxpaying workers one way or another. ``It would either force an increase in their non-Social Security taxes ... or it would force a reduction in their future retirement benefits,'' he said. Moynihan said it was his side that sought to protect the integrity of the Social Security fund. ``But our hope has been dashed by the repeated determination of the administration and the Congress to use Social Security contributions as if they were general revenue,'' he said as he introduced the tax cut bill. The administration's countermeasure is to be called the Social Security Integrity and Debt Reduction Fund. It would appear in budgets beginning on Oct. 1, 1992. That proposal starts with the premise that the budget will be balanced in 1993, as required by current law. That is at best a shaky premise, even though the presumably balanced budget would continue to count the Social Security surplus to offset deficit spending. After all, Jimmy Carter and then Ronald Reagan both took office promising to balance the budget within one term. It went up sharply under Carter and multiplied under Reagan. The Bush budget acknowledges that without a change in the bookkeeping system, chances are that future budgets would show surpluses because of Social Security reserves, and that Congress would be likely to spend the money on other programs. That's the Moynihan argument, although he blames it on the administration. His solution is to cut taxes now, put Social Security on a pay-as-you-go basis, and eliminate the temptation to spend the money elsewhere by not collecting it in the first place. The administration proposal would continue counting Social Security and its surplus as part of the budget, and would require that all future budgets be balanced. But the government would set aside appropriations equal to part, and eventually all, of the projected Social Security surpluses. That's the integrity fund. It would be used to make payments against the national debt. For the year beginning Oct. 1, 1992, the appropriation would be 15 percent of the estimated Social Security surplus for the following 12 months. That would go to gradually, to equal the full annual surplus in the 1996 budget. According to the administration, that would protect the trust fund, substantially reduce the national debt, and strip away ``a temptation for additional spending.'' At some point, if all that happened, there would have to be sharp cuts in other federal programs or sharp increases in other taxes, or both. Then again, by 1996, somebody else will be elected president.

DOC.HEAD: David Suchet Moves Up As Hercule Poirot on PBS' `Mystery!'
LaserPhoto LA1 of Jan. 30
DOC.TEXT: David Suchet, the new Hercule Poirot on PBS' ``Mystery!,'' first became acquainted with Agatha Christie's supersleuth four years ago in the movie ``Thirteen At Dinner.'' In that 1985 TV movie, Peter Ustinov starred as Poirot and Suchet was the plodding Inspector Japp, Scotland Yard's man on the scene who's outwitted by Poirot at every turn. ``I was able to observe Peter up close,'' Suchet said. ``I had no idea at the time I was going to play Poirot myself.'' Suchet is the third Poirot in recent years; Albert Finney also played him in the 1974 movie ``Murder on the Orient Express.'' Christie's books describe Poirot as fat, but Suchet had just shed 35 pounds before taking on the role, so he needed padding over most of his body to attain the detective's bulbous shape. ``I wear a lot of padding and a little fake wax moustache,'' he said. Nine episodes of ``Agatha Christie's Poirot'' will be telecast this season on ``Mystery!,'' which is celebrating its 10th year. The ``Poirot'' series began two weeks ago and continues until March 15. The episodes also star Hugh Fraser as Poirot's eager assistant, Capt. Arthur Hastings, Philip Jackson as Inspector Japp, and Pauline Moran as Poirot's secretary, Miss Lemon. The setting is 1935, so the stories reflect the fashions, atmosphere and politics of Britain's upper class in places ranging from England to the Mediterranean. Poirot is, of course, noted for his ``little gray cells'' and his uncanny ability to unmask all the killers, kidnappers, poisoners, plotters, thieves and treacherous lovers who cross his path. He's eccentric, eating a breakfast every day of two boiled eggs that must be exactly the same size and compulsively tidying up any room he walks into. ``He's very smart. He's a brilliant listener,'' said Suchet. ``Agatha Christie was very clever with Arthur Hastings. She didn't make him a dimwit. She gave him a sidekick who can reason with him as a reader would. Hastings goes for the obvious. That allows Poirot to take his ideas off the wall. He doesn't believe what he sees. ``It's a clever device that allows Poirot to do all this thinking and then flash his green light and arrive at the solution.'' The eccentric little detective first appeared in the 1920 book ``The Mysterious Affair at Styles.'' ``Agatha Christie had no idea he would become so popular,'' Suchet said. ``She once said had she known, she would have made him younger. He must have been 180 when he died in the last book, `The Final Curtain.' She wrote something like 40 short stories and 30 books.'' Although he lives just outside of London, Suchet is a frequent visitor to this country. ``I'm one Englishman who loves America,'' he said. ``I did a truck-and-bus Shakespeare tour. I visited nearly every state.'' He played the Soviet contact in ``The Falcon and the Snowman'' and an Israeli spy in ``The Little Drummer Girl'' and also had roles in the movies ``Harry and the Hendersons'' and ``The Last Innocent Man.'' His English home, near Harrow, once was occupied by Horatia Nelson, the daughter of Lord Nelson and Lady Hamilton. ``The roof beams are taken from ships that defeated the Spanish Armada,'' he said. ``It was originally a small house, but it's had some Victorian and Edwardian additions.'' Suchet grew up in London, where his father was a doctor. He studied acting at the London Academy of Music and Arts, where one of his classmates was John Lithgow, who starred in ``Harry and the Hendersons.'' He's a former member of the Royal Shakespeare Co. and has appeared in numerous British television productions. In one recent BBC production, ``Bingo,'' he played William Shakespeare after the bard's retirement to Stratford. ``My career has been very fortunate,'' Suchet said. ``I don't believe actors can plan a career. My measure of success has nothing to do with money or fame. It has to do with being offered enough scripts that you can pick and choose.''

DOC.HEAD: A Bridge Over Troubled Real Estate Waters
DOC.TEXT: You just received that long-awaited job promotion on the West Coast but you cannot move the family into a new home until your condominium in the Northeast is sold. Or you've discovered your dream house could be had for a song, but only if you raise the money from the sale of your present home before another anxious buyer gets there. In both situations the bottlenecked homeowner could use a quick cash fix to bridge the gap between the purchase of the new home and sale of the old. ``Bridge'' or ``swing'' loans offer consumers the short-term financing, usually three to six months, to cover the new down payment and closing costs. These loans have been around a number of years, helping buyers take quick advantage of a home bargain, make a down payment on a house under construction or simply relieve some of the presssure of house-hunting. But experts warn they're not for everyone, particularly those likely to need them most these days _ homesellers living in regions where sales have been especially soft. ``What you have to emphasize is that there's a `Buyer Beware!' warning on this product,'' said Tara Little, a spokeswoman for the American Bankers Association, a Washington-based trade group. ``If things fall through and the borrower can't find a buyer for the first home, he still has to pay off the loan.'' An alternative may be to get a longer-term standard home-equity loan to cover the down payment on a new home and rent the old house until it's sold. The interest on both types of loans is fully deductible up to $100,000. However, one disadvantage to home equity loans is they take much longer to process. Bridge loans, though, aren't easy to obtain. While there are few available statistics, some experts estimate only about a quarter to a third of all banks and thrifts nationwide regularly offer them. Those that do rarely promote them. ``In 14 years of publishing . .. I doubt we've seen more than two bridge loan ads,'' said Robert Heady, who runs the North Palm Beach, Fla., publication Bank Rate Monitor. Further complicating matters is that most lenders negotiate bridge loans on a case-by-case basis, with terms depending largely on an individual's credit history. Lenders say they look for borrowers with steady income, little credit-card debt or major loans besides a mortgage, and with a home in a fairly stable housing market. ``If it's in a good market we'll do it. In a depressed marketplace we'll back away,'' said Michael G. Noah, director of consumer lending for Goldome bank in Buffalo, N.Y. ``The last thing we want to do is get into the real estate market.'' Noah said Goldome's loans are secured by the equity in the property up for sale. To provide a safety cushion most lenders offer bridge loans equal to around 75 percent to 80 percent of the value of the borrower's current home, minus outstanding mortgages, provided the home is under contract to a buyer. Some banks will lend a little less without a contract. Say John and Mary Homeowner need money in a hurry for a downpayment on a $300,000 home. The house they have is valued at $250,000, and they have $90,000 left on their primary mortgage. Based on the 75 percent ``safety cushion,'' they technically could be eligible to borrow up to $97,500, or almost a third of the value of the new house. Many lenders will only make these loans to first mortgage applicants, said Paul Havemann, a vice president at Butler, N.J.-based HSH Associates, which publishes mortgage market information. Some insist on interest payments only on a monthly basis, with the balance to be repaid when the loan is due. Others ask for no payment until the note is due, Havemann said. The interest on bridge loans is linked to the prime rate, plus one or two percentage points. Some lenders charge more, in addition to tacking on hefty loan origination fees. A fortunate few homeowners, however, can get help from their employer. Many of the nation's biggest companies provide relocating workers with interest-free bridge loans, said Charles Martel, director of client relations for PHH Homequity. The Wilton, Conn., company buys the homes of employees on behalf of client companies' employees based on the homes' appraised value, and resells them. Martel said he's seen about a 10 percent jump nationwide in company-sponsored bridge loans over last year. He said he's also seen a rise in the number of employees who opt for PHH Homequity to buy their home rather than sell it themselves _ 55 percent this year vs. around 40 percent a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: In Pursuit Of Zero Inflation
DOC.TEXT: Would you really like to see zero inflation? A lot of people would, including Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and at least one president of a Federal Reserve Bank, W. Lee Hoskins of Cleveland. These are knowledgeable people, with as much power as anyone to see that their views are accomplished. Already, they are in pursuit of those goals. Also of that mind are some academic theoreticians, lots of business people, and some folks in the financial community, where inflation or its threat is considered an enemy to securities. Many ordinary folks might like it too. Retirees enjoy knowing their pension won't be eroded. Savers want assurance that their money won't diminish in buying power. Workers want raises to mean something. Many people would like to see inflation disappear simply because they have come to think of it as evil, sinful, deceitful, destructive _ a killjoy that ruins the party. Repeatedly, it is so described in the media. In all, inflation is about the most popular enemy in economics, with very few people having anything good to say about it. To support it or defend it is likely to ruin anyone's reputation for common sense. Yet, in the past 60 years inflation generally has been accompanied by economic growth, while its absence has almost always been associated with recession or depression. True, some of that growth is an illusion, with rising prices shaving from buying power almost as much or more than is added to paychecks. That's one of the raps against inflation _ it is deceptive. It is also well known and documented that high or rising inflation is often a prelude to recession, even a cause, and most certainly a reflection of unsustainable growth rates. Using as measuring sticks the 1982 dollar and the so-called gross national product deflator, the most broad-based inflation index, only in 1936 did inflation average exactly zero for the year. While that was in the midst of the Great Depression, it was one of the better years within it. GNP grew sharply, only to fall again in 1938. In most years of the Great Depression, however, there was no inflation whatever. In fact, you might say deflation ran wild. The worst of it was in 1932, when ``inflation'' reached minus 11.5 percent, but it was also evident in every year from 1930 through 1934, and again in 1938 and 1939. In 1949, the inflation-deflation rate dipped below zero again, to 0.4 percent, and while the economy didn't shrink it also failed to grow. Since then there has always been at least 1 percent inflation, the least being in 1961. This record, it can be argued, might add up to nothing. Still, it is hard to dispute the empirical evidence that the pursuit of zero inflation may be dangerous. Theory bolsters the contention. For example, proponents and opponents of the zero-inflation goal agree that to bring down any existing level of inflation means slowing economic expansion. Any slowdown, of course, is reflected in and demonstrated by statistical evidence of curtailed production, sales, profits, wages and layoffs, and perhaps in lower corporate stock prices and dividends too. An intentionally induced slowdown, implemented by restraining money supply and keeping interest rates high, is a fragile undertaking. At best, it is probably mere guesswork as to when to apply or relieve pressure. During this time the Fed must rely on statistical measurements, and some of those measurements provide evidence after the fact; when they reveal their news it is already too late. To seek zero, therefore, is to risk recession. There is also error to contend with. Each year, economist Walter J. Williams surveys his colleagues at a meeting of the National Association of Business Economists. Last year he found 72 percent of them were unhappy with the quality of government data. It is worth noting, he said, ``and perhaps a little frightening,'' that the greatest skepticism was directed at numbers generally given the most weight by financial decision-makers. Among them are reports on the gross national product, whose expansion or shrinkage determines whether we are in recession.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration More Open to Religious Leaders
DOC.TEXT: After being mostly snubbed by the White House for the past decade, U.S. religious leaders are finding the present administration is more receptive. Consequently, they're giving it their views _ and anxieties. They've also received some encouragement from it. ``Certainly there has been more openness on the part of the Bush administration,'' said Mary Cooper, acting director of the Washington office of the National Council of Churches. The latest concern stressed by religious officials in a Jan. 19 meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III has been the harassment, arrests and sometimes killing of church workers in El Salvador. According to the delegation, Baker voiced strong support for the work of the churches in El Salvador, saying it needed to go on unhindered, and said the administration firmly rejects claims the churches are fronts for rebels. That charge has been regularly made by the Salvadoran army in forays on religious institutions. The delegation, with whom Baker met at President Bush's request, gave him documents detailing 54 searches by Salvadoran military forces of 40 different church facilities and homes of church workers in a one-month period. Last November, six Roman Catholic priests were killed and scores of church workers arrested, most of them since deported. The country's Lutheran bishop, Medardo Gomez, his life threatened as a ``subversive,'' now is in exile. Baker wrote to Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani on Dec. 11 emphasizing U.S. concern for ``the well-being of the religious community and humanitarian assistance workers.'' The nine-member inferfaith delegation of Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish leaders who met with Baker expressed appreciation for that appeal, but cited incidents of harassment of churches still occurring. Although the general situation has eased, ``there is still a climate of pervasive fear and tension,'' said the Rev. Daniel Weiss, general secretary of American Baptist Churches. Weiss, who has made several trips to El Salvador, said he found the Salvadoran government seemed to consider the churches' work ``to feed the hungry, to help the uprooted, to resettle refugeees'' as political acts. Both the religious leaders and Baker expressed hope for settling the conflict through negotiations, but Baker defended continued U.S. military aid, while the religious leaders opposed it. ``We said we will not back off'' on that matter, said United Methodist Bishop Melvin G. Talbert of San Francisco. ``What we're pushing for is for both sides to come to the table.'' Episcopal Presiding Bishop Edmond L. Browning, who has met several times with Bush, said, ``I think Secretary Baker heard our concerns.'' Religious delegations also had met earlier with administration officials. Three Roman Catholic bishops, including Arcbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, met with Bush aides at the White House on Dec. 22 _ also about El Salvador. Urging negotiations to end the conflict, the bishops called for an ``end to the pattern of harassment, threats and intimidation'' against religious workers. An interfaith delegation met last November with State Department officials on the same issue. Meanwhile, many churches across the country have scheduled prayer vigils, fasting and sermons about El Salvador between now and March 24, which is the 10th anniversary of the assassination of Salvadoran Roman Catholic Archbishop Oscar Romero. Miss Cooper, an Episcopalian, said the government has been much more willing to listen to religious views under Bush's leadership. She said President Reagan ``was just not interested.'' She said church `relations were fine'' with President Carter, a Southern Baptist, and ``we had a good, active relationship'' with President Ford, an Episcopalian. She said contacts were almost nil with Ford's predecessor, Richard Nixon, a Quaker. The Very Rev. Leonid Kishkovsky, president-elect of the National Council of Churches, said that in a meeting with State Department officials plans were laid for regular meetings with religious leaders. The purpose of the discussions will be to ``look at the baseline of factual information we agree on'' and share perspectives, Kishkovsky said, recognizing that churches will have special insights and sometimes criticisms. He said the meetings were expected to be monthly or every other month.
