DOC.TEXT: Protestant, Jewish and Roman Catholic leaders at an interreligious convocation urged more joint theological and community efforts to end what they called the ``cold war'' among religions. ``The creation of a world at peace is one of the foundation stones of both Judaism and Christianity,'' but their ``cold war'' undermines the credibility of that message, said Rabbi A. James Rudin, interreligious affairs director of the American Jewish Committee. The Rev. John B. Cobb Jr., a United Methodist theologian of Claremont University, said a step toward ending the ``war'' was to bring out ``new overlaps among our faiths'' to inform public life and public schools. He said American society ``has not faced up to the difficulty of transmitting values apart from schools whose ethos is formed by particular religious traditions. What is needed is open interaction from which would emerge agreements on values that all can support.'' He urged ``rethinking of our theology so that the most wholehearted commitment to Christ will be the strongest reason for the full acceptance of Judaism as a companion in the service of God.''

A letter from the Latin American Council of Churches condemns the U.S. invasion of Panama as a violation of international law and the right of the small countries to ``make their own decisions.'' Meanwhile, the United Methodist Council of Bishops appealed to the U.S. government for immediate and generous financial aid to Panama.

The Rev. Frank Heinze, 68, for 22 years news and information officer for the former United Presbyterian Church, U.S.A., died Monday following bypass heart surgery. A much-decorated veteran of World War II, he afterward entered the ministry and was widely known among Presbyterians and religion reporters for his pithy wit about church life. At Presbyterian assemblies, he wrote a daily column called ``Frankly Speaking.'' He retired in 1983.

Guatemala's Roman Catholic archbishop says he will staff a church human rights commission himself because he couldn't find anyone willing to risk the job amid his nation's tide of violence. Archbishop Prospero Penados del Barrio told Catholic News Service that other prospective staffers ``were afraid they'd be killed'' and so bowed out. He said he has received numerous death threats, including a ``Christmas present'' of a blood-stained handkerchief.

When two Roman Catholic priests staged an anti-nuclear protest at the Strategic Air Command headquarters, more than 30 peace advocates offered support. Three hours later when the same priests were arrested outside an abortion clinic, six of the same peace advocates demonstrated against the priests. A Justice and Peace Center spokeswoman said both actions of the priests reflected a ``consistent ethic'' of concern for life.
A U.S. district judge has ruled that invocations and benedictions in which ``a deity is invoked'' are improper at public school graduation ceremonies and have the effect of establishing religion.

An Episcopal diocesan task force on the relevance and meaning of the Bible in the modern world has completed its work after two years, concluding that the ``Bible is the word of God.'' A 45-page report steers clear of either liberalism or fundamentalism about the Bible. Instead, the commission recommends a ``narrative approach'' that sets aside historical analysis to focus on the meanings inherent in the texts, letting the texts speak for themselves and taking the Bible at face value. Bishop John Shelby Spong endorsed the work, saying ``this committee once more puts the church's book into the center of our life.''

DOC.HEAD: Andean Musicians Play the `A' Train
DOC.TEXT: It's a long way from the verdant slopes of the Andes to the murky caverns of the New York subway system. But then, the Otavalo Indians of Ecuador pride themselves on adaptability. An innate wanderlust, and their homeland's worst economic recession in 50 years, have propelled ``Imbaya Kuna'' to seek their fortunes in the United States, Germany, France, Spain and points elsewhere. Clad in dark alpaca wool ponchos over their tribe's traditional white duck pants, long braids topped by fedora hats to ward off evil spirits, the six young musicians from the mountain hamlet of Otavalo lend a touch of exotica to the dingy subterranean train stations where they _ and other musicians and entertainers _ play for tips. The scene forms a stark contrast to their natural habitat on the so-called ``roof of the world'' nearly two miles above sea level, with its snow-capped volcanoes and patchwork green peaks, swathed in clouds and stippled with llamas. Oskar Farinango, a 20-year-old who plays the flute, acts as spokesman for the group, which formed in Ecuador in 1984. He is the only one who speaks English. All are friends who grew up together, and some are related. Asked about the significancys his colleagues at a meeting of the National Association of Business Economists. DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Department Budget-Writers Get Creative
DOC.TEXT: In the arcane, drawn-out process of designing a $48.7 billion spending plan for the Agriculture Department, somebody got a little more creative than usual with a couple of programs. In an effort to get Congress to swallow what it refused to in the past, department budget-writers added a few sweeteners. Take the school lunch program, for instance, which serves meals to more than 24 million children each day. If you want to help more poor children, the administration says, let the richer children pay their own way. According to USDA's own analysis of President Bush's budget proposals sent to Congress last week, unless lawmakers buy the 1991 school lunch blueprint, the program will need about $3.4 billion next year, up $200 million from 1990. The money, which includes USDA-donated commodities, is used to subsidize meals served by schools, based on a child's family income. A middle-income student might pay a ``reduced cost'' price for lunch, a truly low-income child can eat free of charge. As it is, all meals are subsidized, regardless of a child's family income. Those from affluent homes pay full price for lunch at school cafeterias, but those meals still carry a federal subsidy. The White House budget proposal, which originated in the Office of Management and Budget, would eliminate federal meal subsidies for children from affluent homes, an idea that goes back many years. Each time Congress has tossed it aside. But the latest OMB plan also seeks legislation to require children with family incomes of more than 350 percent of the federal poverty level, or $42,350 a year for a family of four, to pay more for school meals. At current rates, their share of the subsidy is 28 cents per serving. That would save $235.4 million next year. Department officials estimate more than 4.8 million children from affluent families are eating subsidized school meals each day. About $54.3 million of the savings would then be spent on more than 1.6 million ``middle poor'' kids who qualify for reduced prices in school cafeterias. Their family income would be in the range of 130 percent to 185 percent of the government's poverty level, or $15,730 to $22,385 a year. Those would pay only 20 cents per meal instead of the current 40 cents. Free meals would continue to be available for 10 million children from homes below 130 percent of the poverty standard, or $15,730 a year for a family of four. No change in the subsidy rates would be planned for 8.1 million children from homes in the 185 percent to 350 percent income category, $22,385 to $42,350 a year for a four-member family. The net savings in the school lunch program, according to USDA budget people, would be a tidy $181.1 million, simply by requiring the top-bracket children to pay more for their meals. The Farmers Home Administration plan also has a little sweetener to help the medicine go down. The FmHA would be able to handle less than $3.4 billion in farm loans in 1991 under the Bush plan, down from $4.2 billion estimated this fiscal year, according to the USDA budget analysis. A further emphasis will be put on FmHA guaranteed loans instead of direct loans by the agency itself. This has been a trend for some years, with guarantees exceeding direct loans since 1987. Under the guarantee procedure, banks or other commercial institutions lend money to farmers, and the FmHA provides a guarantee that the debt will be repaid. However, guarantees have not been popular with many hard-pressed farmers because of higher interest rates charged by commercial lenders. ``Wherever possible, new borrowers will be assisted through guaranteed rather than direct loans, and existing borrowers will be graduated to private sector credit using a guarantee where necessary,'' said the USDA analysis. ``This shift will allow FmHA to provide more intense supervision to those borrowers who can only be reached by direct loans.'' Undersecretary Roland R. Vautour, who oversees the USDA's small community and rural development programs, suggested an interest subsidy for farmers taking out FmHA guaranteed loans instead of direct agency financing. The OMB bought the idea and incorporated it into the Bush budget. Analysts estimated the subsidy would average about 3 percentage points, meaning a loan that might cost a borrower 11 percent could be had for 8 percent with the FmHA subsidy. In 1991, the subsidies would be used on $350 million in FmHA farm operating loans and $50 million of farm ownership loans. Meanwhile, the 1991 plan calls for cutting FmHA farm operating direct loans to $500 million from an estimated $932 million this year. Direct farm ownership loans would drop to $38 million from $80 million. Whether these and other USDA budget maneuvers will survive the will of Congress remains to be seen.

DOC.HEAD: Largest Exhibit of Monet Series Paintings Opens in Boston
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Show opens Feb. 7.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: There's a story that Claude Monet began his ``series'' paintings because the light was changing so fast on a grain stack he was painting that he kept asking his stepdaughter to run for more canvases. ``It's a kind of wonderful and amusing but completely fallacious tale,'' said Paul H. Tucker, associate professor of art at the University of Massachusetts at Boston and guest curator of ``Monet in the '90s: The Series Paintings,'' which opens at the Museum of Fine Arts on Wednesday. Monet, the leading French Impressionist, is known to have done 218 ``series'' paintings, all but 12 during the 1890s when he was in his 50s. He chose 16 subjects, some for their historical or cultural significance. Among the works were 30 paintings each of grain stacks and the Rouen Cathedral, 24 paintings of poplars, and 18 of the Japanese bridge over his waterlily garden at Giverny. There are 86 in the exhibition, more than twice the number Monet ever showed at one time. The works have been loaned from all over the world, including Leningrad, Paris, Tokyo and Boston. ``This is the largest of all the series ever assembled,'' said Tucker. Why Monet painted series is not absolutely certain, he said, but the Monet specialist thinks one reason was to show the wide-ranging effects of nature. Another was to answer the challenges posed by younger artists, especially Georges Seurat, whose ``A Sunday on the Island of the Grande Jatte'' in 1886 was an enormous challenge to Impressionism. ``It was an assault,'' Tucker said. Monet responded to the challenges with the revolutionary idea of doing a series of paintings on the same subject. ``He carved out a completely new niche. ... It was very inventive, very daring,'' Tucker said. Monet painted his subjects in different seasons, at different times of day, sometimes from different angles. ``One of the wonders of the show is to be able to compare and contrast,' Tucker said. The style differs for almost every series as well, in terms of color, composition and the way the paint was applied. The series paintings were a way ``for him to assert the continued vitality of Impressionism,'' Tucker said. The repeating images responded to the repetitiousness in Seurat's style of painting with dots, while retaining an individualism Monet believed was lacking in Seurat's work, Tucker said. Though the approach and style were revolutionary, they were not Monet's sole concern. ``He wants us in the end to be more attuned to nature as well,'' Tucker said. Not one of the series is intact in a single collection, although statesman Georges Clemenceau urged the president of France to buy all the Rouen Cathedral paintings for the country. ``The most important thing was to sell,'' said Tucker, and some paintings from a series were sold before the series was exhibited. ``I'm sure (Monet) would have been thrilled if an individual collector bought them all, (but) he wanted to have them sold. He probably had a big mortgage, too.'' Tucker wrote the text _ more a book than a catalog _ that accompanies the exhibit. He began research for a book on Monet's series paintings six years ago while on a sabbatical, and in talking with people at the Museum of Fine Arts, an exhibit of the paintings was suggested. The museum, which has 38 Monet paintings, the largest collection outside Paris, organized the exhibition. ``These are paintings of extraordinary beauty which speak eloquently of the concerns of French culture and civilization,'' Peter Sutton, the museum's curator of European paintings, said of the series paintings. After closing in Boston April 29, the exhibit will be at the Art Institute of Chicago from May 19 through Aug. 12 and at the Royal Academy in London from Sept. 7 through Dec. 9.

DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: He considers himself a loyal member of the Communist Party and remains an admirer of senior Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping. But in the waning days of last spring's pro-democracy demonstrations, Gao Xin and three others staged a hunger strike in Tiananmen Square. For that he spent six months in jail. Here Gao describes how he was treated.

Gao Xin, denounced by Chinese authorities as a counter-revolutionary plotter, walked out of jail after 185 days _ 12 pounds thinner, his job gone and his wedding plans on hold. In releasing him, the authorities didn't say Gao was rehabilitated, forgiven, or even cleared. They had never formally charged him with anything. Gao says the guards told him that the investigation into his activities was completed. The government said recently it has freed 573 people arrested for taking part in the crushed spring democracy movement, out of thousands jailed in Beijing alone. But Gao and others who have been freed have found their troubles are not over. Their lives have been irrevocably changed by what _ for some _ was an impulse of the moment to join in the student-led protests. Gao, perhaps the first of the protesters to speak for the record about their experiences in jail, says he wanted to tell his story out of a sense of responsibility ``to history and to the Chinese nation.'' Gao's crime was to join with three friends, all young intellectuals, in staging a hunger strike in Tiananmen Square in the movement's final days. Gao, 33, was a Communist Party member who until then stayed out of the protests, keeping busy at his job editing Beijing Normal University's official newspaper. But when the government declared martial law on May 20, he _ along with tens of thousands of Beijing residents _ joined the students. ``I did it because I opposed martial law,'' Gao says. ``The army's guns should be pointed outward, not inward at the people.'' But Beijing Mayor Chen Xitong denounced the four hunger strikers as agitators who sought to overthrow the government. Gao says was strolling outside his fiancee's apartment on June 14 when an unmarked car stopped. Four men got out and told him to come along, he recalls. He was taken to a small jail where prisoners were held for short periods before being tried or executed. There, he says, he shared a 90-square-foot cell with at least seven men at a time, most of them accused of crimes such as rape, murder or theft. Only twice in his six-month stay was he let out for exercise, he says. The cell had a small window, but the heat was overwhelming. The light was kept burning at night. No books or newspapers were allowed. Four men could sleep on a wooden platform that filled half the cell. The others slept on bedrolls on the floor. Relatives could not visit. Gao's family was not even told of his arrest. His fiancee, Zhang Xiaomei, went from police station to station seeking news of his whereabouts, but was told each time, ``We aren't clear.'' Only in October was Gao allowed to send her a postcard with a list of clothing and toiletries for her to bring to him. Guards took the package in to Gao. But in other ways, he says, the guards treated him with courtesy not afforded the common criminals in his cell. ``The others got only two steamed rolls at lunch and dinner, but the guards gave me as many as I wanted, because they sympathized with me,'' he says. ``I think they had consciences and a sense of justice.'' The other prisoners were told to sit quietly, but Gao was allowed to pace back and forth, he says. He estimates he walked over 10 miles a day. His cellmates came and went. A 19-year-old accused of robbing and killing two taxi drivers gave Gao his T-shirt before being led away to be executed.

DOC.TEXT: After several months, Gao says, he was made cell monitor and given a makeshift pen _ an ink cartridge wrapped with tape _ so he could fill out a daily form evaluating his cellmates. He used it to write poems on the inside of the T-shirt: ``Words transcribed in prison ``I give to Xiaomei, ``One glance and the one with my heart ``Knows who wrote it ...'' He also scrawled poetry on a roll of toilet paper. Sometimes he recited for the other prisoners. ``They liked it even though I write bad poetry,'' Gao recalls. ``They were bored. Before I came they would tell dirty stories .. . and bully the newcomers. So I gave them lectures about poetry. They called me teacher and they cried when I left.'' Gao was questioned only rarely, and was given no clue about his eventual fate. ``The loneliness of the spirit was terrible,'' he recalls. Gao was released on Dec. 16, but two of his fellow hunger strikers, Zhou Duo and Liu Xiaobo, remain jailed, he says. The fourth man, Taiwanese pop star Hou Dejian, took refuge in the Australian Embassy and left in August with Chinese guarantees he would not be arrested. Gao says the government should thank the four because they led the students in a peaceful retreat from Tiananmen Square when soldiers surrounded it before dawn on June 4. ``Objectively speaking, we helped the government to avoid bloodshed,'' he says. ``The more people who died, the harder it would have been for the government.'' Gao and Hou also have helped authorities by testifying that there was no bloodbath inside the square, despite the deaths of hundreds and possibly thousands in nearby streets. Both insist they made no deal with the government to say so. On Oct. 1, the 40th anniversary of Communist rule in China, the jail turned on loudspeakers and broadcast the festivities taking place in Tiananmen Square. Gao says he listened with a heavy heart. ``I remember the 35th anniversary in 1984,'' he says. ``I was in the square. It seemed the Communist Party was at its highest level of prestige. Every sector of society _ peasants, workers, students _ all had so much hope in the reforms'' that senior leader Deng Xiaoping was enacting to shake up the economy. ``I wish that time could return.'' He still pays his monthly party dues of 24 cents, and still believes Deng is one of the greatest figures in Chinese history, despite his orders to crush the spring movement. ``It was Deng who opened our eyes, who opened China and let foreigners come in and Chinese go out. This cannot be wiped out,'' he says. ``As for whether the party can save China, we will have to see. Right now, there is no organization that can substitute for it. ``I think I am a good party member. The party's guiding principles say the party works for the interests of the vast majority. I think what I did in Tiananmen Square was for the vast majority.'' Ordinary criminals freed from jail often are given their old jobs back to aid their rehabilitation. But Gao says that when he went back to Beijing Normal University, the school refused to let him resume work. It did not formally fire him, either, meaning that in China's controlled job market he is not free to seek new work. So he is taking turns living with friends _ Hou, Zhang and others. ``They told me to wait, so I'm waiting,'' he says. Meanwhile, Gao says he can no longer think of marrying Zhang: ``What can I give her?''

DOC.HEAD: An AP Newsfeatures Extra
With BC-APN--China-Getting Out, b0796-b0797
DOC.TEXT: Little Cao spends his days in his best friend's one-room apartment, watching television and reading. At night, he goes out on free-lance jobs, translating letters and contracts into English to earn a little money. He quit his government job in June when his boss began questioning him about his participation in last spring's pro-democracy marches. But other work units won't hire him because of his suspect political background. By quitting, he lost his office-assigned housing. He worries that authorities will send him back to his family's hometown unless he finds a job in Beijing soon. ``If you know of any foreign companies in Beijing that have openings, please let me know,'' he pleads. Cao is one of the hidden casualties of June's army crackdown on the democracy movement _ people who were not jailed but have been punished in other, subtler ways traditional to China's communist system. Some have been fired, others demoted. Several college seniors had their degrees withheld, while others were denied approval for planned study abroad. China long has used extra-legal punishments for those considered troublemakers. During the 1966-76 far leftist Cultural Revolution, thousands of alleged ``capitalist-roaders'' were sent to rural villages as punishment. Just being related to a political offender could bring trouble. Even now, some relatives of people arrested in June say they have been ostracized. One woman whose husband was jailed said authorities have refused to help her find a job. Most jobs must be officially arranged. Neighbors refuse to talk to her. ``They figure if I'm his wife, I should suffer,'' she says. A college senior who was active in the movement was expelled without his degree, losing his chance for a job assignment. He found part-time work on his own, but still relies on friends' support to get enough to eat. He lives in an empty storage room at his old school, in constant fear he will be kicked out. Another student was allowed to graduate and was assigned a good job at a central government office, but was fired almost immediately. She was told she would have to work for one year in the countryside before being assigned another job. One woman had her private shop shut down because she supported the movement. Several university lecturers who encouraged their students to march were suspended from work. A department head at an official newspaper was demoted to an ordinary reporter for having marched once last spring. A reporter on another newspaper was downgraded to a researcher, with a cut in pay.
