DOC.HEAD: Book and Miniseries Tell Story of Fitzgeralds and Kennedys
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Show to be broadcast Feb. 18-20.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When Doris Kearns Goodwin was writing her history of the Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys, she was often only a few chapters ahead of the screenwriter for the miniseries ``The Kennedys of Massachusetts.'' Goodwin's book, ``The Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys,'' traces the personal and political histories of the two families from their Irish roots to Boston to the election of John F. Kennedy as president. The six-hour miniseries will be broadcast by ABC on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, starring William Peterson as Joe Kennedy; Annette O'Toole as Rose Fitzgerald Kennedy; Pat Hingle as Joe's father, P.J. Kennedy; Charles Durning as Rose's father, John ``Honey Fitz'' Fitzgerald; Steven Weber as John F. Kennedy and Madolyn Smith-Osborne as actress Gloria Swanson, Joe Kennedy's long-time mistress. The author's 13-year-old son, Michael Goodwin, plays Joe Jr. The book was bought as a miniseries in 1982 in the early stages of the manuscript, and screenwriter William Hanley, working chapter by chapter, frequently called Goodwin to see what was coming next. ``Doing the research was the best part,'' said Goodwin, a former Harvard professor who's now working on a book about the American homefront in World War II with Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt as the focus. It also has been sold as a miniseries. ``It was wonderful to find things that give you the feel and texture of the era,'' she said. ``When I learn something, I become very excited to get it out to the reader. `Honey Fitz' spent a year at the Harvard Medical School, and I became so fascinated with medicine of that period that the publisher had to tell me to cut it out.'' The book began as a traditional biography of President Kennedy. Goodwin's husband, Richard Goodwin, had been a speechwriter for Kennedy and she had been a special assistant to President Johnson and wrote ``Lyndon Johnson and the American Dream.'' It took on a new dimension when she began her research. One of the great treasures she found were 150 cartons of papers saved by Joe and Rose Kennedy. They were at the Kennedy Library, but no one had looked at them and they had not yet been deeded to the library. She obtained permission from Sen. Edward M. Kennedy to go through the material. ``That took a year and a half,'' Goodwin said. ``They had saved every letter, every report card, every piece of paper, even Gloria Swanson's income tax statements. Those letters told me the internal dynamics of the family and enabled Hanley to write their dialogue. The papers fell into the boxes as they would fall in life. You could see how each event related to another.'' Asked what set the Fitzgeralds and the Kennedys apart from millions of other Irish Catholics, Goodwin said: ``The Fitzgeralds, and particularly Joe Kennedy, instilled into their kids that above all else they were a family. They presented themselves to the world like a clan. They had traditions and loyalties and rituals. The kids knew they had to be there for dinner every night. They knew they went to Hyannisport on a certain day. ``Second, part of the family ethos was that they lived on the edge. You create your own success, and if the family backs you it doesn't matter what the world thinks.'' Joe Kennedy, despite his failings, gave the family a center, she said. He drove himself and his family relentlessly to succeed, partly because of the exclusion he had felt in Boston as an Irish Catholic. The miniseries, filmed largely in Boston, evokes a strong feeling for the period. It captures, often through banter, the fierce loyalties and competition within the families. The original screenplay began in Ireland and ran for 11 hours, but it was cut to six hours and now begins when ``Honey Fitz'' already is mayor of Boston. Like the book, it ends with Kennedy's election to the presidency. After Goodwin completed the book, she wasn't sure how the Kennedys would feel, since it exposes many family secrets. ``There are many times in the book when you feel anger toward Joe or Rose,'' she said. ``I wasn't trying to judge them. I heard the family was upset at first. ``Normally, the Kennedys don't read books about them. But there was so much history about the Fitzgeralds that no one knew that theybegan to read the book. Then I received 12 copies of the book from Sargent Shriver, Eunice's husband. He wanted them signed for the kids. In general, they seemed to like the book. I think they'll feel the same way about the miniseries.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Weekend Editions, Feb. 16-18

DOC.TEXT: Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said the nation probably will avoid a recession this year but cautioned, ``I wouldn't want to bet the ranch'' on it. At the same time, he told the congressional Joint Economic Committee on Tuesday that the current inflation rate of about 4.5 percent, while stable, is unacceptably high. His comments roiled financial markets, with traders interpreting them as a sign the central bank will not lower interest rates anytime soon.

The resignation of Peter A. Cohen as head of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the nation's second-largest brokerage, capped a career that personified Wall Street's no-holds-barred expansion in the 1980s as well as its recent decline. Cohen, 43, chairman and chief executive officer of Shearson, stepped down Tuesday. A spokesman for the firm said he was to be replaced as CEO by Howard L. Clark Jr., a senior executive at Shearson parent American Express Co. The resignation also derailed at least temporarily Shearson's plan to raise capital to shore up its balance sheet and preserve its solid credit standing.

Representatives of Eastern Airlines' preferred shareholders suggested the liquidation or outright sale of the carrier, saying they had lost faith in management because it was ``cannibalizing'' the airline. ``Plainly stated, EAL's management has lost control of the enterprise,'' the shareholders committee said in papers filed Tuesday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court here. ``They are simply unable to make the airline work, nor are they able to accurately forecast its future _ even for a few weeks at a time.''

The Stride Rite Corp. has rejected a $900 million takeover bid from a group of investors, declaring the company would best be served by pursuing an independent strategy for growth. Stride Rite, the leading children's shoemaker and retailer in the country, announced Tuesday its board rejected the $32-per-share offer from a group led by Walsh, Greenwood & Co., a Greenwich, Conn.-based investment concern.

A federal bankruptcy judge in Delaware gave SCI Television Inc. another day to line up support for a debt restructuring plan or face the prospect of working out its financial problems under court supervision. Judge Helen S. Balick signed an order Tuesday giving SCI until 4:30 p.m. EST Wednesday to certify that it has been tendered at least 87.5 percent of its 16{ percent senior subordinated debentures, which the company says must be surrendered to fulfill the terms of its latest debt restructuring plan. If SCI can't meet the deadline, the judge said the company would be placed under protection of Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy laws while it reorganizes. As of 4 p.m. EST Tuesday, SCI said 74.6 percent of the debentures had been tendered.

Ford Motor Co. disclosed it may take a charge of up to $500 million against 1989 earnings because it sold its Rouge Steel Company for less than book value. In a filing Tuesday with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Ford also said it is projecting North American production for the first quarter of 1990 to be off 25 percent from the same period in 1989, following a 13 percent decline in the quarter just ended.

Marriott Corp. took the first step in retreating from the fast food business by announcing the sale of its Roy Rogers restaurant chain to rival Hardee's for $365 million in cash. The deal disclosed Tuesday represents the third major acquisition for Hardee's Food Systems Inc., and puts the Rocky Mount, N.C., company firmly in third place ahead of Wendy's in terms of the number of restaurants nationally, analysts said. McDonald's and Burger King are first and second.

IBM and Motorola Inc. announced a nationwide radio network that will allow users of hand-held computers to tap into central computers from almost anywhere without telephone lines. The joint venture, called Ardis, was announced Tuesday. Motorola had offered a similar service to clients in New York, Chicago and Los Angeles and had designed a nationwide in-house system for IBM service technicians. The companies decided to leverage their investments by combining the networks.

The chairman of a House panel reviewing the biggest bankruptcy filing in retail history said that Congress may restrict the kind of corporate takeovers that plunge healthy businesses into enormous debt. Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, criticized the ``anything goes regulators of the past decade'' in his opening statement at a hearing by the House Judiciary Committee's economic and commercial law subcommittee. The subcommittee is investigating leveraged buyouts and bankruptcy _ particularly the recent Chapter 11 filing by the Campeau Corp.'s two main U.S. retailing operations, Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp.

The stock market closed broadly lower Tuesday after being jolted by a news report that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev might resign as Soviet Communist party chief. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 10.14 points to 2,543.24 after flip-flopping throughout the day. Prices of U.S. Treasury bonds surged. The dollar jumped in panicky trading. Sugar futures prices fell sharply; grain and soybean futures lost ground; energy futures were mostly lower; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and precious metal futures retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Citing `Cannibalization' of Airline, Committee Withdraws Management Backing
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of Eastern Airlines' preferred shareholders suggested the liquidation or outright sale of the carrier, saying they had lost faith in management because it was ``cannibalizing'' the airline. ``Plainly stated, EAL's management has lost control of the enterprise,'' the shareholders committee said in papers filed Tuesday in U.S. Bankruptcy Court here. ``They are simply unable to make the airline work, nor are they able to accurately forecast its future _ even for a few weeks at a time.'' The committee urged U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland to advance Eastern only enough money to keep it operating. The move by preferred stockholders comes after Eastern last week filed a new reorganization plan with the court in which it proposed to pay preferred holders no more than 10 cents on the dollar in the form of new securities. Previously, Eastern had promised to repay its creditors in full. The shareholders committee said it no longer supported current management and called for ``dramatic steps'' to salvage value for creditors. It said options included sale of the Miami-based airline or liquidation of its assets. Eastern has been using money from the sale of assets to keep the airline operating and to fund its reorganization as a much smaller carrier. Proceeds from the asset sales have been placed in special accounts monitored by the bankruptcy court. The shareholders committee said Eastern requested a total of $250 million from the accounts last July, September and December, and the judge allowed the airline to withdraw $210 million. Eastern filed a fourth withdrawal request Monday seeking an additional $50 million to fund operating losses through February. The preferred shareholders said a $40 million advance would be enough to cover the next month. The committee accused Eastern of ``the cannibalization of the airline in a frenzied attempt to keep it alive.'' ``The airline is literally living off of the proceeds of its asset sales, funding ever-increasing operating losses and putting its preferred stockholders and unsecured creditors further in the whole,'' it said. Eastern, which sought Chapter 11 protection from creditors last March after its Machinists, pilots and flight attendants walked off the job, last week submitted a revised reorganization plan that calls for partial payment to unsecured creditors. Eastern proposed paying preferred stockholders, to whom it owes $1.175 billion, no more than 10 cents on the dollar in new stock. It called for paying unsecured creditors only 10 percent of their debts in cash when the airline emerges from bankruptcy protection, and another 70 percent over the following 10 years, without interest. In return for accepting partial repayment, Eastern's parent, Texas Air Corp., would give the unsecured creditors 40 percent of the airline's equity. Under Eastern's two previous plans, unsecured creditors were to be repaid in full with interest at the completion of Chapter 11. Eastern owes the unsecured creditors, primarily trade suppliers such as aircraft manufacturers, around $1.1 billion. Eastern also said it expects to post a net loss of $280 million for the fourth quarter, bringing losses for all of 1989 to an estimated $850 million. The airline also projected a $125 million net loss for the first quarter of 1990. ``The problem is that, by any objective yardstiock, the airline is failing,'' the preferred shareholders said in the court papers. ``The preferred committee no longer believes that EAL is viable in its current operating mode.''

DOC.HEAD: Campeau Legacy: Congress May Seek to Prevent a Repeat
DOC.TEXT: A House panel looking into the biggest bankruptcy filing in retail history got an earful about the dangers of leveraged buyouts, and the panel's chief said urged new restrictions to prevent potential ``takeover trophies'' from becoming ``bankruptcy debtors.'' Witnesses ranging from the Massachusetts attorney general to the head of the union representing Bloomingdale's workers testified Tuesday about the problems facing Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp. The two retailing giants have filed for bankruptcy reorganization because of their inability to finance debts taken on when Campeau Corp. acquired the companies in the 1980s. ``The groundwork for today's fiasco was laid by the Reagan Administration, which took a hands-off view of antitrust enforcement,'' said Massachusetts Attorney General James M. Shannon. Rep. Jack Brooks, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee's economic and commercial law subcommittee, echoed that complaint, criticizing the ``anything goes regulators of the past decade.'' Brooks, D-Texas, warned that if the White House doesn't act to rein in debt-financed takeovers such as leveraged buyouts, ``then Congress must take the initiative by considering antitrust, bankruptcy and tax legislation to stop the LBO frenzy.'' Brooks said the Chapter 11 filing by the Campeau subsidiaries ``may have signaled that the takeover trophies of the 1980s will soon become the bankruptcy debtors of the 1990s.'' Toronto-based Campeau amassed $7.5 billion in debt acquiring Allied and Federated, largely through loans and junk bonds. Allied and Federated, both headquartered in Cincinnati, Ohio, operate such well known chains as Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh, The Bon Marche and Lazarus. Without the burden of their buyout debt they would be profitable, healthy businesses. The subcommittee's ranking Republican, Rep. Hamilton Fish Jr., of New York, said Congress ``should carefully review any tax advantages or incentives that encourage the use of the LBO mechanism.'' Fish said the Campeau situation pointed out ``an important flaw in the corporate tax code. It is cheaper for a business to borrow money through a leveraged buyout than it is to raise the necessary funds by the more traditional issuance of stock.'' In a leveraged buyout, a company's buyers put up its assets as collateral to secure financing. They hope to finance the debt with the target company's cash flow and by selling off some operations. Interest on that debt in most cases is tax deductible, making such deals attractive to the buyers. ``Since Campeau took over Federated, an estimated 10,000 jobs have been lost; with 400 positions eliminated at Bloomingdale's alone,'' said Lenore Miller, president of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, which represents 4,000 Bloomingdale's employees. Shannon of Massachusetts said Campeau's problems would have been greater if he and other state attorneys general hadn't taken action on Campeau's Federated takeover. He said the two main department stores in his region, Jordan Marsh and Filene's, would have become Campeau properties if the state officials hadn't acted. Campeau already had Jordan Marsh as part of the Allied operation, while Federated owned Filene's. ``By law, the Federal Trade Commission was responsible for reviewing this proposal at the federal level. But despite our urging, the commission allowed the merger to go through without even giving it an extended review,'' said Shannon. He said Campeau agreed to relinquish Filene's after he and attorneys general in Maine, New Hampshire and New York threatened to oppose Campeau's acquisition of Federated. Shannon said the Bush administration ``unlike its predecessor'' has shown signs ``that it intends to be more active in merger enforcement.'' ``We have not seen or heard his testimony and we really can't comment,'' said Susan Ticknor, a spokeswoman with for FTC. But two professors said the anti-trust laws may be ``insufficient to cope with the deal mania sweeping corporate America.'' Walter Adams, past president of Michaigan State University and James W. Brock, professor of economics at Ohio's Miami University suggested requiring those behind large mergers or buyouts _ $1 billion or more _ to file a public impact statement to demonstrate that the deal is in the national interest.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Board To Get Report
DOC.TEXT: The day before Chrysler Corp. shuts down a major assembly plant, the company's directors will hear that more facilities may have to close because of slumping demand, a United Auto Workers union source says. Chrysler's board, which includes UAW President Owen Bieber, will receive a report at a meeting Thursday. The report is expected to show that despite Friday's closing of the Jefferson Avenue assembly plant, the nation's No. 3 automaker still has the capacity to produce more cars than it is able to sell, said the source, who spoke Tuesday on the condition of anonymity. The report could mean more layoffs on top of the more than 10,000 already announced by Chrysler and General Motors Corp. in recent weeks. U.S. automakers are facing pressure from a slump in new car sales and increasing competition from so-called transplants, or cars made by Japanese auto companies at new plants in this country. Shutting down a plant is the most serious measure an automaker can take to cut costs, shrink new-vehicle inventories and bolster profits. Bieber and other UAW leaders failed Tuesday in an attempt to persuade Chrysler to keep the Jefferson Avenue plant open and avoid 1,700 layoffs there. The plant is the only one making Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon subcompacts. Chrysler officials have held out the possibility that it may have to shut other assembly plants this year as the entire industry heads into what some analysts say is a recession. General Motors Corp. and Chrysler already have said they plan to indefinitely lay off about 13,600 workers at 11 assembly plants by the end of March. GM will close its Lakewood plant in Atlanta indefinitely in mid-March. The other layoffs stem from production reductions at other plants. Ford Motor Co. has avoided indefinite layoffs by eliminating overtime and temporarily shutting down a variety of its factories. Closing or cutting production at Big Three assembly plants typically mean layoffs at component and supplier plants operated by the automakers or other companies. It's difficult to estimate how many layoffs may occur because of the assembly plant closings, but automakers have said it could be thousands of jobs. Most speculation about further Chrysler plant closings have centered on its St. Louis No. 1 plant, which makes Chrysler LeBaron coupes and convertibles and Dodge Daytona cars. UAW and company officials said Tuesday they didn't know if the report would make recommendations about further plant closings. Bieber and Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca met for more than two hours Tuesday, company spokesman Lee Sechler said, and discussed a variety of issues, but focused on the Jefferson Avenue plant. The automaker is closing the plant because of slumping sales of the cars. The UAW has contested the move, saying the company didn't market the cars properly, wanting instead to cut its factory capacity. ``They reviewed a number of alternatives to continuing Omni-Horizon production, all of which had been explored and reviewed by the company,'' Sechler said. ``None of the alternatives or plans discussed provided sufficient volume to continue Omni-Horizon production, so the Feb. 2 decision stands.'' Earlier this month, the UAW presented Chrysler with a proposal that the company continue making the two cars and market them only in areas where Omni and Horizon cars have been selling well. Chrysler rejected that plan.

DOC.HEAD: Automakers Watching Wiper Verdict
DOC.TEXT: A jury verdict that Ford Motor Co. violated patent rights on intermittent windshield wipers held by a former university professor has the potential to cost most major automakers millions of dollars. Robert W. Kearns, a former professor at Wayne State University in Detroit, won his patent infringement suit against Ford on Monday in federal court. He has filed similar suits against General Motors Corp., Chrysler Corp., Daimler-Benz, Honda, Toyota, Nissan and 21 other companies. The Ford case was the first to go to trial. Kearns claimed in his 12-year-old lawsuit that his version of intermittent windshield wipers was unique because of a certain combination of parts. Ford denied that. An eight-member jury sided with Kearns on Monday after a week of deliberations. The jury reconvenes Feb. 26 to set damages. Although his suit doesn't specify damages, Kearns has said he is seeking $50 for every Ford car built with intermittent wipers. Ford is believed to have sold at least a million cars a year with the device since 1982. The device also is a common feature on cars made by most of the world's major automakers. U.S. District Judge Avern Cohn ruled earlier that Kearns failed to prove he could have made and marketed the system on his own and thus can claim only a royalty on each wiper, instead of Ford's profit. If the inventor gets everything he wants, the case could cost the automobile industry hundreds of millions of dollars, and possibly more than $1 billion, The New York Times reported in today's editions. Cohn barred Kearns and Ford officials from talking about the case. Other automakers said they were studying the verdict closely, but they declined to comment further. ``Our people need to look at the details of this Ford verdict before we can really comment much further,'' said Honda North America Inc. spokesman Kurt Antonius. ``Our litigation is in the very early stages.'' ``There are some differences in the technical and legal aspects of our case and Ford's,'' said GM spokesman Don Postma. ``Because the subject is in litigation we will refrain from further comment.'' Chrysler spokesman Lee Sechler said the nation's No. 3 automaker would not comment. Kearns claimed in his lawsuit against Ford that he installed a set of his wipers on a 1962 Ford car and took it to the automaker. Kearns ``made numerous disclosures of confidential engineering test designs'' to Ford engineers, the lawsuit claimed. They repeatedly asked him to discuss designs, the lawsuit said, leading Kearns to believe Ford would buy his system. Kearns, a River Rouge, Mich., native and a University of Detroit graduate who now lives in Gaithersburg, Md., filed suit against Ford and other automakers to protect patents he obtained between 1967-74.

DOC.HEAD: Guinness Agrees to Buy All-Brand Importers
DOC.TEXT: Guinness Import Co. is adding Moosehead Premium Canadian Lager and Dos Equis beer to its roster that includes Harp lager and Bass Ale after agreeing to pay $21 million for All Brand Importers Inc. The deal announced Tuesday will make the Stamford, Conn.-based Guinness Import the fourth-largest beer importer in the United States, according to the the trade publication Impact. All Brand, which is based in Hartford, had been owned by the British companies Grand Metropolitan PLC and Whitbread and Co. PLC. ``It's been our aspiration to be the best import company, representing the best brands,'' said Brian Baldock, chairman and managing director of Guinness Brewing Worldwide Ltd., parent of Guinness Import. He said the acquisition of All Brands would add premium imports from Mexico, Canada, Czechoslovakia and West Germany to Guinness' lineup from Ireland and the United Kingdom. The deal should close within four weeks, he said. Shipments of imported beers to retailers fell by about 5 percent in 1989 compared with the previous year, according to Frank Walters, research director for M. Shanken Communications Inc., which publishes Impact. Baldock conceded that 1989 ``was a dull year for the import sector'' but noted that import sales have climbed over the past five to 10 years. ``People are basically drinking better. They are attracted to premium brands. The long-term trend of imports in this market will be positive,'' he said. In addition to Moosehead Premium and Dos Equis, All Brand handles Moosehead Light from Canada, Sol and Superior from Mexico, Pilsner Urquell lager from Czechoslovakia and Clausthaler non-alcoholic malt beverage from West Germany. The deal does not include All Brand's right to distribute Fosters, a beer from Australia. In addition to Harp and Bass Ale, Guinness imports Guinness stout and Kaliber non-alcoholic brew and, in the Northeast, Guinness Gold lager. The proposed acquisition more than doubles the case volume of Guinness Import, the company said, and increases annual retail sales to more than $300 million. Walters estimated the retail value of the U.S. import market at about $2.6 billion, and that the combined Guinness-All Brand would have just under 13 percent of the market. He said the top three beer importers are Van Munching & Co. with its Heineken brand and others at 27 percent; Barton Beers Ltd. with Corona and others brands at 13.6 percent, and Molson Breweries USA with its Martlet and Century importing divisions at just over 13 percent.

DOC.HEAD: $200,000 Reward Announced For S&L Fugitive
DOC.TEXT: Authorities believe fugitive banker Tom Billman, accused of bilking depositors out of $106 million, is hiding out in Europe, but they hope a $200,000 reward will help bring him to justice in the United States. ``We intend to pursue Tom Billman and bring him to justice. Although we have evidence that he intends never to return to the United States, I am confident that some day, somewhere, we will catch up with him,'' U.S. Attorney fo Maryland Breckinridge Willcox said. The reward announced Tuesday is for information leading to the capture and extradition of the former Community Savings & Loan chairman, who has been a fugitive for nearly 1{ years. Willcox said the Maryland Deposit Insurance Fund and the Postal Inspection Service are offering the $200,000 reward, which would be paid when Billman is brought back to Maryland to stand trial. Authorities also unsealed a 20-count racketeering indictment against Billman; two other Community principals, Clayton C. McCuistion and Barbara A. McKinney; and Crysopt Corp., a holding company that owned Community Savings and Equity Programs Investment Corp., a national real estate syndicate that collapsed in 1985. McCuistion and McKinney are living in McLean and Alexandria, Va., respectively. The indictment charges the three defendants used interstate wires and the U.S. mail to divert more than $106 million of Community Savings depositors' funds to EPIC and EPIC-tied companies, to ``personally enrich themselves.'' Billman, 49, has been the subject of a federal arrest warrant since he fled the country to avoid paying a $112 million judgment awarded in October 1988 in Montgomery County Circuit Court. Willcox announced an international warrant against Billman last June in the hope that someone would give the government information that would lead to Billman's arrest and extradition. Prosecutors also said they have obtained a temporary restraining order that blocks McKinney from spending $550,000 she received last year from Billman in wire transfers from overseas. An affidavit filed in U.S. District Court in Baltimore by prosecutor Joyce M. McDonald said federal authorities learned of the international cash transfers through wiretaps on McKinney's phones. McKinney was Community Saving's former legal counsel and vice president of the holding company that owned the S&L and Crysopt Corp. She also was the subject of a $102 million judgment in the Montgomery County case, which currently is on appeal in the Maryland Court of Appeals. McDonald's affidavit said Billman ``surreptitiously'' wired the $550,000 to McKinney in Alexandria from somewhere in Europe early last year. The indictment charged the trio and their company with a conspiracy and pattern of racketeering activities allegedly begun in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Ford Projects Loss on Stock Sale, Declining Production
DOC.TEXT: Ford Motor Co. says it may have to take a charge of up to $500 million against 1989 earnings because it sold its Rouge Steel Company for less than book value. A filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission Tuesday revealed that Ford is projecting North American production for the first quarter of 1990 to be off 25 percent from the same period in 1989, following a 13 percent decline in the quarter just ended. Ford also said it would increase borrowings ``substantially'' this year because of two recent acquisitions. The disclosures came in a filing by a wholly owned Ford subsidiary, Ford Motor Credit Co., seeking SEC permission to offer $2 billion in debt securities from time to time over the next two years. Ford Motor Credit provides wholesale financing and capital loans to franchised Ford dealers and makes loans to vehicle leasing companies. As part of the SEC's required disclosure to potential investors, the registration filing revealed several situations at the parent company: _ Ford's Dec. 15, 1989 sale of all the outstanding stock of Rouge Steel Company to Marico Acquisition Corp. ``was below book value. The amount of the charge to net income has not yet been determined, but could range up to $500 million for the fourth quarter and full year 1989.'' _ Marico was merged into Rouge Steel and Ford acquired 20 percent in the resulting corporation but also is committed to indemnify Rouge Steel for ``environmental matters'' prior to the sale. ``Ford is unable at this time to determine the amount of its potential responsibility for such environmental matters; however, such costs could be substantial.'' _ On Jan. 12 Ford announced plans to sell Ford Aerospace but ``it is uncertain when, or at what price, such sale may occur.'' _ The acquisition of Associates, a major consumer loan concern, and Jaguar PLC, the British luxury carmaker, ``have used and will continue to use substantial amounts of available cash. Consequently, it is anticipated that Ford and its affilates will substantially increase borrowings in 1990.'' _ Ford estimated its North American vehicle production in the fourth quarter 1989 was ``13 percent below the fourth quarter of 1988, and estimated scheduled production for the first quarter of 1990 is estimated at 25 percent below the first quarter of 1989.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Say Bush's Budget May Set Stage for New Taxes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Grab your wallets _ Democrats in Congress think they have received a signal from President Bush on how much he would be willing to accept in tax increases this year. The magic number is $21.7 billion, the total for the hodgepodge of tax increases, user fees and asset sales that Bush included in his 1991 spending plan. Democrats say they believe the $21.7 billion represents the amount in higher revenues the administration would be willing to accept during budget negotiations this year. Both Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., and House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., told reporters they were satisfied with Bush's new revenue total, but they indicated they would radically alter the way the money was raised. ``That revenue figure in total is something that we can accept. Unfortunately, in Bush's budget, it is not legitimately obtained,'' Sasser said. Critics of the budget questioned, for instance, Bush's claim that he would be able to push tax collections up by $2.5 billion in 1991 through ``management reforms'' at the Internal Revenue Service. At the center of the tax debate will be the administration's renewed push to cut the tax on capital gains, which critics charge would benefit the wealthy, and a rival plan by Sen. Daniel Moynihan, D-N.Y., to trim Social Security payroll taxes by $62 billion over the next two years. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady on Tuesday rejected the idea that the administration might be willing to support Moynihan's proposal, or at least a scaled-down version, in exchange for Democrats dropping their opposition to the capital gains reduction. Brady termed Moynihan's proposal ``goofy'' and the ``height of folly'' because it would raise doubts in Americans' minds about the safety of the Social Security trust funds. Sasser said the administration was not being consistent when it attacked Moynihan's proposal as a revenue-loser while pushing ``a capital gains tax cut that benefits the wealthy and loses huge blocks of revenue in the years ahead.'' But for 1991, the administration's budget shows the capital gains tax cut is a revenue-gainer. In fact, it would account for the single biggest jump in tax revenues in the president's budget, an increase of $4.9 billion. The higher figure is based on a belief that investors would rush to sell assets such as stocks or real estate to take advantage of the lower tax rate. But critics charge the lower rate would result in a loss to the Treasury in later years. In all, the Bush budget proposes $15.7 billion in new tax revenues, which would be offset by $1.8 billion in proposed cuts, including an estimated $200 million loss in the first year from implementation of Bush's proposed Family Savings Accounts offering taxpayers to put away up to $5,000 annually in tax-free accounts. In addition, the president proposes raising $5.6 billion in new user fees charged for providing government services, $1.6 billion in the sale of government assets and $600 million in other new receipts, bringing the total to $21.7 billion. Critics charged that Bush recycled a variety of proposals, some dating back to the early Reagan years, that Congress has repeatedly rejected. One retread is a measure to assess federal Social Security taxes on state and local government employees in the handful of states who are not now covered by the levy, a $3.8 billion revenue raiser that Bush unsuccessfully sought last year. Panetta suggested that Congress might consider compromising on the capital gains cut sought by Bush if the president was willing to consider tax increases in other areas, possibly a higher top tax rate for individuals or a boost in energy taxes.

DOC.HEAD: Quaker Oats Funding More Oat Bran Studies
DOC.TEXT: Quaker Oats Co. says it funds oat-bran research to learn more about oats, not to produce studies that will help sell its products. ``I think it's safe to say that if Quaker had not been providing research funding to universities for the past 25 years, the amount of information known about oats in general would be far less than it is,'' said Ron Bottrell, a spokesman for the Chicago-based company. Bottrell's comments Tuesday came after the company disclosed it is funding research aimed at substantiating the health benefits of oat bran. Quaker's research-supported claim that oat-bran can help lower cholesterol was challenged recently by a Harvard medical study of the heavily marketed food product. Bottrell declined to describe two oat-bran studies partially funded by Quaker that he said have been under way for more than a year. But he said Quaker also helped fund a Syracuse University study announced last week that supported findings that a low-fat diet supplemented with oat bran can help lower cholesterol in the bloodstream. Bottrell said he saw no conflict in Quaker, which controls about 70 percent of the oat-bran market, financing research that theoretically could help sales of its products. ``We're not saying the new studies will be a direct refutation of the medical study, but we think it will add to information about the benefits of oats and oat bran,'' Bottrell said. The Harvard study published in the Jan. 19 issue of the New England Journal of Medicine disputed findings that oat bran can help lower cholesterol when eaten daily as part of a low-fat, low-cholesterol diet. The Syracuse study, which will be published in the February issue of the Journal of the American Dietetic Association, agreed with the Harvard finding that people who add oat bran to their diet tend to cut down on other foods, thereby reducing their total fat intake. But the Syracuse researchers did not conclude, as the Harvard study did, that oat bran alone has no special cholesterol-reducing properties. Quaker has responded to the Harvard study with newspaper ads citing 10 other studies conducted over the past 27 years that indicated oat bran has special cholesterol-lowering properties. Bottrell said five of those studies were partially funded by Quaker, with additional funding from health or government agencies. ``We are in the oats business and we consider it our business anything pertaining to oats,'' Bottrell said in a telephone interview. Meanwhile, an informal national survey of about a dozen grocery chains by Grocery Marketing magazine showed no drop in sales of oat-bran cereals since the Harvard study was published, said Ryan Mathews, the Detroit-based editor of the magazine, which is published in Chicago. ``Our feeling is that the oat-bran products most at risk are the peripheral products that have come on the market in the last couple of years,'' Mathews said in a telephone interview. Peripheral products, he said, include oat-bran snack chips, pretzels and beer, which are among the hundreds of oat-bran products introduced in the past two years. Mathews' story on the survey will be published in the February issue of Grocery Marketing.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Gauge Up Robustly in December
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs files
DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge rose a robust 0.8 percent in December, the Commerce Department said today in a report indicating the nation's sluggish economy can skirt a recession in 1990. The jump in the Index of Leading Economic Indicators followed a tiny 0.1 percent gain in November and a 0.3 percent decline in October. It was the largest increase since a similar 0.8 percent advance last April. The index, composed of 11 forward-looking statistics designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months into the future, was the latest indication that the economy, while weak, can avoid an actual decline in growth. The December report showed the index up just 0.4 percent for the year, compared with an increase of 3.9 percent for all of 1988. It suggests that economic activity this year could be more sluggish than in 1989. Six of the statistics contributed to the December gain, led by an increase in the backlog of manufacturers' unfilled orders. Others showing strength were an increase in plant and equipment orders, higher stock prices, a rise in the money supply, an increase in building permits and a gain in an index measuring consumer confidence. The biggest drag on the index last month was a drop in the price of raw materials. While such a decrease is considered good news for inflation prospects, it is counted as a negative in the index because it also can reflect declining demand. Other negatives were an increase in weekly unemployment claims, a decline in orders for consumer goods and a speedup in business delivery times. The average work week was unchanged. The various changes left the index at 145.7 percent of its 1982 base of 100. For the year, the index posted increases in seven months: January, April, July, August, September, November and December. It declined in February, March, May, June and October. In advance of the report, some analysts had suggested that the current sluggishness is akin to flirting with a recession. ``I think that we're very, very close,'' said Lawrence Chimerine, senior economic adviser for the WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``I mean, we're as close to being in a recession without being in one as you can be.'' Nevertheless, Chimerine and other economists found themselves agreeing with Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan, who told Congress on Tuesday that, while he ``wouldn't want to bet the ranch,'' he thinks the economy will avoid a recession. Growth through much of 1989 was restrained by high interest rates resulting from the Fed's efforts to slow inflation by keeping a tight rein on credit. Some government officials and economists have recently urged a looser grip in order to spur growth. The latest Commerce report on the overall 1989 economy, the gross national product, showed growth slowing from 3 percent in the third quarter of 1989 to just 0.5 percent in the October-December period. And many analysts foresee continued sluggish growth in much of 1990, although some see improvements as the year progresses. ``Things may be a little better than is widely perceived,'' suggested economist Michael Niemira of the Mitsubishi Bank in New York. ``I think that things are likely to improve from here on out.'' Greenspan said in his testimony to the Joint Economic Committee: ``The imbalances and dislocations as we see in the economy today probably do not suggest anything more than a temporary hesitation in the continuing expansion of the economy.'' But Chimerine was not quite so sanguine. ``We'll probably see positive growth, but just barely,'' he said. Part of Greenspan's optimism is based on comparing the Commerce Department's current leading indicators with the indicators just before and during previous recessions. ``The resulting measure suggests that the probability of a recession developing in the next six months increased last spring to almost 30 percent, but according to the most recent estimates has declined to about 20 percent,'' he said. Using another index compiled by economists at the National Bureau of Economic Research, which relies less heavily on data from the manufacturing sector and does not include stock prices, Greenspan said there is about a 10 percent chance of a recession. ``Both probabilities are much smaller than those occurring at the beginning of each of the four recessions since the late 1960s,'' he said.``For example, the probability exceeded 50 percent shortly before each of the previous recessions using the NBER index.'' Nevertheless, he continued, ``I wouldn't want to bet the ranch on such statistical measures,'' and said the central bank would continue to watch developments closely.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Saison Group, Sears Set Up Joint Auto Service Company in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Japan's Saison Group announced Wednesday that it has reached agreement with Sears, Roebuck and Co. to establish a joint auto servicing company in Tokyo. Officials at the giant Japanese business group that operates major department stores, hotels, restaurants and supermarkets as well as consumer finance and life insurance companies, among others, said the new company, to be called Tire Plus Co., will open for business in March. Capitalized at 125 million yen, it will be equally owned by Saison and Chicago-based Sears, which have already been running joint life insurance and other companies in Japan. Saison officials said the new joint company will provide auto maintenance services like changing tires, batteries and oil. Initially, they said, it will open three or four stores in central Japan. During the initial years of business, they said, Tire Plus will study market conditions and will create a system for future expansion. Saison officials said their company and Sears have decided on the new joint project in light of apparently strong demand in Japan for auto maintenance services from the ever-growing motoring public.

DOC.HEAD: Campbell Announces Plan to Sell Juice Bowl and Close England Plant
DOC.TEXT: Campbell Soup Co., a continuing subject of takeover speculation, says it will sell its Juice Bowl Products subsidiary and close a foreign plant. David W. Johnson, Campbell's president and chief executive officer, said Tuesday the decision came after a review of the company's assets. The sale was announced amid speculation that Campbell, famous for its canned soups, might be sold in its entirety, partly because its stock price has remained relatively low. Several member's of the company's founding family, which controls a substantial portion of Campbell stock, have said the company should be sold. ``If Campbell is to achieve the level of financial strength that its shareholders have a right to expect, we must be certain that we are structured to obtain maximum returns from all our assets,'' Johnson said in a statement. ``These two actions are very important and positive steps in that direction.'' Campbell acquired Juice Bowl in 1982 to produce the company's tomato-based juices and expand the company's vegetable juice line. The Camden-based company said Juice Bowl, based in Lakeland, Fla., no longer is needed. Johnson said Campbell will close its frozen convenience food plant at Sittingbourne, Kent, England. The plant employs 262 people and produces frozen sausage rolls. Production will be moved to another Campbell plant in Salford, England, Johnson said.

Stock prices rebounded in early trading today, as some analysts said the market was due for a technical rally on the final session of January. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 18.02 points to 2,561.26 at 10 a.m. EST, about a half-hour after the opening bell. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by a margin of about 13 to 5 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 723 issues up, 277 down and 411 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board totaled 27.43 million shares. Analysts said the market is oversold and could stage a technical rally on the last session of the month. The Dow Jones industrial average has dropped 266 points or about 9 percent since Jan. 2 when it stood at 2,810.15. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks was up 0.96 to 179.39. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index had advanced 2.04 to 347.54. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, Bank of New England was up ] to 5, AT&T had gained \ to 38, Amoco had increased { to 53{ and IBM had moved up } to 98. On Tuesday, the Dow Jones industrials closed down 10.14 points at 2,543.24. Big board volume amounted to 186.03 million shares, up from the previous session's 150.77 million. Declining issues outpaced advancers by nearly 3 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,156 issues down, 399 up and 431 unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Avon Calling ... in China
DOC.TEXT: Avon Products Inc. announced Wednesday that its cosmetics soon will be made and sold in China. The beauty products company said it has begun a joint venture with a Chinese partner, Guangzhou Cosmetics Factory, which will provide the production plant. Avon said it is one of the first foreign cosmetics companies authorized to manufacture in China and the first company either domestic or foreign allowed to sell directly to Chinese consumers. James E. Preston, Avon's chairman and chief executive officer, said China has enormous potential as a market for cosmetics. ``There are about 500 million women in China, more than the U.S. and Europe combined,'' he said. Avon, based in New York, already has a major foreign presence. Its Pacific region business has been growing rapidly in recent years and currently accounts for about $450 million of its annual sales of $3 billion. In addition to the new Chinese venture, countries in which Avon has operations in the Pacific include Japan, the Philippines, Taiwan, Thailand, Malaysia, Australia, New Zealand and Indonesia. Avon is making an initial investment of $1 million in the Chinese venture and will own 60 percent of the new company. Avon will furnish some equipment, cosmetics formulas, technical expertise and sales and marketing programs. The venture is expected to be in operation by the middle of this year and to make a profit in its third year. The charter giving Avon the right right to do business in China allows for distribution throughout the country but Avon said at first it will concentrate on South China. More than 60 million people live within a radius of 100 miles of Guangzhou's plant. About 50 makeup and skin care products will be available initially to the Chinese but the line will be expanded over time, Avon said. Avon said it expects to have at least 3,000 sales representatives working in the Guangzhou area by the end of the first year. The company says it now has about 1.5 million independent representatives selling its products door-to-door around the world.

DOC.HEAD: Value of Software Industry Mergers Dropped in 1989, Survey Shows
DOC.TEXT: The value of takeovers involving U.S. companies that make computer software or offer other computer services fell 18 percent in 1989, according to a report Wednesday from an investment bank that tracks the industry. Despite last year's drop to $7.3 billion from 1988's extraordinary $8.9 billion in mergers, last year's figure was 49 percent above the previous record year of 1987. That year, the value of such deals totaled $4.9 billion. The report was compiled by Broadview Associates of Fort Lee, N.J., a leading investment banker in the computer services industry, on behalf of Adapso, the computer services and software industry association based in Arlington, Va. ``This year (1989) we saw a strong shift from deals over $100 million to middle-market transactions in the $20 million to $100 million range,'' said Broadview partner Harvey L. Poppel. ``The surge in middle-market transactions has been fueled by the mounting reluctance of underwriters to take medium-sized firms public,'' he said. ``Since such firms typically need additional resources to achieve critical economies of scale and scope, acquisition has emerged as a preferred route.'' Another reason for the falloff in the value of deals last year is that the recent earnings volatility of many public computer software and hardware companies has scared off buyers from outside the industry, said Charles Federman, another Broadview partner. The report covers companies offering software products, computer systems integration equipment and professional services, processing and network-based data services, training and maintenance.

DOC.HEAD: Amid Turmoil, Chairman Resigns at Nation's No. 2 Brokerage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with new stock plan, other info, no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The resignation of Peter A. Cohen as head of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., the nation's second-largest brokerage, capped a career that personified Wall Street's no-holds-barred expansion in the 1980s as well as its recent decline. Cohen, chairman and chief executive officer of Shearson, quit Tuesday amid turmoil at a firm that grew from a medium-sized retail brokerage into one of the nation's most powerful investment houses under his leadership. Shearson today announced a plan to raise about $250 million by offering stock to existing shareholders. It replaces a public offering scrapped because of the firm's slumping stock price and Cohen's resignation. Under the plan, parent American Express Co. would cut its stake in Shearson to about 45 percent, fulfilling a longtime goal of dropping the brokerage from its balance sheet. After rising 75 cents Tuesday, Shearson stock gained 50 cents to $11.75 this morning in New York Stock Exchange trading. Cohen's departure culminated a shakeup of senior management in recent months brought on by the tough times facing the securities industry. Late last year, then-Shearson president Jeffrey B. Lane left the firm after he was demoted as part of a series of moves instituted by his longtime sidekick, Cohen. ``They put it together basically,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in San Francisco. ``Much of the growth and expansion in the '80s was Peter and Jeff.'' But Shearson, like other major Wall Stree firms, has suffered because of a slowdown in business since the October 1987 market crash. Many analysts believe the firm expanded too far too fast and now is paying the price. Shearson late last year slashed 800 jobs, cut broker commissions, implemented the senior management shakeup and embarked on the recapitalization plan designed to raise about $865 million. Shearson last week reported 1989 profits of $110 million, up from $96 million a year earlier, but a third of the profits came from the sale of a money management unit. Investment banking revenue, which includes merger advising and securities underwriting, was down 27 percent. Cohen, 43, had been under increasing pressure from American Express to improve business. Some analysts speculated Cohen's departure stemmed from American Express Chairman James D. Robinson III's desire to rein in the brokerage. The fall was sudden for a man considered a wonder-boy on Wall Street, a cigar-smoking strategist described in recent books as a tough negotiator driven to transform Shearson into a top-flight firm. Cohen may have foreseen his own demise. Asked bluntly during a presentation to underwriters on the stock offering last week why he still had his job, Cohen reportedly said: ``If Robinson wants to punch my ticket he can.'' In fact, Cohen was replaced as chief executive by Howard L. Clark Jr., an executive vice president and chief financial officer at American Express, which owns 61 percent of Shearson. Clark also was named president. Cohen will be replaced as chairman on March 1 by F. Warren Hellman, general partner of the New York investment banking boutique Hellman & Friedman, which bought a $75 million block of voting preferred stock on Jan. 15. Analysts have blamed Shearson's recent woes on a massive expansion spearheaded by Cohen during the mid-1980s. The firm expanded into dozens of new businesses and its payroll soared to 47,000. Shearson has cut back to about 35,700 employees now, second behind Merrill Lynch & Co. ``They built up too rapidly. They've got a tremendous excess all over the place,'' said Perrin Long, who follows the industry for Lipper Analytical Services. Cohen joined one of the firm's predecessors, CWBL-Hayden Stone Inc., in 1971 and rose through the corporate ranks of the firm that became known as Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. He was named chief executive officer in 1983 and chairman one year later. Cohen led Shearson's expansion into investment banking in 1984 with the acquisition of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. He also was instrumental in the January 1988 acquisition of defunct brokerage E.F. Hutton & Co. for $962 million, giving Shearson a massive nationwide network of brokerage outlets. But along with Shearson's meteoric rise there were several notable embarrassments. Shearson lost the bidding war for RJR Nabisco Inc., which was taken over last year for $25 billion by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co., losing out on $200 million in fees in the process. Also, Shearson's reputation was sullied last year when a subsidiary, Boston Co., overstated its income; when the firm had to write off about $100 million in bad investments in troubled Texas bank MCorp, and when it backed a hostile bid for Pittsburgh-based Koppers Co. American Express acquired Shearson in 1981 for $360 million. Under the new stock offer, Shearson plans to sell 21 million shares of common stock for $12 a share directly to current shareholders. American Express would buy about 69 percent of the new stock and any shares not purchased. American Express would reduce its stake in Shearson by offering Shearson shares as a dividend to American Express stockholders or a dividend in the form of 100 percent of a spin-off corporation formed with the Shearson shares. The old plan envisioned the sale of 20 million shares to the public.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed On Denial Of Gorbachev Quitting
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were narrowly mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade following Mikhail Gorbachev's denial of plans to resign as the Soviet Union's Communist Party chief. A report that Gorbachev might resign that position triggered a sell-off in grain and soybean futures late in yesterday's session on fears that a change in Soviet leadership could result in fewer Soviet purchases of U.S. grain. With those fears fading this morning, traders refocused on other factors, including continued rainy weather in the South American soybean belt and sluggish export demand for wheat and corn. The rain in Argentina has been good for the recently planted soybean crop. The beneficial showers were expected to spread over the next several days into Brazil, the world's second-largest soybean producer after the United States. In early trading, wheat futures prices were { cent lower to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.76 a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $2.37} a bushel; oats were 1\ cents to 2 cents lower with March at $1.36 a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents lower to \ cent higher with March at $5.58} a bushel. Cattle futures were lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork futures were mixed with pork bellies rebounding slightly after three straight days of steep losses. Live cattle futures were .05 cent to .23 cent lower with February at 79.75 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .28 cent lower with March at 83.15 cents a pound; live hogs were .07 cent lower to .15 cent higher with February at 49.57 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .50 cent higher with February at 50.95 cents a pound. Livestock futures settled mixed on Tuesday while pork bellies fell sharply.

DOC.HEAD: New Management Predicts Turnaround in 1991
DOC.TEXT: Saab Automobile AB, a joint venture with General Motors Corp. launched this month, will turn the corner into profitability next year and produce a new upscale passenger car within five years, the company's president predicted Wednesday. Saab, formerly a money-losing division of the aerospace and automotive group Saab-Scania AB, is plagued by a 13 percent absentee rate and a 20 percent turnover of employees, ''which is more than any place I've ever seen,'' said David Herman. ''That's one of our top priorities ... to reduce both those numbers. It costs a lot,'' said Herman, who worked for GM for 17 years. The new company began operations Jan. 1, after GM bought in on a 50-50 basis for $600 million. GM and Saab-Scania each contributed $100 million to an operating fund. Saab reported losing $200 million in the first nine months of last year. ``By the end of 1991 I hope we will turn the corner into the black, but it depends on a lot of things. This is a living business,'' Herman told a news conference. He said the GM guaranteed the independence and profile of Saab will remain intact and it will continue to be marketed separately. Some components will be produced jointly, he said. A new car for the luxury market has gone onto the drawing boards to compete with the popular West German BMW and the Mercedes 300 series, Herman said. Saab sold 110,000 cars last year, 31,000 of them in the United States. Herman said the Swedish-made car is still in its infancy in Europe, which will be a major target for the new company.

DOC.HEAD: Stride Rite Suitor Withdraws Bid
DOC.TEXT: A group of investors withdrew a $900 million bid for Stride Rite Corp. after officials of the shoe company turned down the offer. But a spokesman for the investors refused today to rule out another bid for Stride Rite. The investors, led by Walsh, Greenwood & Co., of Greenwich, Conn., said they were disappointed Stride Rite would not consider the $32-per-share offer. ``We believe that, in today's marketplace, a negotiated transaction would have been the best way to realize the highest value for the company's shareholders,'' Walsh Greenwood said in a letter to Stride Rite. ``Your response leaves us no alternative but to withdraw our $32 per share proposal and consider all available options consistent with our objectives,'' the letter said. Stephen Walsh, a managing partner for the firm, declined to elaborate on the letter, and he refused to say whether his associates might make another proposal. ``We are meeting to discuss all options,'' he said. Stride Rite said its board had rejected the offer. Arnold Hiatt, chairman of the company, said in a statement the directors determined ``a successful, independent Stride Rite is in the best long-term interests of Stride Rite's shareholders, employees, customers and the communities we serve.'' Stride Rite, the leading children's shoemaker and retailer in the country, received the buyout offer in December. The company makes and sells shoe brands such as Keds and Sperry Top-Sider and has more than 180 stores and more than 60 shoe sections in department stores. ``We think within those brands, there is a lot of opportunity for growth,'' said John Phelan, chief financial officer for the company. In particular, Stride Rite noted an increase last year in Keds sales, which were 43 percent higher than they were in 1988. Phelan said the company may have trouble matching that growth in the future, but he said Stride Rite has been able to boost Keds sales by catering more to women, and the company also views the largely untapped men's market as another potential opportunity.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Announces Five-year Improvement Plan
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines said today it will spend $422 million over the next five years to try to bring more flights in on time, improve inflight food and redecorate its 300 planes. Northwest President Fred Malek said Northwest, the country's fourth-largest airline, wants to become the first choice of more travelers by 1995. Malek didn't divulge results of market surveys on how Northwest fares among competitors currently, but said their results were ``not too good.'' Malek held a news conference in Detroit after briefing a gathering of Northwest sales personnel on the customer service improvement plan. The plan includes spending $100 million to serve more meals and add choices to the standard fare. About an equal amount will be spent to step up maintenance capability and increase spare parts inventories, cutting down on delays due to mechanical problems, Malek said. Northwest flew 45.7 million revenue passenger miles in 1989, fourth behind American Airlines, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines. A revenue passenger mile represents one paying passenger flown one mile. Northwest has been privately held and hasn't reported earnings data since Malek, Chairman Alfred Checchi and others acquired it last year for $3.7 billion. For 1988, its last year as a publicly held company, Northwest reported a net profit of $135 million on revenue of $5.6 billion.
