DOC.HEAD: Author of Limits on Trade With Soviets Urges Lifting Them
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Vanik testimony. Picks up 8th graf pvs `The law ...'
DOC.TEXT: The author of the biggest U.S. restrictions to trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe said today that those restrictions should be waived immediately but not repealed. ``The principles of Jackson-Vanik should be solidly retained ... as a back-up insurance that we will not abandon world leadership on the issue of human rights,'' former Rep. Charles A. Vanik, D-Ohio, told the House Ways and Means Committee. Vanik, however, disagreed with the Bush administration's insistence that Moscow make law its recently adopted free emigration policies before the United States lifts the high tariffs imposed on Soviet imports. President Bush promised Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at the Malta summit in December that if the emigration policies are made law, Bush would seek a one-year waiver of the Jackson-Vanik restrictions as part of a new U.S.-Soviet trade agreement the two leaders hope to sign in June. ``I judge the Soviet Union by the deed more than the statute,'' Vanik said of recent Soviet emigration policies. ``The process appears to be a well-established, non-reversible course.'' He said U.S. slowness in normalizing trade relations with Moscow and the newly reincarnated governments of Eastern Europe risks losing those fledgling free markets to other Western powers such as Japan, West Germany and Italy. House Democrats expressed frustration that the administration has not moved faster to lower the barriers to expanded trade with countries behind the crumbling Iron Curtain _ a region one businessman described as the biggest new market since the opening of the Americas in the 18th and 19th centuries. ``We're worried, we don't see any actual planning for this,'' said Rep. Sam Gibbons, D-Fla. ``We don't spot the administration doing a lot.'' Business people have favored outright repeal of Jackson-Vanik, saying they are unwilling to make the type of investments Bush has called for to rebuild the economies of the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe without better assurance that policies will not be changed suddenly. ``If you think we're going to make investments on the basis of an 18-month waiver, we're not,'' said John Murphy, chairman of Dresser Industries in Dallas. Vanik, however, predicted that repeal of the 1974 law that he co-wrote with the late Sen. Henry Jackson, D-Wash., would have ``a tough time in Congress'' because of 45 years of Cold War conditioning to distrust the Soviet Union. ``It's a matter of political reality,'' he said. ``I think the rest of America is not yet prepared to consider anything more for the Soviet Union than a waiver.'' The law was enacted largely to stop the last proposed U.S.-Soviet trade agreement initiated by former President Nixon in 1972 and to pressure Moscow to remove restrictions that prevented Soviet Jews from emigrating to non-communist countries. Basically, it prohibits all export credits or credit guarantees to Soviet bloc countries that restrict emigration. The law also subjects Soviet bloc exports to the United States to stiffer tariffs than those applied to other countries. Soviet emigration has climbed from just under 2,000 in 1986 to approximately 195,000 in 1989. American officials acknowledge the biggest barrier now is limits the United States and other countries are putting on the number of Soviet immigrants they will accept. ``The reasons for Jackson-Vanik no longer exist, but people find a reason to keep it alive,'' said Rep. Thomas J. Downey, D-N.Y. Meanwhile, Senate Democrats on Tuesday proposed a new half-billion dollar aid package _ $200 million more than Bush wants _ to foster emerging democracies in Eastern Europe. The bill, introduced by Sen. Claiborne Pell, R-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, would augment $738 million in aid already approved for Poland and Hungary with $511 million targeted for Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Romania, Bulgaria and Yugoslavia. Pell said he would not be surprised if his proposal is increased during the legislative process ``in view of the profound interest of the United States in supporting positive developments in Eastern Europe.'' Bush, as part of the fiscal 1991 budget he proposed Monday, asked for $300 million as a ``special assistance initiative'' for Soviet bloc nations, including Poland and Hungary.

DOC.HEAD: Philip Morris Reports Quarterly, Annual Income
DOC.TEXT: Philip Morris Companies Inc. said Wednesday its profit for the final quarter of 1989 more than doubled while earnings for the full year rose 26 percent due to strong sales. The company, which makes such widely-known products as Marlboro cigarettes, Miller beer, Oscar Mayer meats and Post cereals, netted $63 million, or 93 cents per share, in the quarter, compared with $342 million, or 37 cents, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue rose 29 percent to $11.14 billion from $8.64 billion. For all of 1989, Philip Morris earned $2.94 billion, or $3.18 a share, compared with $1.39 billion, or $2.51, in 1988. Revenue totaled $44.75 billion, up 41 percent from $31.74 billion. Last year's results included a $179 million pretax charge reflecting the cost of merging the company's General Foods Corp. with Kraft Inc. and a $276 million gain from the sale of its investment in Rothmans International PLC. Philip Morris acquired Kraft on Dec. 7, 1988, and Kraft results are included in the company's consolidated results only since the date of acquisition. Philip Morris reported gains in all its units, particularly in U.S. tobacco and food operations. Helping increase revenue was the introduction and expansion of several new products, such as additional Maxwell House coffee blends, the Jello-O ready-to-eat pudding snacks and Kraft and Miracle Whip cholesterol-free mayonnaise.

DOC.HEAD: Crime at Merc Widespread, FBI Testifies
DOC.TEXT: Illegal trading was widespread on the floor of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange during the more than a year that undercover FBI agents spent posing as commodity traders there, one of the agents testified. Agent Dietrich Volk, testifying Tuesday at a pretrial hearing involving three indicted traders, said illegal trading was ``systemic and pervasive'' at the Merc. Officials at the Merc and the Chicago Board of Trade, the world's two largest futures exchanges, have repeatedly said abuses are not widespread on their trading floors. They have characterized the 48 traders and a clerk indicted since August on charges of defrauding customers as a few bad apples compared with hundreds of honest traders. Volk's testimony in the U.S. District Court hearing marks the first time that any of the FBI agents who posed as traders at the Merc and the Board of Trade has commented publicly about the sting operation. The three-day hearing, which is scheduled to end today, was being held regarding motions filed on behalf of three yen-futures traders at the Merc: Sam Cali, John Baker and Borbert Bailin. The three are seeking to suppress statements they made last January to government agents implicating themselves and others in illegal trading activities. They contend the government illegally coerced the statements from them, in some cases at their homes, before they had a chance to talk with their lawyers.

DOC.HEAD: SCI Gets Last Chance to Line Up Debt Restructuring Support
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, As of ... to update with latest amount of bonds tendered and extension of offer until 4:30 p.m. EST. Picks up 5th graf, If SCI ...
DOC.TEXT: SCI Television Inc. must certify to a federal bankruptcy judge today that it has lined up the required support for a debt restructuring plan or face reorganization under court supervision. Judge Helen S. Balick signed an order Tuesday giving SCI until 4:30 p.m. EST today to certify that it has been tendered at least 87.5 percent of its 16{ percent senior subordinated debentures under an exchange offer. As part of its latest plan to restructure its $1.3 billion debt, the company said a minimum of 87.5 percent of that $100 million bond issue must be tendered. As of 11:30 a.m. EST today, SCI said 77.8 percent of the debentures had been tendered. It extended the exchange offer until 4:30 p.m. EST. If SCI can't meet Wednesday's certification deadline, the judge said the company would be placed under protection of Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws while it reorganizes. The judge's ruling appeared to have the support of the company, representatives of a majority of its bondholders and attorneys for three bondholders who had filed a petition in November to force SCI into Chapter 7 bankruptcy proceedings, which may have resulted in liquidation of the company. ``I don't know of any holder who favors Chapter 11 rather than the deal,'' said Wilbur Ross of Rothschild Inc., which is a financial adviser to a bondholders group. He said he was on the phone to as many bondholders as he could reach on Tuesday, encouraging them to tender their bonds and advising them that there is no reason to expect any last-minute changes to sweeten the offer. ``My concern is that there may be people out there who have the incorrect impression that something wonderful is still capable of happening,'' Ross said. SCI has had trouble generating enough cash to pay the interest on its debt to bondholders and bank lenders following two debt-financed transactions in the past five years. It owns six television stations that were once part of Storer Communications, acquired by the buyout specialists Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. in a leveraged buyout in 1985. SCI Television was created in 1987 when the Storer television stations were sold for $1.3 billion to a company in which Nashville entrepreneur George Gillett owns 55 percent and Kohlberg Kravis owns 45 percent. The company has been negotiating a debt restructuring with its bondholders and bank lenders since last fall. It recently won agreement from representatives of a majority of bondholders for a plan that would give the bondholders a 39 percent equity interest in SCI and new debt securities. Under the plan, bank lenders would get a 5 percent equity stake while Gillett's stake would fall to 41 percent and Kohlberg's stake to 15 percent. Under the plan, a certain minimum percentage of each of SCI's three issues of publicly-held bonds have to be tendered. SCI has met the required minimum on two issues but is still short on the 16{ percent issue. ``It has become a huge game of chicken,'' said one person familiar with the efforts to get bondholders to tender their bonds, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Bondholders are jockeying for position so that only the bare minimum of 16{ percent bonds are tendered, leaving holders of the remaining 12.5 percent of the issue eligible for cash interest payments. But the risk under bankruptcy protection, he said, is that holders of all of the 16{ percent bonds would be given stock and additional securities in lieu of cash interest payments.

DOC.NOTE: $adv04
For release Sunday Feb. 4
DOC.HEAD: Parent of American Airlines Also a Big Telephone Marketer
DOC.TEXT: Travelers know American Airlines as one of the nation's most familiar carriers. Few know its parent company also is engrossed in a telephone marketing operation that does everything from taking hotel reservations to answering questions about foreclosed S&L property for sale. AMR Information Services Inc., formed four years ago by AMR Corp., is seen by the parent company as a way to tap the experience, investment and success of its computer reservations system, SABRE, the largest in the airline industry. The subsidiary's president, Russell J. Harrison, also said it's aimed partly at cushioning the ups, downs and uncertainties of running an airline. ``An awful lot of what affects the airline industry is out of control of the airline business,'' Harrison said. For example, he said, the sharp rise in fuel costs this winter turned a record year for AMR into disappointment. ``With their powerful computer and telecommunications and reservations resources, it's a natural opportunity or extension to do some incremental business,'' said Mark Daugherty, who follows AMR for the Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. investment firm. The subsidiary does not yet provide much of a cushion, although Harrison said it has been profitable since 1987 and has grown about 50 percent a year. The idea for it was spawned from an effort to make use of the time when reservations agents weren't selling airplane tickets. What started as a time-filler now has its own computer system, separate from SABRE, and last year brought in $100 million in revenues. It is projected to reach $130 million this year. AMR, by comparison, had overall operating revenues last year of $10.48 billion. Harrison said he wanted to recreate the same type of freewheeling business that helped enrich one of his former employers, Electronic Data Systems Inc. billionaire H. Ross Perot. ``It's OK to have fun,'' Harrison said. ``It's OK to laugh and celebrate.'' Harrison said employees are encouraged to ask, ``What do you think we could do if we didn't know we couldn't?'' The subsidiary's only corporate directive comes from AMR Chairman Robert L. Crandall, who ``has said `go build me a business,' '' Harrison said. ``I'm just kind of manufacturing businesses.'' It is comprised of eight divisions and accounts for about 4,000 of AMR's 77,000 employees. While some of the businesses are tied to the airline industry _ such as meeting planning and travel agent training _ others are not. ``The linkage between all these businesses is that they tend to be transactions over long distances,'' Harrison said during an interview at his office near the parent's Fort Worth headquarters. The largest division is American Airlines Direct Marketing Corp., which answers the telephone and makes sales calls for a range of customers. Most of those customers are confidential, Harrison said, because ``they want you to think you're talking to one of their employees,'' when you call for hotel reservations and such. In reality, the phones are answered by 880 people in a building at AMR's Centreport office complex south of Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. However, the division recently landed a high-profile contract: taking calls for the Resolution Trust Corp., the federal agency created to bail out the thrift industry. People who called a toll-free number to order the list of foreclosed properties offered for sale got an AMR telemarketing agent. The subsidiary isn't shy about saying what kind of calls it doesn't take _ those generated by television ads. ``We do not sell Ginzu knives or Zamfir records,'' Harrison said. Another significant component of the subsidiary is Caribbean Data Services, located in Barbados and Santo Domingo, where employees turn written information into computer data. About half the work involves culling information from American Airlines' tickets; the rest is from other companies such as insurance concern Equicorp, which uses the company to type in health claims information. The paperwork is flown to the Caribbean on American Airlines jets, the information typed in, and then either fed directly to a computer or put on computer disks and sent back to the customer. Other divisions sell SABRE to other airlines, provide automated freight tracking systems, operate a hotel reservations system similar to SABRE or provide computer services for other airlines. Another division _ what Harrison calls his ``R&D shop'' _ provides non-airline computer services and information management. Harrison realizes his subsidiary would be a likely candidate for the auction block should AMR be acquired. The parent company was a target last year of billionaire developer Donald Trump, whose $7.5 billion proposal collapsed in the aftermath of a stock market plunge in October. ``I love being a part of AMR,'' Harrison said, ``but I could run the company outside.'' ``We have built the platform for our business on firm, solid ground and if we are cut lose, we can continue to grow.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday Feb. 4

DOC.HEAD: Darman Says White House Ready to Deal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs files
DOC.TEXT: White House budget director Richard G. Darman said today the Bush administration is ready to begin serious negotiations with Congress on developing a bipartisan plan for reducing the deficit. ``We'd be pleased to start at 10 o'clock tonight, after the president's speech,'' Darman told the Senate Budget Committee, referring to the State of the Union address. Sen. Bennett Johnston, D-La., reminded Darman that at this time a year ago, the administration was encouraging such negotiations _ not just expressing a willingness to participate. If there has been a change of heart, Darman replied, it is because ``a couple of very important people have said they don't want to negotiate.'' He did not identify them but apparently was referring to some congressional leaders. Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, expressed frustration that after many hours of criticism from opponents of the administration's budget policies, ``I have yet to see ... a detailed plan'' from those critics. For the second straight day, the administration's 1991 budget was hammered by Democratic lawmakers as unrealistic, too heavy on military spending and dependent on overly optimistic economic projections. Darman defended the budget and projections, as did several Republican members of the Senate Budget Committee. ``This is the most realistic budget that has been submitted by a president in five years,'' said Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas. ``You are not dealing with people who are totally out of bounds'' in trying to forecast how the economy will behave in the coming months, Darman said Tuesday. Testifying before the House Budget Committee, Darman rejected criticism from Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., chairman of the panel, that the new budget relies on rosy assumptions about unemployment, inflation and economic growth. Darman said the administration compiled ``an amazingly accurate record'' in making its forecasts last July. ``This represents not just wisdom but some luck,'' he added. Darman noted, for example, the July forecast for growth in the gross national product last year was 2.9 percent _ exactly what occurred. OMB economists also were right on the mark on unemployment (5.2 percent) and interest rates on short-term Treasury notes (8.5 percent) and came close in predicting inflation would average 5 percent. The actual figure was 4.8 percent. Economic forecasts are a major factor in preparation of a federal budget. For example, if the inflation rate is higher than forecast, the deficit could be worsened considerably because many federal programs, including Social Security, are increased automatically with the inflation rate. The 1991 budget of $1.23 trillion is based on an OMB forecast that the economy will grow by 3.2 percent during the year, although the consensus of several private economists is 2.2 percent. Similarly, the administration projects interest rates on three-month Treasury bills at 5.4 percent in 1991, compared with a 7.2 percent private forecast. Darman spent a considerable part of his time before the House panel defending the administration's decision not to support a reduction in Social Security taxes. The hottest topic among members of Congress is a bill by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., that would cut those taxes as a way to keep the government from using surplus Social Security tax collections to pay for other federal programs. ``It is my personal opinion that he never intended the plan to be taken as seriously as the press has taken it,'' Darman said. Panetta interjected: ``I get the impression that he is quite serious about the proposal.'' Bush's budget proposes that once the federal deficit is eliminated _ and predicts that will be in 1993 _ Social Security taxes that are not needed to pay benefits immediately should be used only to retire government debt. Darman bristled when Rep. James Slattery, D-Kan., said, ``Social Security is the biggest lie we have told the American people in maybe this generation.'' Slattery described Bush's proposed remedy as ``another scam, another scam.'' ``You're saying ... that (federal) debt is no good, that we are bankrupt ... The day that ... U.S. treasuries (securities) are no good is a day I think none of us will ever see,'' Darman said. ``Our proposal is not smoke and mirrors,'' he added. ``It will really get the debt down ... There isn't a trace of dishonesty in this presentation.'' Several Democrats on the House committee criticized the administration's call for $292 billion for the military at a time of declining East-West tensions. Others lamented proposed cuts in various social programs. The budget, said Rep. James Oberstar, D-Minn., reflects ``a view of America that is not shared by a lot of people in my district.'' The new budget anticipates a $63.1 billion deficit in the 12 months that begin Oct. 1, although congressional economists say the figure is likely to approach $100 billion. The budget would rely on spending reductions, user fees and selected tax increases _ but no general boost in income taxes _ to cut the deficit from the 1990 level of about $124 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower
Repeating for all needing.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was little changed against other major foreign currencies today in nervous European trading, dealers said. Gold prices were slightly lower. A rumor that Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev was resigning as Communist Party chief sent the dollar soaring Tuesday in New York and in Japanese overnight trading. Gorbachev denied the rumor this morning, which stemmed the dollar's rise. Traders said the belief that many dealers had overreacted to the rumors and comments by U.S. Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan that inflation is still a concern in the U.S. would force the dollar lower. ``Even though most people would probably agree the dollar is currently undervalued, the dominant impression is that the dollar is on its way down,'' a Milan analyst said. ``Every time it perks up, people take profits and bring it back down.'' In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 1.15 yen to a closing 144.40 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 144.25 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.6804 West German marks, down from 1.6805; 1.4890 Swiss francs, unchanged; 5.7080 French francs, up from 5.7040; 1.9018 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8880; 1,249.50 Italian lire, unchanged; and 1.1885 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1902. In London, the dollar fell against the British pound. It cost $1.6832 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6830 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $417.10 a troy ounce, down from $418.50 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $417.55. In Zurich, the bid price was $417.75, down from $419 bid late Tuesday. Gold in Hong Kong fell 32 cents to close at a bid $416.03. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.21 a troy ounce, down from Tuesday's $5.22.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Finish Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with close
DOC.TEXT: Prices advanced on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday after cautious interest from institutional investors boosted certain stocks. Although Wall Street began on an even keel and surged over 34 points higher by the close of the European day, dealers said there appeared to be a universal reluctance to set foot in the equity market. ``It's a broad-based lack of involvement,'' said one market maker. ``People just don't trust the rise in New York.'' With confidence still somewhat shaky, institutional buyers were selecting stocks with some overseas exposure instead of those with domestic earnings, dealers said. Market watchers said the bulk of the day's trading was done during the morning session, when a fairly sizeable program trade was conducted with an evenly balanced amount of buy and sell orders. At the close, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 15.3 points, or 0.7 percent, at 2,337.3. Volume came to 571.9 million shares, compared with 493.7 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Midway Airlines Rejects Suitor's Bid for Board Seat
DOC.TEXT: Midway Airlines Inc. has rejected a request by Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp. for a seat on the Chicago-based airline's board of directors, documents disclosed today. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Ampco-Pittsburgh also disclosed it is seeking federal approval to increase its holdings of Midway's common stock to more than $15 million. Last September, Ampco, a Pittsburgh, Pa.-based, heavy manufacturing concern, disclosed it had acquired a 9.6 percent stake in Midway. On Nov. 13, Ampco made an informal request for representation on Midway's board. Ampco renewed that request Jan. 2 after a board member, Jeffrey H. Erickson, resigned. But Tuesday, according to the SEC filing, Midway told Ampco that its request for board representation had been rejected. Late last week, Midway elected Frank Reed, president and chief executive officer of Philadelphia's First Pennsylvania Bank Corp., to fill the vacancy. Ampco said it is considering what action, if any, it might take in response to the rejection. Ampco also revealed it is seeking antitrust clearnace from the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission to acquire additional Midway stock which would result in Ampco's holding more than $15 million in common stock but less than 15 percent of the outstanding voting securities of Midway.

DOC.HEAD: Withdraw Offer for Stride Rite
DOC.TEXT: A group of investors said Wednesday it has scrapped a $900 million takeover bid for The Stride Rite Corp., but refused to rule out another offer for the leading shoe company. ``We are meeting to discuss all options,'' said Stephen Walsh, managing partner of Walsh, Greenwood & Co., the Greenwich, Conn., investment concern that led the takeover effort. Stride Rite, based in Cambridge, announced Wednesday it had turned down the $32-per-share offer. The company said its long-term interests would be best served by remaining independent. The investors sent a letter to Stride Rite, saying they were disappointed the company would not consider the offer. ``We believe that, in today's marketplace, a negotiated transaction would have been the best way to realize the highest value for the company's shareholders,'' the letter said. ``Your response leaves us no alternative but to withdraw our $32 per share proposal and consider all available options consistent with our objectives,'' it said. Walsh declined to elaborate on the letter, and he refused to say whether his associates might make another proposal.

DOC.HEAD: Government To Revise Securities Transaction Law
DOC.TEXT: Changes in securities laws are being considered that would protect Japanese companies from sneak attacks from corporate raiders but at the same time relax some restrictions on foreign investment, Finance Ministry officials said Wednesday. The proposed legislation, to be submitted to Parliament when it reconvenes in March, would go into effect by the year's end, they said. A new ``5 percent rule'' would require anyone whose holdings exceed 5 percent of a company's shares to report to the Finance Ministry, stock exchanges and the company, the officials said. The new rule would make stock transactions more visible and prevent hostile raiders from collecting shares secretly, said ministry spokesman Tetsuo Kabe. Last year, American investor T. Boone Pickens became the largest single shareholder in Koito Manufacturing Co., an auto parts maker, when he obtained more than 20 percent of its shares, mostly from a Japanese stock speculator. Pickens has been trying unsuccessfully to gain representation on Koito's board of directors. Experts said that the new legislation would make it more difficult for speculators to amass big holdings from a third party. But the legislation also would ease restrictions on the tender offer bid _ a public announcement of intent to acquire, at a fixed price, any or all of a company's securities. Foreign investors have said the current rules are too strict and curb their investment in Japan. The ministry says there have been only three such bids in 19 years. Such bids no longer would require 10 days advance notice to the ministry, and investors would be allowed 60 days for bidding, instead of the current 30, officials said. Japanese law now requires non-residents to have agents in Japan for such bids. The new legislation would allow lawyers, accountants and others, in addition to banks and securities firms, to represent non-resident investors. ``We realized we have to eliminate restrictions such as advance notice because, among the Western countries, only Japan is imposing such requirements,'' said another ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We expect the revised law will encourage foreign investment in Japan.'' Kabe said the 5 percent rule's main purpose ``is to prevent wild fluctuations in share prices.'' When an investor buys a large number of one company's shares, it often causes wild price moves. Those who fail to report under the new legislation would be punished with fines or prison terms, although details remain to be worked out, Kabe added. At present, the only reporting requirement is that companies issuing shares must notify the ministry of major changes in shareholders holding more than 10 percent of their shares, he said. Critics said the revised law may not have much impact on the market because most stocks are permanently held by business partners and financial institutions, including major securities and life insurance companies and banks. Financial institutions would be exempted from having to immediately notify the ministry as long as they did not intend to gain management rights by increasing their holdings to more than 5 percent of a company's shares, the ministry said.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Group Seeks Controlling Interest in Times
DOC.TEXT: A minority shareholder group that includes Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass has offered to buy controlling interest in the St. Petersburg Times, the newspaper reported Wednesday. David Bonderman of Poynter-Jamison Ventures Limited Partnership offered $270-million for the outstanding shares in the Times Holding Co. in a letter Tuesday to Andrew Barnes, editor, chairman and chief executive officer of the Times. The Holding Co. owns controlling stock in the Times Publishing Co., which owns the Times and its affiliates. The publishing company publishes the St. Petersburg Times, business magazines Florida Trend and Georgia Trend, and Congressional Quarterly and Governing, Washington-based publications. Barnes said the companies' boards of directors are scheduled to meet next week and a formal response would be issued after deliberations. However, Barnes gave his views in a notice to staff at the paper, which was founded in 1884. ``I see no reason to dismantle Nelson Poynter's legacy, which serves Times readers, this community and journalism across America and around the world, merely to enrich private investor interests,'' he said. The Times Holding Co. stock is owned by the Poynter Institute for Media Studies, a local non-profit journalism education facility, and by Marion K. Poynter, widow of Nelson Poynter, former owner of the Times. The institute owns 2,600 shares; Mrs. Poynter owns 400 shares. The Holding Co. controls 3,000 of the outstanding 3,500 shares of stock in the Times Publishing Co.. The other shares are owned by the Poynter Institute, 300 shares; and the Poynter-Jamison Partnership, 200 shares. Five hundred of the shares are voting shares. Nelson Poynter, the newspaper's last individual owner, set up the institute and left it in control of 300 shares of voting stock. He then arranged for the company's chief executive officer to vote the shares, in effect giving the institute control of the Times, the newspaper said. In August 1988, a partnership that includes Bass, Bonderman and other Bass associates bought the other 200 shares of voting stock for an undisclosed price from Poynter's nieces, Anne Poynter Jamison Parker and Mary Alice Jamison Griffin. The nieces are members of the partnership. Dividend income from the institute's stock is used to help support its educational programs.

DOC.HEAD: Sources Say Shearson Cutting Investment Bankers
With AM-Shearson, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In another sign of hard times on Wall Street, already troubled Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is extending staff cuts into the ranks of highly paid investment bankers, sources said. Unlike recent layoffs at Merrill Lynch & Co., the job reductions at the nation's No. 2 brokerage are being done gradually. They were planned and some executed before the resignation Tuesday of Peter A. Cohen as chairman and chief executive. One Shearson investment banker who asked not to be named said 50 to 100 professionals, or 10 percent to 20 percent of the force, could be gone by May. A Shearson official who requested anonymity called the figure ``way out of line'' but said some reductions had occurred as part of ongoing business. Wall Street analysts said layoffs at Shearson are not surprising given the firm's ongoing problems and a general slump in mergers and acquisitions and securities underwriting on Wall Street. ``To cut 10 to 20 percent would be consistent with what other firms have done, so that would not surprise me,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, a securities industry analyst with Prudential Bache Securities Inc. in San Francisco. ``There's not enough banking business.'' Investment bankers generally are regarded as a cut above stockbrokers and other lower-echelon Wall Street employees. Bankers are among the most highly paid professionals in the industry with six- and seven-figure salaries and bonuses. According to Securities Data Co., the dollar volume of mergers and acquitisions completed in the fourth quarter of 1989 declined 36.6 percent from the same 1988 period. Much of the decline is attributed to the collapse of the market for junk bonds, often used to finance such deals. New issues of corporate equity were down 9.9 percent for the full year and more than 28 percent since its peak in 1986, Securities Data said. Debt issues also have slumped. Merrill Lynch earlier this month let go about 140 people in its investment banking division, or about 10 percent, including 70 professionals, spokesman Fred Yager said. Most of the layoffs were effective immediately. Merrill, the nation's largest brokerage, plans about 3,000 total layoffs this year, including 2,000 by the end of March. In recent months, other firms also have scaled back investment banking as part of an overhaul dating to the 1987 stock market crash that has reduced securities industry employment by about 35,000 jobs. Salomon Brothers Inc. recently announced 100 across-the-board cuts, with about 20 in investment banking; Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. slashed 300 employees, including 15 bankers; and Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. cut about 20 investment bankers. Shearson last week reported that its investment banking revenue for 1989 sank 27 percent to $963 million and blamed a slowdown in dealmaking and securities underwriting. ``A lot of firms basically bloated these departments in the expectation that volume was going to increase,'' Eckenfelder said. ``It's a situation where you may have to cut more people percentage-wise than your business is dropping.'' At Shearson, investment bankers are being given time to find other jobs and allowed to remain in their offices as they are dropped from the payroll, one source said. ``There hasn't been the kind of cutting into core that Merrill had,'' the Shearson banker said Tuesday before Cohen's resignation. ``We're talking about tree-trimming that probably should have been done anyway.'' Shearson entered the investment banking field in 1984 with the acquisition of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb, part of an expansion plan spearheaded by the departing Cohen. It is unclear how the changing of the guard at Shearson will affect the investment banking division. Some analysts are predicting further, more drastic cutbacks across the board at the firm, which slashed 800 jobs in December, lowering its payroll to 35,700.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mixed Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a slow session that featured little significant news to move the markets. Soybean futures advanced slightly following Mikhail Gorbachev's denial of a report that he might resign as the Soviet Union's Communist Party chief. That report, which injected uncertainty into all financial markets Tuesday, had triggered a selloff in grain and soybean futures on fears that a change in Soviet leadership could result in fewer Soviet purchases of U.S. grain. Wheat futures ended mixed, corn was off slightly and oats rose a little. Analyst Mickey Luth of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. said a 6-week-old decline in the soybean market may not be over despite technical signals of a turnaround earlier in the week. He cited prospects for a large South American soybean crop due to recent beneficial rainfall in Argentina and Brazil. At the close, wheat futures were { cent lower to } cent higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.75{ a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 2 cents lower with March at $2.38 a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2\ cents lower with March at $1.35 a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 2\ cents higher with March at $5.60} a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Editor & Publisher Posts Record Renewal Rate
DOC.TEXT: Editor & Publisher, the weekly trade magazine for the newspaper industry, said Wednesday its renewal rate for subscriptions reached an all-time high. The renewal rate of 88 percent was contained in the Audit Bureau of Circulation audit statement for the 12 months ended June 1989, the magazine said. Robert U. Brown, editor and president of E&P, said the magazine's renewal rate _ the percentage of subscribers who renew their subscriptions _ has always been in the mid to high 70s. The magazine's circulation has been audited by ABC since 1914, he said. He said the magazine's renewal rate and circulation began to increase over the past two years. ``We didn't, however, expect such a high number,'' he said in a statement. The magazine said its paid circulation for the year ended June 1989 was 25,097.

DOC.HEAD: Commodore Profit Drops 70 Percent In Second Fiscal Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Commodore International Ltd.'s profit decreased 70 percent in the final three months of 1989 as sales of its less-powerful personal computers dropped, the computer maker said Wednesday. Profit totaled $11.3 million, or 35 cents a share, compared with $38.2 million, or $1.20 per share, in the same period a year earlier, Commodore said. Sales for the period, which is the company's second fiscal quarter, declined to $310.7 million, compared with $349 million in the year-earlier quarter, Commodore said. Expenses increased by $15.1 million in the latest quarter as the company spent more on marketing, Commodore said. ``Although our results were below last year's Christmas quarter, we are encouraged by our return to profitability, strong demand for the Amiga product line, and increased sales of our professional PCs,'' said Irving Gould, chairman and chief executive. Sales of the Amiga personal computer accounted for more than half of the company's revenue in the latest quarter, he said. Commodore's C64, C128D and lower-end personal computer sales were down, it said. Strong growth in European sales was overshadowed by weaker sales in other areas of the world and the adverse effects of the strong dollar on foreign exchange, the company said. Commodore lost $8.9 million from April through June of 1989 and $6.5 million from July through September. For the last six months of 1989, profit totaled $4.8 million, or 15 cents a share, down from $47.8 million, or $1.50 a share, a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Quarterly, Annual Income
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. said Wednesday its fourth-quarter earnings fell 40 percent from a year ago, reflecting efforts to remain independent from hostile suitor Georgia-Pacific Corp. Meanwhile, the 3-month-old takeover battle continued in federal courtrooms in Maine and Connecticut. Great Northern said earnings for the last three months of 1989 totaled $51.9 million, or 92 cents a share, on sales of $934.2 million. That compared with earnings of $85.8 million, or $1.56, and $944.1 million in sales. The Norwalk, Conn., company said earnings were reduced by 33 cents a share due to expenses incurred in fending off Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific's $3.8 billion takeover bid. Great Northern has gone to court to block the offer and to thwart Georgia-Pacific's efforts to oust the Great Northern board of directors at a March 2 special shareholders meeting. On Wednesday, the company disclosed documents in federal court in Portland, Maine, accusing Georgia-Pacific of violating securities laws by allegedly hiding plans to sell Great Northern's properties in Maine after a merger. Georgia-Pacific has denied those allegations. Meanwhile, in a court appearance in Bridgeport, Conn., Georgia Pacific Chairman T. Marshall Hahn Jr. denied charges by Great Northern that a merger of the two companies would create a monopoly, saying the resulting company would become more competitive and efficient. The combined company would have sales of around $14 billion. For the year, Great Northern said it earned $321.1 million, or $5.78 a share, down 6 percent from $341.7 million, or $6.21, in 1988. Sales rose to $3.86 billion from $3.56 billion. Chairman William R. Laidig said softer prices for its lumber and other wood products also contributed to last year's earnings decline. ``Our performance in 1990 will depend on both the strength of the U.S. economy and the growth in demand for our products worldwide,'' he said in a statement.
The stock market edged higher in late afternoon trading. About five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was up 45.27 points at 2,588.51.

DOC.HEAD: IMF, World Bank Announce Loans to Mexico
DOC.TEXT: The World Bank on Wednesday announced it was extending a loan of $1.26 billion to Mexico as support for its debt-restructuring agreement to be signed next week with commercial banks. The World Bank also agreed to let Mexico use about $750 million from previously approved loans to help reduce its debt of about $48 billion. The World Bank loan, combined with $1.27 billion in loans announced on Tuesday by the International Monetary Fund, is part of a $7.3-billion-dollar package announced Jan. 16 to support the restructuring of the Mexican debt.

The stock market ended sharply higher in fairly active trading today, reversing a five-session slide. Stocks rallied shortly after the opening on what some Wall Street analysts said was a technical bounce, then moved steadily higher throughout the session. The Dow Jones industrial average had fallen more than 72 points since last Wednesday. ``What's going on is nothing more than a market that got more oversold than at anytime since october 1987,'' said Ralph Bloch, chief market analyst for Raymond, James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla. Wall Street analysts said the market also gained strength from a rallying bond market after recent steep declines. A rebound in corporate junk bonds also spilled over into the stock market. Losses by RJR Holdings Capital Inc., which had dragged the junk bond market lower in recent days and helped pressure takeover stocks, gained ground for the second day. Interest-rate worries, which had plagued the market in recent days, also subsided, thanks in part to today's report by the Commerce Department that the December index of leading indicators went up 0.8 percent. Consensus expectations were for a rise of about 0.5 percent. The index, composed of 11 statistics designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months into the future, was the latest indication that the economy, while weak, can avoid an actual decline in growth _ or recession. ``As interest rate concerns subside, stocks are doing better,'' said Theodore Tung, senior vice president with National City Corp. in Cleveland. ``It's all keyed to interest rates.''

DOC.HEAD: Rejects Amoco Contract; Threatens Strikes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 2 to show that Amoco had no comment.
DOC.TEXT: Oilworkers rejected the industry's two-year contract offer Wednesday and threatened to strike some or all of the nation's largest petroleum companies. The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union said the contract offered by Amoco Corp., the pattern contract for the industry, fell short on pay, health benefits and environmental concerns. The company had no comment. Walkouts could be called at individual oil companies, the union said. ``It is our intention to extend the bargaining agreement on a 24-hour rolling basis,'' said union vice president Robert Wages, referring to the contract set to expire at 12:01 a.m. Thursday. The negotiations affect about 40,000 domestic oil workers and 300 contracts. Wages said negotiations will continue, but major companies that could be struck include Amoco, Texaco, Chevron, Mobil, Shell, Atlantic Richfield and Unocal. The average refinery worker's wage now is $15.18 an hour. The union seeks $1.25 hourly wage increases in each year of the two-year pact, increasing companies health care premium contributions to 90 percent, establishing an independent environmental monitor at each plant, and industry support of legislative efforts to establish a national health plan modeled after Canada's. Wages said the Amoco offer included annual pay raises of 62-64 cents an hour; increases in family medical premiums of $45 the first year and $40 the second; and failed to address both the environmental monitor and national health care proposals. Talks began Jan. 1. Last September, the union's national bargaining committee came up with a seven-point program which was ratified by the rank and file. That ratification also gave the committee strike authorization.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Post Co. Switches from AMEX to Big Board
DOC.TEXT: The Washington Post Co. switched the listing of its Class B common stock on Wednesday from the American Stock Exchange to the New York Stock Exchange. About 7,000 shares of the stock were traded on its first day on the NYSE, and it rose to $270.75 a share, up $2.25 from its close Tuesday on the Amex. The company, which owns the Washington Post newspaper and Newsweek magazine, applied for a listing on the NYSE, the nation's largest stock exchange Jan. 19. It has has 10.59 million Class B shares outstanding. Company spokesman Guyon Knight said Washington Post Co. has nearly 1.9 million shares of Class A common, which are owned by Katharine Graham, the board chairman, and her family and are not traded publicly. The Class A shares have a weighted voting power and elect 70 percent of the board while Class B shares elect 30 percent. When the Washington Post Co. went public in 1971, the NYSE did not list companies with dual classes of stock with different voting rights, Knight said. ``Since that restriction has been removed, the company determined its interest and those of its shareholders would best be served by moving to the Big Board,'' he said. In addition to the Post and Newsweek, the company owns television stations in Detroit, Hartford, Conn., and Jacksonville, Fla., and a cable television division which serves approximately 415,000 customers in 15 states.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The energy futures market turned mixed in lackluster trading Wednesday, with wholesale heating oil and gasoline prices dropping sharply and crude oil posting gains. The contract for February delivery of No. 2 home heating oil lost 1.64 cents to settle at 58.87 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange, after declining 0.60 cent Tuesday. February unleaded gasoline, which fell 0.90 cent Tuesday, dropped another 1.02 cents to close at 61.71 cents a gallon. However, the March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, gained 22 cents to settle at $22.68 per 42-gallon barrel. The near-month contract lost 34 cents in Tuesday's session. Peter Beutel, assistant director of the energy group at Elders Futures Inc., said traders sold heating oil and gasoline contracts following a report late Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute that showed higher-than-expected inventories of those products last week. Beutel said crude prices rose as a result. ``There was buying in crude against the sale in heating oil and gasoline,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: When Dynasty-Owned Businesses Are Sold, Sentimental Value Comes Second
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The Rockefellers have sold control of the Manhattan landmark bearing their name to a Japanese firm, and several grandchildren of Campbell Soup Co.'s founder want that company auctioned to strangers. You might ask how they can they sell the family businesses _ especially those with famous names. As time goes on, it becomes easy. Emotional ties to a family-owned firm, hatched from scratch and sweat by entrepreneurial ancestors, can weaken with each passing generation until the company's asset value outweighs its sentimental value and the corporation becomes an albatross to its owners. For $846 million, the Rockefellers turned over a controlling interest in Rockefeller Group Inc. to Mitsubishi Estate Co. In relinquishing control, the Rockefellers parted with New York's Rockefeller Center, the most visible and tangible symbol of their family fortune, and also surrendered exclusive rights to the Rockefeller name. Meanwhile, three grandchildren of Campbell founder John T. Dorrance Sr. have split with other relatives and want the company sold. The dissident Dorrances, while their names aren't emblazoned on soup cans, also are willing to sever their connection with a brand name familiar to millions worldwide. In some ways, the Rockefellers and Dorrances are like many other heirs of successful business entrpreneurs. Having grown away from the family company, they want to take their inheritance and move on. David Rockefeller Jr. is the great-great grandson of John D. Rockefeller and the great-grandson of John D. Jr., the founder of Rockefeller Center. He said recently that his generation has its own priorities. ``I don't know how far the family, as individuals, would have wanted to go if they had been asked to pump capital funds into keeping up these buildings, compared to supporting charitable causes or pursuing their own careers,'' Rockefeller said in an interview in the magazine Manhattan Inc. ``Frankly, I'm not so sure that if it came down to that, that they would have said, `The way we want to spend our money is to buff up the marble down at the Center,'' Rockefeller was quoted as saying. He refused to be interviewed for this story. It's nothing new for the descendants of a company founder to sell off the family business and its well-known name _ the Fields of Chicago did it twice. Marshall Field III, grandson of retailer Marshall Field, sold the family's famous department store in 1941, and turned instead toward journalism, building the Field Enterprises Inc. media empire. But more than 40 years later, in 1983, Marshall III's own grandsons, Marshall Field V and Frederick Field, dissolved the second family company after a dispute and went separate ways. Marshall Field V's current holdings include Field Corp., which owns Funk & Wagnalls Inc. and other publishers. Frederick Field is among the investors in the group that bid recently for BAT Industries PLC, the British conglomerate with properties that ironically include Marshall Field. On the other hand, the Philadelphia-based department store company Strawbridge & Clothier, founded in 1868, is still controlled by the Strawbridge and Clothier clans. Just about all other big department stores across the country have long since been sold off by their founding families. Strawbridge & Clothier also has dealt with dissident relatives who wanted out. In 1984 a group of Strawbridges decided to sell their 17 percent stake. The company, facing a takeover, bought the shares to retain family control. Even in some of the biggest corporations, founding family descendants are active. Nearly 190 years after DuPont Co. was created, members of the DuPont family still have ties to the chemical company. Several are board members. In 1988, two great-grandsons of Ford Motor Co. founder Henry Ford became the first of their generation elected to the board of the automaker, still 40 percent owned by the Ford family. Both men are also Ford executives. Some families have reasserted total control over their businesses. Southland Corp.'s founding Thompson family, for example, took the company private in a 1987 takeover, borrowing money to repurchase the stock. Other families who preside over publicly held corporations want to be sure they maintain control over their companies. So they've issued different classes of stock with voting rights that puts most power in family hands. Such an arrangement helped the Bryan family that owns Media General Inc. defeat a takeover bid by investor Burt Sugarman in 1988. The family held about 71 percent of the company's Class B shares, which controlled six of the nine seats on the Media General board, allowing the family to easily defeat Sugarman's attempt to win the other seats. But sometimes, when a company is losing money, a family must choose the bottom line over emotional ties. In 1982 E.W. Scripps Co. decided to sell United Press International, which had been losing money for years. UPI was a project of company founder E.W. Scripps, who believed in 1907 that American newspapers needed competing wire services. Scripps Co. executives and members of the Scripps family decided 75 years later the subsidiary's losses were too much to carry any longer. Ted Scripps, an E.W. Scripps grandson who shared his ancestor's belief in competition among the wires, lobbied against a sale and sought a way for Scripps Co. to keep UPI. But relatives told Ted Scripps the family couldn't afford it. There are times when a company can become the pawn in a family feud. That was the case in the Field family and in the notorious 1980s fight among members of Kentucky's Bingham family, owners of a media empire. It began when Sallie Bingham challenged her brother as head of the family business and then found herself off the board of directors. After two years of bickering _ including a threat by Ms. Bingham to sell her 15 percent stake _ her father, patriarch Barry Bingham Sr., put an end to the fight and the family ties to the business, selling its two newspapers, television station and printing company. Bingham, who died in 1988, was forced to break his bonds with newspapers his father bought in 1918. ``It is not easy for me to see The Courier-Journal and Louisville Times pass from my family into other hands,'' he said in announcing the sale in May 1986. But, he added, ``Change is an inevitable rule of life.''
