DOC.HEAD: Treasury Announces $30 Billion in Note, Bond Auctions Next Week
DOC.TEXT: The government plans to borrow $30 billion from the public next week in a series of debt auctions to replenish its coffers, the Treasury Department announced Wednesday. ``We are offering $30 billion of notes and bonds to refund $18.1 billion of privately held notes maturing on Feb. 15 and to raise approximately $11.9 billion of cash,'' Treasury Undersecretary Robert Glauber said at a news briefing. According to Glauber, the auctions for next week will include: _$10 billion in three-year notes in minimum denominations of $5,000 to be auctioned on Tuesday; _$10 billion in 10-year notes in minimum denominations of $1,000 to be auctioned on Wednesday, and _$10 billion in 30-year bonds in minimum denominations of $1,000 to be auctioned on Thursday. These notes and bonds are regularly sold during the large debt auctions which are held four times a year.

DOC.NOTE: For release at 6:30 p.m. EST
DOC.HEAD: Consumers Losing Confidence in Economic Prospects
DOC.TEXT: A widely watched gauge of consumer confidence sank in January for the third straight month, dropping to the lowest point since after the October 1987 stock market crash, according to a survey released Wednesday. The Conference Board said its Consumer Confidence Index tumbled to 105.1 in January from 113 in December and 115.8 in January a year earlier. Fabian Linden, executive director of the New York-based business research group's consumer research center, said ``the size of the decline must be regarded as a possible, though not unmistakable, indication of economic troubles ahead.'' He noted, however, that ``in the context of the survey's history, the present level of consumer confidence does not yet signal a likely recession in the coming months.'' The January reading was the lowest since the index registered 100.8 in November 1987, the month after world financial markets suffered major setbacks. On Oct. 19, 1987, the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks plummeted 508 points to 1,738.74, a loss of 22.6 percent of its value. A monthly survey of 5,000 households throughout the country indicated that people are less comfortable with their situations and less optimistic about the next six months than they were when polled in December, the Conference Board said. The latest poll showed 18.5 percent of all those responding expressed the view that business conditions were bad, a slightly larger percentage than in December. Only about one in four respondents believed that jobs were ``plentiful,'' a figure that has been going steadily lower in recent months. On the employment outlook, pessimists outnumbered optimists for the first time since late 1987. Expectations about economic conditions in the next half-year have deteriorated, the board said. Only 16.2 percent of the respondents thought that business would improve, down about 2 percentage points from December. Buying plans didn't show much change in the January survey. The percentage of people planning to buy a car fell slightly to 6.9 percent. There still was strong interest in purchasing major appliances while the number of people planning to buy homes barely budged from its low level of 3.4 percent. The survey is conducted for the board each month by National Family Opinion of Toledo, Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: Simmons Makes New Move on Georgia Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Dallas takeover investor Harold Simmons, who has coveted the Georgia Gulf Corp. for months, on Wedneday announced a cash offer to its stockholders that values the Atlanta-based chemical company at $1.1 billion. NL Industries, the Houston-based chemical supplier controlled by Simmons, said it intends to begin within five business days a tender offer to buy all outstanding shares of Georgia Gulf at $45 cash each. The company has about 24.5 million shares outstanding, which includes NL's own 9 percent stake. Wall Street welcomed the Simmons announcement. On the New York Stock Exchange, Georgia Gulf jumped $4.62{ a share to close at $40.87{. Georgia Gulf has been seeking ways to avoid Simmons, a wealthy investor known for his takeover forays. For awhile the company beckoned other potential buyers in attempt to raise its stock price and discourage him. In November it abanded those efforts and said it would attempt a debt-financed recapitalization that would give shareholders cash and new stock. The company valued that deal as worth about $55 a share. But NL said in its statement Wednesday that it decided to pursue the acquisition of Georgia Gulf because of the ``belief that under current market conditions, Georgia Gulf's recapitalization plan will not provide its shareholders with values as great as $45 per share.'' NL said it would seek the support of Georgia Gulf's board of directors, and would encourage Georgia Gulf management to ``participate in the acquisition transaction.'' Analysts have said the large stock holdings of Georgia Gulf's management could make takeover of the company difficult without management's cooperation. Company officials declined to comment on NL takeover offer.

DOC.HEAD: Kimberly-Clark Sends Out Letters Opposing Wisconsin Diaper Tax
DOC.TEXT: Kimberly-Clark Corp., one the nation's largest diaper makers, said Wednesday it has begun a letter campaign urging parents in Wisconsin to fight a proposed environmental tax on disposable diapers. Jean Allen, director of corporate communications at Kimberly-Clark's headquarters in Irving, Texas, said the company last week sent out 100,000 letters to parents of young children in Wisconsin. The letters urge opposition to a bill pending in the Wisconsin Legislature that calls for a 1-cent-per-diaper tax to raise money for recycling efforts in the state. ``Kimberly-Clark favors Wisconsin efforts to recycle,'' Ms. Allen said. ``But to be fair we think such a tax should be levied on all product that go in landfills. ... We believe it should be a more broad-based, equitable tax.'' Ms. Allen said other states also are reviewing recycling legislation that could affect diapers, but this is the first time her company, which commands about a 30 percent share of the nation's disposable diaper market, has campaigned to oppose such a bill. ``We are very concerned that people understand the ramification of this part of the bill. Once informed it's then their decision on what action they should take,'' she said. But Rep. Spencer Black, D-Madison, the Assembly sponsor of the recycling bill, said he believed Kimberly-Clark does not support any tax to help recycling despite its statement. ``This is typical of the special interest effort to kill the recycling bill,'' Black said. ``Every special interest says `we're for recycling' but then they're against the portion of the bill that affects their profits.'' The Wisconsin diaper tax is included in an amendment to a recycling bill pending before the Legislature's Joint Finance Committee. The amendment was considered a compromise on an earlier proposal to ban disposable diapers entirely from Wisconsin landfills. Supporters say the tax is justified because disposable diapers are not considered biodegradable and do not decay easily when buried in landfills. A legislative study estimated the tax would cost a family with a young child $80 to $100 a year in additional costs.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Skid on U.S. Call for IMF Use of Gold Holdings
DOC.TEXT: Gold futures prices tumbled Wednesday amid reports that the United States has asked the International Monetary Fund to consider using its gold holdings to wipe out past-due loans to some of its member countries. Traders feared that such a plan could lead to sales of several million ounces of gold on the open market. On other commodity markets, oil futures were mixed; livestock and meat futures were lower; and grains and soybeans were mixed. Gold futures settled $5.70 to $6.40 lower on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for delivery in February off $5.70 at $412.40 a troy ounce. Silver futures followed gold, ending 1.1 cents to 1.7 cents lower with March at $5.228 a troy ounce. The first report about the IMF said the United States had proposed the 152-nation lending agency sell $4 billion worth of gold to obtain cash needed to offset about $4 billion in delinquent loans to 15 of its poorer members. That report prompted heavy selling of gold futures, analysts said. A Treasury Department source told The Associated Press that the actual proposal was that the IMF ``consider mobilizing'' a portion of the IMF gold holdings contributed by the delinquent members, amounting to less than 3 percent _ or about $1.23 billion _ of the 103 million ounces held by the IMF. The source, who requested anonymity, would not elaborate on what ``mobilizing'' meant. Market analysts said the United States probably was proposing to use gold as collateral to obtain loans from central banks to cover the past-due loans. Still, said metals economist Fred Demler of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., ``even if you use it as collateral, a default could end up being a gold sale.'' Analysts said the gold market's weakness also reflected Wednesday's strong rally in the stock market and the prospects for steady, rather than lower, interest rates. Petroleum futures finished mixed on the New York Mercantile Exchange in quiet trading. Peter Beutel, assistant director of the energy group at Elders Futures Inc., said traders sold heating oil and gasoline contracts following a report late Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute that showed higher-than-expected inventories of those products last week. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 11 cents to 22 cents higher with March at $22.68 a barrel; heating oil was .13 cent to 1.64 cents lower with February at 58.87 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.02 cents lower to .40 cent higher with February at 61.71 cents a gallon. Livestock and meat futures retreated on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange with much of the selling linked to weaker spot markets and to positioning by cattle traders ahead of Friday's semi-annual Agriculture Department cattle inventory report. The report is expected to show a continued modest growth in the nation's cattle herd. Live cattle futures settled .30 cent to 1.05 cents lower with the contract for delivery in February at 79.35 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to .75 cent lower with March at 82.52 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .72 cent lower with February at 48.70 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .12 cent to .45 cent lower with February at 50.45 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures ended mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade with soybeans up, corn down and wheat nearly unchanged. Wheat settled { cent lower to \ cent higher with March at $3.75} a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 1} cents lower with March at $2.38\ a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 2\ cents lower with March at $1.35\ a bushel; soybeans were \ cent lower to 2{ cents higher with March at $5.61 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slips, Late Gold Drops Sharply
DOC.TEXT: The dollar slipped against most key currencies in thin trading Wednesday after the markets discounted a report that Mikhail Gorbachev would resign as Soviet Communist Party chairman. U.S. gold prices dropped sharply on reports that the Treasury had proposed a $4 billion gold sale by the International Monetary Fund to strengthen the lending agency's finances. But the Treasury said later it had only proposed that the IMF consider using gold as collateral for loans. On New York's Commodity Exchange, a troy ounce of gold fell $5.70 to close at $412.40. Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $411.25 a troy ounce, down $7.05 from Tuesday. The dollar closed mixed against other major currencies in European trading, affected by uncertainty over Soviet politics, Japanese central bank intervention and domestic inflation. Foreign exchange dealers said traders sold dollars after they discounted the report about Gorbachev. The report Tuesday by Cable News Network sent the dollar sharply higher that day. There also was pressure on the dollar due to dollar-selling by the Bank of Japan and Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's comments Tuesday that inflation was still a concern in the United States. In New York, currency traders said there was little reaction to the Commerce Department's release Wednesday morning of its leading indicators figure for December. The figure, regarded as the government's main economic forecasting gauge, jumped a strong 0.8 percent, indicating the economy may avoid a recession this year. Walter Simon, a vice president in the New York office of Bank Julius Baer & Co. of Switzerland, said traders expected the robust figure after Greenspan's remarks Tuesday. He said the dollar traded in a narrow range most of the day. He said there is a belief that despite the leading indicators figure and Greenspan's comments, the U.S. economy is weakening. That belief hurts the value of the dollar because it implies the Fed will act to ease interest rates, which tends to lower the value of the dollar. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.40 Japanese yen, up from 143.25 on Tuesday. In London late Wednesday the dollar closed higher at 144.45 yen. In New York it closed at 144.45 yen, down from 144.65 yen late Tuesday. In London, one British pound cost $1.6870 late Wednesday, more expensive for buyers than Tuesday's late $1.6830. Later, in New York, it sold for $1.6792, up from $1.6725 Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday rates: 1.6848 West German marks, down from 1.6990; 1.5010 Swiss francs, up from 1.5005; 5.7250 French francs, down from 5.7600; 1,251.75 Italian lire, down from 1,260.50; and 1.1870 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1865. Other dollar late rates in Europe compared with late Tuesday: 1.6800 marks, down from 1.6805; 1.5025 Swiss francs, up from 1.4890; 5.7275 French francs, up from 5.7040; 1.8950 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8880; 1,252.75 Italian lire, up from 1,249.50; 1.1856 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1902. Gold bullion in London traded late at a bid $413.25 a troy ounce, down from $418.50 late Tuesday. The Zurich late bid price was $412.50, down from $419. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold closed at $417.85 bid, down from $418.15 on Tuesday. Silver prices were unchanged to lower. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery finished at $5.194 a troy ounce, down from $5.207 Tuesday. Earlier, in London, silver bullion traded $5.22, unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Announces $422 Million, Five-year Improvement Plan
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines will spend $422 million over the next five years to lure customers with new plane interiors, more choices of food and more on-time arrivals, airline President Fred Malek said Wednesday. The nation's fourth-largest airline, already experimenting with German and Thai dishes on some flights, will spend about $100 million to serve meals on more flights and add choices to standard in-flight fare, Malek said. Northwest also will spend about $100 million to put more powerful engines on some Boeing 747 jumbo jets, strengthen maintenance capability and build up spare parts inventories to cut mechanical delays, he said. Malek and Chairman Alfred Checchi, who with other investors acquired Northwest last August for $3.7 billion, have said they want it to be the first choice of travelers by 1995. Malek wouldn't detail how Northwest rates in market surveys, but said its performance is ``not too good.'' The new management is working to boost employee morale, said Malek, who was formerly president of Marriott Hotels and is co-chairman of Coldwell Banker Commercial Group, a leading real estate services company. ``It is now time to couple this with some meaningful improvements in our levels of service,'' he said. Malek predicted a consolidation of the airline industry and said Northwest wants to take part, either through acquisitions or joint ventures, though he said it hasn't any immediate targets in sight. Besides improved meals, maintenance capability and enticements such as free drinks and headsets for trans-Atlantic passengers, Northwest will spend $80 million to refurbish its 324 planes, Malek said. Executive class passengers will have wider seats in the airline's Boeing 747 jumbo jets. Window rows will still be two seats wide, but center tiers will be three rather than four seats wide. All planes will be redecorated. Uniforms for pilots, flight attendants and other employees will be redesigned, Malek said. Northwest leads the industry in trans-Pacific flights, which can be 13 to 14 hours long, Malek said. ``That's a long trip. You want a tranquil, comfortable, pleasing decor package.'' Flight attendants will be added on some flights, he said, and the airline will spend $30 million over the five years to clean planes more often. He didn't elaborate on how the airline will allocate the remaining $110 million. Malek held a news conference in Detroit, Northwest's largest hub, after briefing an annual conference of the airlines' sales and marketing staff on the customer service plans. Northwest is based in Eagan, Minn., a suburb of St. Paul. The airline flew 45.7 million revenue passenger miles in 1989, fourth behind American Airlines, United Airlines and Delta Airlines, and had a more than 11 percent market share among U.S. airlines, spokesman Bob Gibbons said. The airline is privately owned and hasn't reported sales and earnings since Malek, Checchi and the others acquired it. In 1988, its last year as a publicly held company, it reported earnings of $135.1 million on revenues of $5.65 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Approves Mitsubishi-Backed Takeover Bid
DOC.TEXT: Members of Aristech Chemical Corp.'s board Wednesday approved a $934.2 million cash takeover bid submitted by a group of the Pittsburgh company's senior managers and the Mitsubishi Corp. of Japan. But the agreement also allows the company to solicit proposals from others. Utah chemical magnate Jon Huntsman asked Aristech to extend its bidding deadline from Monday to Feb. 14 to give him time to put together a bid worth at least $934.2 million, or $27 a share, with help from General Electric Co.'s GE Plastics division. Under terms of the agreement, a cash tender offer will begin within five days for all of Aristech's outstanding common shares, Aristech spokesman David Higie said. Aristech stock rose $1.12{ Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $26.37{. Aristech will pay Mitsubishi and the management group, headed by Aristech Chairman Thomas Marshall, up to $13 million in expenses if their deal falls through, according to the agreement. Huntsman on Wednesday said he would study the agreement carefully over the next few days. ``We are very disappointed with the manner in which Aristech's board of directors proceeded in this instance,'' he said in a statement released by spokeswoman Leslie Cotten. Ms. Cotten declined to comment on whether Huntsman plans to continue pursuing his own bid. Plans call for Marshall's group to to buy about 12.5 percent of the common stock of a new holding company of which Aristech will be a subsidiary. Another 8.5 percent will be granted to members of the management group in restricted common stock. A broader group of Aristech management will have the opportunity to participate up to a total of about 11.5 percent in common stock equity of the holding company, which can be earned through performance incentives over a five-year period. Financing for the transaction has been arranged through The Mitsubishi Bank Ltd. and the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corp. Aristech said it will maintain operations in their present form and locations and keep its headquarters in Pittsburgh under the arrangement. No other details of the transaction were released. ``Our management will be freed from the pressures of quarter-to-quarter performance and will be able to concentrate more fully on long-term planning, expansion and growth,'' Marshall said. Aristech makes and markets polymers and related products and industrial chemicals. It employes 1,850 people in Arkansas, California, Florida, Kentucky, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Texas and West Virginia. Huntsman's earlier bid of $25 a share was rejected in November as inadequate. He owns the nation's largest privately held chemicals company and currently owns 8.7 percent of Aristech's stock, spokeswoman Joele Frank said.

DOC.HEAD: Dow Reports 1989 Profits Up, 4th Quarter Down
DOC.TEXT: Lower chemical prices cut Dow Chemical Co.'s fourth-quarter earnings by nearly a third, the company said Wednesday. Even with the decline, earnings for all of 1989 were up 5.5 percent, the company said. Dow reported earnings of $427 million, or $1.59 a share, for the three months ended Dec. 31, down from $635 million, or $2.29 a share, for the fourth quarter of 1988. Quarterly sales totaled $4.26 billion, down from $4.30 billion a year earlier, the company said. For the year, Dow reported earnings of $2.49 billion, or $9.20 a share, on sales of $17.60 billion, vs. earnings of $2.40 billion, or $8.51 a share, on sales of $16.68 billion in 1988. Prices for Dow's chemical products were down nearly 9 percent from record highs during product shortages a year earlier, the company said. In addition, Dow said the North American construction market that extensively uses vinyl chloride products slowed, contributing to a 26 percent drop in income in the category of chemicals and performance products.

DOC.HEAD: Xerox Reports Fourth-Quarter Earnings of $212 Million
DOC.TEXT: Xerox Corp. on Wednesday reported fourth-quarter earnings of $212 million, rebounding from the same period in 1988 when it reported a $77 million loss due to a restructuring program. The profit in the most recent quarter amounted to $1.93 per share, compared with a loss of 80 cents a share a year earlier. Revenue for the fourth quarter totaled $4.7 billion, up 6 percent from $4.4 billion in the year-earlier quarter. David T. Kearns, Xerox's chairman and chief executive officer, credited the growth in earnings to successful new products, cost control measures and benefits from the restructuring program, which involved a reduction in manufacturing capacity and the elimination of certain business lines. ``Assuming a reasonable economic environment, we expect full-year benefits of our restructuring program and continued customer acceptance of our new products to deliver good growth and improved returns in document processing,'' Kearns said. ``Overall corporate results, however, may be somewhat dampened by the effects of a continuation of the current industrywide pricing weakness in property and casualty insurance,'' he said. The company's insurance and financial services division reported a slight drop in earnings, from $48 million in the fourth quarter of 1988 to $43 million in 1989, and from $240 million for all of 1988 to $216 million for 1989. The company blamed the earnings drop on soft markets for property and casualty insurance. Overall for 1989 Xerox reported income of $704 million, or $6.41 per share, on revenue of $17.6 billion. In 1988, the company reported earnings of $388 million, or $3.49 per share, on revenue of $16.4 billion. Excluding the impact of the $244 million restructuring program, the company's 1988 earnings were $632 million, or $5.88 per share.

DOC.HEAD: Brokerage House Seeks To Restore Faith, Announces New Stock Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 6th graf pvs, `Another sign... to UPDATE with new CEO comments; PICKS UP 7th graf pvs, `Basically, they're...
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Shearson-Cuts, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. took steps Wednesday to bolster its financial footing under tighter control of parent American Express Co. following the sudden resignation of Shearson chairman Peter A. Cohen. The departure of Cohen, a cigar-chomping Wall Street wunderkind, typified the faltering fortunes of the nation's second-largest brokerage and of the securities industry, which is mired in a protracted slump following the booming 1980s. Nine years after acquiring Shearson, American Express removed the final high-level link to the firm's past when company chairman James D. Robinson III asked Cohen to leave amid mounting acrimony between the two executives. American Express and Shearson on Wednesday jointly announced a plan to raise about $250 million by offering stock to existing shareholders. It replaces a public offering scrapped because of the firm's slumping stock price and Cohen's resignation Tuesday. Under the new plan, American Express would cut its stake in Shearson to about 45 percent from 61 percent, enabling it to drop the brokerage from its balance sheet. American Express would remain Shearson's largest stakeholder. A sign of tighter parental control came with the appointment of Howard L. Clark Jr., chief financial officer and executive vice president of American Express, as Shearson's new president and CEO. Clark's father was American Express chairman before Robinson. Clark said in a telephone interview that his short-term goal ``is to get out and see the employees and management and retail system. I will be doing a lot of that. Longer term is to restore Shearson to its prior levels of returns.'' He said his appointment would not mark a radical change in the relationship between American Express and Shearson. Analysts had a different view. ``Basically, they're running the company directly now,'' said Lawrence Eckenfelder, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. ``Robinson always had influence but it was Peter Cohen's company.'' Shearson's current troubles stem in part from a recession on Wall Street stemming from a decline in individual stock activity, mergers and acquisitions and securities underwriting. Because of their size and exposure in many areas, Nos. 1 and 2 Merrill Lynch & Co. and Shearson have been among the hardest hit. But analysts lay much of the blame on overexpansion. Shearson moved from a medium-sized retail outfit to a diversified brokerage by acquiring investment banking firm Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb in 1984 and retail brokerage E.F. Hutton & Co. in 1988. ``In this drive to become a major, global, full-service firm, they like Merrill expanded to the point where they started to realize diminishing returns,'' Eckenfelder said. ``They found out you can be all things to all people but you can't always make money doing it.'' For Cohen, 43, described as a tough negotiator driven to transform Shearson into a top-flight firm, the fall was swift. Last week, he offered a hint of his own demise and of his soured relationship with Robinson. Asked bluntly during a stock-offering presentation why he still had his job, Cohen said: ``If Robinson wants to punch my ticket he can.'' He did. American Express officials say the company now will focus on assessing what problems need to be resolved. They do not rule out a sharp consolidation following the '80s growth. ``Shearson will be adapting to the demands and requirements of the environment,'' said Lawrence Armour, an American Express senior vice president. ``Shearson is really filled with talented, high-energy people,'' he said. ``I don't think long-range planning, strategic thinking is one of the things they shine at.'' Securities industry analysts said Clark is the antithesis of the brash and combative Cohen. An investment banker in the 1970s, Clark, who turns 46 on Thursday, was described as a subdued and practical manager expected to run Shearson less aggressively than Cohen. ``Over the next several years you could see a swing back to the Shearson of old where the main concern was the retail side of the business,'' said Perrin Long of Lipper Analytical Services. The first order of business is the new stock offer. Shearson plans to sell 21 million shares of common stock for $12 a share to current shareholders. American Express would buy about 69 percent of the new stock and any shares not purchased. The old plan envisioned the sale of 20 million shares to the public. Shearson stock reacted positively to the developments, rising 75 cents to $12 in New York Stock Exchange trading Wednesday after a 75-cent rise on Tuesday spurred largely by Cohen's resignation. American Express would reduce its stake in Shearson by awarding Shearson shares to American Express stockholders as a special dividend. As it moves forward, Shearson still faces the expansion problems left behind by Cohen, including the merger with Hutton, the securities industry's largest ever. Analysts and American Express officials say Shearson paid too much for Hutton _ $962 million _ when retail brokering was slumping after the stock market crash in 1987. In addition, Shearson must patch up morale among its merged troops, particularly its 10,500 stockbrokers. John Feloni, a former Hutton executive who wrote a book about the merger, said Hutton's trademark was that of a friendly retail brokerage while Shearson symbolized the arrogance characterizing the '80s takeover craze. ``It was just a culture clash,'' said Feloni, who now runs his own small investment firm. ``If there were better times I think they might have overcome all that. Now there's just no room for error.''

DOC.HEAD: Drexel To Pay $1 Million in Settlement
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. will pay Missouri $1 million to settle charges arising from the Wall Street firm's guilty plea to securities fraud charges, the state said Wednesday. In a separate action, state Attorney General William Webster asked the state's supreme court to revoke the company's charter in Missouri and order it to pay an additional $2 million fine. Secretary of State Roy Blunt said at a news conference that the felonies to which Drexel pleaded guilty were ``as un-American as rigging the World Series.'' Missouri was the 40th jurisdiction with which Drexel has settled. The New York-based firm said it has paid a total of $7.3 million so far in settlements. Drexel pleaded guilty last September to six felonies and paid $650 million to settle a range of fraud allegations stemming from the government's lengthy investigation of insider trading on Wall Street. Drexel also agreed to dozens of administrative changes and unprecedented federal supervision in the April settlement of civil charges by the federal Securities and Exchange Commission. Under the latest agreement, Drexel cannot solicit new business in Missouri for three years without the secretary of state's consent; must hire an agent to find investors hurt by the company's actions; and must pay $100,000 above the $1 million to a national investor education fund. The company can continue to deal with its existing customers in Missouri. Of Drexel's payments to the state, $500,000 pay for toward investor education materials and an equal amount for grants for business programs at Missouri colleges and universities. Blunt said persons found to have been financially hurt by Drexel's action are entitled to money from a $350 million fund under a settlement between the firm and the government. Investors who file a claim must prove damage. Settling with the states relieves the firm of possible litigation, and frees state regulators from having to investigate the firm's trading activities from 1984 to 1986, when the SEC alleged the fraud occurred. It also generally preserves the firm's ability to underwrite securities and do other business in the states. Most states can revoke a company's right to do business, if the firm is convicted or admits to committing a felony. Drexel abandoned the retail brokerage business last year.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Rally On Final Day Of January
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT decline for month to 5.9 percent.
DOC.TEXT: The stock market surged Wednesday, reversing a five-session slide and ending the month on a bright note as interest rate concerns subsided. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials finished the day at 2,590.54, up 47.30 points. The Dow Jones industrials fell 162.66 points, or 5.9 percent, during January, despite starting the year with a gain of 56.95 points that pushed the index to an all-time high of 2,810.15 on Jan. 2. Advancing issues outpaced decliners by a margin of about 5 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1,116 issues up, 449 down and 411 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 189.66 million shares, up from 186.03 million in the previous session. Stocks rallied at the opening on what some Wall Street analysts called a technical bounce amid oversold conditions, then moved steadily higher throughout the session. It was the first gain in five sessions for the Dow Jones industrials, which had fallen more than 72 points since last Wednesday. ``I don't think this is the start of an uptrend. This is properly termed a technical bounce,'' said Hugh Johnson, senior vice president at First Albany Corp. Wall Street analysts said the catalyst for the rally was the bond market's strength despite an unexpected 0.8 percent rise in the December index of leading indicators. Consensus expectations were for a rise of about 0.5 percent. The index, composed of 11 statistics designed to forecast economic activity six to nine months into the future, was the latest indication that the economy, while weak, can avoid an actual decline in growth _ or recession. Ordinarily the report would have been taken by the bond market as a signal that the Federal Reserve would continue to push interest rates higher, which would lower bond prices _ a negative for the credit market, traders said. ``The bond market ignored the strong data suggesting to some that interest rates might have peaked,'' Johnson said. Theodore Tung, senior vice president with National City Corp. in Cleveland, said interest-rate worries, which have plagued the market in recent days, have now been discounted in the market. ``As interest rate concerns subside, stocks are doing better,'' Tung said. ``It's all keyed to interest rates.'' Analysts said reports that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev denied he might resign as head of the communist party eased market jitters early in the day. The television report Tuesday jolted the financial markets and sent the dollar soaring. Despite the rally, several analysts said a combination of worries could still send the market lower in coming days _ including whether U.S. interest rates are attractive enough to lure foreign investors to buy U.S. securities. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 221.76 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market gained $50.308 billion, or 1.62 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 3.07 to 181.50. Among actively traded issues on the NYSE, AT&T advanced 1[ to 38~, Philip Morris gained ~ to 37~ on better-than-expected earnings and IBM added 1] to 98|. Chase Manhattan gained ] to 30}, Bank of New England rose \ to 4~, and Federal National Mortgage went up 2 to 31\, among interest-rate sensitive stocks. Dow Chemical, whose fourth-quarter earnings fell short of expectations, dropped 1} to 63~, Exxon was unchanged at 47 and Occidental Petroleum, the most active stock, ended unchanged at 26|. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 6.77 to 378.69, and S&P's 500-stock composite index added 6.10 to 329.08. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 5.09 to 415.81. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 350.07, up 4.57.

DOC.HEAD: Video `Super Bowl' Debuting in Texas
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of finger-twitching Nintendo enthusiasts will test their skills in ``the Super Bowl of video games,'' a nationwide playoff that promoters announced here Wednesday. The Nintendo World Championship, beginning here in March, is expected to draw more than 40,000 video game enthusiasts. The competition eventually could involve as many as 1.2 million contestants as the playoff moves to 29 other cities in the United States and Canada. Winners from each city will compete for the championship in Orlando, Fla., in late October. While providing a forum for true enthusiasts to show their stuff, Nintendo also hopes to draw non-competitors and will have games on hand for them to try. The company also will give competitors sneak previews of new software. The Japanese game company is sponsoring the contest, but local promoters are arranging competitions in each city, Dallas promoter Danny Eaton said. ``Since we are the first, all the other promoters have been calling me,'' Eaton said. Promoters in other cities also are expecting to draw 30,000 to 40,000 people to what Eaton called ``the Super Bowl of video games.'' The Dallas playoff will be held March 8-11 at an exhibition hall nearly the size of two football fields at the city's fairgrounds. The competition features more than 100 game stations. One portion of the hall, called the ``power walk,'' will preview the new software, with game counselors on call to handle questions from stumped players. Games will be played at two-minute intervals. Players will move to the second or ``super stage'' where they can get tips on the games and question counselors. Costumed Nintendo-character musicians will sing lyrics based on the games, while counselors read correspondence from stumped players in a ``mail room.'' The third section is the two-level competition stage. A video game triathlon, the competition will combine elements of Super Mario, Rad Racer and Tetris games. The top seven players from the Dallas playoff and contests in other cities will be invited to Orlando for the national finals, Eaton said. They will compete for prizes that will include a 5-figure savings bond, a car and Nintendo software for life, said Laurie Muslow, a company spokeswoman. A ticket to the championships costs $9.50 for children and $12.50 for adults. Competitors have to pay an extra $3, Eaton said. The Nintendo World Championship was created by EMCI@Rockbill, a New York-based worldwide entertainment marketing company.

DOC.HEAD: AP Business News
Loss Blamed on Downturn in Appliances, Bedding
DOC.TEXT: Allegheny International Inc., which is seeking approval for its bankruptcy reorganization plan, posted a $3.1 million loss in the fourth quarter of 1989 on a 5.8 percent drop in sales. The maker of Sunbeam and Oster appliances said lower operating profits in small appliances and bedding products reflected heightened competition. For the quarter ended Dec. 31, the company's fiscal first quarter, Allegheny lost $3.1 million, or 98 cents a share, on sales of $213.8 million. That compared with earnings of $1.8 million, or 53 cents a share, on sales of $227 million in the same quarter a year earlier, the company said Wednesday. Operating profit on consumer products, which doesn't take account of interest payments or taxes, fell to $10.6 million in the quarter from $21.4 million a year earlier. Sales and operating profits of Allegheny International's small appliance companies in Mexico, Venezuela and Peru also declined, mostly because of unsettled economic conditions in those countries and a decline in the value of their currencies, the company said. Allegheny said earlier this week it expects to submit its reorganization plan to a vote of creditors and shareholders within the next week. The company said it believes its plan then can be confirmed by U.S. Bankruptcy Court. Allegheny has said it could emerge from Chapter 11 protection by June 30.

DOC.HEAD: Bethlehem Steel Reports Decrease In Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Bethlehem Steel Corp. Wednesday said higher costs and reduced demand contributed to a 25 percent decrease in earnings and a 22 percent drop in sales in the final quarter of 1989. Fourth quarter earnings totaled $50 million, or 58 cents a share, on sales of $1.14 billion. That compared with earnings of $65.7 million, or 79 cents a share, on sales of $1.33 billion in the same period of 1988. Profits for all of 1989 dropped 39 percent to $245.7 million, or $2.93 a share, from $403 million, or $5.32 a share, in 1988. Sales slipped 4 percent to $5.25 billion from $5.48 billion. Special charges, primarily to cover the downsizing of the company's Baltimore Marine and BethForge divisions, reduced earnings for 1989 by $105 million, Bethlehem Steel said. Restructuring charges reduced net income by $55 million in the fourth quarter of 1988 and by $113 million for all of 1988. Steel shipments fell to 2.11 million tons in the fourth quarter from 2.39 million tons a year earlier. For the year, steel shipments fell to 9.52 million tons from 10.07 million tons.

DOC.HEAD: Iran-Contra Company Broke, Cannot Pay Fine, Lawyer Contends
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with agreement to return unspecified amount of money to U.S. government. Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: Albert Hakim, the businessman who controlled the proceeds from the Reagan administration's arms sales to Iran, has agreed to return an unspecified amount of money to the U.S. government, Iran-Contra prosecutors said Wednesday. Hakim, who pleaded guilty Nov. 21 to supplementing Oliver North's income, faces sentencing Thursday before U.S. District Court Judge Gerhard Gesell. The Justice Department approved an agreement this week ''for the return to the United States of certain funds'' by Hakim, the office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh said in court papers. The Swiss government has frozen some $7.8 million held in accounts of the ``Enterprise,'' the network of companies Hakim and business partner Richard Secord set up to handle money in the Iran-Contra affair. The court papers did not specify how much money would be returned. On Monday, Iran-Contra prosecutors said in a sentencing memo that Hakim has agreed to provide them with testimony in ``an anticipated future case'' that pertains to a grand jury investigation being conducted outside Washington. The prosecutors did not elaborate, but called his cooperation ``of significant value.'' The question of who owns the proceeds from the Iran-Contra affair has lingered since the scandal erupted in November 1986. In the secret Iran initiative, the U.S. government was paid the cost of the weapons it sold to the Iranians. But the ``Enterprise'' charged Iran exorbitant prices for the arms, with the difference being kept in the accounts controlled by Hakim. Several million dollars were diverted to the Contras fighting the leftist government of Nicaragua. Other money was set aside for profits for Hakim, Secord and arms dealer Thomas Clines, congressional investigators found. Some of the money also was supposed to be funneled to other covert U.S. programs, North has testified. Iran-Contra prosecutors said that one of Hakim's companies, Lake Resources, ``unlawfully converted for its own use profits of approximately $11.4 million.'' A lawyer for the firm, John Hume, denied that. Lake Resources pleaded guilty to a charge of theft of government property in the diversion of Iran arms sales profits to the Contras and also faces sentencing before Gesell. Walsh's office has ``grossly miscalculated'' by ``vastly understating Lake Resources' costs and expenses,'' said Hume. As of Dec. 31, 1986, the company had $430.60 in a bank account that has been frozen by the Swiss government. ``Since that time, we believe, bank fees and charges have significantly reduced that amount,'' said Hume. Hume urged Gesell to levy no fine when he sentences the company, Theft of government property carries a $500,000 maximum fine for a corporation. The prosecution asserted that a fine can be enforced ``against those entities that have received the assets of Lake Resources through fraudulent transactions.'' ``The fact that, after such fraudulent transactions, Lake Resources itself has only limited resources does not prevent imposition of an appropriate sentence,'' associate independent counsel Stuart Abrams said in court papers. Hakim, who admitted that he helped Secord pay for a $13,800 security system at North's home, could face up to one year in prison and a $100,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Credit Corp. Pays $460 Million For PacifiCorp Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: AT&T Credit Corp. said Wednesday it purchased two financing divisions of PacifiCorp Credit Inc., a subsidiary of PacifiCorp Financial Services for $460 million. The distribution financing division helps support equipment sales for manufacturers by providing financing for their customers, said PacifiCorp spokesman Mike Nelson. The asset leasing and financing division, with field offices in Atlanta and Denver, helps provide financing for franchises, such as restaurant chains, and media customers, Nelson said. The two divisions, based in Portland, Ore., were purchased for cash obtained mostly through the sale of debt by AT&T Credit Corp. and preferred stock issued by AT&T Commercial Finance Corp. to PacifiCorp Credit. AT&T Credit Corp. is a wholly owned subsidiary of American Telegraph and Telephone Co. that does a wide variety of equipment leasing and financing.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Lucky Stores Official Settles Insider Trading Case
DOC.TEXT: A former official of Lucky Stores Inc. has settled civil insider trading charges that he tipped his father to the planned acquisition of the company, federal regulators announced Wednesday. The Securities and Exchange Commission said David Hellberg agreed to the settlement without admitting or denying wrongdoing in documents filed Tuesday at federal court in Salt Lake City. Hellberg, a former manager of special projects for a subsidiary of Dublin, Calif.-based Lucky Stores, was fined $328,844, but U.S. District Judge Aldon Anderson waived all but $5,000 of the fine because Hellberg was unable to pay more. The penalty ``will take roughly half his net assets, short of selling his house,'' said James A. Kidney, an SEC attorney in Washington. The SEC complaint charged that Hellberg tipped his father, Gerald Hellberg, in 1988 to a planned acquisition of Lucky by Irvine, Calif.-based American Stores Co. The father allegedly bought $15,000 in call options for Lucky common stock. When American announced a $45-a-share tender offer, the father allegedly made more than $328,000 in illegal profits. Kidney said the father has not settled with the SEC and that the son has not made any agreement with the government to testify at his father's upcoming trial. The younger Hellberg's lawyer, Doug Griffith, was in a conference late Wednesday and was not immediately available for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Northrop Completes Sale of HQ Building, Other Properties to Pay Down Debt
DOC.TEXT: Northrop Corp. said it has agreed to sell the twin high-rises that house its Century City headquarters to reduce its $1.2 billion debt. The builder of the B-2 stealth bomber also said it would sell a 53-acre site in Anaheim where 1,300 employees produce missile test equipment and advanced sensors for aircraft, helicopters and missiles. Northrop said the properties are being sold for a total of more than $250 million. It did not break down figures, but real estate experts previously said the 15- and 19-story Century City buildings, with about 540,000 square feet of space, would bring about $220 million. Northrop will lease back its 131,000-square-foot corporate offices in one of the Century City buildings. The employees in Anaheim are being transferred to facilities in Hawthorne and El Segundo and will not be laid off, although their division is undergoing a previously announced reduction of 500 workers through attrition, company spokeswoman Maria Oharenko said. Northrop said the sale of the office buildings is expected to be completed next month and the Anaheim sale completed in 1991. The California State Teachers Retirement System is buying the twin towers; the Anaheim property is being purchased by Taiyo Development USA, Torrance, an American subsidiary of a Japanese company. Northrop's new chief executive, Kent Kresa, said earlier this month the company hopes to sharply reduce its debt in the 1990s and eliminate short-term bank debt by the middle of the decade.

DOC.HEAD: Zoetrope Says Orion Was Misidentified in Bankruptcy Filing
DOC.TEXT: Orion Pictures Corp. was wrongly identified as a creditor of film maker Francis Ford Coppola's Zoetrope Productions in a bankruptcy filing made last week, Zoetrope said Wednesday. The filing for protection under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy law said Zoetrope owed Orion $6.2 million. Orion issued a statement Wednesday saying it was not owed the money. Asked about that, San Francisco-based Zoetrope referred calls to an outside publicist, Ginger Slaughter, who gave the following statement: ``Zoetrope Productions believes that the debt listed in its Chapter 11 filing as due Orion is not in fact due Orion.'' Ms. Slaughter said she did not know who the real creditor is. The biggest creditors, accounting for more than half the total Zoetrope debt, are production companies Coppola set up to film the movies ``The Outsiders'' and ``Rumble Fish'' in the early 1980s. They are owed $16.2 million, according to the filing.

DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators on Wednesday seized Phoenix-based MeraBank, Arizona's largest savings institution and the latest victim of the state's real estate slump. The Resolution Trust Corp. took over MeraBank after the Office of Thrift Supervision declared that the thrift was operating in an unsafe and unsound condition. The action comes despite a Dec. 7 pledge by the thrift's parent company, Pinnacle West Capital Corp., to inject $450 million by March 31 into its troubled subsidiary in exchange for a release from further obligation. The thrift office said it still expected Pinnacle West, which owns Arizona's largest utility, Arizona Public Service Co., to comply with the agreement. However, it said the infusion would still leave MeraBank far short of its capital requirement and said the thrift continued to weaken. Henry B. Sargent Jr., Pinnacle West's chief financial officer, said the holding company would honor the agreement. ``This receivership doesn't affect our agreement with the OTS at all. We didn't know when this was going to happen, but it was not an unexpected event,'' Sargent added. Wednesday also was the deadline for Pinnacle West to domplete a $624 debt million restructuring required by regulators to make sure the holding company would be able to handle another $450 million in debt. All 45 lenders involved had to sign the restructuring document, and Sargent said late in the evening that only one signature had not been obtained. He said the company was not working for other ``standstill agreements'' after five extensions of the original Jan. 7 deadline. At the end of November, MeraBank was $337 million in the red. With $6.6 billion in assets, it is Arizona's largest S&L. It was ranked 29th nationwide at mid-year by Sheshunoff Information Services Inc., an Austin, Texas, consulting firm. Regulators said all MeraBank branches will remain open for business as usual, operating under a new government-owned thrift called MeraBank Federal Savings Bank. Deposits will be insured up to $100,000 per account. MeraBank is the sixth Arizona savings and loan to be seized by the government, leaving only four operating privately. The state's second-largest, Western Savings and Loan Association of Phoenix, was seized in June and put up for sale earlier this month. Arizona has been hard hit by a real estate slump. Home prices in Phoenix, for instance, fell 6.1 percent between the third quarter of 1989 and the same period a year earlier, according to the National Association of Realtors. MeraBank operates a subsidiary in El Paso, Texas, MeraBank Texas, which was a buyer in the 1988 government-assisted bailout of three Texas S&Ls. It got about $670 million from the government to acquire State Federal, Lubbock; First Financial, El Paso, and Brownfield Federal, Brownfield. The Texas thrifts, along with MeraBank's other holdings in the state, now fall back into the government's possession. MeraBank is the 32nd S&L failure so far this year. An additional 225 to 295 are likely to fail, compared with a record 328 last year and 223 in 1988. Merabank was purchased for $426 million by Pinnacle West in December 1986, the same year the state's real estate market hit the skids. The S&L has been suffering for some time, losing $209 million in 1988 and more than $190 million through the first three quarters of 1989. The thrift had about $4.5 billion in deposits in 833,000 accounts.
